{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Run Facebook Ads: A Step-by-Step Guide to Advertising on Facebook","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-paid-ad-checklist","description":"<p>When setting up a paid Facebook ad, there are a lot of boxes to be checked.</p> \n<p>Are you targeting the right people? Are your image dimensions to scale? Are you running the right type of ad? If we're being honest, it can get a little confusing.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>With more than <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\">2.6 billion people</a> using Facebook every month,&nbsp;and nearly <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/346167/facebook-global-dau/\">1.7 billion users</a> every day, Facebook offers up a unique opportunity for marketers to augment their organic efforts. The trouble is, with both an investment of time and money on the line, there's not much room for oversight.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>To help, we've put together a checklist to help you keep all of your campaign details straight. Or watch this short video on how to increase the effectiveness of your ads and budget. These will help ensure that you're tapping into the right audience with the right ad at the right time.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; display: block; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 640px; max-height: 360px; min-width: 256px;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/P7ers2RZxqA\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Facebook offers a variety of paid ad options and placements, but all ads can be broken down into three elements:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Campaigns.</strong> The campaign houses all of your assets.</li> \n <li><strong>Ad sets.</strong> If you're targeting separate audiences with different characteristics, you'll need an individual ad set for each.</li> \n <li><strong>Ads.</strong> Your actual ads live within your ad sets. Each ad set can hold a variety of ads that vary in color, copy, images, etc.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>With that terminology out of the way, let's dive in to creating an ad.</p> \n<h3>1. Create an account with Facebook Ads Manager.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/learn/facebook-ads-reporting-performance/\">Facebook's Ad Manager</a> is a sophisticated dashboard that provides users with an overview of all their campaigns.</p> \n<p>Upfront, the dashboard highlights an estimate of how much you're spending each day. The dashboard is organized by columns, which makes it easy to filter through your ads so you can create a custom view of your results. Key numbers like reach, frequency, and cost are readily available, making reporting on performance a no brainer.</p> \n<p>In order to use the Facebook Ads Manager, you'll need a Facebook Business Page (learn how to set one up <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5492/how-to-create-a-facebook-business-page-in-5-simple-steps-with-video.aspx\">here</a>). This is because you can't run ads through personal profiles.</p> \n<p>Then, follow these steps:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Navigate to <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/tools/ads-manager\">https://www.facebook.com/business/tools/ads-manager</a>.</li> \n <li>Click the button that says \"Go to Ads Manager.\"</li> \n <li>Confirm your information on the ad account setup page.</li> \n <li>Set up your payment method.</li> \n <li>Save changes.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Once set up, the Ads Manager becomes the control center for your Facebook ads.</p> \n<h3>2. Start creating an ad through Facebook's Ads Manager.</h3> \n<p>Once you log into the Ads Manager, you'll see a performance dashboard where all of your campaigns, ad sets, and ads will be listed including the results they've driven for your Facebook page. Unless you've already created an ad for your Facebook page, this dashboard will be empty.</p> \n<p>To create a new campaign, ad set, or ad through the Facebook Ad Manager, tab over to the type of ad you want to create and click the green \"Create\" button to far left of these ad types, as shown below. You can see from this screenshot that we're currently set to create a new <strong>campaign</strong>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebook-ad-manager.jpg?width=690&amp;name=facebook-ad-manager.jpg\" alt=\"facebook ad manager create a new ad button\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<h3>3. Choose an objective.</h3> \n<p>Facebook's Ads Manager, like many social media advertising networks, is designed with your campaign objective in mind. Before getting started, Ads Manager will prompt you to choose an objective for your campaign:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebook-ad-campaign-objective.jpg?width=690&amp;name=facebook-ad-campaign-objective.jpg\" alt=\"facebook ad campaign objective\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<p>There are 11 different objectives to choose from. The list includes everything from general brand awareness, to getting installs of your app, to increasing traffic to your online store.</p> \n<p>By choosing one of these objectives, you're giving Facebook a better idea of what you'd like to do so they can present you with the best-suited ad options. As shown in the screenshot above, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/post-engagement/photo/\">Facebook's ad options</a> include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Brand awareness</li> \n <li>Reach</li> \n <li>Website traffic</li> \n <li>Engagement</li> \n <li>App installs</li> \n <li>Video views</li> \n <li>Lead generation</li> \n <li>Messages</li> \n <li>Conversions</li> \n <li>Catalog sales</li> \n <li>Store traffic</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Let's say, for sake of this blog post, you're looking to drive more traffic to your website. When you select this option, Facebook will prompt you to enter the URL you're looking to promote. If you're using marketing automation software, be sure to create <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht?_ga=2.179189668.12369809.1557758544-983944916.1546275206\">a unique tracking URL with UTM parameters</a> for this to ensure that you'll be able to keep track of traffic and conversions from this ad. For HubSpot customers, this can be done using the Tracking URL Builder.</p> \n<p>Once selected, Facebook will then display the ad option that makes the most sense in terms of achieving this objective.</p> \n<h3>4. Choose your audience.</h3> \n<p>Your next step is to configure your target audience -- you can do this for each ad set that belongs to the same campaign. If you're just starting out with paid advertising on Facebook, it's likely that you'll have to experiment with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-audience-insights-guide\">several different targeting options</a> until you reach an audience that fits just right.</p> \n<p>To help you narrow your focus, Facebook's targeting criteria are accompanied by an audience definition gauge. This tool -- located to the right of the audience targeting fields -- takes all of your selected properties into consideration in order to come up with a potential reach number.</p> \n<p>If you're wavering between choosing a specific audience over a broad one, consider your objective. If you're looking to drive traffic, you'll probably want to focus on the type of people you know will be interested in your offering. However, if you're looking to build brand awareness or promote a widely appealing offer, feel free to focus on a more general audience.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/Screen_Shot_2015-08-20_at_10.23.53_AM.png?width=669&amp;height=621&amp;name=Screen_Shot_2015-08-20_at_10.23.53_AM.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"621\" alt=\"Audience creation page in the Facebook Ad Manager\"></p> \n<p>Facebook's built-in targeting is vast, including options such as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Location</li> \n <li>Age</li> \n <li>Gender</li> \n <li>Languages</li> \n <li>Relationship</li> \n <li>Education</li> \n <li>Work</li> \n <li>Financial</li> \n <li>Home</li> \n <li>Ethnic Affinity</li> \n <li>Generation</li> \n <li>Parents</li> \n <li>Politics (U.S. only)</li> \n <li>Life Events</li> \n <li>Interests</li> \n <li>Behaviors</li> \n <li>Connections</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You also have the option to select a Custom Audience -- this allows you to <a href=\"https://mobilemonkey.com/blog/facebook-ads-hubspot-crm\">target people on Facebook who are in your company's contact database</a>, visited a page on your website that has a tracking pixel, or use your app or game. To learn more about how to set up a Custom Audience on Facebook, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/170456843145568\">check out these instructions</a>. (And for more on the specifics of these criteria, visit <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/433385333434831\">this Facebook targeting resource</a>.)</p> \n<p>Once you find a group that responds well to your ads, Facebook allows you to save these audiences to be used again later -- so you may not need to dive into this step once you've been running Facebook ads for a while.</p> \n<h3>5. Set your budget.</h3> \n<p>Facebook allows you to set either a daily budget or a lifetime budget. Here's how they differ from each other:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Daily budget.</strong> If you want your ad set to run continuously throughout the day, this is the option you'll want to go for. Using a daily budget means that Facebook will pace your spending per day. Keep in mind that the minimum daily budget for an ad set is $1.00 USD and must be <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/560163334110364\">at least 2X your CPC</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>Lifetime budget.</strong> If you're looking to run your ad for a specified length of time, select lifetime budget. This means Facebook will pace your spend over the time period you set for the ad to run.</li> \n</ul> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebook-ad-budget.jpg?width=502&amp;name=facebook-ad-budget.jpg\" alt=\"facebook ad budget and schedule page\" width=\"502\"> \n<p>To further specify your budgeting, turn to the advanced options -- this option is linked at the bottom of the screenshot shown above. This section allows you to specify a few things:</p> \n<h4>Schedule</h4> \n<p>Choose whether or not your want your campaign to run immediately and continuously or if you want to customize the start and end dates. You can also set parameters so that your ads only run during specific hours and days of the week.</p> \n<h4>Optimization &amp; Pricing</h4> \n<p>Choose whether or not you want to bid for your objective, clicks, or impressions. (This will alter how your ad is displayed and paid for.) By doing so, you'll pay for your ad to be shown to people within your target audience that are more likely to complete your desired action, but Facebook will control what your maximum bid is.</p> \n<p>If you don't want Facebook to set optimal bids for you, you'll want to opt for manual bidding. This option awards you full control over how much you're willing to pay per action completed. However, Facebook will provide a suggested bid based on other advertisers' behavior to give you a sense of what you should shoot for.</p> \n<h4>Delivery</h4> \n<p>Delivery type falls under two categories: standard and accelerated. Standard delivery will show your ads throughout the day, while accelerated delivery helps you reach an audience quickly for time-sensitive ads (Note: this option requires manual bid pricing).</p> \n<h3>6. Create your ad.</h3> \n<p>What do you want your ad to look like? It all depends on your original objective.</p> \n<p>If you're looking to increase the number of clicks to your website, Facebook's Ad Manager will suggest the <strong>Clicks to Website</strong> ad options. Makes sense, right?</p> \n<p>This ad option is broken down into two formats: Links and Carousels. Essentially, this means that you can either display a single image ad (Links) or a multi-image ad (Carousel) with three to five scrolling images at no additional cost.</p> \n<p>A Links ad will be displayed like this:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/Single_image.jpg?width=458&amp;height=345&amp;name=Single_image.jpg\" width=\"458\" height=\"345\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Facebook Ad with link to Shop Now\"></p> \n<p>A Carousel ad will be displayed like this:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/Carosel_Ad.jpg?width=455&amp;height=285&amp;name=Carosel_Ad.jpg\" width=\"455\" height=\"285\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Example of a Facebook Carousel Ad with images of Grand Canyon\"></p> \n<p>Once you decide between the two, you'll need to upload your creative assets. It's important to note that for each type of ad, Facebook requires users to adhere to certain design criteria.</p> \n<p>For single image ads, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/image/facebook-feed/traffic\">Facebook asks that users adhere to the following design recommendations</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Text: 125 characters</li> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Ad Headline: 25 characters</li> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Image ratio: 1.91:1</li> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Image resolution (including CTA): 1080 x 1080 pixels</li> \n</ul> \n<p>For multi-image ads -- also known as Carousel Ads -- <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/clicks-to-website/carousel/\">Facebook provides the following design recommendations</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Recommended image size: 1080 x 1080 pixels</li> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Image ratio: 1:1</li> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Text: 125 characters</li> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Headline: 40 characters</li> \n <li class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">Link description: 20 characters</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"mbm _52if _3m9\">\n Your image may not include more than 20% text. \n <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/ads/tools/text_overlay\">See how much text</a> is on your image.\n</div> \n<p><strong>Keep in mind that these are the ad options for the \"Traffic\" objective.</strong></p> \n<p>If you selected \"boost your posts,\" you'd be presented with different ad options like the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/post-engagement/photo/\">Page Post Engagement: Photo ad</a>. This ad has a unique set of design recommendations. To explore all of the ad options and their design specifics, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/clicks-to-website/links/?toggle0=Photo\">refer to this resource</a>.</p> \n<p>Once you select an ad type, the Ads Manager will prompt you to identify how you'd like to display your ad. The options they provide are as follows: Desktop News Feed, Mobile News Feed, and Desktop Right Column.</p> \n<p>Here's how each ad would appear:</p> \n<h4>Desktop News Feed</h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/Screen_Shot_2015-08-20_at_11.29.29_AM.png?width=438&amp;height=474&amp;name=Screen_Shot_2015-08-20_at_11.29.29_AM.png\" width=\"438\" height=\"474\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Facebook Ad with single image on a desktop news feed\"></p> \n<h4>Mobile News Feed</h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/IMG_5234.png?width=360&amp;height=640&amp;name=IMG_5234.png\" width=\"360\" height=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Facebook ad with single image on mobile news feed\"></p> \n<h4>Desktop Right Column</h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/00-Blog-Related_Images/Screen_Shot_2015-08-20_at_11.29.03_AM.png?width=245&amp;height=233&amp;name=Screen_Shot_2015-08-20_at_11.29.03_AM.png\" width=\"245\" height=\"233\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Facebook Ad with single image on desktop right column\"></p> \n<p>Be aware if your ad isn't associated with a Facebook page, you'll only be able to run Desktop Right Column ads. To leverage all three display locations, you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5492/How-to-Create-a-Facebook-Business-Page-in-5-Simple-Steps-With-Video.aspx?_ga=2.106969602.12369809.1557758544-983944916.1546275206\">learn how to create a Facebook Page here.</a></p> \n<h3>7. Monitor your ad's performance metrics.</h3> \n<p>Once your ads are running, you'll want to keep an eye on how they're doing. To see their results, you'll want to look in two places: the Facebook Ad Manager and your marketing software.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/510910008975690\">According to Facebook</a>, here are some of the key metrics to look for (and their definitions):</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Performance. </strong>Can be customized further to include metrics like results, reach, frequency and impressions</li> \n <li class=\"fcb\"><strong>Engagement.</strong> Can be customized further to include metrics like Page likes, Page engagement and post engagement</li> \n <li class=\"fcb\"><strong>Videos. </strong>Can be customized further to include metrics like video views and avg. % of video viewed</li> \n <li class=\"fcb\"><strong>Website.</strong> Can be customized further to include metrics like website actions (all), checkouts, payment details, purchases and adds to cart</li> \n <li class=\"fcb\"><strong>Apps.</strong> Can be further customized to include metrics like app installs, app engagement, credit spends, mobile app actions and cost per app engagement</li> \n <li class=\"fcb\"><strong>Events.</strong> Can be further customized to include metrics like event responses and cost per event response</li> \n <li class=\"fcb\"><strong>Clicks.</strong> Can be further customized to include metrics like clicks, unique clicks, CTR (click-through rate) and CPC (cost per click)</li> \n <li class=\"fcb\"><strong>Settings. </strong>Can be further customized to include metrics like start date, end date, ad set name, ad ID, delivery, bid and objective</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Regardless of which of these metrics you use to measure the success of your advertising efforts, you can find the data in the Ads Manager.</p> \n<p>As you analyze, you'll be thinking about your data in four main ways, depending on how granular you need to get:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The account level</li> \n <li>The campaign level</li> \n <li>The ad set level</li> \n <li>The ad level</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>The Account Level</h4> \n<p>This gives a high-level view of performance across all campaigns. You'll find aggregate data that gives you a bird's eye view.</p> \n<p>Simply navigate to the ads manager and click Account Overview. From there, you'll be able to customize the metrics you want to see drill down time ranges, and more.</p> \n<h4>The Campaign, Ad Set, or Ad Level</h4> \n<p>You can also get far more specific with your analysis by checking the performance of campaigns and even down to individual ads. This can help you figure out which messaging, audiences, and collateral are resonating the best.</p> \n<p>All you have to do is navigate to the Campaigns, Ad Sets, or Ads tabs next to Account Overview in the ads manager.</p> \n<h3>8. Reporting on Facebook ad performance.</h3> \n<p>You can receive custom reports via email as well. Here's how to set it up:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Navigate to Analyze and Report through the upper main menu.</li> \n <li>Choose Ads Reporting.</li> \n <li>Select Create Custom Report.</li> \n <li>Select and open a saved report.</li> \n <li>Choose Save As next to the save icon. Give your report a name and check Schedule Email.</li> \n <li>Follow the prompts to edit and confirm your reporting preferences.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>While there are certainly a lot of details to keep straight when planning a paid Facebook ad, it's important that you don't lose sight of the big picture. Reporting on clicks and conversions from Facebook is important. However, if you're using URLs with specific UTM codes, you have an opportunity to measure your ads' full-funnel effectiveness <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/analytics?_ga=2.115217543.12369809.1557758544-983944916.1546275206\">using your marketing software</a>.</p> \n<p>Tracking URLs will help your marketing software keep track of how many leads, or better yet, how many customers you've gained from your advertising efforts. This information is useful in determining the ROI of this source, and can also be used to inform your overall <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing\">Facebook marketing</a> strategy.</p> \n<p>If you're a HubSpot customer using <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/ads\">our ads tool</a>, this process is already taken care of for you. You can also create unique tracking codes for your Facebook campaign by navigating to the Tracking URL Builder on the Reports Home page. All you'll need to do is plug in the URL, attach a campaign, and choose the source you want the URL to be attributed to in your Sources Report. Once your ad launches and you start getting traffic and conversions on your website, you'll be able to easily track how many visits, contacts, and customers you're generating.</p> \n<p>Now that you know how to set up an ad, it's time to create one of your own so that you can spread brand awareness on Facebook and generate traffic and leads from your ideal prospects on the platform.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in September 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\"> </a>\n</div>  \n<img 15-08-20_at_11.29.03_AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn66@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-28-281_ee71dfad7778e461.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-paid-ad-checklist&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn58@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-26-392_47375d84c907c6e4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336428},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"A Content Marketing Playbook for Times of Crisis","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-playbook-for-times-of-crisis","description":"<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has sent businesses scrambling to pause plans, edit emails, and cancel campaigns. And while everybody seems to know what <em>not</em> to publish these days, many marketers are asking: what <em>should</em> we put out into a world in the throes of a crisis?</p>  \n<p>It's a conundrum facing countless creators across the globe.</p> \n<p>They're wondering how to be empathetic without being disingenuous. How to offer value without seeming opportunistic. And how to be there for their audience without adding to the noise.</p> \n<p>These are important questions to ask at a time like this. Essential, in fact. But underpinning all of them is a much simpler question that gets to the very heart of what content marketing has always been about. A question that every creator staring at a blank canvas right now should be asking: <em>how can we help?</em></p> \n<p>Because now, more than ever before, audiences are seeking help.</p> \n<h2><span>Increasing Engagement Rates</span></h2> \n<p>Entire industries have been forced into hibernation in recent weeks, but this does not mean audiences' appetites for helpful content has gone away. On the contrary. Consumers are increasing searches for valuable information and engaging with businesses at record rates.</p> \n<p>According to an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/covid-19-benchmark-data-edition3\">analysis of anonymized data from HubSpot's global customer base</a>, engagement with marketing emails, website traffic, and live chat sessions have all been on the rise, with email open rates an eye-catching 25% higher than pre-pandemic levels.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis.png?width=1500&amp;name=Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis.png\" alt=\"increasing engagement rates\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Meanwhile, traffic to <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/\">HubSpot Academy</a>, our free online training program, has more than doubled in recent weeks, and our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing\">Marketing Blog</a> has experienced a 40% increase in weekly organic traffic.</p> \n<p>The pandemic has triggered a striking surge in the very thing that many marketers care about most: audience attention. And such a high level of interest in the content companies are sharing, coming at such a sensitive time, places a huge responsibility on marketers to deliver materials that are not only relevant to the current moment, but genuinely impactful, too.</p> \n<p>Those that fall short run the risk of doing damage to their reputation — according to <a href=\"https://www.edelman.com/research/covid-19-brand-trust-report\">Edelman</a>, \"71 percent of consumers agree that if they perceive that a brand is putting profit over people, they will lose trust in that brand forever.\"</p> \n<p>But those that succeed will leave a lasting impression on their audience — according to <a href=\"https://www.gartner.com/en/marketing/insights/articles/adapt-the-marketing-strategy-for-covid-19\">Gartner</a>, brands that meet consumer's needs at this time can \"re-establish trust through customer-centric actions.\"</p> \n<p>So, it is not only engagement rates that are high during this crisis. The stakes are high, too. And a situation this unique requires a unique strategy to match.</p> \n<h2>When a Crisis Descends, Pause Before Planning</h2> \n<p>When times of crisis strike, the first thing marketers should think about is what <em>not</em> to do. Planned projects, campaigns, and announcements should be reviewed and postponed if possible. For those assets that are released as planned, it's likely they'll need a new tone that's appropriate for the new environment.</p> \n<p>Marketers should examine every article, email, ad, and social media post scheduled to be published to ensure that the tone of each asset is empathetic and respectful.</p> \n<p>If this sounds like a lot of work, it's because, in many cases, it is. No one team can manage a company-wide content audit alone.</p> \n<p>Communications teams have expertise in developing messaging, social media teams have deep connections to their online community, email marketing teams have a strong understanding of brand tone, and customer-facing teams, including sales to service, have their fingers on the pulse of how customers are feeling — all of these teams should be consulted on content strategy during a crisis to ensure that a consistent and helpful approach is adopted across every touchpoint with the public.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, before we began creating new content for the new environment, we significantly reduced the frequency of our social media posting, dialed back the promotion of a major product launch (<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms\">CMS Hub</a>), and created a centralized set of guidelines on how we as a company should be communicating during this crisis.</p> \n<p>Making such sweeping adjustments on short notice isn't simple, but for us, two things helped make it easier.</p> \n<p>First, we have an established decision-making process for crisis communications that minimizes confusion in the moment.</p> \n<p>Second, by centralizing all of our customer interactions in a shared CRM, we're able to see what communications customers are getting and roll out adjustments quickly to marketing, sales, and service.</p> \n<h2>Creating New Content in Times of Crisis</h2> \n<p>When it comes to creating new content during a crisis, marketers' sole focus should be on delivering work that is genuinely helpful to their audience, without being opportunistic or adding more noise to a topic that has already been widely covered by others.</p> \n<p>According to research conducted by <a href=\"https://www.edelman.com/research/covid-19-brand-trust-report\">Edelman</a>, 85% of people expect companies to use their power to educate their audiences during the COVID-19 crisis. For some companies, that could mean writing in-depth articles that offer expert advice on relevant topics or aggregating publicly available information to make it more accessible for readers.</p> \n<p>Intuit, for example, did this well when they teamed up with GoFundMe to create a <a href=\"https://quickbooks.intuit.com/small-business/coronavirus/\">Small Business Relief Initiative</a> and when they built an <a href=\"https://aidassist.intuit.com/app/home#/home\">interactive tool</a> to help small businesses learn if they are eligible for government-provided financial relief.</p> \n<p>We saw similarly helpful content from Care.com, whose team leveraged their deep knowledge of caregiving best practices to share <a href=\"https://www.care.com/c/stories/16747/navigating-covid-19-care/\">expert advice</a> on the precautions for families and caregivers facing the global health crisis.</p> \n<p>These powerful examples directly address the situation at hand. But for other companies, providing helpful content could mean offering an alternative to the cacophony of crisis-centric content flooding feeds all day, every day.</p> \n<p>For example, NPR has unsurprisingly witnessed a spike in listenership to its news shows as people seek up-to-date, reliable information as the pandemic evolves. But it has also seen a 120% increase in weekly visits to its <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/series/tiny-desk-concerts/\">Tiny Desk Concerts</a> — an entertainment series — indicating that audiences are not only interested in information directly about the crisis, but are also desiring content that provides an escape from it.</p> \n<p>This should make content marketers feel encouraged.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>It suggests that help can take many forms in the midst of a crisis and that there are multiple ways creators can add value to the lives of their audiences at this time.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>For marketing teams that don't have the necessary resources to create new content given the trying economic environment, there are still creative ways to adapt to audiences' needs. Gathering together old content that's relevant to the current situation, updating it as needed, and presenting it as an easily digestible ebook or content series can be efficient ways of overcoming resource shortages.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, we did just this when we published <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/topic-learning-path/remote-work\">a new landing page featuring all of our articles about remote work</a> to offer some timely support to companies and employees adjusting to the new normal of working from home.</p> \n<p>During times of crisis, there are a number of ways for marketers to approach new content creation — some that directly address the unique environment at hand, others that look to complement the new patterns of behavior that are emerging — but the one thing that should be consistent is an honest effort to help.</p> \n<h2>Choose Channels Carefully, Distribute Delicately</h2> \n<p>Marketers have an abundance of options for how they distribute their work, but just because we <em>can</em> publish content on multiple channels doesn't always mean that we <em>should</em>.</p> \n<p>Our research tells us that marketing email send volumes have <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/covid-19-benchmark-data-edition4\">increased significantly in recent weeks</a>, meaning that subscribers' email inboxes are even busier than usual. As well-intentioned as a new article or video might be, if it isn't distributed delicately and at a considerate cadence, it could end up doing more harm than good in a company's efforts to help audience members.</p> \n<p>Marketers should reserve their most intimate communications channels, like email and push notifications, for key content updates during a crisis and adopt more subtle distribution approaches for their more niche materials.</p> \n<p>For example, an SEO-optimized article that's easily discoverable through search may be a more appropriate way to share certain new content offerings than a direct email or paid social media post, both of which could come across as excessively promotional or tone-deaf.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, when the pandemic was declared, we cut our social media posting by approximately 50% in the first week and reduced the number of ads we were sending to avoid overloading our audience with information at a time when there's already a lot to process.</p> \n<p>And when we developed a new educational content series, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/adapt2020\">Adapt 2020</a>, we made clear to potential subscribers what type of content to expect, as well as where and when it would be distributed.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis-1.png\" alt=\"content marketing adapt 2020 campaign\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>The Adapt series became the cornerstone of our content strategy during the current crisis and provided a powerful proof point of the value of the diverse app ecosystem that's deeply integrated with HubSpot's suite of tools.</p> \n<p>With Looker we've been able to share regular updates on shifting trends in sales and marketing, with Canva we've been able to quickly design on-brand assets to promote upcoming webinars, and with Slack we've been able to collaborate with confidence on all of the elements that make up the weekly content series.</p> \n<p>With distribution channels and cadence established with our subscribers, we have been able to turn our attention towards monitoring how the crisis and the needs of our audience are evolving from week to week.</p> \n<h2>Adapt Early, Adapt Often</h2> \n<p>Crises are unpredictable by nature. And what was deeply valuable to audiences last week, may be irrelevant by the next. To provide helpful content for the duration of a crisis, marketers should prepare to continually evolve their strategy in line with their audiences' shifting needs.</p> \n<p>Choosing the right metrics to monitor is key to not falling behind the pace of change. Creators should closely monitor metrics that indicate engagement — such as 'average time spent on page' for articles and show-up rates for webinars — to gain an insight into whether or not their new content is resonating with audiences. And from there, they can use those learnings to look for ways to improve the relevance and helpfulness of their next offering.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, we initially focused on delivering content aimed at helping businesses to set up virtual events and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/topic-learning-path/remote-work\">adapt to the new normal of remote work</a>.</p> \n<p>We then quickly shifted focus to creating content to help businesses take advantage of new relief measures available by publishing the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/en-us/coronavirus-response\">pricing and packaging changes we've made</a> along with an<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/us-stimulus-package\"> </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/us-stimulus-package\">overview of the U.S. Stimulus Package</a>.</p> \n<p>Following that, we shifted focus to creating content to help businesses adjust their medium- and longer-term strategies and prepare for the post-pandemic economy.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>We have never witnessed such sudden and dramatic shifts in what audiences need, and the marketers that are nimble enough to adapt their strategy quickly are the ones most likely to provide meaningful help for the duration of the crisis at hand.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>And by doing so, they stand to establish long-lasting levels of loyalty with their audience.</p> \n<h2>What Content Marketing Has Always Been About</h2> \n<p>It's no secret that consumers' trust in companies has been dwindling in recent years. According to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-acquisition-study\">HubSpot Research</a>, 55% of people no longer trust the companies they buy from as much as they used to, and 71% do not trust sponsored ads on social networks.</p> \n<p>However, times of crisis create unique environments and unexpected outcomes, one of which can be the recovery of some of that lost trust, and the deepening of long-term relationships between consumers and companies.</p> \n<p>Audiences are turning in record numbers to businesses for resources, information, and support. Customers are taking to social media to rally support for their favorite businesses. And content marketers are returning to first principles and re-establishing helpfulness at the heart of their strategies.</p> \n<p>There are many challenges facing businesses at this time — content strategy is just one of them — but I am hopeful that marketers adopting the advice outlined here will see their efforts rewarded in the form of closer relationships with the audiences, and the fulfillment of knowing they've provided help when it's been needed the most.</p> \n<p>After all, that's what content marketing has always been about.</p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-marketing-playbook-for-times-of-crisis&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 10:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"c5760aa0fc813a19a26af70839ac7c61","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"manderson@hubspot.com (Meghan Keaney Anderson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis.png?width=1500&name=Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn55@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-23-725_b3f407fe1f42c77d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis-1.png?width=1500&name=Content%20Creation%20in%20Times%20of%20Crisis-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn12@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-24-001_3fae8f649b5c442c.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-marketing-playbook-for-times-of-crisis&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn10@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-25-237_d469ddd1ee8ae4cd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336431},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"What Is Phishing and How Can You Protect Your Business From an Attack?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-phishing","description":"<p>Staff at MacEwan University, a school in Edmonton, Canada, <a href=\"https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/macewan-university-phishing-scam-edmonton-1.4270689\">received an email</a> from a major vendor stating they had recently changed their electronic banking information and needed payments to be sent to a new account.</p>  \n<p>Assuming their trusted business partner was just going through some changes, the university complied and transferred three payments to the new bank account within a span of 10 days.</p>  \n<p>But four days later, MacEwan University received a phone call from this same vendor asking them why they hadn't paid their fees yet. Perplexed by the call, the university told them they had just transferred the payments to their new bank account.</p> \n<p>The vendor had no idea what they were talking about.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, this bank account didn’t actually belong to MacEwan’s vendor. It belonged to cyber criminals in Canada and Hong Kong. And MacEwan University had just transferred them $11.8 million.</p> \n<p>Eventually, the university discovered the email requesting them to transfer their payments to the new bank account was actually fraudulent and a prevalent form of cyber attack that <a href=\"https://www.proofpoint.com/sites/default/files/gtd-pfpt-uk-tr-state-of-the-phish-2020-a4_final.pdf\">thousands of businesses</a> fall victim to every year — phishing.</p> Examples of these credentials include passwords, credit card details, bank login information, and social security numbers. \n<p>Most cyber criminals deploy phishing attacks through email, like the picture below, but some have also started to exploit social media, messaging apps, and text message to steal people’s personal information.</p> Phishing instances have rose in number over recent years — in fact, there were over over \n<a href=\"https://docs.apwg.org/reports/apwg_trends_report_q1_2020.pdf\">60,000 phishing sites reported in March of 2020 alone</a>. This cybercrime could wreak havoc on your brand and bottom line. \n<p>So how do you defend your customers and employees from phishing without making them your brand’s first line of defense?</p> \n<p>Here are three shields you can leverage to protect your brand from these prevalent attacks.</p> \n<h2>How to Protect Your Business From Phishing Attacks</h2> \n<h3>1. Build a DMARC record.</h3> \n<p>DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance) is a cutting-edge email authentication protocol that leverages two other authentication protocols, SPF (Sender Policy Framework), and DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail) to verify legitimate messages sent from your domain and block fraudulent emails that <em>appear</em> to be sent from your domain.</p> \n<p>These email authentication protocols are rather technical, so in a nutshell, SPF is a record of IP addresses that are authorized to send emails on your behalf that email service providers check against, and DKIM is a verification process that leverages cryptographic authentication.</p> \n<p>DMARC is the only technology that can ensure your \"header from” address (what your users usually look at first when they see your emails) is trustworthy.</p> \n<p>To do this, they’ll only authenticate email messages that pass SPF authentication and SPF alignment or DKIM authentication and alignment. If an email message fails SPF authentication or alignment and DKIM authentication or alignment, it’ll fail DMARC.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-08-19%20at%209.07.34%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-08-19%20at%209.07.34%20AM.png\" alt=\"how dmarc works when protecting against phishing\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 14px;\"><a href=\"http://rejoiner.com/resources/email-authentication/\"><em>Source</em></a></p> \n<p>DMARC also allows you to tell email service providers what they should do with any fraudulent mail that appears to be sent from your domain. You can either monitor all of your emails, move unauthenticated messages to users’ spam folders, or decide not to deliver this type of mail at all to inboxes on your server.</p> \n<p>Additionally, email service providers will regularly send you forensic DMARC reports, showing you which emails are authenticating, which ones are not, and why.</p> \n<h3>2. Train customers and employees to spot an attack.</h3> \n<p>According to PhishMe, a phishing defense solution, companies who train employees to identify and report attempted phishing attacks only have a <a href=\"https://phishme.com/phishing-resiliency-%20report-2017/\">5% susceptibility rate to phishing.</a></p> \n<p>To help employees and customers spot one of these attacks and better defend your business, teach them these common phishing markers:</p> \n<h4>Poor Spelling, Grammar, or Writing</h4> \n<p>A lot of amateur cyber criminals don’t take the time to craft clear and convincing emails, which brands always seem to do, and foreign cyber criminals will usually rely on Google Translate to translate their messages. So if you receive a poorly written email from a seemingly legitimate sender, take caution.</p> \n<h4>Suspicious URLs</h4> \n<p>Most phishing emails lure people into clicking through to a malicious or fake website. To do this, cyber criminals will usually spoof the website’s URL by creating a lookalike one, or they’ll mask their dodgy URL by shortening it.</p> \n<p>Whenever you see a weird or shortened URL, make sure you hover your mouse over it to see if the landing page’s web address is different or fake.</p> \n<h4>Mismatched Sender Address</h4> \n<p>Even if a cyber criminal can perfectly imitate your brand’s voice, formatting, logo, address, and contact email address in their phishing email, there’s still a trait of yours they can’t copy — your sender address.</p> \n<p>Cyber criminals will usually create a lookalike sender address or just use a string of characters in hopes that you won’t check it. To verify a brand’s sender address, check out the sender’s domain in the email’s “from” header and see if it matches the brand’s domain.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.5rem; font-weight: 500;\">3. Invest in email security software.</span></p> \n<p>If your company has the funds, email security software like <a href=\"https://www.proofpoint.com/us/solutions/email-fraud\">Proofpoint</a> and <a href=\"https://www.barracuda.com/products/totalemailprotection\">Barracuda</a> are the most reliable and effective lines of defense against phishing.</p> \n<p>Well-versed employees can still fall victim to cleverly-crafted phishing emails and cyber criminals constantly refine their malicious tactics, like sending phishing emails from the legitimate domains of compromised websites.</p> \n<p>But since email security software can identify unusual traffic patterns and monitor fishy URLs, it can effectively detect, block, and respond to these sophisticated threats before they reach your customers and employees’ inbox.</p> \n<h2>Avoid Getting Snagged</h2> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">Arm yourself with DMARC, thorough employee training, and the best-fit email security software for your specific systems and situation, to shield your customers, employees, and brand from phishing attacks — no matter how enticing the bait is.</span></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in December, 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/HsfbPqtSPNa55Y5Mz65rjvNfaGjEb01shhbiZuCRq1IdlV-gvoTp6VejmS7sbMatYgOinlWNdMXqIWFZKSM46oIpLkCzxWm8FYkKFuTiUQvN1bSoSEvfJpfdPOrPhvXo9y5s6iS7\" title=\"\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n<span style=\"font-size: 1.5rem; font-weight: 500;\"> </span>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-phishing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 21 Aug 2020 10:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"794a23c8f2e7708ff4b01d92f26fe513","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-08-19%20at%209.07.34%20AM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-08-19%20at%209.07.34%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn93@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-29-364_037fd73bb681908b.webp","https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/HsfbPqtSPNa55Y5Mz65rjvNfaGjEb01shhbiZuCRq1IdlV-gvoTp6VejmS7sbMatYgOinlWNdMXqIWFZKSM46oIpLkCzxWm8FYkKFuTiUQvN1bSoSEvfJpfdPOrPhvXo9y5s6iS7":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-phishing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn77@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-27-624_6507597db9e875da.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336423},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"12 Social Media Tools You Need to Use in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-tools","description":"<p>You already know how important <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/social-media?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=social_media\">social media </a>is to increase brand awareness, generate more leads, and ultimately score more conversions.</p> \n<p>The world is on social media — <a href=\"https://hootsuite.com/pages/digital-2020\">50% of it</a>, at least — so if you want your product, service, and mission to reach the maximum amount of people, your business needs to be on social media, too.</p>  \n<p>Social media, however, can be extremely time-consuming. Additionally, it spans so many diverse tasks, ranging from number-based activities like tracking analytics, to creative jobs such as designing graphics.</p> \n<p>It can be difficult to find the skills and manpower needed to execute a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-marketing?_ga=2.148338675.551210183.1559051592-1451183703.1557949920\">good social media strategy</a> — which is why you need social media tools to help you out.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll cover the top 12 <a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/social-media-management/\">social media tools</a> you should be using in 2020 to help you save time and increase conversions.</p> \n<h2>What makes for a good social media tool?</h2> \n<p>Although the term \"social media tool\" is very general and can apply to a wide range of services, there are a few key features each social media tool should have.</p> \n<h3>1. It saves you time.</h3> \n<p>The goal of a social media tool is to save you time while getting similar — or better — results than you could without it. Look for social media tools that automate a process, but make sure the process still happens correctly, since some shortcuts might be too fast and therefore won't focus on quality.</p> \n<h3>2. It helps you increase brand awareness.</h3> \n<p>One of the biggest benefits of social media is its ability to increase your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-awareness\">brand awareness</a>, which is why each social media tool you select should perform its services with brand awareness in mind.</p> \n<p>Maybe your tool of choice is an editing platform such as <a href=\"http://lightroom.com\">Lightroom</a>, which can help you create images to match the rest of your feed. Or, maybe it's an Instagram scheduler like <a href=\"http://later.com\">Later</a> so you can preview your profile before you post images. Whatever the case may be, social media tools should focus largely on brand awareness.</p> \n<h3>3. It's easy to use.</h3> \n<p>Social media tools are only a time-saver if they're easy and intuitive. Each tool you select should be super user-friendly so that, if needed, your accounting team could edit photos and your creative, right-brained writers could still use the analytics function to track daily social metrics.</p> \n<p>Many social media tools provide tutorials on their websites. Others, such as <a href=\"http://Kicksta.com\">Kicksta</a>, have top-notch customer service so you can get immediate expert advice if you need help getting off the ground.</p> \n<h3>4. It's affordable.</h3> \n<p>Social media tools should be affordable (and most of them are). Many high-quality social media tools are even free, such as the <a href=\"https://unfold.com/\">Unfold</a> app, which is perfect for creating Instagram stories.</p> \n<p>With social media tools, there's no need for you to go back and forth with the accounting department trying to get your budget approved. Most social media tools are already budget-friendly so all you need to do is sign up.</p> \n<h3>5. It keeps you organized.</h3> \n<p>One of the ways social media tools save you time is by keeping you organized, so make sure the social media tools you decide to use are efficient and tidy.</p> \n<p>For example, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox\">HubSpot's Social Inbox tool </a>helps you prioritize your social media interactions, and graphic design website <a href=\"http://canva.com\">Canva</a> saves your designs so you can go back and edit them later.</p> \n<h3>1. HubSpot's Social Inbox Tool</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong>Starts at $800/month, included in the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/pricing/marketing?selectedPackage=professional&amp;_ga=2.247452224.551210183.1559051592-1451183703.1557949920\">Marketing Hub Professional tier</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox?_ga=2.247452224.551210183.1559051592-1451183703.1557949920\">HubSpot's Social Inbox tool</a> saves you valuable time while still optimizing your social efforts. Schedule your posts, integrate your social networks with your blog, and monitor messages and mentions so you can nurture new leads.</p> \n<p>HubSpot also integrates all of your marketing with your CRM, so it's easy to figure out how many leads and customers you're receiving directly from social media. \"HubSpot Marketing Hub … puts the potential of corporate marketing within everyone's reach,\" <a href=\"https://www.g2.com/products/hubspot/reviews/hubspot-review-2127203\">one customer says</a>.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-1.jpeg?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-1.jpeg\" alt=\"Example of HubSpot's social tool\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<h3>2. Kicksta</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong>Starts at $49/month for individual creatives</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://kicksta.co/\">Kicksta</a> is an Instagram growth service that helps you get more organic followers on your Instagram business account. Using your company account, the growth service \"likes\" around 30,000 photos a month on carefully-targeted accounts. Those users — real people, not spam bots or fake accounts — will begin to follow your account, increasing your brand awareness.</p> \n<p>Kicksta is a good fit for any industry and provides a friendly, responsive, and helpful customer success team. \"Kicksta helps introduce new audiences to our brand while providing consistent organic Instagram growth,\" <a href=\"https://kicksta.co/case-studies/original\">says Ryan Beltran</a>, CEO of watch company Original Grain. \"It’s great for social proof too!\"</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019.png?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019.png\" alt=\"Kicksta's homepage\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://kicksta.co/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>3. Later</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong>Free, or starts at $7.50/month</p> \n<p>Social media marketing platform <a href=\"https://later.com/\">Later</a> lets you plan and schedule your Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, and Pinterest posts. The drag-and-drop calendar makes it easy for you to map out your upcoming posts and see at a glance how your feed will look.</p> \n<p>You can also track your analytics, which will help you figure out the best time of day to post, and the best hashtags to use. Additionally, the Linkin.Bio feature for Instagram helps your posts become instantly shoppable.</p> \n<p>\"I love that you can either use it via the website or app on-the-go,\" <a href=\"https://www.g2.com/products/later/reviews/later-review-1998168\">one user</a> remarks. \"It is one of those apps that I could not live without … Later is [a] super easy tool to set up.\"</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-1.png\" alt=\"Example of Later's offerings and dashboard\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://later.com\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>4. Lightroom</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong>Starts at $9.99/month</p> \n<p>Adobe's <a href=\"https://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop-lightroom.html\">Lightroom</a> product is a tool that lets you organize and edit photos. Since social media is all about visuals, it's critical your business's social media accounts showcase vibrant, on-brand photos.</p> \n<p>Sliders, filters, and many other features make Lightroom a user-friendly tool to create beautiful photos even if you don't have much editing experience. Lightroom is available for both mobile and desktop, and best of all, changes made on one device immediately apply to all devices.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-2.png\" alt=\"Example of editing in Lightroom\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://create.adobe.com/2017/6/19/make_it_impactful_optimizing_images_with_lightroom.html\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>5. Canva</h3> \n<p><strong>Price:</strong> Free, or starts at $9.95/month</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a> is an easy-to-use graphic design website where you can create custom, on-brand graphics for your company's social media accounts. The website has dozens of templates -- everything from Facebook banners to Instagram stories to Twitter posts -- so if starting from scratch to create social graphics seems intimidating, use a template instead.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.g2.com/products/canva/reviews/canva-review-2099002\">One user said</a>, \"Canva has been a lifesaver to me and my business. No more hours sitting in front of the computer coming up with graphics for social media post[s] or Pinterest post[s].\"</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-4.png?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-4.png\" alt=\"Example of a Canva template\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://about.canva.com\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>6. Unfold</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong>Free</p> \n<p>Described as \"a toolkit for storytellers\", <a href=\"https://unfoldstori.es/\">Unfold</a> is an iOS and Android app that helps you create beautiful templates for Instagram stories. Bringing your creative visions to life is the driving idea behind Unfold. It's an ideal app for lifestyle brands who want to create stylish collages to keep their social media accounts on-brand and receive the maximum amount of engagement from followers.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-5.png?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-5.png\" alt=\"Image of Unfold's capabilities.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.apple.com/itunes/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>7. HypeAuditor</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong>Starts at $200/month for 50 reports</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buy-instagram-followers?_ga=2.143643505.551210183.1559051592-1451183703.1557949920\">You'll never earn money</a> from fake followers — they just make your engagement look bad (think millions of followers, but only a few hundred likes per photo) and ruin your reputation. That's why <a href=\"https://hypeauditor.com/en/\">HypeAuditor</a> weeds out fake followers on your Instagram account to help you determine your organic reach.</p> \n<p>Additionally, HypeAuditor analyzes your audience to figure out where they live, their age and gender, and which of your followers are ghosts.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-3.png?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019-3.png\" alt=\"Example of HypeAuditor's dashboard\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 11px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://hypeauditor.com\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>8. Retouchup</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong>Starts at $0.25 per image</p> \n<p>The website <a href=\"https://www.retouchup.com/\">Retouchup</a> provides an easy way to edit photos for social media, from basic color correction to more advanced Photoshop-like features such as adding or removing people from a photo. With Retouchup, you don't do the work yourself -- instead, just submit a photo and the website's experts will edit the photo for you within 24 hours.</p> \n<p>\"You're making me look like an awesome photographer!\" <a href=\"https://www.retouchup.com/reviews.php\">one user gushed</a>. Retouchup can save you time during the editing stage, and make your images appear higher-quality and more compelling.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019.jpeg?width=1500&amp;name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019.jpeg\" alt=\"Retouchup image examples \" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.retouchup.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>9. Quuu</h3> \n<p><strong>Price:</strong> Free, or starts at $19/month.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://quuu.co/\">Quuu</a> is a platform that helps its users execute visually stunning social media content. It automates the time-consuming process of properly creating professional, engaging multimedia assets for campaigns.</p> \n<p>When using Quuu, you can choose from over 500 interest categories, like marketing or real estate, and receive content suggestions based on those choices. You'll receive a certain amount of content suggestions per day per profile based on your settings, ensuring you'll always have relevant posts for your audience.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Quuu%20dashboard%20example.png?width=1500&amp;name=Quuu%20dashboard%20example.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" alt=\"Quuu dashboard example\" width=\"1500\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/quuu\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<p>If you're a HubSpot customer, you can integrate the two platforms. Quuu finds the best content for your social profiles, and HubSpot lets you control those suggestions. You can go to your draft folder via HubSpot and pick which content you want to upload if your Quuu account isn't automated, which you can change.</p> \n<p>Quuu looks for content so you don't have to. The tool also integrates with Buffer, Hootsuite, and Socialbee.</p> \n<h3>10. Marketing Video Builder</h3> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>Price:</strong> Free, or starts at $33/month.</p> \n<p>Marketing Video Builder by <a href=\"http://animoto.com/\">Animoto</a> helps you make professional-tier videos to engage with audiences. Videos can be created in minutes using the online video editor. The best part about the tool is that you don't even need editing experience to get started.</p> \n<p>You can increase brand awareness by making videos for your company, and share them across social channels to grow your audience. Additionally, if you're a HubSpot customer, you can integrate that account with your Animoto account.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.19%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.19%20AM.png\" alt=\"Marketing Video Builder dashboard example\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 1500px; display: block;\" width=\"1500\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/animoto\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<p>When you create videos, you can use a pre-built storyboard template curated by either Animoto or HubSpot. Alternatively, you can make a video from scratch. When you're done, you can export the video to your HubSpot file manager with one click and manage it from there.</p> \n<p>Animoto also integrates with Getty Images, Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, and LinkedIn, so you can have video tools for a good portion of social media platforms all in one place.</p> \n<h3>11. Design Wizard</h3> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>Price:</strong> Free, or starts at $9.99/month</p> \n<p>This tool lets you create different types of content, like photos and videos, with no professional editing experience required. If you have a limited budget and time on your hands, this free visual content tool is ideal for you.</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://designwizard.com/\">Design Wizard</a> has a library of over a million multimedia graphics for inspiration and use. Plus, all images are licensed for commercial use, so if you use one from the site, you won't run into copyright infringements.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.28%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.28%20AM.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 1500px; display: block;\" alt=\"Design Wizard editing screen\" width=\"1500\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/design-wizard\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<p>Your beautiful, on-brand images will be able to integrate with HubSpot. You can manage all of the files you create with Design Wizard from your HubSpot account, which you can use for campaign posts.</p> \n<h3>12. Falcon</h3> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><strong>Price:</strong>&nbsp;$129/mo.</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://falcon.io/\">Falcon</a> is a social media management platform that allows you to create posts for social networks on a collaborative content calendar.</p> \n<p>It integrates with HubSpot, Microsoft, and Salesforce to help users streamline marketing tasks among teams. For a visual to see how Falcon integrates with other software, refer to the photo below:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/falcon%20example.png?width=1500&amp;name=falcon%20example.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" alt=\"Falcon integration example\" width=\"1500\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/falcon-io\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<p>HubSpot customers can use this integration to create audience segments. These segmentations will help you target your customers with social media posts, making sure your content is being seen by the right people. Any changes you make within HubSpot will automatically transfer to Falcon, so you don't have to worry about manually updating content.</p> \n<p>There are numerous choices out there for high-quality social media tools. Ultimately, it's your job to decide which tool is the best fit for your needs, your budget, and your marketing goals.</p> \n<p>Need a painless way to track your social interactions? Try <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox?_ga=2.108414400.35687068.1585574311-940436819.1565181751\">HubSpot's social inbox tool</a> today.</p> \n<p>Editor's note: This
