vr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn70@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-27-534_824ae9f21d88a73e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019.jpeg?width=1500&name=8%20Social%20Media%20Tools%20You%20Need%20to%20Use%20in%202019.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn63@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-20-099_f080453711caadc2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Quuu%20dashboard%20example.png?width=1500&name=Quuu%20dashboard%20example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn58@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-25-579_e56c354c2eace63f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.19%20AM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.19%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn51@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-19-993_bd572a336cc79a26.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.28%20AM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-04-01%20at%2011.54.28%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-23-427_8afb630964df75ee.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/falcon%20example.png?width=1500&name=falcon%20example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn94@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-24-229_ef35c0a971fa6c93.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsocial-media-tools&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn94@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-27-039_dcf39d2ffb529be1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336430},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How Behavioral Targeting Gets Your Content Seen By the Right Audiences","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/behavioral-targeting","description":"<p>What optimization strategies are you using to improve the performance of ads? If you're like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?__hstc=20629287.baf2406400c73bbe46641b2b9cd8a38f.1563824949326.1584540014200.1584545281370.484&amp;__hssc=20629287.18.1584545281370&amp;__hsfp=3755920611\">almost half of marketers</a>, your answer probably includes ad placement and targeting.</p>  \n<p>As we know, targeted ads are used to find the most qualified leads by showing audiences content that's relevant to them.</p> \n<p>Targeted ads connect you with the leads that are going to be the most interested in what you offer.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>So, how can you be sure that you're generating the <em>most </em>qualified leads with your targeted ads? While there's no sure fire way to tell, there's an optimization strategy you may be missing: behavioral targeting.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/audience-targeting-blog?_ga=2.187036584.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">Targeted advertising</a> allows you to use demographic information, including location or age, to surface ads to relevant audiences. Behavioral targeting uses web behavior as the determining factor, instead of demographics. This increases the impact ads have on audiences.</p> \n<p>Some of the criteria behavioral targeting looks at includes previously visited websites, search history, and past purchases.</p> \n<p>If a marketer spent 20 minutes browsing CRMs, Googling software prices, and reading customer management blogs, behavioral targeting would analyze those actions to show that person ads for a CRM product the next time they visited a site like Facebook.</p> \n<p>Behavioral targeting is used to improve campaign effectiveness. The sales manager weighing their CRM options would likely be more interested in a product ad for one rather than an SEO strategist, making them a qualified lead for the software company.</p> \n<p>Now, let's talk about how behavioral targeting can boost sales. If I were in the market for a social media scheduler and browsed websites like <a href=\"https://www.loomly.com/\">Loomly</a> and <a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/\">Sprout Social</a> before turning to Google, the search engine's behavioral targeting features would show me ads for the sites I visited first.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Behavioral%20Targeting%20Gets%20Your%20Content%20Seen%20By%20the%20Right%20Audiences.png\" alt=\"a SERP that indicates previous web activity.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>My previous internet behavior told Google what type of sites I'd already visited, so the search engine pulled the top list of options that are related and relevant to my search. And, when I checked my Facebook account a little while later, I saw that my web behavior influenced my ads there, as well:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Behavioral%20Targeting%20Gets%20Your%20Content%20Seen%20By%20the%20Right%20Audiences-2.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"An ad being shown based on behavioral targeting.\">\n</div> \n<p>Pretty cool, right? And to run behavioral targeted ads, you wouldn't have to stray too far from your ad strategy. If your ad host offers targeted options, like <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/ad-targeting\">Facebook</a> or <a href=\"https://business.twitter.com/en/advertising/targeting.html\">Twitter</a> do, create audience segments based on demographics, like location and age. You can also choose psychographics, like interests and values.</p> \n<p>After that, the software will do the work, choosing browsers to show your content based on the preferences you set.</p> \n<p>So, now we know that behavioral targeting helps reach those leads who are intending to make purchases. But what about the potential customers who are in a different stage of their journey?</p> \n<p>Enter: predictive behavioral targeting.</p> \n<p>Behavioral targeting uses website history to show users ads that relate to their interests. Predictive behavioral targeting is a form of analysis — it looks at those targeted ads as a whole, so advertisers can come to conclusions about audience interaction.</p> \n<p>For instance, this is a behavioral targeted ad I came across on Facebook. If I, and others with similar demographics, interact with the ad in the same way, WordStream's advertisers can infer that audiences like me respond well to similar content offer ads.</p> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fwordstream%2Fposts%2F10158788220547743&amp;show_text=true&amp;width=552&amp;height=400&amp;appId\" width=\"552\" height=\"400\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe> \n<p>Predictive behavioral targeting helps improve the performance of ads for audience segments. It lets advertisers look critically at the similarities of customers and cater to them. This improves the effectiveness of behaviors being targeted.</p> \n<p>If you're still on the fence about using this strategy, don't worry. Let's look at the good and bad of behavioral targeting to help you make your decision.</p> \n<h2>Pros and Cons of Behavioral Targeting</h2> \n<p>There are a <em>lot </em>of ad types to choose from, and it's up to advertisers to choose ones that maximize the effectiveness of campaigns. Like with all types, behavioral targeting has its upsides and downsides. Let's look at a few.</p> \n<h3>Behavioral targeting pros</h3> \n<h4>1. Nurture leads through the buyer's journey.</h4> \n<p>Behavioral targeting helps you fill in the gaps you may have with your ad strategy. If you're seeing excellent <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/measure-content-marketing-roi?_ga=2.14572471.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">ROI</a> from brand awareness ads, but want to drive more conversions from content offer ads, behavioral targeting can help.</p> \n<p>For example, if you're using an ad to promote a new webinar you've hosted, turning on behavioral targeting will increase the ad's chance of reaching audiences who have been looking for webinars like yours.</p> \n<h4>2. Make more sales.</h4> \n<p>Behavioral targeting makes retargeting a better experience for customers. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/retargeting-campaigns-beginner-guide?_ga=2.14572471.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">Retargeted ads</a> catch website visitors who have abandoned your site without making a purchase. Behavioral retargeting takes that up a notch by crawling more previous web visits.</p> \n<p>When you use behavioral retargeting, your ads will convey a more personalized message to audiences. They’ll remind those who closed your site to visit again with content that's already tailored to their interests.</p> \n<h4>3. Improve the overall customer experience.</h4> \n<p>When you analyze behavioral targeting results, you can begin to draw conclusions about how your audience engages with ads. For instance, if you find that millennial customers are looking for a certain product stack, you can start tailoring your ads in response.</p> \n<p>Behavioral targeting shows customers data-driven ads based on their web behavior. Based on the data you collect from the ads, like click-through rate and conversions, you can tweak the messaging or content of those ads to fit the browsing patterns of your audience.</p> \n<h3>Behavioral targeting cons</h3> \n<h4>1. Behavioral targeting can get costly.</h4> \n<p>Running<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc?_ga=2.15081142.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"> pay-per-click ads</a> isn't the most budget-friendly solution. Behavioral targeting falls under that umbrella, and it can get expensive. Make sure to check your advertising budget — and set budget caps — to make sure you have the financial bandwidth to produce ads for the entire campaign.</p> \n<h4>2. Ads can fail without proper audience knowledge.</h4> \n<p>If you don't know your audience, it's likely behavioral targeting won't give you positive results. Generally, the ads are shown based on audience segments you select. But, without proper knowledge of what customers respond to, there's room for lack of resonance from your target market.</p> \n<p>For instance, your buyer persona may be a 30-year-old marketer who's looking for a CRM to make the team she manages more organized. So, you decide to show that portion of your audience a brand awareness ad.</p> \n<p>But, if that ads messaging fails to capture the interest of the majority of your target audience, it won't be very effective. Behavioral targeting finds the right customers, but it's up to your ad to seal the deal. Make sure you're up-to-date with how your target market responds to ads to improve performance.</p> \n<h4>3. Behavioral targeting can lead to an advertising overload.</h4> \n<p>Be wary of producing too many. They can lead to an oversaturation of content and ultimately deter customers from wanting to engage with your ads. As a consumer, if I'm presented with numerous targeted ads from the same companies, I begin to mentally block out any advertising messages from that business.</p> \n<p>Use behavioral targeting sparingly. It'll save you money and catch customers at the right time. Be sure to modify your ad settings so you're not showing users targeted ads every five minutes, just which it's the most impactful.</p> \n<p>Behavioral targeting is just one of the many <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/optimizing-ads-hubspot\">a</a><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/optimizing-ads-hubspot?_ga=2.15081142.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">dvertising optimization strategies</a> that are great for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-inbound-lead-generation-guide-ht?_ga=2.15081142.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">generating leads</a>. It's also one of the most effective. If you're finding that your current ad strategies aren't producing the ROI you're looking for anymore, this tactic could be your answer.</p> \n<p>How do you plan to use behavioral targeting to revamp your ad strategy?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbehavioral-targeting&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Behavioral%20Targeting%20Gets%20Your%20Content%20Seen%20By%20the%20Right%20Audiences.png","linkMd5":"f97b818aca2bc9376620659d6e5d48f1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-18-610_f003629dd2fd2f0c.webp","destWidth":1018,"destHeight":623,"sourceBytes":38496,"destBytes":38496,"author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Behavioral%20Targeting%20Gets%20Your%20Content%20Seen%20By%20the%20Right%20Audiences.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-18-610_f003629dd2fd2f0c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Behavioral%20Targeting%20Gets%20Your%20Content%20Seen%20By%20the%20Right%20Audiences-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn62@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-28-176_43ae2d15e1136c38.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbehavioral-targeting&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn86@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-29-349_b590d25d5967a41e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336445},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"Why A Digital PR Specialist Should Always Be Involved in Content Creation","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/digital-pr-specialist-content-creation","description":"<p>If you've been on the creative side of content marketing, you know not every idea is a winner. Sometimes projects gather a few links and then vanish under a pile of other content.</p> \n<p>To compete, you have to ensure the content you're creating, from the idea to the actual execution, is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/how-to-generate-effective-content-ideas\">compelling</a> enough to earn the coverage and attention you hope it'll achieve.</p> \n<p>And there's one really excellent way to do this: involve a digital PR specialist from the get-go.</p> \n<p>I work in digital PR and have consulted on hundreds of content projects.</p> \n<p>Below, let's review what I've learned about how content creators and digital PR professionals can successfully work together to create engaging, newsworthy content.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Recognize viral ideas.</h3> \n<p>Digital PR specialists are responsible for interacting and building relationships with the media, so they likely spend around 70% of their workday online.</p> \n<p>Typically, they're reading new studies, picking apart articles, and getting to know writers. It's only natural that after experiencing the nuances of the news cycle, PR specialists are able to recognize which ideas make it big.</p> \n<p>If that kind of market research already exists in the brains of the outreach specialists on your team, why not utilize it?</p> \n<p>Getting feedback from the birth of a project means the trajectory of the content will be aimed for top-tier coverage. From the idea stage, it may make sense to create a ranking system with your team.</p> \n<p>Outreach specialists can categorize each idea by newsworthiness, relevance, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-promotion-ideas\">promotional viability</a> to get a better understanding of where your projects stand.</p> \n<p>From there, you can go back to the drawing board or work with your best concepts.</p> \n<p>Using your PR pros will help expand creative ideas from using only what the creative team thinks is interesting to using what publishers think is interesting. Who knows? A single tip from an outreach specialist could turn a mediocre campaign into a huge win for a client.</p> \n<p>For example, at <a href=\"https://www.frac.tl/\">Fractl</a>, one of our biggest recent wins in the career vertical involved pivoting an idea about millennial work/life balance to a survey packed with \"would you rather\" questions.</p> \n<p>This new formatting allowed the creative strategist to ask more hard-hitting questions and challenged millennials to give concrete information about how much they'd be willing to sacrifice in their personal lives in order to get ahead in business. Some of the notable takeaways included:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>More than two in five millennials are willing to end a relationship if it meant getting a promotion at work.</li> \n <li>One in three would dump their S.O. for a raise.</li> \n <li>Millennials put their career before marriage: most are willing to postpone marriage for another seven years if it means they'd land a promotion.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Keep data human.</h3> \n<p>In a recent study from <a href=\"https://www.buzzstream.com/blog/creating-the-most-authoritative-content.html\">BuzzStream and Fractl</a>, consumers ranked data analysis and index as the most authoritative form of online content.</p> \n<p>Those who work in content production are exceptional at analyzing these numbers to reveal their hidden insights. However, it can be easy to get lost in the data while exploring every perspective and lose sight of the most compelling pieces.</p> \n<p>Outreach specialists can help bridge the gap between data and human interest. If there isn't a cohesive narrative weaved throughout your data, a digital PR specialist can pull from their experience in studying what kind of stories emotionally resonate, and can help identify the true story in the data.</p> \n<p>While analyzing data, touch base with your outreach team to develop a storyline. Be sure they identify the simplest ways to digest the information you're trying to get across. If it takes longer than 60 seconds to understand the information in a graph, you're going to lose your audience.</p> \n<p>Oftentimes, content creators become attached to their data and believe every aspect is essential to the piece. While this may be true in some cases, oftentimes slimming down excess information can be beneficial to the narrative as a whole.</p> \n<p>Don't be afraid of feedback, and remember that outreach specialists spend <em>a lot</em> of time dissecting stories online. They're likely a trustworthy editor for your work.</p> \n<p>For example, when presenting repetitive information, it's important to provide interesting visuals to accompany data. When creating infographics about dangerous tools for a home improvement client, our team at Fractl decided to spice up statistics that would otherwise be mundane by placing the information within a tool shed.</p> \n<p>This project ended up being a winner within the home and garden vertical and I owe the promotional viability to the engaging way the information was presented.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png?width=600&amp;name=%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png\" alt=\"Infographic helps humanize data.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>If your data tells a story your audience wants to hear, graphs and images become as essential as the words on the page. Using industry knowledge from your outreach specialist's tool belt, you can elevate data-driven content to make it worthy of top-tier press.</p> \n<h3>3. Extract the juiciest takeaways.</h3> \n<p>You have a great idea, you research it, pull all the data, and it falls flat. Sometimes the stories you thought would be told through data don't come to fruition. But this doesn't mean your project is DOA, your outreach specialist may be able to revive it.</p> \n<p>Having an eye on the media means that outreach specialists may be able to extract something from a project that would have otherwise been overlooked. Digital PR pros can draw up some ideal headlines or takeaways to increase the project's chances of appealing to particular publishers and audiences.</p> \n<p>Whether it means tying the data to a trending story or pitching a vertical not initially intended to be a match for your content, there's usually always a way to distill data into a highly promotable headline.</p> \n<p>Chris Lewis, account manager and creative strategist at Fractl, said he incorporates feedback from media specialists into his projects.</p> \n<p>\"Outreach specialists are my secret weapon in creating compelling data-driven story content,\" he said. \"More than anything, they help me get out of my own way by always finding the promotable and most interesting parts of content and finding ways to highlight them.\"</p> \n<h3>4. Create better content.</h3> \n<p>Incorporating feedback from several team members throughout the life of a project can mean improved results from your content marketing efforts.</p> \n<p>Consider hosting collaborative meetings every once in a while or implementing edits from your outreach specialists if an idea falls dry.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, using a digital PR specialist in your content creation will help you create promotable content because of the work with the media and interaction online.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdigital-pr-specialist-content-creation&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"7254e177cdc584fa16ca62f114c4c6b5","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Delaney Kline","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png?width=600&name=%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn68@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-29-190_ba3466db66c4767b.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdigital-pr-specialist-content-creation&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn32@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-22-702_cc7c73145b6ec61a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336433},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Cybersecurity","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cybersecurity","description":"<p>If asked you to list the most valuable things you own, how would you answer? I guess this would be another way of asking the infamous “What would you grab if your house was on fire?” question.</p> \n<p>For me, I’d grab an old keepsake box filled with things from my childhood, my engagement ring, my phone and computer (for pictures and writings!), and an old Iowa sweatshirt of my dad’s.</p> \n<p>But I’d also have to say that my identity, social security number, credit cards, and bank accounts are valuable to me.</p> \n<p>While these things can’t exactly burn down in a fire, they <em>can</em> be stolen … and if I were to ask a computer hacker what they thought my most valuable possessions were, they’d probably quote the intangible.</p> \n<p>That’s why we’ve compiled this guide on cybersecurity. Below, we’ll talk about why you should care about cybersecurity, how to secure your and your customer’s digital data, and what resources to follow to stay up-to-date with emerging tech.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>Personal data is incredibly valuable. Hackers know it, and businesses know it. That’s why both go to great lengths to collect it — albeit one following a much more legal and moral avenue to do so.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, as technology and data collection practices progress, so do the methods that hackers follow to steal data. As business owners, we have a special responsibility to protect our customers’ data and be transparent with our practices.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Why You Should Care About Cybersecurity</h2> \n<p>In the first half of 2019, data breaches exposed <a href=\"https://pages.riskbasedsecurity.com/2019-midyear-data-breach-quickview-report\">over 4 billion records</a>. Moreover, a recent study found that hackers attack <a href=\"https://eng.umd.edu/news/story/study-hackers-attack-every-39-seconds\">every 39 seconds</a> — that adds up to, on average, 2,244 attacks per day.</p> \n<p>Small to medium-sized businesses (SMBs) are especially at risk. You might see corporations like Target and Sears topping the headlines as top data breach victims, but it’s actually SMBs that hackers prefer to target.</p> \n<p>Why? They have more — and more valuable — digital assets than your average consumer but less security than a larger enterprise-level company … placing them right in a “<a href=\"https://www.businessnewsdaily.com/8231-small-business-cybersecurity-guide.html\">hackers' cybersecurity sweet spot</a>.”</p> \n<p>Security breaches are frustrating and frightening for both businesses and consumers. <a href=\"https://www.ca.com/us/collateral/white-papers/the-global-state-of-online-digital-trust.html\">Studies show</a> that, after a company data breach, many consumers take a break from shopping at that business — and some consumers quit altogether.</p> \n<p>But cybersecurity is about more than just avoiding a PR nightmare. Investing in cybersecurity builds trust with your customers. It encourages transparency and reduces friction as customers become advocates for your brand.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>“Everyone has a role in helping to protect customers’ data. Here at HubSpot, every employee is empowered to solve for customer needs in a safe and secure way. We want to harness everyone’s energy to provide a platform that customers trust to correctly and safely store their data.” — Chris McLellan, HubSpot Chief Security Officer</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/stay-current-emerging-tech\"><em>Keep your business ahead of the tech curve with the tips, systems &amp; recommended resources in our guide to staying current on emerging tech.</em></a></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Cybersecurity Terms to Know</h2> \n<p>Cybersecurity is a very intimidating topic, not unlike <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cryptocurrency\">cryptocurrency</a> and <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/artificial-intelligence\">artificial intelligence</a>. It can be hard to understand, and, frankly, it sounds kind of ominous and complicated.</p> \n<p>But fear not. We’re here to break this topic down into digestible pieces that you can rebuild into your own cybersecurity strategy. Bookmark this post to keep this handy glossary at your fingertips.</p> \n<p>Here’s a comprehensive list of general cybersecurity terms you should know.</p> \n<h3>Authentication</h3> \n<p>Authentication is the process of verifying who you are. Your passwords authenticate that you really are the person who should have the corresponding username. When you show your ID (e.g., driver’s license, etc), the fact that your picture generally looks like you is a way of authenticating that the name, age, and address on the ID belong to you. Many organizations use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cybersecurity#two\">two-factor authentication, which we cover later</a>.</p> \n<h3>Backup</h3> \n<p>A backup refers to the process of transferring important data to a secure location like a cloud storage system or an external hard drive. Backups let you recover your systems to a healthy state in case of a cyber attack or system crash.</p> \n<h3>Data Breach</h3> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/data-breach\">data breach</a> refers to the moment a hacker gains unauthorized entry or access to a company’s or an individual’s data.</p> \n<h3>Digital Certificate</h3> \n<p>A digital certificate, also known as an identity certificate or public key certificate, is a type of passcode used to securely exchange data over the internet. It’s essentially a digital file embedded in a device or piece of hardware that provides authentication when it sends and receives data to and from another device or server.</p> \n<h3>Encryption</h3> \n<p>Encryption is the practice of using codes and ciphers to encrypt data. When data is encrypted, a computer uses a key to turn the data into unintelligible gibberish. Only a recipient with the correct key is able to decrypt the data. If an attacker gets access to strongly encrypted data but doesn’t have the key, they aren’t able to see the unencrypted version.</p> \n<h3>HTTP and HTTPS</h3> \n<p>Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-the-internet-works\">how web browsers communicate</a>. You’ll probably see an <em>http://</em> or <em>https://</em> in front of the websites you visit. HTTP and HTTPS are the same, except HTTPS encrypts all data sent between you and the web server — hence the “S” for security. Today, nearly all websites use HTTPS to improve the privacy of your data.</p> \n<h3>Vulnerability</h3> \n<p>A vulnerability is a place of weakness that a hacker might exploit when launching a cyber attack. Vulnerabilities might be software bugs that need to be patched, or a password reset process that can be triggered by unauthorized people. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cybersecurity#defensive\">Defensive cybersecurity measures (like the ones we talk about later) </a>help ensure data is protected by putting layers of protections between attackers and the things they’re trying to do or access.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>A cyber attack is a deliberate and typically malicious intent to capture, modify, or erase private data. Cyber attacks are committed by external security hackers and, sometimes, unintentionally by compromised users or employees. <a href=\"https://blog.netwrix.com/2018/05/15/top-10-most-common-types-of-cyber-attacks/\">These cyber attacks</a> are committed for a variety of reasons. <a href=\"https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/common-cyberattacks.html\">The majority are looking for ransom</a>, while some are simply launched for fun.</p> \n<p>Here are the four most common cyber threats.</p> \n<h3>1. Password Guessing (Brute Force) Attack</h3> \n<p>A password guessing (or “credential stuffing”) attack is when an attacker continually attempts to guess usernames and passwords. This attack will often use known username and password combinations from past data breaches. An attacker is successful when people use weak passwords or use the password between different systems (e.g., when your Facebook and Twitter password are the same, etc). Your best defense against this kind of attack is using strong passwords and avoiding using the same password in multiple places as well as using two factor authentication,<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cybersecurity#passwords\"> as we talk about later</a>.)</p> \n<h3>2. Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) Attack</h3> \n<p>A distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack is when a hacker floods a network or system with a ton of activity (such as messages, requests, or web traffic) in order to paralyze it. This is typically done using <strong>botnets</strong>, which are groups of internet-connected devices (e.g., laptops, light bulbs, game consoles, servers, etc) infected by viruses that allow a hacker to harness them into performing many kinds of attacks.</p> \n<h3>3. Malware Attack</h3> \n<p>Malware refers to all types of malicious software used by hackers to infiltrate computers and networks and collect susceptible private data. Types of malware include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Keyloggers</strong>, which track everything a person types on their keyboard. Keyloggers are usually used to capture passwords and other private information, such as social security numbers.</li> \n <li><strong>Ransomware</strong>, which encrypts data and holds it hostage, forcing users to pay a ransom in order to unlock and regain access to their data.</li> \n <li><strong>Spyware</strong>, which monitors and “spies” on user activity on behalf of a hacker.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Furthermore, malware can be delivered via:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Trojan horses</strong>, which infect computers through a seemingly benign entry point, often disguised as a legitimate application or other piece of software.</li> \n <li><strong>Viruses</strong>, which corrupt, erase, modify, or capture data and, at times, <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/2014/11/countdown-to-zero-day-stuxnet/\">physically damage computers</a>. Viruses can spread from computer to computer, including when they are unintentionally installed by compromised users.</li> \n <li><strong>Worms</strong>, which are designed to self-replicate and autonomously spread through all connected computers that are susceptible to the same vulnerabilities. .</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Phishing Attack</h3> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-phishing\">phishing attack</a> is when hackers try to trick people into doing something. Phishing scams can be delivered through a seemingly legitimate download, link, or message. It’s a very common type of cyber attack — <a href=\"https://www.wombatsecurity.com/state-of-the-phish\">over 75% of organizations fell victim to phishing in 2018</a>. Phishing is typically done over email or through a fake website; it’s also known as <strong>spoofing</strong>. Additionally, <strong>spear phishing</strong> refers to when a hacker focuses on attacking a particular person or company, instead of creating more general-purpose spams.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Cybersecurity Best Practices: How to Secure Your Data</h2> \n<a></a> \n<p>Cybersecurity can’t be boiled down into a 1-2-3-step process. Securing your data involves a mix of best practices and defensive cybersecurity techniques. Dedicating time and resources to both is the best way to secure your — and your customers’ — data.</p> \n<h3>Defensive Cybersecurity Solutions</h3> \n<p>All businesses should invest in preventative cybersecurity solutions. Implementing these systems and adopting <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cybersecurity#cyber-security-tips\">good cybersecurity habits (which we discuss next)</a> will protect your network and computers from outside threats.</p> \n<p>Here’s a list of six defensive cybersecurity systems and software options that can prevent cyber attacks — and the inevitable headache that follows. Consider combining these solutions to cover all your digital bases.</p> \n<h4>Antivirus Software</h4> \n<p>Antivirus software is the digital equivalent of taking that vitamin C boost during flu season. It’s a preventative measure that monitors for bugs. The job of antivirus software is to detect viruses on your computer and remove them, much like vitamin C does when bad things enter your immune system. (Spoken like a true medical professional …) Antivirus software also alerts you to potentially unsafe web pages and software.</p> \n<p><strong>Learn more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.mcafee.com/consumer/en-us/store/m0/catalog/mavb_511/mcafee-antivirus-basic.html\">McAfee</a>, <a href=\"https://us.norton.com/antivirus\">Norton</a>. or <a href=\"https://www.pandasecurity.com/usa/homeusers/solutions/free-antivirus/\">Panda</a> (for free)</p> \n<h4>Firewall</h4> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/personal-firewall\">firewall</a> is a digital wall that keeps malicious users and software out of your computer. It uses a filter that assesses the safety and legitimacy of everything that wants to enter your computer; it’s like an invisible judge that sits between you and the internet. Firewalls are both software and hardware-based.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p><strong>Learn more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.mcafee.com/consumer/en-us/store/m0/catalog/mls_430/mcafee-livesafe.html\">McAfee LiveSafe</a> or <a href=\"https://www.kaspersky.com/internet-security\">Kaspersky Internet Security</a><a href=\"https://www.kaspersky.com/internet-security\"></a></p> \n<h4>Single Sign-On (SSO)</h4> \n<p>Single sign-on (SSO) is a centralized authentication service through which one login is used to access an entire platform of accounts and software. If you’ve ever used your Google account to sign up or into an account, you’ve used SSO. Enterprises and corporations use SSO to allow employees access to internal applications that contain proprietary data.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p><strong>Learn more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.okta.com/\">Okta</a> or <a href=\"https://www.lastpass.com/\">LastPass</a><a href=\"https://www.lastpass.com/\"></a></p> \n<h4>Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/two-factor-authentication\">Two-factor authentication (2FA)</a> is a login process that requires a username or pin number <em>and</em> access to an external device or account, such as an email address, phone number, or security software. 2FA requires users to confirm their identity through both and, because of that, is far more secure than single factor authentication.</p> \n<p><strong>Learn more</strong>: <a href=\"https://duo.com/\">Duo</a></p> \n<h4>Virtual Private Network (VPN)</h4> \n<p>A virtual private network (VPN) creates a “tunnel” through which your data travels when entering and exiting a web server. That tunnel encrypts and protects your data so that it can’t be read (or spied on) by hackers or malicious software. While a VPN protects against spyware, it can’t prevent viruses from entering your computer through seemingly legitimate channels, like phishing or even a fake VPN link. Because of this, VPNs should be combined with other defensive cybersecurity measures in order to protect your data.</p> \n<p><strong>Learn more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/anyconnect-secure-mobility-client/index.html\">Cisco's AnyConnect</a> or <a href=\"https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/globalprotect/cloudservice\">Palo Alto Networks’ GlobalProtect</a><a href=\"https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/globalprotect/cloudservice\"></a></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Cybersecurity Tips for Business</h2> \n<a></a> \n<p>Defensive cybersecurity solutions won’t work unless you do. To ensure your business and customer data is protected, adopt these good cybersecurity habits across your organization.</p> \n<h3>Require strong credentials.</h3> \n<p>Require both your employees and users (if applicable) to create strong passwords. This can be done by implementing a character minimum as well as requiring a mix of upper and lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols. More complicated passwords are harder to guess by both individuals and bots. Also, require that passwords be changed regularly.</p> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Cybersecurity.png?width=1500&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Cybersecurity.png\" alt=\"guide to cybersecurity require strong credentials\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<h3>Control and monitor employee activity.</h3> \n<p>Within your business, only give access to important data to authorized employees who need it for their job. Prohibit data from sharing outside the organization, require permission for external software downloads, and encourage employees to lock their computers and accounts whenever not in use.</p> \n<h3>Know your network.</h3> \n<p>With the rise of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/internet-of-things-iot\">Internet of Things</a>, IoT devices are popping up on company networks like crazy. These devices, which are not under company management, can introduce risk as they’re often unsecured and run vulnerable software that can be exploited by hackers and provide a direct pathway into an internal network.</p> \n<blockquote>\n  “Make sure you have visibility into all the IoT devices on your network. Everything on your corporate network should be identified, properly categorized, and controlled. By knowing what devices are on your network, controlling how they connect to it, and monitoring them for suspicious activities, you'll drastically reduce the landscape attackers are playing on.” — Nick Duda, Principal Security Officer at HubSpot \n</blockquote> \n<p><em>Read about how HubSpot gains device visibility and automates security management in <a href=\"https://www.forescout.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/fs-cs-hubspot.pdf\">this case study compiled by security software ForeScout</a>.</em></p> \n<h3>Download patches and updates regularly.</h3> \n<p>Software vendors regularly release updates that address and fix vulnerabilities. Keep your software safe by updating it on a consistent basis. Consider configuring your software to update automatically so you never forget.</p> \n<h3>Make it easy for employees to escalate issues.</h3> \n<p>If your employee comes across a phishing email or compromised web page, you want to know immediately. Set up a system for receiving these issues from employees by dedicating an inbox to these notifications or creating a form that people can fill out.</p> \n<h2>Cybersecurity Tips for Individuals</h2> \n<p>Cyber threats can affect you as an individual consumer and internet user, too. Adopt these good habits to protect your personal data and avoid cyber attacks.</p> \n<h3>Mix up your passwords.</h3> \n<p>Using the same password for all your important accounts is the digital equivalent of leaving a spare key under your front doormat. A <a href=\"https://blog.centrify.com/verizon-compromised-credentials/\">recent study</a> found that over 80% of data breaches were a result of weak or stolen passwords. Even if a business or software account doesn’t require a strong password, always choose one that has a mix of letters, numbers, and symbols and change it regularly.</p> \n<h3>Monitor your bank accounts and credit frequently.</h3> \n<p>Review your statements, credit reports, and other critical data on a regular basis and report any suspicious activity. Additionally, only release your social security number when absolutely necessary.</p> \n<h3>Be intentional online.</h3> \n<p>Keep an eye out for phishing emails or illegitimate downloads. If a link or website looks fishy (ha — get it?), it <em>probably</em> is. Look for bad spelling and grammar, suspicious URLs, and mismatched email addresses. Lastly, download antivirus and security software to alert you of potential and known malware sources.</p> \n<h3>Back up your data regularly.</h3> \n<p>This habit is good for businesses and individuals to master — data can be compromised for both parties. Consider backups on both cloud and physical locations, such as a hard drive or thumb drive.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Cybersecurity Resources</h2> \n<p>To learn more about cybersecurity and how to better equip your business and team, tap into the resources below. Check out some of the most <a href=\"https://solutionsreview.com/identity-management/twenty-cybersecurity-podcasts-you-should-be-listening-to/\">popular cybersecurity podcasts</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.feedspot.com/cyber_security_blogs/\">cybersecurity blogs</a>, too.</p> \n<h3>National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.nist.gov/\">NIST</a> is a government agency that promotes excellence in science and industry. It also contains a <a href=\"https://www.nist.gov/topics/cybersecurity\">Cybersecurity department</a> and routinely publishes guides that standards.</p> \n<p><strong>Bookmark:</strong> The Computer Security Resource Center (CSRC) for security best practices, called <a href=\"https://csrc.nist.gov/News/2019/draft-nist-sp-800-205-available-for-comment\">NIST Special Publications (SPs)</a>.</p> \n<h3>The Center for Internet Security (CIS)</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.cisecurity.org/\">CIS</a> is a global, non-profit security resource and IT community used and trusted by experts in the field.</p> \n<p><strong>Bookmark</strong>: The <a href=\"https://www.cisecurity.org/controls/\">CIS Top 20 Critical Security Controls</a>, which is a prioritized set of best practices created to stop the most pervasive and dangerous threats of today. It was developed by leading security experts from around the world and is refined and validated every year.</p> \n<h3>Cybrary</h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://cybrary.com\">Cybrary</a> is an online cybersecurity education resource. It offers mostly free, full-length educational videos, certifications, and more for all kinds of cybersecurity topics and specializations.</p> \n<h2>Signing Off … Securely</h2> \n<p>Cyber attacks may be intimidating, but cybersecurity as a topic doesn’t have to be. It’s imperative to be prepared and armed, especially if you’re handling others’ data. Businesses should dedicate time and resources to protecting their computers, servers, networks, and software and should stay up-to-date with emerging tech. Handling data with care only makes your business more trustworthy and transparent — and your customers more loyal.</p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: Any legal information in this content is not the same as legal advice, where an attorney applies the law to your specific circumstances, so we insist that you consult an attorney if you’d like advice on your interpretation of this information or its accuracy. In a nutshell, you may not rely on this as legal advice or as a recommendation of any particular legal understanding.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in February 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcybersecurity&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 19 Aug 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"adb5ec7389d0186668a970d4bc699807","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"adecker@hubspot.com (Allie Decker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Cybersecurity.png?width=1500&name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Cybersecurity.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn93@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-25-062_5cfbf2998341e38b.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcybersecurity&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn73@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-24-738_1b3be1c1fe423fae.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336425},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"7 Helpful Resources for Creating Beautiful Infographics","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resources-for-creating-infographics","description":"<p>Visuals have a huge impact in marketing. Not only do they make content more sharable -- <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/infographics-for-seo-strategy#sm.0000e1w1nuwvbeo5sq61j1tim2kyj\">40 times as much</a> -- but they help us retain information. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/infographics-for-seo-strategy?&amp;_ga=1.166843966.1053898511.1470656920#sm.0000e1w1nuwvbeo5sq61j1tim2kyj\">When details are paired with an image, we remember 55% more of it</a>.</p> \n<p>That can be pulled off with infographics -- the nifty images that visually break down complex statistics. They're customizable, sharable, and they're easier to create than you might think.</p> \n<p>Sure, you could hire a professional to create the infographics for you. But if you're restricted by budgets or time, there are some great DIY resources out there for making compelling visuals.</p> \n<p>To help visual marketers, we scouted the web for some of best sites and tools for building infographics. Check them out below.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Helpful Resources for Creating Infographics</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.canva.com\">Canva</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free with limited features, $9.95/month for Pro, or $30/month for Enterprise.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Canva-16.png?width=600&amp;name=Canva-16.png\" width=\"600\" title=\"Canva-16.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"creating infographics in Canva\"></p> \n<p>Oh, how we love the ease and intuitiveness of Canva.</p> \n<p>From the very beginning, it asks you a series of simple, colorfully-illustrated questions about what’s brought you to their site. (Today, it’s infographics, but there’s a ton of other stuff you can create there, too.)</p> \n<p>Once you’ve let Canva know what you want to do, the site generates several templates you can use as a foundation for your infographic. Plus, it’s got a library of roughly 1,000,000 images that you can add to your project.</p> \n<p>From there, you can edit the text, background image, shapes and other aspects of the infographic to make it your own. And it’s so easy -- here’s a goofy one that I put together on how my dog spends his day:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png?width=669&amp;name=Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png\" alt=\"Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png\" width=\"669\" title=\"Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/design/DACA4CZE14s/cbwuFIIiTFB1Zdcq_doPPw/view?utm_content=DACA4CZE14s&amp;utm_campaign=designshare&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_source=sharebutton\">Image Source</a></em> </span></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://piktochart.com/\">Piktochart</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free, with paid packages available starting at $24/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Piktochart2.png?width=669&amp;name=Piktochart2.png\" alt=\"Piktochart2.png\" width=\"669\" title=\"Piktochart2.png\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p>Similar to Canva, Piktochart can be used to design more than just infographics -- it can also build reports, presentations, and posters.</p> \n<p>But the templates available for infographics are numerous, and there’s an upgrade available. “Pro” memberships -- which run between $24 to $80, depending on the features you want -- allow access to even more templates, as well as removed watermarks and hi-res downloads.</p> \n<p>When it comes to creating the infographic itself, the features are fairly similar to Canva’s -- the background, text, and images can all be changed, or users can upload their own files for greater personalization.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://venngage.com/\">Venngage</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free, with paid packages available starting at $19/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Vanngage.png?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=Vanngage.png\" alt=\"Venngage infographic software steps\" width=\"600\" title=\"Venngage.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Like its predecessors above, Venngage has quite a few design features, including&nbsp;<span>an </span><a href=\"https://venngage.com\"><span>infographic maker</span></a><span> and&nbsp;</span>its great social media templates, which users can download to create their own personalized Instagram posts, blog headers, and more.</p> \n<p>For infographics, there's a decent range of templates, each categorized by type -- statistical, process, and timeline, to name a few.</p> \n<p>Some of the templates are limited to premium members, reflecting Venngage's four-tiered approach to pricing -- free, premium, education, and non-profit. Plus, there are templates available for those latter two categories. Here's one that helps non-profits visually communicate highlights from an annual report:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/thumbnails.venngage.com/template/bbc41da5-9284-44d3-a915-bec91ff75f26.png?noresize\" alt=\"Venngage Infographic\" width=\"669\" title=\"Venngage Infographic\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.easel.ly\">Easel.ly</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Starts at $4/month with special discounts for students and educators.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/easelly.png?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=easelly.png\" alt=\"easelly infographic templates\" width=\"600\" title=\"easelly.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Upon visiting Easel.ly's website, you're immediately presented with a plethora of infographic templates, most of which can be immediately clicked and customized without having to create an account. If you want to save and share your work, though, you will have to join -- for free.</p> \n<p>Unlike its predecessors listed here, Easel.ly seems to be a no-frills platform that's comprised of infographics. You can choose which category you'd like, but it's not quite as organized as some other sites -- the drop-down menu is a bit hidden to the left of the templates. Still, most of templates appear to be available for free (more become available with a Pro membership), and they're fairly easy to edit.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"http://www.freepik.com\">Freepik</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free, with paid packages available starting at $7.50/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/freepik.png?noresize&amp;width=669&amp;name=freepik.png\" alt=\"freepik.png\" width=\"669\" title=\"freepik.png\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p>As its name suggests, Freepik is a resource for, well, free pictures. Infographics are just one type, but after performing a search for them, there are plenty of options -- most of which are complimentary.</p> \n<p>The only drawback? Freepik doesn't quite allow the same level&nbsp;of customization that some others in this list do. You can download the images for free, but you’ll need a vector graphics editor in order to customize them -- Brittany Leaning and Megan Conley of HubSpot's content marketing team both suggest using <a href=\"http://www.adobe.com/products/illustrator.html\">Adobe Illustrator</a>.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://infogr.am\">Infogram</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost:</strong> A limited number of options available for free, with paid packages available starting at $19/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/infogram%20examples-1.png?width=600&amp;name=infogram%20examples-1.png\" alt=\"infogram examples\" width=\"600\" title=\"infogram examples-1.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Like many of its visual peers, Infogram is a resource that helps users create both picturesque charts and infographics. It's definitely one of the more \"grown-up\" sites available for building these images, which might explain why very few of their tools a re free -- including restricting your work from public consumption.</p> \n<p>However, Infogram also has the option of enlisting professional help with infographic design. So if you're short on time and have a bit of room in your budget, this route might be the best one for you.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/chart/\">Google Charts</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: Free</strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_charts.gif?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=Google_charts.gif\" alt=\"Google_charts gif example\" width=\"600\" title=\"Google_charts.gif\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Okay, maybe a chart isn’t exactly the same as an infographic. But, given the interesting selection templates made available by Google, we would be remiss to exclude it.</p> \n<p>There are a few items of value in Google charts. First, we love the selection of charts available. From animated bubble graphs -- like the one above -- to clever word trees, the features allow users to bring information to life. (I mean, admit it -- adding animation to data always makes it a little less boring.)</p> \n<p>Plus, these charts can be created to be interactive. One of our favorites, GeoCharts, allows data to be assigned to different regions of a map that appear when hovered over. Check it out:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_Geo_Charts.gif?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=Google_Geo_Charts.gif\" alt=\"Google_Geo_Charts.gif\" width=\"600\" title=\"Google_Geo_Charts.gif\" style=\"width: 600px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/gallery/geochart\">Image Source</a></em> </span></p> \n<p>We'll admit that some features of Google Charts might be a bit more advanced than the other resources we’ve listed. But, if you’re ready to step up your visuals game, give it a try.</p> \n<h2>Start Creating Infographics</h2> \n<p>There's no shortage of resources when it comes to creating your own visuals -- charts, reports, and infographics. And, depending on your budget and needs, there's a veritable plethora of options available, all of which have their pros, with very few cons.</p> \n<p>Want to learn more about designing brilliant infographics? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-infographics-with-free-powerpoint-templates\">Check out these helpful tips</a>.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fresources-for-creating-infographics&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
