style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"fba938449a6562b793d104947f750ea1","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Amanda Zantal-Wiener","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Canva-16.png?width=600&name=Canva-16.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn24@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-24-377_cfaa08a627856143.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png?width=669&name=Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn25@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-26-928_8516b0a93c76b0c1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Piktochart2.png?width=669&name=Piktochart2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn78@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-20-991_99f03e97d8ab3710.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Vanngage.png?noresize&width=600&name=Vanngage.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn43@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-22-968_773ab0960b65f583.webp","https://s3.amazonaws.com/thumbnails.venngage.com/template/bbc41da5-9284-44d3-a915-bec91ff75f26.png?noresize":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn36@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-20-133_eb42a7670a367740.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/easelly.png?noresize&width=600&name=easelly.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn27@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-20-663_1b94ce1f79060b1d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/freepik.png?noresize&width=669&name=freepik.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn50@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-25-981_7dfd1560c61ec582.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/infogram%20examples-1.png?width=600&name=infogram%20examples-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn65@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-25-637_809907476669fb88.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_charts.gif?noresize&width=600&name=Google_charts.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn50@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-28-296_01640727dad5e3fa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_Geo_Charts.gif?noresize&width=600&name=Google_Geo_Charts.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn12@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-21-981_1a165a7d66171e7f.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fresources-for-creating-infographics&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn36@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-22-772_4f9c272a6eea9c51.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336433},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"The 30-60-90 Day Plan: Your Guide for Mastering a New Job [Template + Example]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/30-60-90-day-plan","description":"<p>With all the joy and excitement of landing a new job, you can feel just as much fear and anxiety. The same can go for the hiring manager.</p>  \n<p>Overcoming a new role's learning curve and the desire to make a lasting impression on your employer can put a lot of pressure on you. What if you can't adapt in time?</p>  \n<p>Fortunately, there's a way to organize and prioritize your time and tasks, helping you seamlessly adapt to your new environment. It's called a 30-60-90 day plan. And following it enables you to soak in as much information as possible, master your core job responsibilities, and sets you up to make a lasting impact on your new team.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Think of a 30-60-90 day plan as a new employee's North Star, keeping your sights set in the right direction and guiding you toward success. But before we show you how to write this plan, let's go over what exactly it is and how it'll enhance your performance during your (or your employee's) first three months on the job.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll cover everything you need to know about 30-60-90 day plans whether you're writing one for yourself or a new hire on the team.</p> \n<p>There are two situations where you'd write a 30-60-90 day plan: during the final stages of an interview process and during the first week of the job itself. Here's how each type can be executed:</p> \n<h3>30-60-90 Day Plan for Interview</h3> \n<p>Some hiring managers ask candidates to think about and explain their potential 30-60-90 day plan as a new hire. They want to see if they can organize their time, prioritize the tasks they'd likely take on, and strategize an approach to the job description.</p> \n<p>For a new hire, a well thought-out 30-60-90 day plan is a great way to help the hiring manager visualize you in the role and differentiate yourself from all other candidates.</p> \n<p>Of course, it can be difficult to outline your goals for yourself before you accept a new job. So, how are you supposed to know what those goals are? Start with the job description. Normally, open job listings have separate sections for a job's responsibilities and a job's qualifications. Work to find commonalities in these two sections, and how you might turn them into goals for yourself staggered over the course of three months.</p> \n<p>For example, if a job requires three years of experience in Google Analytics, and the responsibilities include tracking the company's website performance every month, use these points to develop an action plan explaining how you'll learn the company's key performance metrics (first 30 days), strengthen the company's performance in these metrics (next 30 days), and then lead the team toward a better Google Analytics strategy (last 30 days).</p> \n<h3>30-60-90 Day Plan for New Job</h3> \n<p>The second situation where you'd write a 30-60-90 day plan is during the first week of a new job. If you're the hiring manager, this plan will allow you to learn how the new employee operates, address any of their concerns or preconceived notions about the role, and ultimately help them succeed.</p> \n<p>If you're starting a new job, and are not asked to craft a 30-60-90 day plan during the first week of that job, it's still a good idea to write one for yourself. A new job can feel like a completely foreign environment during the first few months, and having a plan in place can make it feel more like home.</p> \n<p>Even though 90 days is the standard grace period for new employees to learn the ropes, it's also the best time to make a great first impression.</p> \n<p>The purpose of your plan is to help you transition into your new role, but it should also be a catalyst for your career development. Instead of just guiding you over your job's learning curve, the goals outlined in your plan should push you to perform up to your potential and raise your bar for success at its every stage.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>30-60-90 Day Plan for Managers [Template]</h2> \n<p>Almost all 30-60-90 day plans consist of a learning phase, a contributing phase, and a leading phase — which we'll go over in the example plan below. This includes plans that are designed to guide people in new <em>management</em> roles. What sets apart a <em>manager's</em> plan from any other is their obligation to their direct reports and the decisions they're trusted to make for the business.</p> \n<p>If you're accepting (or hiring for) a new manager role, consider any of the following goals and how to roll them out at a pace that sets you up for success.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable 30 60 90 day plan template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Get to your know your team's strengths and weaknesses.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>Everyone is learning the ropes in their first month at a company. For managers, much of that learning happens by talking to the team.</p> \n<p>If you're a new manager, grab some time with your direct reports and get to know their roles. What do they like about them? What are their biggest pain points?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.projectmanager.com/blog/5-goals-of-effective-managers\">Making your team happy</a> is a hard goal to measure, but it's an important responsibility to take on as a manager. Your first step is to figure out how you'll manage and coach your employees through their day-to-day work.</p> \n<h3>Improve the cost-effectiveness of your team's budget.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>Managers often have access to (and control over) the budget for their department's investments — things like software, office supplies, and new hires. After you spend the first couple of months learning what the team spends its money on, consider using the final 30 days of your plan to make suggestions for new investments or how to reallocate money where you think it needs to be.</p> \n<p>Is there a tool that can automate a task that's taking your team forever to do manually? Draft a financial strategy that includes this tool in the following quarter's budget.</p> \n<h3>Help a direct report acquire a new skill.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Second 30 days</h4> \n<p>Even though you're new to the company, you were hired for a reason: You've got skills. And you can bring these skills to the people you work with, particularly those people who report to you.</p> \n<p>After meeting with and learning about your new colleagues, you might use the second month of your on-boarding plan to find skill gaps on your team that you can help fill.</p> \n<p>Do you have expert-level experience with HubSpot, and your new company just started using <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing?_ga=2.73575319.440552189.1554432490-1093622293.1516842654\">HubSpot Marketing Hub</a>? Teach them how to do something in the platform they didn't know before.</p> \n<h3>Draft a training strategy that can help guide your direct reports into new roles.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>You won't be expected to promote people in the first three months of your new job, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't have learned enough about your team to decide who's good at what and how to coach them to where they want to be.</p> \n<p>In the final 30 days of your 30-60-90 day plan, you might agree to a goal to develop a training strategy that outlines how to manage your direct reports, and ultimately how to guide them into new roles in the future.</p> \n<h2>30-60-90 Day Plan for Executives</h2> \n<p>Executives are a little different from managers in that there's higher performance expectations coming in. As an executive, you'll need to be highly engaged with the organization from the first day and implement high-impact changes in your role as soon as you can. At the same time, context is important, and you'll need to understand the culture, team, current operating processes, and challenges before you solve for them.</p> \n<p>Here are some critical steps to include in your 30-60-90 day plan in an executive role.</p> \n<h3>Soak up as much information as possible.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>There's no point in taking action without context, so start your ramp-up period by gathering information and charting the lay of the land. That means reviewing existing documentation, attending as many meetings as you can, meeting with direct reports and skip levels, and ask a lot of questions.</p> \n<h3>Create alignment between you and the team.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>In the first 30 days, you'll be meeting new people and understanding their roles in the organization. Ultimately, your job as an executive is to set the vision for the organization while removing roadblocks for your team as they strategize and execute on it.</p> \n<p>One of the best questions you can ask as you familiarize yourself and align with your team is, \"In your opinion, what are some existing threats to our business (external or internal)?\"</p> \n<p>This shows that you care about their opinion and trust their expertise while getting unique perspectives from multiple vantage points in the organization. Plus, if you start hearing some of the same points from multiple team members, you'll be able to identify the biggest pains, equipping you to make the highest impact changes.</p> \n<h3>Create goals based on what you've learned.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Second 30 days</h4> \n<p>When you are interviewing or shortly after you're hired, you'll get a feel for the types of pains that the executive team has and the objectives in mind for bringing you on.</p> \n<p>Once you have more context about how the organization works, you can take this vision and translate it into concrete, measurable goals that will take your department to the next level.</p> \n<h3>Identify the A players on the team.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>An A player is a member of your team that goes above and beyond what's expected in their role. While not every employee will be an A player, you'll want to ensure that critical roles and teams have at least one A player to lead, inspire, and strengthen camaraderie.</p> \n<p>From there, you can figure out the existing gaps in staffing and training, whether it's team members who need a lot of guidance and must be coached up to performance or empty roles that need to be filled altogether.</p> \n<h3>Diagnose process issues.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Second 30 days</h4> \n<p>Companies of all sizes run into operational issues as they implement processes that are efficient and work at scale. Sometimes, when an executive team isn't aligned with middle management, processes can become unwieldy.</p> \n<p>Learn why things are done the way they are and then figure out if there are workarounds you can implement to streamline operations. Perhaps it's as simple as eliminating bottlenecks or adding automation to certain functions.</p> \n<h3>Put together and implement hiring plan.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>You know your A and B players, and you hopefully have a plan to retain, invest in, and mentor them. However, you'll likely come across gaps that you need to fill and positions that need to be created to eliminate bottlenecks. From there, you'll want to create a hiring plan to execute, both for short-term, middle-term, and long-term needs.</p> \n<h3>Effect changes in operations.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>Speaking of bottlenecks, your final 30 days of your plan should be focusing on the areas of the business that can achieve the results the fastest. Once you've identified these, you can focus on removing these roadblocks to start hitting goals and achieving higher performance.</p> \n<h3>Contribute to broader company goals.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>As a member of the executive team, you'll also be looped in one high-level company initiatives, and the other executives of the company will be relying on you to contribute your deep discipline expertise and experience.</p> \n<p>Be ready to lean in on executive meetings and contribute to the vision and strategy of the organization as it moves forward.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Write a 30-60-90 Day Plan</h2> \n<p>No matter what the level of the job for which a company is hiring, improving an employee's skills requires concrete performance goals, so watch out for vagueness in the objectives you set for yourself.</p> \n<p>“Write a better blog post,” or “get better at brainstorming” are terrific ambitions, but they don't give you a way to measure your progress in them. Set goals that are realistic, quantifiable, and focused. You'll know exactly how to achieve them and gauge your success.</p> \n<p>To write challenging yet feasible performance goals, ask yourself the following questions:</p> \n<h3>What are my team's goals?</h3> \n<p>Try to understand the purpose behind your team's goals. It'll give you more insight into why you and your team should achieve them, motivating you to work as hard as possible to meet those goals.</p> \n<h3>What will be my main priorities?</h3> \n<p>By connecting your personal responsibilities to your team's goals, you'll know exactly how to align your tasks with the needs of the team, which keeps you accountable and compels you to help your team achieve their goals.</p> \n<h3>How will I measure my progress?</h3> \n<p>Tracking your progress helps you gauge your performance and rate of improvement. To see how you're doing, set up weekly meetings with your manager to ask her what she thinks of your work and track the improvement of your own performance metrics, like the growth of your blog posts' average views or the amount of qualified leads your eBooks generate.</p> \n<p>Reaching your performance goals isn't the only path toward future success in your new role, though. You also need to study the ins and outs of your team and company, take initiative, and develop relationships with coworkers — all things that a lot of new hires underestimate the importance of.</p> \n<p>Consider setting the following types of goals during each stage of your 30-60-90 day plan:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Learning Goals</strong> - How will you absorb as much information as possible about your company, team, and role?</li> \n <li><strong>Initiative Goals</strong> - What will you do to stand out?</li> \n <li><strong>Personal Goals</strong> - How will you integrate with your company and team?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Aiming to achieve these types of goals will help you hit the ground running in all the right areas of your job. And if you stick to your plan, you'll notice you'll be able to spend less time learning and more time executing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>30-60-90 Day Plan Template With Examples</h2> \n<p>Behold, your 30-60-90 day plan template. Click the image below to download your own copy.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable 30 60 90 Day Plan Template, Blog Image\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>So, how might you fill in the lines shown in the template above? Here's an example:</p> \n<h3>30 Days</h3> \n<h4>Primer</h4> \n<p>Many new hires are eager to impress, so they dive head-first into their work or try to make suggestions about their team's process with limited experience in how their new team operates. But have patience.</p> \n<p>Understanding your company's vision and your team's existing strategy is crucial for producing high-quality work and actually making an impact. If you don't know the purpose behind your role or the optimal way to perform, you'll risk missing the mark and your early efforts won't pay off the way you expect them to.</p> \n<p>It's always better to over-prepare than under-prepare. And it's okay to take time to learn the ropes — it pays huge dividends in the long run. In the first 30 days of your employment, your priority is to be a sponge and soak in as much information as possible. Once you do that, you can then try to improve more specific parts of your team's work style.</p> \n<h4>Theme: Be a Sponge</h4> \n<h5>Learning Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Study my company's mission, vision, and overarching strategy.</li> \n <li>Read my company's culture code to learn more about our company culture and why we implement it.</li> \n <li>Read the customer persona and target audience overview to truly understand who our customers are, their pain points, and how our product and content can help them.</li> \n <li>Meet with my team's director to learn about how meeting our goals will help our business grow.</li> \n <li>Read up on our team's new SEO strategy, editorial process, and traffic goals.</li> \n <li>Learn how to use the SEO Insights Report to plan and structure blog posts.</li> \n <li>Review my team's pillar-cluster model overview and understand how to match posts to clusters.</li> \n <li>Meet with my manager to learn more about her expectations.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Performance Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Complete new hire training and pass the test with a 90% or higher.</li> \n <li>Be able to write 3 blog posts per week.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Initiative Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Run the Facebook Instant Article experiment that my manager recommended me to do.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Personal Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Grab coffee with everyone on my team, so I can get to know them on a professional and personal level.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>60 Days</h3> \n<h4>Primer</h4> \n<p>By the end of your first 60 days, you should ramp up your workload, start overachieving, and make a name for yourself on your team.</p> \n<p>To do this, start speaking up more at meetings. Don't be afraid to share your ideas about improving your team's processes. This shows you're quickly conquering the learning curve and recognizing some flaws that your colleagues might've overlooked. You still have a fresh perspective on the company, so your insight is invaluable.</p> \n<h4>Theme: Be a Contributor</h4> \n<h5>Learning Goals:</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Learn how to optimize a new post from scratch based on both the SEO Insights Report and my own competitive research.</li> \n <li>Read every other marketing team's wiki page to learn about other marketing initiatives and how our entire department works together to grow our business.</li> \n <li>Deep dive into my company's product roadmap and strategy to fully grasp our mission and vision.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Performance Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Be able to write 5 blog posts per week.</li> \n <li>Be down to one cycle of edits per post.</li> \n <li>Understand how to edit a guest post -- clean up at least one rough draft.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Initiative Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Share content strategy idea at my team's monthly meeting and ask if I can spearhead the project to boost blog traffic.</li> \n <li>Ask my manager if I can oversee Facebook messenger and Slack distribution strategy.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Personal Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Meet with my colleagues on other teams to learn about their marketing initiatives and develop relationships outside of my team.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>90 Days</h3> \n<h4>Primer</h4> \n<p>By the end of your first three months, you should have a firm grasp of your role, feel confident about your abilities, and be on the cusp of making a breakthrough contribution to your team. Instead of reacting to problems that pop up at random, be proactive and spearhead a new initiative for your team.</p> \n<p>You should also be cognizant of how you can collaborate with other teams to improve your own team's processes. By taking on some new projects outside of your main role, you'll start turning some heads and catch the attention of the department at large.</p> \n<h4>Theme: Be a Leader</h4> \n<h5>Learning Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Do an analysis of my highest and lowest performing blog post up to date. How can I use this information to optimize new content so it performs better out of the gate?</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Performance Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Be comfortable with writing five blog posts per week</li> \n <li>Edit one guest post per week</li> \n <li>Try to have 75% of my blog posts not require revisions.</li> \n <li>Write at least one new post that generates over 10,000 views in one month.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Initiative Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Ask SEO team if they want to partner with product marketing team to brainstorm content topics related to our product road map.</li> \n <li>Ask social media team if they're willing to develop a relationship where we can share each other's content.</li> \n <li>Ask sales team what our customers' pain points are, so we can write content that our target audience craves and help them close more qualified leads.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Personal Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Join the yoga club.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Learning the nuances of your new role in less than three months won't be easy. But crafting a strong 30-60-90 day plan is your best bet for accelerating your development and adapting to your new work environment as quickly as possible.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<div></div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F30-60-90-day-plan&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 14:53:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"8a6f144720f7dbd1b6377623ebd539b7","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn78@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-21-256_aee4f44e77411392.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F30-60-90-day-plan&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn94@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-21-519_937e7560f9c90806.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336436},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Write a Press Release [Free Press Release Template + Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht","description":"<p>When it comes to content, sometimes old school can be a good thing (namely, when it comes to old-school rap or Throwback Thursday on Instagram). But when it comes to your company's <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/newsworthy-guide-to-inbound-public-relations\" style=\"letter-spacing: 0px; background-color: transparent;\">public relations strategy</a>, being old school isn't advantageous for your business or your brand.</p> \n<p>Ten years ago, people still relied on morning papers for news. Today, the vast majority of your company's customers and prospects scan headlines on Twitter or see what’s trending in their Facebook feed.</p> \n<p>People now have control over where, when, and how they consume information. As a result, public relations is no longer about feeding into a traditional news cycle; it's about providing relevant content when, where, and how your prospects, influencers, and customers will consume it.</p> \n<p>Sounds pretty hopeless, right? Wrong. While relationship-building still helps you get into popular publications, we now have the <strong>opportunity to quit playing the waiting game and generate our own buzz</strong>. By <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/newsworthy-guide-to-inbound-public-relations\">turning your PR strategy into an inbound one</a>, you create opportunities that weren’t there before and carve out a place for your company, building meaningful mindshare with your target audiences in the process.</p> \n<p>One of the most crucial updates to make to your PR strategy is to think of opportunities to connect to the audiences you care about -- including, but not limited to, reporters. And that starts with press releases. In this post, we'll discuss:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht#what-is\">What Is a Press Release?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht#types\">Types of Press Releases</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht#sample\">Sample Press Release Format</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht#how-to-write\">How to Write a Press Release</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht#examples\">Press Release Examples</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht#tips\">Tips for Publishing Press Releases</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What Is a Press Release / News Release?</h2> \n<p>A regular cadence of meaningful news can help a company stand out and build mindshare with journalists over time. That's where the press release (or news announcement) comes in.</p> \n<p>A press release is an official announcement (written or recorded) that an organization issues to the news media and beyond. Whether we call it a \"press release,\" a \"press statement,\" a \"news release,\" or a \"media release,\" we're always talking about the same basic thing.</p> \n<p>While the heading should contain action verbs, the first paragraph should answer the \"who,\" \"what,\" \"why,\" and \"where.\" The press release should also contain understandable language and a quote.</p> \n<p>Most press releases are succinct at just a page long -- two pages, tops. Ultimately, companies want to provide enough information so that news outlets have sufficient material for publishing their own stories about whatever the company is announcing in the release.</p> \n<p>And while it may be tempting to craft a press release that embellishes your company's accomplishments or twists the facts to make a story sound more intriguing to the media, remember: Press releases live in the public domain, which means your customers and prospective customers can see them. So instead of thinking of a press release solely as a ticket to earning news coverage, you should also think of it as a valuable piece of marketing content.</p> \n<p>While there's no cut-and-dried formula for what a press release should include, here are a few types of occasions to help you carve out a focus for your press release and determine what content would help you broadcast your news in the best way:</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<h3>New Product Launches</h3> \n<p>The product launch type of press release is valuable to get the word out about the new solutions your organization is offering to consumers. This release will emphasize the product's specs, pricing, availability, and any other details that may be valuable to consumers.</p> \n<h3>Mergers and Acquisitions</h3> \n<p>Organizational change is noteworthy enough to warrant a press release, especially for informing current and future stakeholders about the growth and trajectory of a company. To announce an acquisition or merger, include details about all organizations involved, information about the merger or acquisition, and quotes from the leadership teams.</p> \n<h3>Product Updates</h3> \n<p>Similar to a new product launch, product updates and expansions are also ripe for promotion. Explain what the change is, why it was made, and how it benefits the user.</p> \n<h3>Events</h3> \n<p>Press releases are an important component of event marketing to attract promotion from news outlets and other media sources. You'll want to include what the event is about, who should consider attending, when and where it will be held, pricing, and any other necessary details.</p> \n<h3>Grand Openings</h3> \n<p>Whether you opened up a new office, relocated, or are opening for the first time, announce the details with a grand opening press release. Announce the date and location the grand opening will be held, who is involved, how the grand opening is being celebrated, and the reason for the move (if applicable).</p> \n<h3>New Partnerships</h3> \n<p>Similar to mergers and acquisitions, a press release announcing new partnerships is a mutually beneficial marketing tactic. To effectively execute this type of release, be sure to write a summary about each company, why the partnership was created, who benefits, and any additional important details for current and future stakeholders.</p> \n<h3>Rebranding</h3> \n<p>Rebranding is a difficult thing for any business to do, and it can occasionally result in confusion and awkwardness. One way to make the transition smoother is by announcing the rebrand with a press release, including details on what is changing, the reason for making the change, dates the changes go into effect, and quotes from the leadership team.</p> \n<h3>Executive Promotions/Hiring</h3> \n<p>Executives often serve as faces of the company, and a press release functions to kick off this role. It may include biographical information to establish their credibility along with a photo and other pertinent details.</p> \n<h3>Awards</h3> \n<p>When it comes to business excellence, it's okay to brag. Press releases about awards and accomplishments serve to cement your organization as an authority in your space. Such a press release includes information about the company and why they were given the award, information about the award itself, and details about the ceremony (if applicable).</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Sample Press Release Format</h2> \n<p>When formatting a press-release, you want to write it in a newsy, straightforward way so a journalist who might write about it can imagine it as an article on their news site.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>As noted above, you'll want your format to include traditional press-release items like your contact information, the words \"For immediate release,\" a note about your location, and a quick bio about your company. Having specific spots for those elements will prevent you from needing to mention it in your body copy so you can focus on discussing the news at hand.</p> \n<p>You also might want to include \"###\" or another signifier to show the journalist that the release has ended. In the past, this prevented busy journalists from waiting or flipping the page for more information when there was no more news. However, this tradition is <a href=\"https://www.thehalogroup.com/what-does-mean-at-the-end-of-a-press-release/\">still adopted and highly-respected today</a>.</p> \n<p>When it comes to formatting the body copy and headline, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/press-release-template-ht#Rule1\">click here</a> or scroll down for writing tips.</p> \n<p>In this example, Catbrella Inc., a fictitious ad agency which just gained its 10th Twitter follower after two years of paid social media efforts, announces its achievement in a press release.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/press-release-example-hubspot.png\" alt=\"Sample press release format by HubSpot, with orange markers showing five rules to follow\" title=\"press-release-example-hubspot.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" /></p> \n<p><em>*Disclaimer: HubSpot is entirely responsible for the silliness of this faux announcement.</em></p> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <a></a> \n  <h2>How to Write a Press Release</h2> \n </div> \n <img alt=\"How to write a press release\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/press-release-example-hubspot.png?width=347&amp;name=press-release-example-hubspot.png\" width=\"347\" style=\"width: 347px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n  <div>\n    Writing a press release to break important company news can help businesses grow better, but doing it right is just as important. Here's how to write a press release, like the one above, step-by-step. \n  </div> <a></a> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <h3>Rule 1: Make your headline irresistible.</h3> \n   </div> \n   <div> \n    <div> \n     <p>You've got your announcement in mind, and now it's time to get it down in words to share with your community, industry, and followers. Just like <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/a-simple-formula-for-writing-kick-ass-titles-ht\">writing the perfect blog post title</a>, setting up your press release for success starts with your headline. You only have one line to work with, which can seem scary, but consider diction carefully to make your headline captivating.</p> \n     <p>Use action verbs, clear, understandable language, and keep your headline simple and short -- fortune (and search engines) reward the brief, so keep your title to one line to clearly focus people's attention on your topline message.</p> \n     <p>Most importantly, make it interesting: Keep in mind that reporters get dozens, if not hundreds, of releases each day, so invest the time to write a compelling headline. It's worth the time and effort on your part.</p> \n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <h3>Rule 2: Convey the news value to the press.</h3> \n   </div> \n   <div> \n    <div> \n     <p>For reporters, analysts, influencers, or followers to be inclined to share your announcement, you have to tell them upfront why they should care.</p> \n     <p>The first paragraph of your release should cover the who, what, why, where, and how of your new launch, update, or development. Reporters don't have a ton of time to sift through details and fluffy background information -- they just need the facts that'll help them tell your story to someone else from a position of authority.</p> \n     <p>There shouldn't be any new, crucial information covered after this section that the reader could potentially miss. <i>A good way to ensure this is by using the </i><a href=\"https://blog.justreachout.io/how-to-write-press-release/\"><i>reverse pyramid formula</i></a><i> when writing your press release.&nbsp;</i></p> \n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <h3>Rule 3: Offer a tempting quote.</h3> \n   </div> \n   <div> \n    <div> \n     <p>Once you've set the scene, it's time to bring your details to life with a quote that reporters can use for context around your announcement and help paint a picture of how your news affects the given industry, customer base, and landscape.</p> \n     <p>Ideally, quotes will be from key stakeholders in your company including your executive team, project leads, or those directly impacted by your announcement. Quoting key figures and authorities underlines the importance of your development. The chosen quote should shape your narrative and emphasize the core of the announcement. Don't ask everyone in your office for a comment or feel compelled to quote all 25 people included in the acquisition -- pick one or two critical spokespeople and focus the quotes around their unique perspective.</p> \n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <h3>Rule 4: Provide valuable background information on the subject.</h3> \n   </div> \n   <div> \n    <div> \n     <p>In this last paragraph, keep in mind that the reader already has all of the vital details and information they need to file a story or spread the word.</p> \n     <p>It can be tempting to provide superfluous facts and tidbits about your company or the development of your announcement -- we sometimes think a piece of writing is lacking if it isn't drawn-out and just shy of being a novella. However, a press release <strong>needs to be helpful and concise</strong>.</p> \n     <p>Offer details here that strengthen your narrative, like creative or noteworthy ways your company developed the project or announcement at hand. Or, when applicable, comment on future implications of your announcement.</p> \n     <p><i>Another good way to add value to your press release is by using </i><a href=\"https://blog.justreachout.io/how-to-write-press-release/\"><i>newsjacking</i></a><i>. A process of relating your press release to something currently going on to make it more valuable to the journalist and reader.</i></p> \n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <h3>Rule 5: Summarize the \"who\" and the \"what\" in a boilerplate.</h3> \n   </div> \n   <div> \n    <div> \n     <p>Twitter is chock-full of reporters lamenting press releases or pitches that don't clearly explain what the company does or what the announcement is actually about, so instead of being the butt of a joke, make your release incredibly easy to reference.</p> \n     <p>Describe what your company does in clear, plain English, include a link to your company's homepage early on, and make your boilerplate succinct and straightforward. If you cite data, include a reference link for the data source, and make sure every name in the release has an associated title and company as well.</p> \n     <p>To keep yourself honest on this front, ask a friend or colleague to read the release without context and ask if they can easily and readily explain why the announcement matters, what your company does, and why the executives included are quoted. If the answer to any of those questions is no, get back to the drawing board.</p> \n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The key to keeping your PR strategy new school is forgetting preconceived notions of what public relations is and instead focusing on creating highly remarkable content. Traditional press releases can still be really valuable when executed well, so instead of ditching releases as a tactic, give them a modern makeover to make them more useful for your marketing.</p> \n<p>Think about how you've used <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/insiders/pr-and-inbound-marketing\">inbound methods to transform your marketing strategies</a> to be more personalized, approachable, and build relationships. Those same principles apply to your PR strategy: Create content to craft your own story and use tactful outreach to get reporters and analysts familiar with your brand.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Press Release Examples</h2> \n<p>Many people think press releases have to be chock full of buzzwords and branded terms. \"Big data,\" anyone? Five-syllable words you have to look up on Thesaurus.com? Quotes from every executive on the planet that go on for pages? We've seen it all. Unfortunately, so have reporters -- and they are <em>not</em> fans.</p> \n<p>Instead of stuffing your next release with industry jargon, take a page out of our book (okay fine, ebook), <em><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/newsworthy-guide-to-inbound-public-relations\">The Newsworthy Guide to Inbound Public Relations</a></em>, and brainstorm some creative approaches for your next announcement. Can you include new data? A remarkable graphic or video? A shareable SlideShare? If so, a creative angle can help carry your content and increase the likelihood of social sharing.</p> \n<p>Now, to get you thinking on the right track, take a look at some creative press release examples below, the type of news each one is reporting on, and what makes the release unique:</p> \n<h3><a href=\"https://www.skoda-press.be/wrc-spain-skoda-teams-with-trouble-free-run-kopecky-second-and-nordgren-fourth-in-wrc-2\">ŠKODA at the World Rally Championship</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of press release: Event</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/skoda-press-release-example.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Event press release by Skoda, showing a picture of the company's green racing car\" /></p> \n<p>Škoda, a car manufacturer based in the Czech Republic, recently showed off its sponsored racing team in two big places: at the 2017 World Rally Championship, and in a sleek, image-based press release reporting on the event.</p> \n<p>The news release, shown above, doesn't have any trouble aligning the look and feel of the Škoda brand with the press release itself -- which is a crucial aspect of any company's press content. The release opens with a large feature image of one of its vehicles in the same vibrant green that covers the business's website. The press release also begins with three helpful bullet points summarizing the news for readers, and ends the release with a couple of captioned actions shots to give reporters more context around the event.</p> \n<h3><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4RZj-hF2f0s\">ScribbleLive Acquires New Company</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of press release: Acquisition</h4> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; display: block; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 640px; max-height: 380px; min-width: 256px;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 59.38%; margin: 0;\"> \n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/4RZj-hF2f0s?ecver=1\" width=\"640\" height=\"380\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Yes, a video press release! This news item from ScribbleLive gave reporters nearly everything they'd need to republish this story, all in a thorough two-minute video about the company's latest acquisition.</p> \n<p>ScribbleLive opens the video press release above with the company's logo and a clear header stating the news. This allowed the company's CEO to jump right into his commentary on the acquisition, giving reporters plenty of quotable material on the state of the industry and why this merger was so important to them.</p> \n<p>The press release also segments the video the same way a written press release would, breaking up the CEO's commentary by the question he's answering. This makes it easy for viewers to jump through the video and find the information they're most interested in hearing about.</p> \n<p>And, being on YouTube, a press release in this format allows reporters to embed the news content directly on their site, making ScribbleLive's news that much easier to share.</p> \n<h3><a href=\"https://about.peapod.com/peapod-officially-opens-new-headquarters-in-chicago\">Peapod's New Headquarters</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of press release: Opening a new office</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/peapod-press-release-example.png\" alt=\"Press release by Peapod reporting on the company's new headquarters in Chicago\" /></p> \n<p>When you open a new headquarters, it can be hard to figure out what to say. People just want to get a look at the new digs! In the above press release by Peapod, an online grocery service, the company puts photos of its new office right at the top, immediately showing readers what makes this news so significant for Peapod.</p> \n<p>The release even singles out a quote by the Mayor of Chicago just below the headline, hinting to reporters who are writing about Peapod's new HQ that this is the remark Peapod is most interested in sharing with readers.</p> \n<p>Check out the boilerplate text at the bottom of the above press release. \"About [company]\" text can too easily blend in with the actual news text, making the piece seem longer than it really is. By isolating this copy in a dark gray box, Peapod provides a smoother reading experience and ensures the story itself doesn't get lost in an intimidatingly long wall of text.</p> \n<h3><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/company-news/inbound-2018-product-announcements\">HubSpot's New Product Announcements</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of press release: New product launches</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/INBOUND%20Announcements-1.png\" alt=\"Product launch press release by HubSpot showing pricing information on each new product\" /></p> \n<p>When you're launching products or services, the information is often best expressed in written form. But when all you're doing is writing about your new offering's price and features, it can be difficult for others to refer to and report on it later. We at HubSpot know the challenge well.</p> \n<p>The graphic above helped us to supplement our own product announcement -- written by our fantastic Communications Manager, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/eleanorbotelho/\">Ellie Botelho</a> -- with details that needed a visual aid. Using a combination of colors and shapes, this graphic allowed us to reveal important relationships between products, as well as their respective prices and when they'll be available. (Interested one of our products? Take note! ^)</p> \n<p>We've also crafted this comprehensive, easy-to-follow <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/newsworthy-guide-to-inbound-public-relations\">press release template</a> complete with a promotional plan and considerations for your next announcement. We use these same guidelines when writing and formatting our releases here at HubSpot, and created a faux, sample release to illustrate what content goes where and why.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Tips for Publishing Press Releases</h2> \n<p><em>Writing</em> a press release is really only half the battle. Once you're finished with production, it'll be time to focus on distribution.</p> \n<p>Of course, we're all familiar with the traditional distribution levers we can pull, which include publishing the press release on our website/blog, as well as sharing the press release with our followers/subscribers via social media and email. But for ensuring a press release gets the maximum amount of distribution possible, here are some tips you can follow.</p> \n<h3>1. Reach out to specific journalists.</h3> \n<p>Instead of blasting a press release out to every journalist you can find an email address for, focus on a few journalists who have experience covering your industry (and company, hopefully) and send them personalized messages. Connect the dots. Show why what <em>you</em> wrote connects to what <em>they</em> write.</p> \n<h3>2. Don't be afraid to go offline.</h3> \n<p>Most journalists have mountains of emails (and press releases) to sort through. Try sending your release through snail mail or another offline channel to differentiate yourself.</p> \n<h3>3. Send the release to top journalists the day before.</h3> \n<p>Give journalists some time to craft a story around your press release by sending it to them -- under embargo -- the day before it officially goes live. (FYI \"under embargo\" just means they aren't allowed to share the information in the press release until the time you specify.)</p> \n<h3>4. To avoid competition, don't publish your release on the hour.</h3> \n<p>If you're publishing your press release on a distribution service like PR Newswire or Business Wire, avoid publishing it on the hour (e.g., 1 p.m., or 3 p.m., or 5 p.m.). The reason? Most companies schedule their releases to go out on the hour, which means if your release goes out on the hour too, it's more likely to get lost in the shuffle. Instead, try going with a more distinct time (e.g., 1:12 p.m., or 3:18 p.m., or 5:22 p.m.).</p> \n<h3>5. Share your media coverage.</h3> \n<p>If all goes according to plan, and your press release gets picked up by the media, your job still isn't finished. To keep the buzz going, you can release a \"second wave\" of distribution by sharing the specific stories that news outlets write based on your press release.</p> \n<div> \n <a class=\"close\"> </a> \n</div> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in November 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness. </em></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpress-release-template-ht&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 20 Aug 2020 00:35:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/press-release-example-hubspot.png","linkMd5":"e521ad147ee0dd8dec92fa53f3b1e06c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn87@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-16-654_4ca3cbd1c3e567a5.webp","destWidth":651,"destHeight":645,"sourceBytes":264604,"destBytes":264604,"author":"hfleishman@hubspot.com (Hannah Fleishman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/press-release-example-hubspot.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn87@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-16-654_4ca3cbd1c3e567a5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/press-release-example-hubspot.png?width=347&name=press-release-example-hubspot.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-23-461_f1c35088261ceb29.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/skoda-press-release-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn47@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-24-732_560c553f99f0dba6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/peapod-press-release-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn40@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-21-223_c57697bd9abf592d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/INBOUND%20Announcements-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-19-910_f75ff2f052c5581e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpress-release-template-ht&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn22@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-29-551_269056dc720495f5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336424},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How Facebook Ads Have Evolved [+What This Means for Marketers]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/history-facebook-adtips-slideshare","description":"<p>According to a <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\"><span>recent study from Statista</span></a>, Facebook has an estimated <em>2.7 billion</em> monthly active users worldwide, including roughly <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/408971/number-of-us-facebook-users/\"><span>two-thirds</span></a> of the US population. There's no social media platform more prominent or ubiquitous. No other online destination offers you more potential exposure to prospects.</p> \n<p>A well-maintained Facebook presence is central to many — if not most — companies' social media strategies. It's a key factor in processes like conducting outreach, projecting legitimacy, generating interest, and driving traffic to other content and company resources.</p> \n<p>One avenue businesses can leverage to make effective use of Facebook as a marketing tool is paid advertisements — a format that has moved through several iterations over the years.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll get a timeline of some of the most important, interesting milestones in Facebook ads' evolution, a picture of what the future might hold for the medium, and what this all means for marketers.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>The History of Facebook Ads</h2> \n<h3><strong>2004:</strong> Facebook first starts generating ad revenue with its \"Flyers\" project.</h3> \n<p>Roughly two months after Mark Zuckerberg and Eduardo Saverin launched Facebook in February 2004, the two took some minor steps to monetize the platform — just enough for a small financial cushion to help while the company got off the ground.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As Zuckerberg said in an <a href=\"https://www.thecrimson.com/article/2004/3/1/facebook-expands-beyond-harvard-harvard-students/?print=1#\"><span>interview with the Harvard Crimson</span></a> shortly after the platform went live, \"It might be nice to get some ads going to offset the cost of the servers.\"</p> \n<p>That April, Facebook started selling bits and pieces of ad space to companies promoting moving services, T-Shirts, job listings, and other offerings for students.</p> \n<p>The ads themselves weren't particularly sophisticated, and the founders didn't have much of a firm grasp on digital advertising. Still, the project represented a milestone in the history of Facebook advertising.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/KaQQyE-Ys9j2WvSYZaG3QEwNNg2ApGI5j1Sp11EJoMVwxZvaKlVuKx9Jlp1M5ch8wl7r_rAl4mnFvbd9y_E9zV4oBHgyvtRGQQ_AB3GeSke7IbF_3JLsSQEkQxzTU6tRztEOSXXf\" width=\"135\" height=\"377\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"The history of Facebook Ads flyers\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.business2community.com/facebook/facebook-advertising-work-01436933\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: Business 2 Community</a></p> \n<p>It was the first time the platform tried to make money from the platform through ad sales. Unrefined and seemingly uncoordinated as it might have been, the Flyers project still helped keep the platform afloat during its early days and warrants a mention on this timeline.</p> \n<h3><strong>2007:</strong> Facebook officially launches its Facebook Ads platform.</h3> \n<p>Some three years after Facebook's initial launch, the company introduced a large-scale, official ads program to the platform. It gave <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/24422/the-ultimate-facebook-marketing-cheat-sheet.aspx?_ga=2.101869377.1529852439.1597866496-1371271315.1597866496\"><span>businesses the space to create individual profiles</span></a> — just like standard users — to post content, share photos, and engage with Facebook users.</p> \n<p>As <a href=\"https://about.fb.com/news/2007/11/facebook-unveils-facebook-ads/\"><span>Zuckerberg put it,</span></a> \"The core of every user’s experience on Facebook is their page, and that’s where businesses are going to start as well...The first thing<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-facebook-business-page-ht?_ga=2.96149980.1529852439.1597866496-1371271315.1597866496\"><span> businesses can do is design a page</span></a> to craft the exact experience they want people to see.\"</p> \n<p>The new program also introduced \"Social Ads\" — ads that combined social actions from a user's friends, like a recent purchase or review of a business, with an advertiser’s message.</p> \n<p>This allowed advertisers to deliver more specific, targeted ads to users that included information from their friends. These ads appeared either within a user's news feed or in the site's designated ad space.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/7pR1YN_yXBYEn-DC3XucEY343fvoVrL8dgms9LIppaqb14yyZtWEeSAxB88N6G3wkh-YRRA6MdT8RUfWZ4R_wMbLWVnwsbuYt-tkdg2w7Aydm_EQRFTrLvL0Zl65lKtU8aZKb3m7\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"The history of Facebook Ads 2007\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2011/10/13/tech/gallery/facebook-changes-since-launch/index.html\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: CNN</a></p> \n<p>At Facebook Ads' official launch — 2007's Facebook Social Advertising Event — Zuckerberg summed up his vision for the program, \"Facebook Ads represent a completely new way of advertising online. For the last hundred years, media has been pushed out to people, but now marketers are going to be a part of the conversation.\"</p> \n<h3><strong>2011:</strong> Facebook launches its desktop ad program called \"Sponsored Stories.\"</h3> \n<p>In 2011, Facebook introduced its \"Sponsored Stories\" project — a program that placed paid advertisements directly on users' news feeds. Initially, the company pledged to only show users just one sponsored story on their news feeds per day. Those stories also stemmed solely from friends or pages users already liked.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/OUr30oEzqMjcAN7_5bwQg8l9FXwo7Mvuy0NfllwpGVwLCycs9iB_JfhC1YzM_J-nPs7F-LsCXRXyMn2Lztrb9AiOtZVuDjwXktmR5l6JTlKiGj2A4sBRQQd2xEPtSIJnoAFoz-y-\" width=\"568\" height=\"321\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"The history of Facebook Ads sponsored stories\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2011/12/20/sponsored-stories-news-feed/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: Mashable</a></p> \n<p>As a <a href=\"https://money.cnn.com/2011/01/26/technology/facebook_sponsored_stories/index.htm\"><span>product manager from Facebook described it</span></a>, \"Anything that one of your friends is seeing as a sponsored story which features some of your content is actually something they would have already seen in their news feed. A sponsored story never goes to somebody who is not one of your friends.\"</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/iP2v0SRTqV--RoX9P-m43LQCOtOrtZFqcsSMRsRAnWjKl8u8B_ri8FF24l55gATYcYyIBqx3XgoQunz-A941qhtIGfpujBITYF2qdGpU5cnWvq_P1b8IlkmNaSym44KbfK8w726t\" width=\"624\" height=\"637\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"The history of Facebook Ads sponsored stories 2\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2011/12/20/sponsored-stories-news-feed/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: TechCrunch</a></p> \n<p>Though it was impossible for users to opt-out of the program entirely, they still had the option to close out individual ads. \"Sponsored Stories\" certainly rubbed some users the wrong way, but advertisers saw it as a big win. Finally, they had the space to display their ads directly in the mix of social content and consumers' news feeds — a wildly valuable stretch of virtual real estate.</p> \n<h3>2012: Facebook launches its mobile ads program.</h3> \n<p>Up until 2012, Facebook's mobile app didn't actually make money. It didn't feature ads, and the move to incorporate them was considered a risky play. Consumers weren't exactly thrilled with the idea of having ads take up space on their mobile feeds.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/o5zobWqOJyb8XZz-VrRwd-7hnRZQB7nMiFwArQTDar0QGKo5MOPIfKQeV04N4tsUh4jBgTT57-75wzYTcA3NVv8jok5tt7N4XSEDTIqz5uka_YkI1jSCIbMel8SBl8L3S6MRh4-Q\" width=\"399\" height=\"471\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"The history of Facebook Ads mobile\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://venturebeat.com/2012/02/29/facebooks-mobile-ads/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: VentureBeat</a></p> \n<p>Facebook opted to subtly ease advertisements into users' feeds. Its mobile ads plan borrowed heavily from the desktop platform's \"Sponsored Story\" strategy — seamlessly blending in paid promotional content and having it look like standard statuses or other user-generated content.</p> \n<p>The company's mobile advertising strategy aimed to make ads as discreet as possible. It provided limited real estate to advertisers, pressing businesses to create engaging, interesting content to capture consumer attention within tight confines. The strategy ultimately proved successful and further drove advertisers' collective need to optimize for mobile.</p> \n<h3>2014: Facebook rolls out its three-level advertising campaign structure, offering \"campaigns\" and \"ad sets\" — on top of standard ads.</h3> \n<p>In March 2014, Facebook introduced its new ad structure. Until that point, the platform's campaign structure consisted of two levels: campaigns and ads.</p> \n<p>Campaigns — the overarching plans that correspond to specific advertising objectives — were designed to help users optimize, and measure results of individual ads. With this new development in Facebook advertising's evolution, a buffer was put between those two levels.</p> \n<p>Ad sets — subsets of a campaign that could feature their own budgets and target separate audience segments — were introduced. Those sets gave advertisers a new level of structure for honing in on, best appealing to, and better understanding demographics of particular interest.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/0Bj6_lqmhyJRGBGpBfbZNmi_l7UcL0JF01hXY0UmYeYP-GgVamSkbdx69EioVRB2P8rtb3yqIfzGeGHpYji5cNkhhqBHz7Al9Fha-FwSnKtME-teccDUqpfx8jq_4EbjBdkeNqKJ\" width=\"619\" height=\"648\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"The history of Facebook Ads ad set\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/news/new-campaign-structure\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: Facebook</a></p> \n<p>According to a <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/news/new-campaign-structure\"><span>Facebook press release</span></a>, the program was designed to \"make it easier for advertisers of every size to organize, optimize and measure their ads.\" It was a game-changing milestone for the platform — one that made its advertising infrastructure more thoughtfully regimented and easier to navigate.</p> \n<h3>2016: Facebook introduces bots to its Messenger platform.</h3> \n<p>In 2016, Facebook made a push to capitalize on the tremendous advertising potential of its siloed mobile messaging function. One of the ways the company looked to take advantage of the system was through the incorporation of chatbots. Facebook offered businesses two paths for bot incorporation — \"Sponsored Messages\" and \"Click-to-Messenger\" ads.</p> \n<p>\"Sponsored Messages\" are ads that appear directly in a user's Messenger inbox — ones that allow users to automatically communicate with a chatbot by clicking them.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/h_TTzhP3LPmx8rr7E6rCNYZODiIv6lOoMJQ6-dlYbQ_E2nDa0EdlKKnxHDBc2slDb5oQ_SrUy4dYUdxe7kOBlW_kfksWQyl5FpXMr0szKOtX7GcTLxMtgb8NMHr0ZpMX2qT4qAzA\" width=\"624\" height=\"547\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"The history of Facebook Ads chatbot\"></span><span style=\"border: none;\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://botscrew.com/blog/facebook-ads-chatbots/\"><em>Image Source: BotsCrew</em></a></span></p> \n<p>\"Click-to-Messenger\" ads leverage CTAs to place ads in users' Messenger inboxes. A business will draw users in with some sort of incentive — like a discount or piece of content — on the original Facebook platform and automatically send them a message via chatbot once they click on the offer.</p> \n<h3>2018-2020: Facebook expands its ad formats, featuring eight separate advertising options.</h3> \n<p>Over its history, Facebook has consistently expanded its available advertising formats, aiming to effectively monetize the platform without compromising user experience. As of 2020, the company offers eight different <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/ad-formats?ref=ads_guide\"><span>advertising options</span></a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/photo-ad-format\"><span>Photo</span></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/video\"><span>Video</span></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/stories-ad-format\"><span>Stories</span></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/messenger-ads\"><span>Messenger</span></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/Carousel-ad-format\"><span>Carousel</span></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/slideshow-ad-format\"><span>Slideshow</span></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/collection\"><span>Collection</span></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads/playable-ad-format\"><span>Playable Content</span></a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>As time goes on, you should expect to see this list expand and the nature of mediums it covers shift and progress. New technology and trends will bring new formats to explore and familiar processes to refine.</p> \n<h2>The Future of Facebook Advertising</h2> \n<p>If there's anything to learn from Facebook advertising's evolution, it's that the processes and practices behind the concept will never remain stagnant. Mark Zuckerberg will never look at the platform's advertising infrastructure and say, <em>\"Yeah, I think we nailed it. We'll never need to change any of this ever again.\"</em></p> \n<p>Advertising on Facebook will continue to evolve and adapt as new ad formats emerge, privacy and data regulations loosen or constrict, its user base changes, and social media trends come and go. There are too many factors at play to expect anything but constant, likely significant changes in the practice as time goes on.</p> \n<p>So, what can marketers take away from this article? Is there any recurring theme underlying success across every phase of Facebook advertising's evolution?</p> \n<p>As Facebook advertising has progressed, the companies that thrived in every stage were the ones that shared high-quality, engaging content that wasn't too abrasive.</p> \n<p>Consumers aren't using the platform because they want to see ads. That's why the content you share on the platform has to come across as natural, interesting, and not too jarring.</p> \n<p>If you prioritize producing and sharing valuable, interesting advertisements that won't overwhelm or frustrate your target audience, you'll put yourself in the best position possible to thrive as Facebook advertising continues to progress.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhistory-facebook-adtips-slideshare&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/KaQQyE-Ys9j2WvSYZaG3QEwNNg2ApGI5j1Sp11EJoMVwxZvaKlVuKx9Jlp1M5ch8wl7r_rAl4mnFvbd9y_E9zV4oBHgyvtRGQQ_AB3GeSke7IbF_3JLsSQEkQxzTU6tRztEOSXXf","linkMd5":"7a9a301cab5ea9795385268b1530fcbf","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-16-830_0721b824a88fb997.webp","destWidth":135,"destHeight":377,"sourceBytes":33865,"destBytes":13422,"author":"jfuchs@hubspot.com (Jay Fuchs)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/KaQQyE-Ys9j2WvSYZaG3QEwNNg2ApGI5j1Sp11EJoMVwxZvaKlVuKx9Jlp1M5ch8wl7r_rAl4mnFvbd9y_E9zV4oBHgyvtRGQQ_AB3GeSke7IbF_3JLsSQEkQxzTU6tRztEOSXXf":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-16-830_0721b824a88fb997.webp","https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/7pR1YN_yXBYEn-DC3XucEY343fvoVrL8dgms9LIppaqb14yyZtWEeSAxB88N6G3wkh-YRRA6MdT8RUfWZ4R_wMbLWVnwsbuYt-tkdg2w7Aydm_EQRFTrLvL0Zl65lKtU8aZKb3m7":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn47@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-22-900_2a452e31693c7341.webp","https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/OUr30oEzqMjcAN7_5bwQg8l9FXwo7Mvuy0NfllwpGVwLCycs9iB_JfhC1YzM_J-nPs7F-LsCXRXyMn2Lztrb9AiOtZVuDjwXktmR5l6JTlKiGj2A4sBRQQd2xEPtSIJnoAFoz-y-":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn61@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-23-798_5abaa021b61c517e.webp","https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/iP2v0SRTqV--RoX9P-m43LQCOtOrtZFqcsSMRsRAnWjKl8u8B_ri8FF24l55gATYcYyIBqx3XgoQunz-A941qhtIGfpujBITYF2qdGpU5cnWvq_P1b8IlkmNaSym44KbfK8w726t":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn98@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-29-608_64208534b8abd43d.webp","https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/o5zobWqOJyb8XZz-VrRwd-7hnRZQB7nMiFwArQTDar0QGKo5MOPIfKQeV04N4tsUh4jBgTT57-75wzYTcA3NVv8jok5tt7N4XSEDTIqz5uka_YkI1jSCIbMel8SBl8L3S6MRh4-Q":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn20@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-23-362_29d2972e1d2141e1.webp","https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/0Bj6_lqmhyJRGBGpBfbZNmi_l7UcL0JF01hXY0UmYeYP-GgVamSkbdx69EioVRB2P8rtb3yqIfzGeGHpYji5cNkhhqBHz7Al9Fha-FwSnKtME-teccDUqpfx8jq_4EbjBdkeNqKJ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn53@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-25-670_9e00bf44a4036799.webp","https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/h_TTzhP3LPmx8rr7E6rCNYZODiIv6lOoMJQ6-dlYbQ_E2nDa0EdlKKnxHDBc2slDb5oQ_SrUy4dYUdxe7kOBlW_kfksWQyl5FpXMr0szKOtX7GcTLxMtgb8NMHr0ZpMX2qT4qAzA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-27-717_ab0a16b42880a5fc.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhistory-facebook-adtips-slideshare&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn11@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-19-925_46bba680d512efd3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336422},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Make Digital Credentials Your Most Impactful Marketing Tool","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/digital-credentials","description":"<p>Marketing can have an enormous, positive impact on both revenue and brand recognition. Which is why organizations spend so much time, energy, and resources trying to reach their target audience.</p> \n<p>And yet, from billboard ads and radio slots to the roughly <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/456500/daily-number-of-e-mails-worldwide/\">300 billion</a> emails sent each day, it's hard to boost your brand amidst all the noise.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there are innovative ways to cut through the crowded market and build brand awareness: and one of those opportunities is through <a href=\"https://resources.credly.com/what-is-a-dc-infographic\">digital credentials</a>.</p> \n<p>Digital credentials have emerged as an impactful marketing tool across a variety of industries including corporate training, associations, professional development and certifications, and higher education. If your organization issues digital credentials, there are several things you can do to make the most of their marketing power.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll cover four areas where incorporating digital badges can help your brand stand out.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Social</h3> \n<p>With over <a href=\"https://thenextweb.com/contributors/2019/01/30/digital-trends-2019-every-single-stat-you-need-to-know-about-the-internet/\">3.4 billion</a> active users, there's no denying social media is a modern marketing powerhouse. If your brand doesn't already have a social strategy in place, you're potentially losing out on the opportunity to engage with <em>millions</em> of customers.</p> \n<p>Incorporating digital credentials into your social media strategy can drive brand awareness, increase engagement with the individuals who earn your badges, and strengthen the reputation of your company online.</p> \n<p>To incorporate digital credentials, try using keywords and hashtags to search for individuals sharing your digital credentials online and interact with them — give them a \"Like\", a re-tweet, or congratulate them on their achievement. You'll build stronger connections and create new engagement opportunities with your badge earners.</p> \n<p>For instance, anyone who's earned a HubSpot certification could post it on their LinkedIn, like the example below:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Digital%20Credentials%20Your%20Most%20Impactful%20Marketing%20Tool.png?width=427&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20Digital%20Credentials%20Your%20Most%20Impactful%20Marketing%20Tool.png\" alt=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 427px;\" width=\"427\">\n</div> \n<p>Connecting with these users over social media in a meaningful way provides an opportunity for every single one of them to become an evangelist for your brand.</p> \n<p>Another way to leverage digital credentials in this way is for employees to share their certifications socially. Think of this as employees promoting company news or recent awards. By sharing achievements on their social channels, your employees are promoting your brand among users you may not have had the chance to get in front of otherwise.</p> \n<h3>2. Email</h3> \n<p>We've already established there is an inordinate number of emails exchanged each day, which means the average person receives multiple emails every hour. Even so, email marketing is still one of the most important and effective ways for your business to connect with customers and build meaningful relationships.</p> \n<p>Since your team is sending emails to people outside your organization, putting digital credentials in employee email signatures drives brand awareness and validation from the moment an email is opened. When your employees' certifications are on display, they work alongside your company logo to reinforce your brand every time an email is sent, forwarded, or replied to.</p> \n<p>Likewise, encourage your external badge earners to add digital credentials to their professional email signatures, too. Credentials help them establish credibility from the moment they hit \"Send\", allows email recipients to instantly verify the digital badge, and helps them learn more about your products and organization in the process.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Article_Email%20Example.png?width=381&amp;name=Hubspot%20Article_Email%20Example.png\" alt=\"Hubspot Article_Email Example\" width=\"381\" style=\"width: 381px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>3. Online</h3> \n<p>As a marketer, driving quality traffic to your company's site is a core focus. It's the reason there's such importance placed on including backlinks to a website in emails, social media posts, and content.</p> \n<p>The beauty of digital credentials is they're meant to be seen and shared. Developing a dedicated landing page for your digital credentials where potential earners can see the badge associated with the skill is a great way to get visibility for your credentials and is a great place for new earners to start the trial or purchase process. The more people visiting the page, the more recognition you'll have for your initiative.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Example_Online%20Landing%20Page.png?width=1172&amp;name=Hubspot%20Example_Online%20Landing%20Page.png\" alt=\"Hubspot Example_Online Landing Page\" width=\"1172\" style=\"width: 1172px;\"></p> \n<h3>4. Events</h3> \n<p>Events are a critical marketing initiative because they offer the opportunity to build relationships with key customers and prospects. In an increasingly digital world, many marketers believe face-to-face interactions at events are crucial to generating pipeline.
