In fact, <a href=\"https://www.marketingcharts.com/customer-centric/lead-generation-and-management-82291\">68% of B2B marketers</a> agree that live events help generate the most leads.</p> \n<p>Since events place a significant focus on generating brand awareness in a sea of industry solutions, you have to ensure your brand stays top-of-mind for attendees.</p> \n<p>Whether it's a job fair or conference, including digital badges at your booth is a great way to encourage conversation and spark questions about your organization's products and programs, as well as your commitment to employee development.</p> \n<p>The visual representation of competencies allows key audiences to see your expertise before they even engage with your team.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Example_Event%20Flyer.png?width=541&amp;name=Hubspot%20Example_Event%20Flyer.png\" alt=\"Hubspot Example_Event Flyer\" width=\"541\" style=\"width: 541px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>Today, having a great product or service is only half the battle. Making sure people know about your organization and how to engage with it is a huge challenge, but also a huge part of brand success. Creating brand awareness won't happen overnight. Using these ideas can help carve out your place in the market and help your brand stand out in no time.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdigital-credentials&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"ce7b89a71f8f29571df96c8ba23cf23a","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Adam Masur","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Digital%20Credentials%20Your%20Most%20Impactful%20Marketing%20Tool.png?width=427&name=How%20to%20Make%20Digital%20Credentials%20Your%20Most%20Impactful%20Marketing%20Tool.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn8@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-27-821_f2f3e8a420d8da75.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Article_Email%20Example.png?width=381&name=Hubspot%20Article_Email%20Example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn41@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-21-982_83fedb2362a96f80.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Example_Online%20Landing%20Page.png?width=1172&name=Hubspot%20Example_Online%20Landing%20Page.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn29@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-26-358_05965a407430c494.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Example_Event%20Flyer.png?width=541&name=Hubspot%20Example_Event%20Flyer.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn2@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-28-712_ca32349614f22d1f.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdigital-credentials&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn81@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-23-037_8c978c1062e98dd3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336432},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Design Content Remarketing Campaigns That Actually Work","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns","description":"<p>You know content marketing works, so you've been plugging away at blog posts, ebooks, and other valuable, educational content for your potential customers.</p> \n<p>And people come -- they find your content in search results and in their social media feeds. But they may not fill out a form and become a lead right then and there. It's not always because they're not interested in your message -- so how do you recapture those viewers who left your site?</p> \n<p>Recapturing audience attention to turn lookers into leads is an effective marketing tactic, and if you're not doing it, you're leaving money on the table.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Let me outline for you the sections I'm going to cover in this post:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#what-is-remarketing\">What the Heck is Remarketing?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#what-is-gdn\">What Is the Google Display Network?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#campaign-examples\">Remarketing Campaign Examples</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#set-up-remarketing-campaign\">How to Set Up a Remarketing Campaign</a></li> \n</ol> \n<a></a> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What the Heck Is Remarketing?</h2> \n <p>At its core, remarketing is the process of tagging your site visitors and targeting them with content after they leave your site in an effort to reengage them and bring them back to your site.</p> \n</div> \n<p>Remarketing gives you the opportunity to appear in front of people who have already expressed an interest in your website. They could be checking their email, reading the news, watching a YouTube video… and there you are, with something new and awesome to show them. It could be a reminder to complete an action they had started, or a new piece of content to further a buying decision, and so on.</p> \n<p>Remarketing provides the opportunity to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Turn bounced website visitors into leads.</li> \n <li>Increase brand recall (and thus increase branded searches).</li> \n <li>Increase repeat visitor rates and engagement.</li> \n <li>Increase the effectiveness of search engine optimization (SEO) and content marketing.</li> \n</ul> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 650px;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811089655-png/Remarketing1.png?width=650&amp;name=Remarketing1.png\" width=\"650\" alt=\"a graphic illustrating all the users who visited your website vs. bringing them back to your website\" /></p> \n<p>A common stat in the industry is that <strong>96% of people who visit a website leave without completing the action the marketer would have liked them to take.</strong> Remarketing gives you a second chance to make that first impression (and even a third, and a fourth). We can't afford to be forgettable -- we have to make our content more <em>sticky</em>.</p> \n<p>Alright, so we understand both the problem and the opportunity. Now, let's dive into the solution.&nbsp;You're going to learn how to use remarketing strategies with the Google Display Network to dramatically increase the effectiveness of your inbound marketing efforts.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>What Is the Google Display Network?</strong></h2> \n<p>The Google Display Network is a group of websites where your Google display (banner) ads can appear. <br><br>More than 2 million sites are in the network, including heavily trafficked ones such as YouTube. Google estimates that the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/117120?hl=en\">GDN can reach 90% of people on the internet</a>. <br><br>Who you reach and how often will depend on your ad targeting (more on that later).</br></br></br></br></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809803507-png/Remarketing2.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing2.png\" alt=\"graphic that shows google display network's reach in the US across millions of sites, videos, and devices including LinkedIn, CNN, lastfm, eHow, xe, howstuffworks, The New York Times, YouTube, Blogger, Gmail, Google Finance, and Google maps\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Remarking Campaign Examples</strong></h2> \n<p>To further underscore the opportunity that remarketing has to offer, there are some really cool campaign types that you can dig into.</p> \n<h3>Online Activity</h3> \n<p>By far the most common remarketing tactic is creating an audience based on their behavior on your website. Your options here are virtually endless — with parameters such as by number of page views (indicating a high level of interest) or by which pages viewed (indicating intent).</p> \n<p>Here are some ideas for using this type of campaign:</p> \n<h4>Targeting by Buyer's Journey Stage</h4> \n<p>Your blog posts are earlier in the buyer's journey than other pages on your site. That means you'd match their intent with an ad that moves them further down their journey rather than one that sells. Targeting by topic or category-say you run a bakery. Why run general ads to audiences that landed on your wedding-related content? Instead, you'd target them with more personalized ads around wedding cakes and desserts.</p> \n<h4>Targeting by Intent</h4> \n<p>Aside from just topic, there's a lot you can learn from your audience's site behavior. For example, visiting a product page indicates interest, but not making it to checkout could mean a price objection or other friction. This means you need to sweeten the deal in some way (like a promo or discount).</p> \n<h4>Past Purchases</h4> \n<p>You can also target those that did make it through your purchasing process and target them with ads to earn an upsell.</p> \n<h3><strong>YouTube TrueView</strong></h3> \n<p>The human race spends billions of hours every month watching YouTube ads. You may have your own YouTube content, but perhaps your viewing metrics aren’t quite as high as you’d like them to be, or perhaps your users have no idea you have interesting video content to share.</p> \n<p>Using <a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2014/01/15/youtube-remarketing\">YouTube TrueView ads</a>, you can target your audiences as they are watching other videos on YouTube.</p> \n<p>Take the screenshot below, for example.&nbsp;I’m trying to watch a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle video and it’s showing me an ad for a tourism company in Italy. Why? Because I was planning a trip to Florence at the time I took this screenshot, and they’re remarketing to me.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811335425-png/Remarketing995.png?width=551&amp;name=Remarketing995.png\" width=\"551\" style=\"width: 551px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"image ad in youtube video\" /></p> \n<p>The cool thing about TrueView videos is that you only pay if people view your video content. There’s no cost if the person clicks on the “skip ad” button. If you’re creating video content, why wouldn’t you pay a few bucks to promote it?</p> \n<h3>Video Views</h3> \n<p>Speaking of YouTube, your visitors don't even need to make it to your website in order for you to retarget them. If you have a solid YouTube presence, you can create an audience based on video views. If someone watched one of your videos, you can create a display campaign that shows them your ads even beyond the YouTube platform.</p> \n<h3><strong>Remarketing Lists for Search Ads (RLSA)</strong></h3> \n<p>Here’s another interesting but advanced thing you can do. It’s a little complicated, but I promise it's awesome. It’s called Remarking Lists for Search Ads.</p> \n<p>RLSA lets you target people in your audiences with customized ads when they perform searches for specific keywords on Google.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809994192-png/Remarketing998.png?width=522&amp;name=Remarketing998.png\" width=\"522\" style=\"width: 522px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"graphic illustrating RLSA process: users visit your site, get added to your remarketing list, then you show them customized ads when they search on Google\" /></p> \n<p>Say, for example, someone visits your site. You tag them, and now they’re in one of your audiences.</p> \n<p>That person then searches for a competitor of yours. This probably means they’re doing some comparison shopping.</p> \n<p>Using RLSA, you can target that comparison shopper with a specific ad, like a 10% discount code or something similar. Knowing that the person visited specific pages on your site and is now performing specific searches, it’s possible to come up with very specific and compelling ad copy.</p> \n<h3>Bonus: Remarketing With Facebook</h3> \n<p>Noticeably absent from the GDN is Facebook, the other big player on the web, and that's because they have their own remarketing system through Facebook Custom Audiences.</p> \n<p>It works in much the same way — the difference being that ads are shown to users within the Facebook platform.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>How to Set Up a Remarketing Campaign With Google Ads</strong></h2> \n<p>Like I said earlier, using the GDN for remarketing gives you a great deal of reach. Generally, you can find your tagged site visitors on the network many times per day, several days per week, and across many different sites.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Define your audience.</strong></h3> \n<p>One of your first steps in remarketing is to define the specific audience(s) you want to remarket to. For example, you could create an audience for people who visited your blog or for people who visited specific pages on your website, like your pricing page. This will enable you to reach out to<em> just</em> those people with offers and messaging to suit their interests.</p> \n<p>To define an audience, <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adwords/answer/2454064?hl=en\">create a new remarketing list</a> in Google Ad. Google will take care of setting all of the cookies; all<em> you</em> need to do is specify which website visitors to include or exclude from your audience.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809833607-png/Remarketing4.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing4.png\" alt=\"new remarketing list interface within google ads\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<p>Segmenting different lists of users enables you to show different ads, depending on which section of your site they visited.</p> \n<p>A secondary benefit is that you can bid more aggressively to get more impressions and higher ad positions, and to get visitors to the higher value sections of your website. For example, your data might show that visitors to your pricing or product page are more valuable than your blog visitors.</p> \n<p>Another creative remarketing strategy for content marketers is to <a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2012/02/09/how-to-create-adwords-audiences\">define audience categories</a> in Google Ads based on the different post categories in your blog. If you already have a ton of blog content that is classified by topic, leverage those existing classifications in your remarketing audience definition strategy.</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Set audience membership duration.</strong></h3> \n<p>In remarketing, the audience membership duration is the number of days that you follow a user around with your ads. For example, if I set my audience membership duration to 60 days, then users who visit my site will see my ads for 60 days. You can test and tweak this number to see what's right for your audience.</p> \n<p>Ad fatigue is a real thing in every industry and across every medium: TV, radio, print … and, yes, display ads.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Now, I'd like to address a concern I've heard from some fellow marketers: that overly aggressive remarketing will make your prospective customer feel uncomfortable.&nbsp;Let's look at a few facts and see just how \"creepy\" remarketing really is.</p> According to \n<a href=\"https://kenshoo.com/blog/retargeting-stats/\">Kenshoo</a>, retargeting can lift ad engagement rates up to 400%, 60% of consumers are neutral about the topic of retargeting ads, and 25% say they actually like them. \n<a href=\"https://blog.wishpond.com/post/97225536354/infographic-7-incredible-retargeting-ad-stats\">Wishpond</a> reports that the average click-through rate for retargeted ads is 10 times that of a regular display ad, and retargeting can lead to a 726% lift in site visitation after four weeks of exposure. \n<p>So, be bold!&nbsp;People visited your site for a reason, and past browsing history is among the strongest predictors of future purchasing intent.&nbsp;It’s worth testing out remarketing with relatively higher impression caps and membership durations and seeing what happens. <strong>A</strong><strong>s long as your offers and messaging are on target and you're providing value, it's not creepy.&nbsp;</strong>I would suggest:</p> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"normalCxSpMiddle\">Try setting your audience membership duration to an amount equal to 3x your average sale cycle length.</li> \n <li class=\"normalCxSpMiddle\">If it typically takes an average of one week to go from first touch to sale, set the<strong> audience membership duration to three weeks.</strong></li> \n <li class=\"normalCxSpMiddle\">Don’t worry too much about impression caps. (Remember, more impressions means higher conversion rates. Consider <strong style=\"font-size: inherit;\"><em>rotating though multiple ads per campaign</em></strong> to combat ad fatigue.)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>3. Create a killer ad.</strong></h3> \n<p>Now that we’ve talked about defining an audience to remarket to, let's focus on how to create killer remarketing ads.</p> \n<h4><strong>Understand Ad Formats on the GDN</strong></h4> \n<p>There are several different display ad formats on the Google Display Network, some of which are shown below.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-display-ads-responsive-formats.jpg?width=600&amp;name=google-display-ads-responsive-formats.jpg\" alt=\"examples of google display ads responsive formats\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"><a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2019/05/23/google-display-ads\">Image Source</a><br><br /></br></img></p> \n<table style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: table;\"> \n <tbody> \n  <tr style=\"height: 21px;\"> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Type</td> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Dimensions</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr style=\"height: 21px;\"> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Mobile</td> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">300x250, 320x50, 320x100, 250x250, 200x200</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr style=\"height: 21px;\"> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Desktop</td> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">300x250, 336x280, 728x90, 300x600, 160x600, 970x90, 468x60</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p><br>Ad formats matter to marketers because of how the ad auction works. Different ad formats do not compete against each other for positioning, as shown in this screenshot:</br></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811230125-png/Remarketing9.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing9.png\" alt=\"example webpage with multiple display ads: shows that different ad formats do not compete against each other but same format ads still do\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<h4><strong>Write Copy That Resonates Emotionally</strong></h4> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://www.neurosciencemarketing.com/blog/articles/emotional-ads-work-best.htm\">neurosciencemarketing.com</a>, an emotional approach in advertising is nearly twice as effective as a rational approach. The same emotions that draw people to your content will drive people to click on your ads.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The key here is to create ads that resonate with users on an emotional level. Stay away from boring, plain, informational ads that look the same as every other ad out there. Instead, create ads that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/emotion-marketing\">appeal to your audience on an emotional level</a>.</p> \n<p>Content marketers are uniquely qualified to become fabulous PPC marketers. Why?&nbsp;Because so much of the success and failure of PPC marketing relies on the creativity of your ads.</p> \n<p>For example,&nbsp;look at these ads for a search of “Big Data Solutions” -- the ads are essentially all the same:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 650px;\" title=\"Remarketing992\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811305370-png/Remarketing992.png?width=650&amp;name=Remarketing992.png\" width=\"650\" alt=\"ads for &quot;big data solutions&quot; where none of the competing advertisers have unique ad headlines\" /></p> \n<p>Content marketers, on the other hand, tend to have a few creative bones in their bodies. I call this a&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2014/01/29/hacking-adwords\">Google Ads Jackpot</a>&nbsp;because it reminds me of hitting a row of lucky 7s in Vegas -- I just hit a Big Data Solutions jackpot! If you can come up with an emotionally charged, totally different and stand-out ad,&nbsp;you can blow away the competition.</p> \n<h3><strong>4. Perform ongoing CTR optimization.</strong></h3> \n<p>Google doesn’t make money by showing ads no one clicks on, so it makes sense for them to show ads that are more likely to get clicks. They use&nbsp;an algorithm called&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/quality-score\">Quality Score</a>&nbsp;to determine which ads to show, what position each will display in, and how much to charge the advertiser for each ad click.</p> \n<p>To provide an incentive for advertisers to create great ads, they give out huge discounts for ads with high clickthrough rates… and dish out huge penalties for ads with low clickthrough rates.</p> \n<p>This all sounds good in theory, but how do you create an ad with high clickthrough rate?</p> \n<h4><strong>1. Send people to your high-value offers.&nbsp;</strong></h4> \n<p>What should you be featuring in your image ads? The most common tactic is to simply promote your highest value offers, like a free trial of your product, a request for a demo, etc. This is my top-performing ad:&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809918942-png/Remarketing97.png?width=463&amp;name=Remarketing97.png\" alt=\"remarketing ad from wordstream with a puppy on it that says &quot;my dog ate my ppc! no more excuses for poor results&quot;\" width=\"463\" style=\"width: 463px; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>Of course it has a cute puppy. How could it not? Make people&nbsp;love your ads, not dread them.</p> \n<h4><strong>2.</strong>&nbsp;<strong>Do a conversion path analysis.</strong></h4> \n<p>The goal here is to figure out which pages on your site, if visited during a user’s session, result in a much higher probability of the user converting to a lead or a sale. For example, the highest converting page on your site could be your product overview page.&nbsp;Come up with a list like this one and target those pages in your remarketing audience.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809918967-png/Remarketing98.png?width=444&amp;name=Remarketing98.png\" alt=\"excel spreadsheet showing different pages and their conversion rates, indicating the top converting pages are ideal for remarketing\" width=\"444\" style=\"width: 444px; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<h4>3. Send people to your best content.</h4> \n<p>Check out this ad from my colleague <a href=\"http://www.linkedin.com/in/aimclear\">Marty Weintraub</a> at AimClear, which sends anyone who clicks to his PPC analyses.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" title=\"Remarketing99\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1808175089-png/Remarketing99.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing99.png\" alt=\"remarketing ad at the top of a page that says &quot;10 kevlar ppc analyses and process for a bulletproof account&quot;\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<p>But how do you know what content to feature in your ads?</p> \n<h4><strong>4. Analyze social shares on your blog content. </strong></h4> \n<p>If you analyze your blog content, what you’ll usually find is that around 5% of your pages generate half of the shares on social media.</p> \n<p>For example, I analyzed all of the articles on one business blog over the last year and found that on average, a typical article gets several hundred shares on social media. However, the top 5% of articles gets tens of thousands of social shares.&nbsp;Not surprisingly, we found that the same stories that work well on social media also tend to do very well as featured content within ads.</p> \n<h3><strong>5. Get strategic with bid management.</strong></h3> \n<p>Now that you have remarketing audiences and ads down to a science, let's turn our attention to bid management strategies.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Remember, in PPC marketing, you have to pay for each click. The advertiser specifies a maximum cost per click that they’re willing to pay, but the key here is not to buy every possible click.&nbsp;Rather, you want to be super picky and just cherry-pick the clicks that are the most relevant to your business. The way to do this is through bid management.</p> \n<p>It doesn’t make any sense to remarket ads to everyone in your audience. Why? Because not everyone who visits your website is a qualified buyer.</p> \n<p>With Google Ads, you can overlay user demographic information on top of your remarketing audiences to find the needles in the haystack. For example, someone from Zimbabwe could visit your site -- but they can't convert if you can't ship there.</p> \n<p>Here’s when it comes in handy to know a thing or two about your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona\">target customer persona</a>.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What are the ages?</li> \n <li>Parental status?</li> \n <li>Where do they live?</li> \n <li>Gender?</li> \n <li>What time do they search for your products?</li> \n <li>What is their income?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You can be very picky, and <em>just</em> bid for the people in your audience who also meet your demographic filters.</p> \n<p>You've done your research, you know your topic, you have something interesting and entertaining to say -- but sometimes you need that extra push. As individuals and brands have become publishers, the game has been upped big time. Competition is fierce.</p> \n<p>With remarketing, we at WordStream increased our repeat visitors by 50%, tripled our average time on site, and saw a huge increase in direct visits to our site.</p> \n<p>In short, content remarketing enabled us to maximize the value of every piece of content we put out. We were able to get each piece in front of the audience with the most intent, at the right time, and via the right channels.</p> \n<p>You can achieve this kind of success too with a killer remarketing campaign and the right advertising plan.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2014 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdesign-content-remarketing-campaigns&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 14 Aug 2020 20:30:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"db6f2d622208acfd36a8fd982db57de6","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Larry Kim","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811089655-png/Remarketing1.png?width=650&name=Remarketing1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn20@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-22-972_7f9d6bef4c26dd7d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809803507-png/Remarketing2.png?width=600&name=Remarketing2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn36@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-23-762_a3b51dcf9b6a5942.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811335425-png/Remarketing995.png?width=551&name=Remarketing995.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn66@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-21-506_e0b8d834d22e645a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809994192-png/Remarketing998.png?width=522&name=Remarketing998.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn4@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-23-154_70e98a5efa6eb181.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809833607-png/Remarketing4.png?width=600&name=Remarketing4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn82@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-26-821_e6cabad0f0a4d023.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-display-ads-responsive-formats.jpg?width=600&name=google-display-ads-responsive-formats.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn7@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-21-766_6e97d8123a28fc27.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811230125-png/Remarketing9.png?width=600&name=Remarketing9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn73@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-21-421_bb594b382858491f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811305370-png/Remarketing992.png?width=650&name=Remarketing992.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn17@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-21-280_515561343d895aeb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809918942-png/Remarketing97.png?width=463&name=Remarketing97.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn61@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-24-927_d1cb5c874a3097ff.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809918967-png/Remarketing98.png?width=444&name=Remarketing98.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-23-264_a7dfbc18e5136323.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1808175089-png/Remarketing99.png?width=600&name=Remarketing99.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn70@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-25-250_c6c0d33a392e7f64.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdesign-content-remarketing-campaigns&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn35@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-28-887_b7a9a25e68780be2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336428},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Set Up Automated Email Marketing Workflows (+ Examples)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-automation-examples","description":"<div class=\"hs-migrated-cms-post\"> \n <p>Are your contacts going with the flow, or are they just sitting dormant in your marketing database? If you don't have any automated email workflows set up, your answer is probably the latter -- which means you're missing out on some&nbsp;major opportunities to nurture and engage your existing&nbsp;contacts.</p> \n <p>Did you know that&nbsp;marketing automation can lead <a href=\"https://www.invespcro.com/blog/marketing-automation/\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\">to a 14.5% increase in sales productivity</a>? </p> \n <p><a title=\"Lead nurturing emails\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/optimizing-lead-nurturing?_ga=2.207193875.1667640274.1563800435-1307414301.1541080541\">Lead nurturing campaigns</a> aren't the only type of <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">email marketing</a> automation you can use to get more out of your contacts database. Think about the contacts who are already your customers. Email automation can not only help you <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm/lead-management\">convert leads into customers,</a> but it can also help you delight your existing customers and encourage activity like greater product adoption, upsells, evangelism, and additional purchases.&nbsp;</p> \n <p></p> Email marketing automation is useful because it eliminates small but time consuming tasks, such as preparing email lists, sending generic messages, or scheduling events manually. This allows marketers and salespeople more time to work on more productive projects or bigger deals. \n <p>Email marketing automation is centered around the workflow, which is essentially a blueprint of actions you're directing your automation software to take. Software can' t read minds, so one of the challenges is implementing a repeatable process that takes all use cases into account.</p> \n <h3>1. Identify who you're sending to.</h3> \n <p>Personalization is critical when it comes to email, and if your CRM is set up effectively, you'll be able to send automated emails to targeted segments of your database. It all comes down to the integrity of the data you've collected from your contacts and their behavior on your site and with your emails.</p> \n <p>First, know who you want to send to. An upsell campaign might go to existing customers who have not purchased a particular product yet. For another campaign, you might want to promote a new feature to a specific type of prospect who finds it most useful.</p> \n <p>Then, you want to translate the case you identified into criteria your software an understand. For the first example, you might use \"Lifecycle Stage = Customer\" and see if any of your custom properties can whittle that group down to only those who haven't purchased the product yet.</p> \n <p>For the second example, you'd need to determine if you have any properties that can segment the group you're looking for. It might be a property/field for job title, customer type, or buyer persona.</p> \n <p>Criteria can be as specific as the data you have in your CRM.</p> \n <h3>2. Determine your goal.</h3> \n <p>Your email marketing is only as good as your strategy, so ensure you know why you're contacting these individuals. Do you want them to buy something? Learn something? Do something?</p> \n <p>Once you know this, you can figure out the messaging you need to take them from where they're at to where you want them to go.</p> \n <p>You also have to plan for what happens when you succeed.</p> \n <p>For example, imagine a 10-email series to get prospects to request a consultation. Prospect A converts within the first email. If Prospect A continues to receive emails telling them to do what they've already done, they'll get frustrated. In HubSpot, if you define your goal, it will unenroll any contacts who meet the goal.</p> \n <p>If your software doesn't have this feature or you choose not to use it, you will need to consider this case as you build your workflow's logic.</p> \n <h3>3. Set enrollment criteria.</h3> \n <p>\"Enrollment criteria\" refers to the qualities that must be met for a contact to be entered into a workflow. You'll need to be intimately familiar with the types of data you have in your CRM (properties or fields) and be able to trust the accuracy of that data.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hub/2832391/hubfs/Automation/Workflows/adding-workflow-enrollment-criteria.gif?width=600&amp;name=adding-workflow-enrollment-criteria.gif\" alt=\"adding workflow enrollment criteria in hubspot\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <p>If you're using <a title=\"HubSpot's Workflows tool\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing-automation\">HubSpot Workflows</a>, for example, you can create personalized, automated email workflows that can get triggered in a number of different ways -- when a contact gets added to a list, submits a form on your website, clicks a link in an email, views a page on your blog, clicks on one of your ads, or becomes a marketing qualified lead.&nbsp;</p> \n <p>You can also set up email workflows based on any information you have about the contacts in your marketing database, such as page views, email or social media clicks, content downloads, contact properties, or any combination of these and more.&nbsp;</p> \n <h3>4. Identify the actions that must be taken.</h3> \n <p>If you were manually emailing these contacts, what would you do? Automation actions include the following and more:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Email sends</li> \n  <li>Time delays</li> \n  <li>If/then branching</li> \n  <li>CRM updates</li> \n </ul> \n <p>You'll need to map out the sequence of events according to \"actions\" that your software understands and specify when the actions need to be taken.</p> \n <h3>5. Create the necessary assets.</h3> \n <p>By this point, you know how many emails you want to send and the general messaging they should include. Before you begin creating your workflow, all assets should be created and loaded into the software.</p> \n <p>In HubSpot, automated emails must be specified as such in the \"email type\" prompt.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-type-automated.jpg?width=600&amp;name=email-type-automated.jpg\" alt=\"&quot;choose an email type&quot; prompt in hubspot with options: regular, automated, blog/rss\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>5. Implement the workflow logic and attach email assets.</h3> \n <p>Automation software works in an overly literal way, so think of your workflow as a blueprint that outlines each action in order, no matter how minuscule those actions seem.</p> \n <p>In HubSpot, you'd specify which actions to take in the \"choose an action\" window in the workflows tool.</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-workflows-choose-an-action.jpg?width=426&amp;name=hubspot-workflows-choose-an-action.jpg\" alt=\"hubspot workflows choose an action prompt\" width=\"426\" style=\"width: 426px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <h3>6. Check your setup and do a test if possible.</h3> \n <p>Some things to consider implementing into your workflow publishing process:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Looking at the list of enrolled contacts for errors</li> \n  <li>Checking that the number enrolled matches what you'd expect</li> \n  <li>Considering the workflow chart and use cases</li> \n  <li>Checking the the send settings</li> \n </ul> \n <p>In HubSpot, there's also a way to \"Test\" the workflow by receiving the emails all at once (but in order).</p> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-workflows-test.jpg?width=318&amp;name=hubspot-workflows-test.jpg\" alt=\"hubspot workflows test button\" width=\"318\" style=\"width: 318px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <p>This won't cover all cases but is still a best practice.</p> \n <h3>8. Set live and monitor progress.</h3> \n <p>Once you're happy with the workflow, set it live.</p> \n <p>Mistakes can happen, so monitor for anomalies. Don't be afraid to adjust as needed to resolve issues or improve performance.</p> \n <p>And&nbsp;that's just the beginning&nbsp;of what you can do with workflows.&nbsp;Workflows can also enable&nbsp;you to automate other actions <em>besides</em> email, such as setting or clearing a contact property value, updating a contact's lifecycle stage, adding/removing a contact from a list, and other administrative tasks that allow for more targeted, effective marketing to your prospects and customers.&nbsp;</p> \n <h2>13 Examples of Email Marketing Automation Workflows You Should Try</h2> \n <p>Now let's walk through some examples of automated email workflows you can set up to start getting more out of your contacts database and <a title=\"marketing automation tools\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing-automation\">marketing automation </a>tools.</p> \n <h3>1. Topic Workflows</h3> \n <h4>Main Triggers: Page Views or Content Offer Downloads</h4> \n <p>Create a workflow for each of the industry-related topics you create content about. So if, hypothetically, you're a unicorn breeder whose main content&nbsp;topics include unicorn diets, unicorn gear, and unicorn boarding, you could bucket your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-strategy-guide\">content marketing</a> offers (e.g. ebooks, webinars, kits, etc.) and blog posts by these topics, create an email workflow for each topic, and trigger the appropriate workflow when one of your contacts views a page or downloads an offer centered around that topic.</p> \n <p>You can trigger a content download workflow based on a form submission from a tool like HubSpot’s free conversion tool, <a href=\"http://hubs.ly/H05dT0b0\">HubSpot Marketing Free</a>. (HubSpot customers: You can <a href=\"http://marketingfree.hs-sites.com/knowledge/add-lead-flows-to-hubspot\">add Lead Flows, HubSpot's pop-up forms,&nbsp;as an add-on by following the instructions here</a>. To trigger an automated workflow in HubSpot, you can use the “Lead Flow Submission” option as the starting condition.)</p> \n <p>So if a contact downloaded your ebook called&nbsp;<em>10 Tips for a Balanced Unicorn Diet</em>, your \"unicorn diet\" workflow would be triggered, sending that contact other helpful content, like blog posts about unicorn dietary tips.</p> \n <h3>2. Blog Subscriber Welcome Workflow&nbsp;</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Subscription to Your Blog</h4> \n <p>Give your brand new blog subscribers a nice, warm welcome with a blog welcome email. You can use this email to thank contacts for subscribing,&nbsp;remind them what they'll get out of reading your blog,&nbsp;review their subscription settings (and allow them to make adjustments), and promote your blog's best-performing articles or other offers.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-subscriber-welcome-emails-ht\">Get&nbsp;tips for creating a successful blog welcome email here</a>, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/optimize-welcome-emails\">learn more about optimizing welcome emails here</a>.</p> \n <h3>3. New Customer Welcome/Training Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Lifecycle Stage</h4> \n <p>While we're on the subject&nbsp;of warm welcomes, consider&nbsp;setting up a series of welcome emails when a contact converts into a paying customer, which you can trigger when a contact's lifecycle stage gets updated to \"customer.\"</p> \n <p>Not only is this a great way to&nbsp;kick off your new customer&nbsp;relationship on a positive note, but it can also keep&nbsp;your customers engaged after they buy. And if your product or service requires a little training on your customers' part, use this workflow as an opportunity to introduce helpful training materials on an incremental basis.</p> \n <h3>4. Engaged Contact/Evangelist Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Triggers: Visits, Clicks, or Form Submissions</h4> \n <p>Create a dynamic list (we call these Smart Lists in <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products\">HubSpot's Marketing Platform</a>) that automatically updates to include contacts who are really engaged with you. To create this list, use trigger criteria such as a high threshold of visits to your website, clicks on your emails&nbsp;or social media&nbsp;posts, or form submissions. Then create an email workflow to leverage this list as a way to encourage evangelism of your top content in social media.</p> \n <p>Because these contacts are highly engaged with you already, they're more apt to share your top content. You&nbsp;can&nbsp;also consider adding list criteria&nbsp;to pull in&nbsp;contacts with a certain number&nbsp;of Twitter followers so you can leverage the power of those social media influencers in your database.&nbsp;</p> \n <h3>5. Lead Nurturing Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Multiple Top-of-the-Funnel Conversion Events&nbsp;</h4> \n <p>If a contact has&nbsp;downloaded&nbsp;several&nbsp;of your top-of-the-funnel marketing&nbsp;offers like ebooks and webinars, it might be a good sign they're ready for a little bit more. Set up workflows that help to advance these contacts further down the&nbsp;funnel.</p> \n <p>If the contact is a lead, try sending them emails containing more middle-of-the-funnel content that might upgrade them to a marketing qualified lead (MQL) or an opportunity in your sales process. This workflow could include content and web pages you've identified from an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/attribution-reports-definition\">attribution report</a>&nbsp;analysis as influential in converting leads into customers -- perhaps content like customer success stories/case studies, free trial offers, or product demos.&nbsp;</p> \n <p><em>(Bonus: If you're using <a title=\"HubSpot's Workflows\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing-automation\">HubSpot's Workflows</a>, you could set up a condition that automatically upgrades these leads to a new lifecycle stage as a result!)</em></p> \n <h3>6. Internal Sales Rep Notification Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Triggers: Bottom-of-the-Funnel Page Views/Conversion Events</h4> \n <p>On any given website, there&nbsp;are certain page visits and conversion events that indicate product interest more so than others. First, identify these pages and conversion events using an <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/analytics\">attribution reporting tool like HubSpot's</a>. You’ll notice that, more often than not, the pages you unearth will be your pricing page, your product pages, etc. -- pages contacts view when they're truly evaluating your products or services.</p> \n <p>Use workflows here to trigger an&nbsp;internal email notification to your sales rep informing them of these high-value activities. Using personalization, give the rep all the information they need about the lead in question,&nbsp;including&nbsp;relevant mid- and bottom-of-the-funnel content that they can send to the lead in their outreach email. This allows you to&nbsp;connect sales&nbsp;reps&nbsp;with the best possible leads at the right time.</p> \n <h3>7. Re-Engagement Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Inactive&nbsp;Contacts</h4> \n <p>Reawaken inactive contacts with a re-engagement workflow, enrolling contacts once they've met certain list criteria. For example, you could set conditions such as the length of time since their last form submission, website visit, or email click, triggering the email when it's been a while since a contact last engaged with you.</p> \n <p>In your workflow, try sending them an exclusive offer or coupon to get them excited about your company again. For more tips about launching an effective email re-engagement campaign, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32123/How-to-Use-Email-to-Re-Engage-Sleepy-Subscribers.aspx\">check out this post</a>.<strong><br></strong></p> \n <h3>8. Event Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Registration or Attendance</h4> \n <p>Hosting a live, in-person <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/the-new-age-event-marketing\">event</a>? Or maybe an online event, like a webinar? Use email workflows to automate your communication to event registrants and attendees before, during, and after the event.</p> \n <p>For example, create a workflow that delivers important information&nbsp;registrants&nbsp;should know leading up to the event, such as hotel accommodations and agenda information for live events, or webinar log-in information for online events. When the event ends, set up&nbsp;a workflow that gives&nbsp;attendees online access to session slides&nbsp;and continues to&nbsp;nurture&nbsp;them with additional content or promotion for&nbsp;future events.&nbsp;<strong><br></strong></p> \n <h3>9. Abandoned Shopping Cart Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Shopping Cart Abandonment</h4> \n <p>If you're an <a title=\"ecommerce business\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/ecommerce/\">ecommerce business</a>, you'll likely benefit from an abandoned shopping cart workflow. The concept here is simple: When someone&nbsp;adds an item to&nbsp;their online&nbsp;shopping cart but leaves your&nbsp;site without completing the purchase, you can trigger an email workflow that reminds them of their forgotten purchase and motivates&nbsp;them to complete the transaction by offering a special&nbsp;discount code or some other incentive to buy.</p> \n <h3>10. Upsell Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Past Purchases</h4> \n <p>Communication with your customers shouldn't stop after they make a purchase. This is especially true if you sell a variety of different products and/or services. Use workflows as an opportunity to <a title=\"upsell your customers\" href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33214/How-to-Make-More-Money-From-Existing-Customers-With-Marketing-Automation.aspx\">upgrade or upsell your existing customers</a>, or sell them complementary products and services depending on what they've already purchased.</p> \n <p>Create dynamically updating lists of contacts who purchase a certain product<strong> -- </strong>or combination of products -- and create workflows aimed at recommending other products/services or encouraging upsells or add-ons.<strong><br></strong></p> \n <h3>11. Customer Happiness Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: High or Low NPS Scores</h4> \n <p>If you administer regular Net Promoter surveys of your customer base, you can use customers' <a title=\"Net Promoter Scores\" href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-definition-of-net-promoter-score-nps-in-under-100-words\">Net Promoter Scores</a> as a property to trigger workflows.</p> \n <p>Simply determine what your ideal customer happiness score is, and use that as the threshold for your dynamic list&nbsp;of happy customers. Then trigger a workflow for&nbsp;customers with \"happy\" scores and reward them&nbsp;with exclusive content, offers, or discounts.</p> \n <p>Trigger a different workflow for your \"unhappy\" customers that includes&nbsp;content/offers aimed at helping to&nbsp;improve their happiness. We'll give you a few bonus points if you segment those unhappy customers by the reasons they're unhappy, and send them even more targeted workflows aimed at addressing the issues that are making them so grumpy.<strong><br></strong></p> \n <h3>12. Customer Success/Engagement Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Triggers: Success Metrics or&nbsp;Product Usage</h4> \n <p>If you keep track of customer success metrics, you have a prime workflow opportunity on your hands. For example, if you're trying to build up your arsenal of <a title=\"customer case studies\" href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33282/The-Ultimate-Guide-to-Creating-Compelling-Case-Studies.aspx\">customer case studies</a>, you could automatically trigger an email that asks customers if they'd be interesting in being featured as&nbsp;a success story once certain customer success metrics were met.</p> \n <p>Furthermore, if you keep track of customers' product adoption or feature usage, you could trigger a workflow for users who are exhibiting low product engagement,&nbsp;providing resources that educate and train them on how to use the product features they're not taking advantage of.<strong><br></strong></p> \n <h3>13. Upcoming Purchase Reminder Workflow</h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: Purchases Made on a Cycle</h4> \n <p>Does your contacts database include customers who typically purchase on a cycle? Enter those people into a workflow that gets triggered when they make a&nbsp;purchase.</p> \n <p>For instance, let's say you sell eye care products, and a customer purchases a six-month supply of prescription contacts. Enroll that customer into a workflow that sends them an automated email five months later as a&nbsp;reminder that their six-month supply is about to run out, and it might be time to order a new batch of contacts.<strong><br></strong></p> \n <h3>14. <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/workflows/contact-company-deal-ticket-or-quote-unexpectedly-enrolled-in-workflow\">Customer Service or Ticket Workflow</a></h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: A customer or prospect contacts customer service via email or an online form.</h4> \n <p>Sometimes, your customers or prospects might have trouble using your free or paid software. When this happens, fielding a bunch of customer service emails and messages can take tons of valuable time from your schedule.&nbsp;</p> \n <p>One way to avoid this it to create a workflow that categorizes that makes customer concerns into tickets that can be categorized, labeled and assigned to customer service reps on your team. These tickets can also help you keep tack of ongoing problems as well as when issues with a customer or prospect are resolved.&nbsp;</p> \n <h3>15. <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/workflows/contact-company-deal-ticket-or-quote-unexpectedly-enrolled-in-workflow\">Deal-Based Workflows</a></h3> \n <h4>Main Trigger: When someone e-signs a quote or contract.</h4> \n <p>Sealing the deal is obviously key to successful sales. Automating small aspects of this process, like emails someone might get after signing a contract or quote page with you, can allow you to spend more time nurturing the client over the phone, during demos, or through other messages.</p> \n <p>With a deal-based workflow, you can trigger confirmation emails when a prospect becomes a client or qualified lead by signing a quote or contract. With systems like HubSpot, you can also set the workflow to change the contact's status to show where they are in the sales lifecycle.</p> \n <p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in September 2012 and has been updated for freshness, accuracy, and comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n <p><em></em></p> \n <p><em></em></p> \n <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2016 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n</div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Femail-marketing-automation-examples&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 19 Aug 2020 20:20:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"6f2f88e7bba67e8f14bb69a0b4d346ea","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"pvaughan@hubspot.com (Pamela Vaughan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hub/2832391/hubfs/Automation/Workflows/adding-workflow-enrollment-criteria.gif?width=600&name=adding-workflow-enrollment-criteria.gif":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-type-automated.jpg?width=600&name=email-type-automated.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn39@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-23-688_b0605e1249b500f1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-workflows-choose-an-action.jpg?width=426&name=hubspot-workflows-choose-an-action.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn55@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-28-975_ff4af860e21c45d4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-workflows-test.jpg?width=318&name=hubspot-workflows-test.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn24@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-25-258_aadbae3ae9781e54.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Femail-marketing-automation-examples&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-29-119_ec62bf6fc968ede0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336425},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"The 17 Best Resume Templates for Every Type of Professional","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-resume-templates","description":"<p>While an eye-catching resume alone probably won't land you your dream gig, it doesn't hurt to put a little extra effort into how you present yourself on paper.</p>  \n<p>The right resume design speaks to your individual skills and personality, and can propel your application to the top of the stack. But finding a cool design that also fits your professional identity can be a major hassle — and applying for jobs is already hard enough.</p> \n<p>We've scoured the web for some of the best resume templates to help you stand out in a sea of Times New Roman and crowded copy.</p> \n<p>You'll want to steal each and every one of these creative resume templates — and the good news is: You can! These generous designers have made their work available for free download. Read on to check them out and find a great fit for your next job application.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Resume%20Template%201-1.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Resume%20Template%201-1.jpg\" alt=\"free editable resume word pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-resume-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagesir&amp;hubs_signup-url=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resume-templates-word&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\" style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: none; font-weight: 600; margin: 0px; border: 0px;\"><em style=\"font-style: italic; font-weight: inherit; margin: 0px; border: 0px;\">Download a free, editable resume template.</em></a></p> \n<p>We've organized them by the type of candidate they're best for.</p> \n<h2>The 17 Best Resume Templates for Every Type of Professional</h2> \n<h3>Best for Creatives</h3> \n<p><em>These templates emphasize the design, color, and typography skills that creatives need to show from the get-go.</em></p> \n<h4>1. Resume Template with a Photo Background</h4> \n<p>This template from Polish designer <a href=\"http://tydziennik.pl/\">Patryk Korycki</a> is perfect for photographers, graphic designers, and other creatives looking to showcase a sample of their best work. The template can be downloaded <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28413891/Free-Minimalistic-ResumeCV-Illustrator\">here</a> for free.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_04.png\"> \n<h4>2. Monochromatic and Retro Resume Template</h4> \n<p>This design from freelancer <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/Fay-Zodiac\">Fay Zodiac</a> is a whimsical take on traditional resumes. The retro typography adds a playful element, while the boxy layout keeps everything from looking too busy or crowded. You can download this resume design <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/22623583/FREE-Resume-Template\">here</a> for free.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_13.png?width=500&amp;name=resume_template_13.png\" alt=\"Typography resume template for illustrators and graphic designers\" title=\"Typography resume template for illustrators and graphic designers\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px;\"> \n<h4>3. Vibrant and Visual Resume Template</h4> \n<p><a href=\"http://alessiacurcio.dk/\">Alessia Curcio</a>, a Copenhagen-based designer, gives us a perfect example of how to incorporate kaleidoscopic color without going over the top. Infographic-inspired elements help clearly display work experience and skills with minimal text. Download Curcio's free template <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/23923945/Infographic-resume-vol2\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_15.jpg?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_15.jpg\" alt=\"Resume template with colorful header and footer\" title=\"Resume template with colorful header and footer\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>4. Infographic Style Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Created by digital art director and freelance designer <a href=\"http://www.justcreativeideas.com/\">Fernando Báez</a>, this unique, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/infographic-resume\">infographic-inspired resume</a> template helps you organize your work experience and skills into a minimal visual layout. Báez has made the template available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/8477535/Freebie-Vertical-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_01.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_01.png\" alt=\"Resume template formatted like an infographic\" title=\"Resume template formatted like an infographic\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h3>Best for Freelancers</h3> \n<p><em>These templates emphasize the headshot photo for freelancers who might not meet their employers in person, and need substantial text space and a visual to offer something memorable.</em></p> \n<h4>5. Resume Template with a Simple Color Accent</h4> \n<p>Adding color to a resume might seem intimidating at first — especially if you're applying to a more traditional workplace — but a few sophisticated pops of color can add some interest without compromising on professionalism.</p> \n<p>This template from designer <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/eogawac\">Eduardo Ogawa</a> uses bright accents to spice up the traditional layout. You can download it for free <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/42485071/Free-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_03.png?width=500&amp;name=resume_template_03.png\" alt=\"Resume template with photo space on the top right\" title=\"Resume template with photo space on the top right\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px;\"> \n<h4>6. Bold Classic Resume Template</h4> \n<p>If you're looking for a more traditional resume template that still makes a bold impression, check out this creation from Finish designer <a href=\"http://creativebooster.net/\">Mats-Peter Forss</a>. The template includes space for a headshot, and is available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/30805663/Free-Resume-Template-for-Word-Photoshop-Illustrator\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_02.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_02.png\" alt=\"Creative resume template with vertical header and space for a headshot photo\" title=\"Creative resume template with vertical header and space for a headshot photo\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>7. Resume Template with Pops of Primary Colors</h4> \n<p>Proof that color can be professional, this template boasts a compact, sophisticated layout and bright, colorful accents. It also has room for a substantial summary. Designer <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/davisai\">David Gómez</a> actually uses this resume template himself, and he's been generous enough to share it for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28465321/Free-resume-template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_07.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_07.png\" alt=\"Colorful resume template with blue primary font color\" title=\"Colorful resume template with blue primary font color\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h3>Best for Recent Graduates</h3> \n<p><em>These templates make great use of empty space — perfect for students who are still building experience — through eye-catching designs that help these candidates make a splash in their industry.</em></p> \n<h4>8. Graphic and Adventurous Resume Template</h4> \n<p>This is not a resume template for wallflowers. The folks at <a href=\"https://beta2.createer.com/\">Createer</a> whipped up this daring design as part of a free resume template pack, which you can check out <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28945909/Free-Resume-Template-Pack\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_05.png\"> \n<h4>9. Resume Template with an Unexpected Format</h4> \n<p>If you want to <i>really</i> stand out in a crowded applicant pool, then this resume is definitely for you. Graphic designer and freelance photographer <a href=\"http://www.paolopettigiani.com/\">Paolo Pettigiani</a> created this bold template for his own professional use, but has made it available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/24416019/Self-Promotion-Free-CV\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_12.png\"> \n<h4>10. Center-Aligned Resume Template</h4> \n<p>If you want to mix up your resume format without going too crazy, try a center-aligned layout, like this clean, modern design by <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/Zohanhabib\">Zohan Habib</a>. The custom icons and colored border add a nice creative touch. This template is available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28111401/Laconique-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_14.png\"> \n<h3>Best for Executive/Upper-Level Professionals</h3> \n<p><em>These templates offer ample real estate for candidates to express their deep experience in the plain but formal manner that many employers expect.</em></p> \n<h4>11. Black and White Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Running low on colored ink? Check out this minimal black and white template from editorial designer <a href=\"http://broluthfi.co/\">Bro Luthfi</a>. The simple design is anything but boring, and includes a set of custom icons to add some visual interest. You can download the free template <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/16124595/FREE-Simple-Resume\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_08.jpg?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_08.jpg\" alt=\"Black and white resume template\" title=\"Black and white resume template\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>12. Clean and Modern Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Your resume is really your first impression with a potential employer, and this template design from the team at <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/GoaShape?u=GoaShape\">GoaShape</a> is modern without being too edgy.</p> \n<p>The template pack includes a two-page resume layout and cover letter design, and can be downloaded for free <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/41819029/Unique-Resume-CV-Template-Pages-Word\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_11.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_11.png\" alt=\"Resume and cover letter template\" title=\"Resume and cover letter template\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>13. Resume Template with Subtle Color Scheme</h4> \n<p>Beirut-based designer <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/'https://www.behance.net/blugraphic&quot;\">Wassim Awadallah</a> serves up a simple, two-page resume template for more advanced professionals.</p> \n<p>Displaying the headshot and contact information on the cover leaves plenty of room on the second page to document all your career highlights and accomplishments. Download the template for free <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/38750701/Minimal-Advanced-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_06.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_06.png\" alt=\"Best two-page resume template with cover page\" title=\"Best two-page resume template with cover page\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h3>Best for People Changing Careers</h3> \n<p><em>These templates help those who are changing industries organize their experience by skill, rather than employer. Sections can be customized to the candidate who needs to show how his/her background can transfer.</em></p> \n<h4>14. Resume Template with an Organized Use of Space</h4> \n<p>When you're trying to crunch years of work experience and a laundry list of skills onto a single sheet of paper, things tend to get crowded quickly. This template from designer <a href=\"http://www.helsinkibranding.com/\">Tina Von Helsinki </a> invites you to simplify.</p> \n<p>The distinct sections highlight different aspects of your qualifications — eliminating anything extraneous and putting the focus on what matters to your potential employers the most. Download the template <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/30716433/Free-Resume-CV-vol2\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_09.png?width=500&amp;name=resume_template_09.png\" alt=\"Minimalist resume template\" title=\"Minimalist resume template\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px;\"> \n<h4>15. Playful and Professional Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Italian designer <a href=\"http://martinacavalieri.name/\">Martina Cavalieri</a> created this resume template with a set of 16 custom icons to highlight your interests and skills. The modern layout is anchored by a bold two-toned border: just enough color to help your resume stand out in the pile. Cavalieri offers this template for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/33273657/Free-CV-and-icons-Its-time-to-change\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_10.png\"> \n<h3>Best for Hardcore Marketers</h3> \n<p><em>We couldn't help ourselves. Although every template in this blog post can work for marketers, the templates below are perfect for those who love to brand themselves.</em></p> \n<h4>16. Heavy Header Resume Template</h4> \n<p>\"Hey, you!\" That's what I think of when I see this flashy yet classy template. Made by designer <a href=\"http://www.cursiveq.com/about/\">Mike Bradshaw</a>, the resume features a variety of sections without seeming too cluttered.</p> \n<p>Long first or last names might look overwhelming with this header, but it certainly does a good job conveying a breadth of information. Download it for free <a href=\"http://www.cursiveq.com/designs/modern-swiss-style-resume-cv-psd-template/\">here</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/swiss-resume-template.jpg?width=600&amp;name=swiss-resume-template.jpg\" alt=\"Creative resume template with large, red header\" title=\"Creative resume template with large, red header\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"></p> \n<h4>17. Profile Style Resume Template</h4> \n<p>This last resume was actually designed by the company, <a href=\"https://www.hloom.com/\">Hloom</a>, and is rather plain. But there's something so familiar about it: The resume header looks like a Facebook profile!</p> \n<p>While Hloom suggests the lengthy skills section could make this template appealing to the IT industry, we think it is equally perfect for digital marketers — especially those who work in social media. Download it for free <a href=\"https://www.hloom.com/get/glimmer/\">here</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/profile-resume-template.png?width=480&amp;name=profile-resume-template.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 480px;\" alt=\"Social media marketing resume template\" title=\"Social media marketing resume template\" width=\"480\"></p> \n<p><i><strong>Didn't find the design you were looking for?</strong> We bet you'll find an awesome template in this <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-resume-templates\">free resume template pack</a>.</i></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October, 2016 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img
