Cook)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Resume%20Template%201-1.jpg?width=1500&name=Resume%20Template%201-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn79@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-29-399_7390cb8949bf4f13.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_04.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn77@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-25-769_3c1d7bc028fa95dd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_13.png?width=500&name=resume_template_13.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn86@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-20-961_125b7eb35748df87.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_15.jpg?width=600&name=resume_template_15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn65@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-27-151_77714a17314092fd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_01.png?width=600&name=resume_template_01.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn9@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-26-103_09a3d1ad90d598d9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_03.png?width=500&name=resume_template_03.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn59@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-29-127_1a67438dc4cdfaea.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_02.png?width=600&name=resume_template_02.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn66@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-25-044_e4ced3cc49807a3c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_07.png?width=600&name=resume_template_07.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-20-132_511a0e10d6cc4e5c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_05.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn46@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-26-472_5426b32d24aca92b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_12.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn6@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-25-199_f91f094b537923d1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_14.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn77@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-26-492_1c508a4feb5945e7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_08.jpg?width=600&name=resume_template_08.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn2@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-20-998_2c3bed4db56663a3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_11.png?width=600&name=resume_template_11.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn90@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-23-283_1ca2e0001c00aa89.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_06.png?width=600&name=resume_template_06.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn80@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-20-145_befbcfc92db89e5e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_09.png?width=500&name=resume_template_09.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn32@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-20-096_d9ff14fb687e2957.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_10.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn86@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-25-854_96e1b43819786ab5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/swiss-resume-template.jpg?width=600&name=swiss-resume-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-22-917_9fc8b47be35100ce.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/profile-resume-template.png?width=480&name=profile-resume-template.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn41@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-26-401_f1f4ce7414afdebc.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-resume-templates&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn81@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-24-063_947f9e84854215f2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336434},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Optimize Your Content for Google's Featured Snippet Box","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-featured-snippet-box","description":"<p>In the past few years Google have been refining the way that it displays results to users. In particular, Google has been increasing the number of Featured Snippets that it displays for queries. This actually pushes organic results further down the page. So what does that mean for SEOs?</p>  \n<p>Well, that's what I set out to explore. Naturally, ranking in the Featured Snippet itself remedies the problem of positioning, but is this strategy something worth doing? What&nbsp;<em>is&nbsp;</em>a Featured Snippet, anyway?&nbsp;And more importantly, what do you have to do to appear there?</p> \n<p></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is a Featured Snippet?</h2> \n <p>Featured Snippets — also known as answer boxes — are selections of content displayed on the search engine results page (SERP) without the user having to visit the page where the content lives. Google puts these snippets above regular SERP results but below the ads in an effort of serving the user better.</p> \n</div> \n<p>For example, the Featured Snippet below displays the direct instructions pulled from the tasteofhome.com web page.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how_to_make_bread_featured_snippet.png?width=669&amp;name=how_to_make_bread_featured_snippet.png\" alt=\"List Featured Snippet on Google for how to make bread\" title=\"Featured Snippet: how to make bread\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>There are no ads for this query, so the Featured Snippet shown in the answer box is above position 1 of the SERPs for \"how to make bread.\" The directions are shown in four steps before the user has to click a single link.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Types of Featured Snippet</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Paragraph</li> \n  <li>List</li> \n  <li>Table</li> \n  <li>Video</li> \n  <li>Accordion</li> \n  <li>Rich Answer</li> \n  <li>Tool or Calculator</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>Paragraph</h3> \n<p>Paragraph-formatted answer to the searcher's query. This is the most common type of Featured Snippet, encompassing 50% of all snippet results (Moz 2019).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-paragraph.png?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-paragraph.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"example of a paragraph featured snippet that shows a long-form answer to the question &quot;what is marketing automation?&quot;\"></p> \n<h3>List</h3> \n<p>Bulleted or numbered list that answers the searcher's query (typically shows up for more process-driven, step-by-step, and list queries). This is the next most common type of Featured Snippet, encompassing 37% of snippet results (Moz).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-list.png?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-list.png\" alt=\"example of a featured list snippet that provides a list for the query 'best college websites'\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>List snippets can take the form of numbered or bulleted lists.</p> \n<h3>Table</h3> \n<p>Answer to the searcher's query involving data or other information presented in a table format.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-table.jpg?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-table.jpg\" alt=\"example of featured snippet in table format that shows data for '2016 car sales by brand'\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Video</h3> \n<p>Video result embedded on the page intended to answer the searcher's query in a visual/auditory format.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-video.jpg?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-video.jpg\" alt=\"example of featured video snippet for the query 'how to crochet'\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Accordion</h3> \n<p>Answer to the searcher's query presented with additional information that the searcher can choose to expand to learn more about.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-accordion.jpg?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-accordion.jpg\" alt=\"example of featured snippet with accordion for the query 'bio oil' with expanding accordion boxes for additional categories such as ingredients\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Rich Answer</h3> \n<p>Short call-out in which the answer to the searcher's query is featured in bold along with additional information.</p> \n<p>These often manifest for questions that have factual, metric-based answers:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-rich-answer.jpg?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-rich-answer.jpg\" alt=\"example of a rich snippet answer box for the query 'how many miles from pluto to the sun' and displaying a short bold answer of '3.7 billion miles'\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>In addition, dictionary definitions are common rich answers:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-definition.png?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-definition.png\" alt=\"example of a rich answer featured snippet displaying the dictionary definition for 'seo'\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Tool or Calculator</h3> \n<p>Answer to the searcher's query in the form of an interactive tool that can output user-specific answers.</p> \n<p>Tools can appear for very high-level and concrete queries. Examples of tools that Google shows are calculators, conversions, time zones, weather, game scores, and more.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-tool.jpg?width=600&amp;name=featured-snippet-tool.jpg\" alt=\"featured snippet that shows an interactive mortgage calculator tool where the user can input their own values and receive a custom output directly on the serp\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h2>Why Should You Care About Featured Snippets?</h2> \n<p>One of the first conclusions that a lot of people involved with SEO jumped to was that Featured Snippets would have a hugely negative impact on the amount of people that actually click through to the pages within the results. This actually hasn't been the case. In fact, it's dramatically <a href=\"http://searchengineland.com/seo-featured-snippets-leads-big-gains-236212\">increased the click-through rate</a>&nbsp;(CTR) of results ranking within it.</p> \n<p>From a sample of just under 5,000 queries, I found that the CTR to the HubSpot website for high volume keywords <strong>increased by over 114%</strong>,&nbsp;even when we ranked #1 (just below the Featured Snippet -- like in the example below).</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Inbound_Marketing_Featured_Snippet.png?width=671&amp;name=Inbound_Marketing_Featured_Snippet.png\" alt=\"Inbound Marketing Featured Snippet\" title=\"Inbound Marketing Featured Snippet\" width=\"671\" style=\"width: 671px;\"></p> \n<p>So to give you an example, let's say you&nbsp;rank #1 (the first post below the snippet) on page one of Google for a keyword that's searched for 10,000 times. From the data I've collected, you&nbsp;could expect roughly&nbsp;1,700 visits, compared to the 3,700 you might see if you landed the Featured Snippet spot -- and that's just one keyword.</p> \n<p>Here's another interesting piece of data that illustrates how valuable it can be to rank in the Featured Snippet within Google:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SERP_CTR_for_Featured_Snippet_vs_No_Featured_Snippet-1.png?width=669&amp;name=SERP_CTR_for_Featured_Snippet_vs_No_Featured_Snippet-1.png\" alt=\"Chart: SERP CTR for Featured Snippet vs No Featured Snippet\" title=\"Chart: SERP CTR for Featured Snippet vs No Featured Snippet\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p>Again, to decipher this graph, here's a brief overview:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The x-axis relates to the <em>monthly search volume</em> for the search queries measured.</li> \n <li>The y-axis shows the click-through rate (CTR) of the ranking HubSpot URL from within Google (i.e. how many people clicked on our search result versus the rest of the results in the search results page for a query).</li> \n <li>The blue line plots the CTR from the SERPs for HubSpot URLs when we&nbsp;<strong>do not </strong>appear in the Featured Snippet, broken down by query search volume (x-axis).</li> \n <li>The orange line plots the CTR from the SERPs for HubSpot URLs when we&nbsp;<strong>do&nbsp;</strong>appear in the Featured Snippet, broken down by query search volume (x-axis).</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>By and large, we get much more clicks through to our content when we appear in the Featured Snippet, but this becomes increasingly important as the search volume for a query increases.</strong></p> \n<p>For high traffic keywords, ranking in the Featured Snippet saw an <strong>average increase in CTR of over 114%</strong>, and that's even if we're ranking #1 on page one.</p> \n<p>Now that you know that featured snippet acquisition is a worthwhile SEO strategy, there are a few things that you should keep in mind as you attempt to win your own placements.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Get a Featured Snippet</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Target question-based queries.</li> \n  <li>You don't necessarily need to use schema.</li> \n  <li>Organize the structure of your pages with headings and paragraph tags.</li> \n  <li>For non question-based keywords, take a definition-style approach.</li> \n  <li>When applicable, include steps for solving a problem or answering the question.</li> \n  <li>The content should be between 54-48 words long.</li> \n  <li>Don't rule out an international approach.</li> \n  <li>Don't worry about backlinks as much for Featured Snippets.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.07%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/4rbrouufDP0\" width=\"560\" height=\"314\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>If you're looking to learn more about how to optimize your content for Featured Snippets, HubSpot Research has a full research report: <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/winning-googles-featured-snippet\">HubSpot's Guide to Winning Google's Featured Snippet</a>&nbsp;and HubSpot Academy has a <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/seo-training\">free SEO course.</a></p> \n<p>Featured Snippets have been a bit of a mystery for a lot of people involved with SEO, as it&nbsp;hasn't&nbsp;been that easy to determine what influences getting your content&nbsp;to appear within them. Here's what we know for sure:</p> \n<h3>1. Target question-based queries.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.stonetemple.com/rich-answers-in-search/\">Stone Temple found</a> that from 850,000 question-based queries, 19% of them had a Featured Snippet.</p> \n<h3>2. You don't necessarily need to use schema.</h3> \n<p>There's been a lot of conflicting advice out there about markup for snippets, including the idea that <a href=\"https://schema.org/\" class=\"external-link\">Schema.org</a> data was the reason behind Google displaying this data. However, considering that more than 80% of the websites I've looked at that rank within the Featured Snippet don't use any kind of Schema.org markup data, it's safe to say that this isn't the case.</p> \n<p>Not only that but Gary Illyes, a Webmaster Trends Analyst at Google, has&nbsp;said outright that structured data <a href=\"https://www.seroundtable.com/google-structured-data-not-featured-snippets-21206.html\">has nothing to do</a> with ranking in the Featured Snippet.</p> \n<h3>3. Organize the structure of your pages with headings and paragraph tags.</h3> \n<p>Markup aside, a clear page structure seems to be important as well as the semantic relevance to the keyword in question.</p> \n<p>There should be an area on the page where the search query appears in a header (h2, h3, h4, etc.). The content you want to appear in the Featured Snippet should be placed in a &lt;p&gt; tag directly below the header.</p> \n<h3>4. For non question-based keywords, take a definition-style approach.</h3> \n<p>For shorter, less question-orientated keywords that display a Featured Snippet (e.g. \"Inbound Sales\"), it's much more likely that Google will pull through a paragraph of text. Google tends to prefer 'answers' that begin logically as an answer would.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Featued_snippet_example_1.png?width=669&amp;name=Featued_snippet_example_1.png\" alt=\"Featured Snippet Example\" title=\"Featured Snippet Example\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<h3>5. When applicable, include steps for solving a problem or answering the question.</h3> \n<p>Some answers require a more in-depth explanation, often involving a step-by-step process. Page structure is incredibly important here. Each step should be structured appropriately in a list format or represented on the page as heading (h3) tags.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Featured_snippet_example_4.png?width=669&amp;name=Featured_snippet_example_4.png\" alt=\"Featured Snippet Example\" title=\"Featured Snippet Example\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px;\"> \n<h3>6. The content should be between 54-58 words long.</h3> \n<p>For the paragraph-style answers (not the steps), content that's between 54-58 words long tends to perform the best.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Chart_-_Frequency_of_Featured_Snippet_Word_Count.png?width=669&amp;name=Chart_-_Frequency_of_Featured_Snippet_Word_Count.png\" alt=\"Chart: Frequency of Featured Snippet Word Count\" title=\"Chart: Frequency of Featured Snippet Word Count\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p>I extracted all of the content from within the Featured Snippets that I sampled. I did this to identify any trends in the content being displayed in order to better understand what Google is looking for.</p> \n<p><strong>As you can see, content between the length of 54-58 words in total seemed to appear by far the most frequently.</strong></p> \n<h3>7. Don't rule out an international approach.</h3> Featured Snippets for the same query often have different content within Google.com, Google.co.uk, Google.com.au, and Google.ie. Try \"how to search on Google\" as one of many examples.\n<br> \n<h3>8. Don't worry about backlinks as much for Featured Snippets.</h3> \n<p>During my analysis of 4,713 HubSpot queries for Featured Snippets, I uncovered something unusual, shown in the chart below.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Chart_-_Appearance_in_Featured_Snippet_vs_URL_Ranking.png?width=669&amp;name=Chart_-_Appearance_in_Featured_Snippet_vs_URL_Ranking.png\" alt=\"Chart: Appearance in Featured Snippet vs URL Ranking\" title=\"Chart: Appearance in Featured Snippet vs URL Ranking\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p>Allow me to explain what this chart is demonstrating:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The numbers (1–5) in the y-axis relate to the position on page one that a HubSpot URL ranks for a given query.</li> \n <li>For each position HubSpot&nbsp;ranks for, there is a bar that shows how often we appear&nbsp;in the Featured Snippet (blue) and how often we don't (orange).</li> \n</ul> \n<p>So, for keywords that we rank #1 for on page one in Google SERPs, we only appear in the Featured Snippet 18% of the time. Contrastingly, we appear in the Featured Snippet 28% of the time when we rank #5. Strange, right?</p> \n<p><strong>Well, what this says to us is that once you're in the top 5 results on page one, <a href=\"http://www.matthewbarby.com/link-building-2014/\">building backlinks</a> and other authority signals matter much&nbsp;less for ranking in the Featured Snippet</strong>.</p> \n<p>In fact, I've seen lots of occasions where relatively unknown websites with much less SEO authority than HubSpot have ranked above us, possibly due to more intentional use of page structure and other best practices described above.</p> \n<p>My advice for anyone looking to increase their visibility within the Featured Snippet box is to first run a quick audit of the keywords that you're ranking for within your current SEO campaign&nbsp;and how many of them are question-based queries.&nbsp;Once you've got this list, you can drill down on where you're currently ranking, how well your content is structured, and then devise a plan to reoptimize your content based on the advice I've given above.</p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-featured-snippet-box&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 17 Aug 2020 20:30:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"92eafffd810e3144787be9af5699a321","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"mbarby@hubspot.com (Matthew Howells-Barby)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how_to_make_bread_featured_snippet.png?width=669&name=how_to_make_bread_featured_snippet.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn76@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-22-181_cd3cd2578aa44907.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-paragraph.png?width=600&name=featured-snippet-paragraph.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn55@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-22-864_06af6695c48c4446.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-list.png?width=600&name=featured-snippet-list.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn70@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-26-502_0f39fe50ed7657fb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-table.jpg?width=600&name=featured-snippet-table.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn86@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-26-585_4e948cfc122b0cc4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-video.jpg?width=600&name=featured-snippet-video.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn90@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-21-523_124d025d7feee4e3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-accordion.jpg?width=600&name=featured-snippet-accordion.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn13@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-26-802_7c629c8acd17b366.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-rich-answer.jpg?width=600&name=featured-snippet-rich-answer.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn91@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-19-915_2cd3455224096a26.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-definition.png?width=600&name=featured-snippet-definition.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn24@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-28-816_1374081d7a96f5f2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/featured-snippet-tool.jpg?width=600&name=featured-snippet-tool.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn60@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-19-950_47d65c52174131ff.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Inbound_Marketing_Featured_Snippet.png?width=671&name=Inbound_Marketing_Featured_Snippet.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn69@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-24-022_b6559ccb3fe97782.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SERP_CTR_for_Featured_Snippet_vs_No_Featured_Snippet-1.png?width=669&name=SERP_CTR_for_Featured_Snippet_vs_No_Featured_Snippet-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-28-898_2ecb5b24a387e1bb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Featued_snippet_example_1.png?width=669&name=Featued_snippet_example_1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn99@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-21-606_cd8569ef3be88126.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Featured_snippet_example_4.png?width=669&name=Featured_snippet_example_4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-27-853_53753cda9db3ddae.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Chart_-_Frequency_of_Featured_Snippet_Word_Count.png?width=669&name=Chart_-_Frequency_of_Featured_Snippet_Word_Count.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn84@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-20-078_2670f21e5e6835cf.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Chart_-_Appearance_in_Featured_Snippet_vs_URL_Ranking.png?width=669&name=Chart_-_Appearance_in_Featured_Snippet_vs_URL_Ranking.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn86@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-24-114_2165960f72c81e29.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-featured-snippet-box&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn27@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-25-411_6ecb5cd9ca3467a2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336438},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"11 Ad Design Tips to Help Your Brand Cut Through the Noise","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ad-design","description":"<p>Before your copy can persuade an audience to buy your product, your design must persuade them to buy your copy. In advertising, your design catches your audience’s eye and points their attention to your copy. Then, it’s your copy’s job to hold your audience’s attention.</p>  \n<p>To help grab people’s attention in your advertisements, we’ve put together a list of seven ad tips, supported by examples, that’ll help give you ad design ideas to your brand cut through the noise.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>Advertisement Design Tips</h2> \n<p>Read on to learn how to craft creatively refreshing ads that will convert your audience into customers.</p> \n<h3>1. Stand out from the crowd.</h3> \n<div style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\">\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ad-tips-how-to-stand-out.jpg?width=600&amp;name=ad-tips-how-to-stand-out.jpg\" alt=\"Estee Lauder ad that is in black and white to stand out from the colorful magazine pages\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\">\n <a href=\"https://www.citizenwatch.com/us/en/eco-drive.html\">Image Source</a>\n</div> \n<p>In a world where countless brands fight for a limited amount of attention, the only way your advertisement can grab people’s attention is by being original.</p> \n<p>As a marketer, though, it can be tempting to leap onto the latest trend that all your competitors have already pounced on. If everyone else is implementing the latest tip or trick, it must work, right? To captivate an audience, though, you must resist this urge.</p> \n<p>Cliches repel attention. They sap your advertisement's creativity and <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/18/opinion/sunday/the-neuroscience-of-your-brain-on-fiction.html?pagewanted=all&amp;_r=0\">can’t activate the prefrontal cortex</a>, which is the part of the brain responsible for experiencing emotions. But how exactly do you create an original advertisement? Consider one of Estée Lauder’s print campaigns from the 1960s.</p> \n<p>Back then, Estée Lauder’s main competitors like L’Oréal, Revlon, and Helena Rubinstein all ran vibrant, colorful ads in magazines. Every makeup ad was beautiful and rich. But even though they seemed eye-popping at first glance, audiences became accustomed to these types of ads -- they all looked the same. They started blending in with each other.</p> \n<p>Realizing that no one could differentiate between the brands running full-color makeup ads flooding magazines during that time period anymore, Estée Lauder did something so controversial it was deemed “radical”, “stupid”, and even “ugly”: they ran their ads in sepia.</p> \n<p>Estée Lauder’s print advertising move received its fair share of criticism, but they’re ability to be original helped them immediately stand out from the crowd and rake in <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Breakthrough-Copywriter-Eugene-Schwartz-Advertising/dp/1387028081\">25% more responses</a> than their previous color print campaigns.</p> \n<h3>2. Focus on benefits and not just features.</h3> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 623px; max-height: 350px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.18%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/gEqN0t_NI14?autoplay=0&amp;fs=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;cc_load_policy=0&amp;start=0&amp;end=0&amp;origin=https://youtubeembedcode.com\" width=\"623\" height=\"350\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>A feature is an attribute or aspect of your business that distinguishes it from others in the space. Features are important for consumers as they compare providers and make purchasing decisions. However, in advertising, you are often marketing to a wide audience, many of whom may not be familiar with your organization or know they have need for your goods or services.</p> \n<p>For this reason, advertising features can be ineffective and overly salesy. The benefits of a product, on the other hand, can be far more persuasive and impressionable to a wide audience.</p> \n<p>Tide exhibits this idea well with their Superbowl commercial.</p> \n<p>They could have demonstrated the features of their product by showing a dirty shirt becoming clean again.</p> \n<p>Instead, they focus on the advantage: clean and crisp shirts.</p> \n<p>They even use a bit of humor while calling out this approach as #NotaTideAd.</p> \n<h3>3. Use humor.</h3> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 623px; max-height: 350px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.18%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/-pVnnGK6BP4?autoplay=0&amp;fs=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;cc_load_policy=0&amp;start=0&amp;end=0&amp;origin=https://youtubeembedcode.com\" width=\"623\" height=\"350\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Speaking of humor, it is an effective tool in advertising because it evokes positive emotion.</p> \n<p>The best thing advertising can do is make your solutions memorable. The second best thing it can do is associate that memory with positive emotions.</p> \n<p>Zola uses this in their wedding website ad. Weddings are already associated with love and happy times, but Zola differentiates their approach by flipping the script on audience expectation with a silly situation.</p> \n<p>Instead of imagining somber heartfelt \"I dos,\" the couple talks through logistics, which Zola can help with.</p> \n<h3>4. Convey one message — and one message only.</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/design-tips-simple-copy.jpg?width=600&amp;name=design-tips-simple-copy.jpg\" alt=\"Eco-Drive ad that reads &quot;A watch that never needs a battery&quot; alongside an image of a watch\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"><a href=\"https://www.citizenwatch.com/us/en/eco-drive.html\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Sometimes, marketers think the more benefits and features they include in their ads, the higher their conversion rate will be. But trying to read a jumbled ad requires a lot of thought and energy, so cramming an ad with a bricks of copy doesn’t actually grab people’s attention. It repels it.</p> \n<p>To immediately hook people and persuade them to read the rest of your ad, consider conveying one message per ad. Spotlighting your product or service’s main benefit or feature will make it easy for your audience to understand its value and increase the likelihood of doing business with you because they’ll leave your ad remembering only one message: your product’s or service’s main feature will benefit their lives somehow, someway.</p> \n<p>For example, in Citizen’s ad for their Eco-Drive watch, they only use a single line of copy and a simple image to convey their product’s value to their audience -- a watch that never needs a battery.</p> \n<h3>5. Make it visual.</h3> \n<div style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\">\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/visual-best-practices-for-ads.jpg?width=600&amp;name=visual-best-practices-for-ads.jpg\" alt=\"a lego ad that displays a t-rex in the shadow of a blocky lego shape\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\">\n <a href=\"https://mymodernmet.com/creative-ads-lego-the-shadow/\">Image Source</a>\n</div> \n<p>When we were babies, we relied on vision to associate objects with behaviors, like a ball meaning play time. Vision was the only way to learn about the world.</p> \n<p>That’s why you can understand visual information in <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/learn/visual-marketing/\">250 milliseconds and why your visual system activates over 50% of your brain</a>. Visual storytelling is the best way for people to grasp concepts and data easily.</p> \n<p>For instance, in LEGO’s ad, they only use two images, a simple lego creation and a shadow of a dinosaur, but you can instantly form a concrete understanding of its core idea -- with Legos, you can create anything.</p> \n<h3>6. Know your market.</h3> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fpopfitclothing%2Fvideos%2F424148705066611%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=476\" width=\"476\" height=\"476\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n<p>You can't hope to capture your audience's attention if you don't know who they are.</p> \n<p>Pop Fit is a leggings company that makes apparel for all sizes and body shapes. A good portion of their target audience is women who are rarely represented by models, particularly in the health and wellness space, and have difficulty finding athletic wear. For these women, an ad that shows people who look like them is a show stopper.</p> \n<h3>7. Leverage hyperbole.</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pasted%20image%200-25.png?width=450&amp;name=pasted%20image%200-25.png\" alt=\"Nikol Paper Towels Ad that shows dried grapes, implying it sucked the moisture out of them to turn them into raisins\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6489808059668537344\" style=\"font-size: 1em;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Exaggerating your product’s benefits, in a clever and obvious way, is one of the best methods for slipping some humor into your advertisement, which can capture your audience’s attention and trigger an emotional response from them.</p> \n<p>For instance, Nikol’s paper towels obviously can’t turn grapes into raisins, but this ad highlights the product's absorbent powers in such a clear and artful way, they didn’t need to write a single line of copy.</p> \n<h3>8. Show, don't tell.</h3> \n<div style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\">\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ad-tips-show-don't-tell.jpg?width=600&amp;name=ad-tips-show-don't-tell.jpg\" alt=\"siemens ad that shows washing machines in a library\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\">\n <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6490261063861440512/\">Image Source</a>\n</div> \n<p>Showing your audience something is much more engaging and interesting than telling them it. Relying on implication to convey a message is mysterious, making it more fun for your audience to figure out.</p> \n<p>For example, in Siemens’ creative ad, they show the benefits of their product by unexpectedly placing their washers and dryers in a library to show you that they’re so quiet, even a librarian wouldn’t need to shush them.</p> \n<h3>9. Swap connotations.</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1em;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(1)-9.png?width=328&amp;name=pasted%20image%200%20(1)-9.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 328px;\" alt=\"heinz ad that shows someone holding the ketchup bottle with an oven mitt\" width=\"328\"></em><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6489147159219441664/\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>In relation to food, the word “hot” has multiple meanings: having a high temperature and being spicy. Heinz brilliantly used the connotation of high temperature to highlight the spiciness of their ketchup, and their creative method of communicating the value of their product helped them instantly attract people’s attention.</p> \n<h3>10. Be authentic.</h3> \n<p>Planet Fitness is a brand that has long worked to make fitness less scary and more accessible to people, as evidenced by their \"judgment-free zone\" policies.</p> \n<p>Part of that mission means encouraging people to be themselves. True to form, as many of their facilities open with new sanitizing procedures, they released this video ad announcing their policies. In it, Planet Fitness employees dance with inhibition. This fun and authentic ad supports who Planet Fitness is as a company.</p> \n<h3>11. Turn your ad into a game.</h3> \n<div style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\">\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gamification-of-ads.png?width=444&amp;name=gamification-of-ads.png\" alt=\"Mazda ad that shows a car in a video game environment\" width=\"444\" style=\"width: 444px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n <a href=\"https://www.digitaland.tv/blog/7-gamified-banner-ads-taking-display-advertising-to-a-whole-new-level/\">Image Source</a>\n</div> \n<p>The brain is wired to predict things. It’s an evolutionary trait that allows us to anticipate what’s going to happen next and quickly react to it. That said, advertisements that are predictable only require a shred of thought to understand, so they’re too easy to grasp and, in turn, too boring to engage anyone.</p> \n<p>With this in mind, if you can scrap predictability from your advertisements, you force your audience into a deeper level of thinking to digest your message, compelling them to pay more attention to it.</p> \n<p>One of the best ways to ensnare your audience attention and get them to interact with your advertisement is by turning it into a game. By framing your advertisement like a game that can be beat, just like Mazda’s ad, above, your audience has the opportunity to earn an intellectual reward if they spend just the right amount of mental energy playing your brand’s game and grasping your advertisement's message, which is something most people won’t ever pass up.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a></h3> \n<p>Canva is one of the premier free design platforms, available on both desktop and via a robust mobile app.</p> \n<p>As an online ad maker, Canva provides a large library of pre-designed templates, 1 million stock images, and drag-and-drop design building. It can also <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/cms/canva-205937?_ga=2.251620806.1542171071.1595616247-385841540.1575822951\">integrate with HubSpot</a> so that you can access Canva directly within the CMS.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.designwizard.com/\">DesignWizard </a></h3> \n<p>DesignWizard is another great option with integration capability. With pre-made templates across multiple sizes and dimensions, you'll find attractive designs for any need — print and digital. Unlike other online ad makers, Design Wizard also offers free easy resizing so you can quickly create across multiple formats with less hassle.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.bannersnack.com/\">Bannersnack</a></h3> \n<p>If you're creating ads for PPC display campaigns, Bannersnack is a must. Since display ads come in so many shapes and sizes, Bannersnack allows you to create one ad and then generate several more based on the original design but with different dimensions, taking \"resizing\" features to another level. The only downside is that the free plan limits the number of designs you can create. However, the premium upgrade is reasonably priced.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.visme.co/\">Visme </a></h3> \n<p>Step up your social ads game by tapping into Visme's library of templates for ads and posts for:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Facebook</li> \n <li>Twitter</li> \n <li>Pinterest</li> \n <li>Instagram</li> \n <li>YouTube</li> \n <li>Linkedin</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Pick from millions of free photos, icons, shapes, and animations to convey what your brand has to say.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://snappa.com/\">Snappa </a></h3> \n<p>If you've ever struggled to remove a background from a brand photo in an expensive photo editor, you'll be relieved to know that Snappa can do it in one click.</p> \n<p>Add this capability to a library of templates, 3 million quality stock photos, 100,000 shapes, and over 200 fonts — you're on your way to unhampered creativity.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://www.lucidpress.com/pages/\">Lucidpress</a></h3> \n<p>Lucidpress is one of the more versatile platforms on this list, with capabilities ranging from graphic ad design to asset management and direct mail. The free version does limit functionality and the number of designs, though, but Lucidpress's design environment includes layouts for every type of print and digital use possible from social media ads to flyers and coupons.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://bannerboo.com/\">BannerBoo</a></h3> \n<p>BannerBoo is unique in that you can make animated banner ads with their easy-to-use HTML5 ad builder. All ads are responsive, and you can choose from their library of animation effects and transitions. The free plan does contain a watermark, however.</p> \n<p>With the inspiration from this list and tools that can help you create amazing ads, there's nothing stopping you from creating an advertising plan that will help you drive brand awareness and generate revenue for your business.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fad-design&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\"
