\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 21 Aug 2020 20:30:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"2fdac416aa260b18c371ea516fc27775","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ad-tips-how-to-stand-out.jpg?width=600&name=ad-tips-how-to-stand-out.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn100@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-37-509_393dda8467a8fe95.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/design-tips-simple-copy.jpg?width=600&name=design-tips-simple-copy.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn34@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-27-211_5b40d9978074b727.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/visual-best-practices-for-ads.jpg?width=600&name=visual-best-practices-for-ads.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn48@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-20-089_1d0fd94f5ab4fc65.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pasted%20image%200-25.png?width=450&name=pasted%20image%200-25.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-20-092_071c34780ac754c6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ad-tips-show-don't-tell.jpg?width=600&name=ad-tips-show-don't-tell.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-22-924_83689df78d0b5205.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(1)-9.png?width=328&name=pasted%20image%200%20(1)-9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn13@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-25-217_aa624a94d25f04e5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gamification-of-ads.png?width=444&name=gamification-of-ads.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-22-267_4eb89875de5cc616.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fad-design&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn81@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-20-942_46710b9514375dc6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336437},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"Writing for SEO: How to Write Blogs That Rank on Page 1 of Google","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-for-seo","description":"<p>If you've ever written a blog post before, you know how much time they can take.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>From topic selection, to gathering research, to writing the post and pressing \"Publish,\" the process often demands hours.</p> \n<p>That's why, if your post <em>doesn't</em> earn the traffic you expected, it can be a major letdown. All that work that goes into a post for less-than-stellar engagement is, no doubt, one of the most frustrating experiences.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there's a way to combat low traffic and bring eyes to your writing: search engine optimization. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo\"><span>SEO</span></a> is a language that speaks specifically to search engines like Google to tell it your post deserves to be at the top of search engine results pages (SERPs).</p> \n<p>As marketers, we're always aiming to write content that'll rank highly on Google, and SEO is the bridge that'll help you get there.</p> \n<p>Of course, that begs the question: How do you write in SEO's language?</p> \n<p>For that, don't worry — we've got you covered. In this post, we're going to dive into 13 ways you can master writing for that high ranking your content deserves.</p> \n<p>Ready to get started?</p> \n<h3>1. Use headings to your benefit.</h3> \n<p>Headers tell Google what different sections of your blog article will be about. In this post, for example, the header, \"How To Write Blog Posts for SEO,\" tells the search engine what this section is about.</p> \n<p>Users who type search queries like, \"writing for SEO\" into Google will likely come across this post because of what the header tells Google. Ultimately, search engines are going to look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-search-engine-optimization?_ga=2.256326411.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>headers and snippets before they look at body text</span></a>.</p> \n<p>Think of Google as a reader who is skimming your blog. They're going to focus on the main ideas — and that's what headers, like H2s and H3s, display. Use headers to accurately convey the main idea of your section, but make sure each header uses accurate, high-intent keywords. When you use the right keywords (using <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/22842/4-helpful-tools-for-identifying-the-right-keywords.aspx?_ga=2.256326411.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>keyword research tools</span></a>) you have a much higher chance of helping your post rank on the first page.</p> \n<h3>2. Take advantage of featured snippets.</h3> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/9351707?p=featured_snippets&amp;hl=en&amp;visit_id=637322668994927457-279137339&amp;rd=1\"><span>Google</span></a>, \"Featured snippets come from web search listings. Google's automated systems determine whether a page would make a good featured snippet to highlight for a specific search request.\"</p> \n<p>Featured snippets on Google are the most direct answers to search queries. For instance, if I were to search, \"How do you write a blog post?\", Google might use a featured snippet to show the most sufficient answer:</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/jkrLX_FCneOwRvR527KfiHOfFW4ZYp15QeyUkS8X363Wr52Q5NKHlUw2JCvyFVAGwgi7k5CTIka7eKnNWO7XNaIHBbzMknV1lBsQCiE5ogQZdW0Yw0y1EGJbrB58OcHM8C1tY8IE\" width=\"624\" height=\"436\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Example of a featured snippet on Google.\" /></span></p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-featured-snippet-box?_ga=2.256326411.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>To earn a featured snippet</span></a> on Google, you'll want to answer the questions readers might have when they come to your blog post. For instance, if the search term is \"how should I write a blog post?\", answer that question with a list, starting with \"How to Write A Blog Post\" as the header, accompanied by a list of items that are relevant and actionable.</p> \n<p>If you're wondering how to make list items actionable, a good rule of thumb is to write complete sentences and start each sentence with a verb, like \"Write\", \"Research\", \"Create\". Additionally, make sure each sentence answers the question or challenge. For definitions, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/winning-googles-featured-snippet?_ga=2.210163477.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>paragraph snippets</span></a>, make sure they're succinct, but give enough background to explain the word or phrase.</p> \n<h3>3. Write to answer questions for customers.</h3> \n<p>One of the reasons we write blog posts is to diversify the content on our website. Another reason is to boost the credibility of our business. But if \"to solve for your audience\" isn't in your list of reasons, you may be losing out on key SEO opportunities.</p> \n<p>Google answers countless questions a day. For instance, I must've Googled about five questions in the last hour alone. When you frame posts to answer the queries of your audience, Google will see that and push your post to a higher page.</p> \n<p>Earlier, we talked about the bells and whistles you can add to posts to boost rankings. But, additionally, you'll want to ensure the content you're beefing up is also working towards that goal.</p> \n<p>If you're stuck on trying to figure out what your audience is asking, you'll want to perform keyword research. Sites like <a href=\"http://ahrefs.com/\"><span>Ahrefs</span></a> and <a href=\"http://woorank.com/\"><span>Woorank</span></a> crawl search engines for popular search queries. To organize the process, create different topic clusters to write about, such as \"Instagram Marketing,\" \"LinkedIn Advertising\" — subjects you can dive into that provide value to your audience.</p> \n<p>Still stuck on keywords? Don't worry — this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht?_ga=2.210163477.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>keyword research guide is perfect for beginners.</span></a></p> \n<h3>4. Use meta descriptions to your advantage.</h3> \n<p>Are you adding meta descriptions to your post? If your answer is \"No,\" then you're probably not giving your post the most exposure possible. Let's get into why they're important.</p> \n<p>By now, we've talked about a couple of the ways a blog post can communicate with Google: with headers, keywords, and snippets. However, that's not an exhaustive list.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/meta-descriptions?_ga=2.210163477.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>Meta descriptions</span></a> is another method Google leverages when ranking search results. Meta descriptions are the 1-3 sentence descriptions you'll find underneath the title of a result.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/SthW36UwXSSgw6xA9MsSlcduXxbbMVKP3QpXTdUdc1KGMa4pqGAvSipqTkuL-TZICne4Dr-WXlVVEDagqYlDYavLLIPJEzesocOU6Gy9_qEHPbWEGmvwB6vIZJmd5zRmxy0YbxCg\" width=\"624\" height=\"227\" alt=\"Example of a meta description on Google.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" /></span></p> \n<p>Use meta descriptions to sum up what your post is about. Remember to keep it short, use keywords, and make sure it's engaging. After all, there are going to be loads of posts similar to yours, aiming to rank at #1. You're going to want yours to stand out above the rest.</p> \n<p>Most blogging software have meta description boxes built into the toolbar or post formatting options, so you won't have to look far to use the function. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/?_ga=2.216912790.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>HubSpot</span></a> and <a href=\"https://wordpress.com/\"><span>WordPress</span></a>, for example, point out where to add meta descriptions in the post editor.</p> \n<h3>5. Add alt text to images.</h3> \n<p>With any image you add to your post — whether it be the featured image or a body text one — you'll want to add alt text. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32567/a-marketer-s-guide-to-optimizing-images-for-google-search.aspx?_ga=2.216912790.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>Alt text describes what's happening</span></a> in the photo. Think of it as a closed caption for images.</p> \n<p>Alt text helps Google, as well as those who are visually impaired, understand why the photo is in your post. This improves your article's rank and accessibility, making it more shareable.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you include an infographic about audience segmentation, the alt text should read something like, \"A helpful infographic that explains audience segmentation.\" Notice how this sentence uses keywords to appeal to Google even further.</p> \n<p>Now let's say you're using a stock image as a featured photo, but it doesn't necessarily depict anything that relates to your post's content. For instance, let's say your topic is click-through rate, and this is your featured image:</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/2jNZPSwpDQmCpp93qSsfmJzrztmQR8rQSjoBxLZDUz6vQLjPKBNCkbd2_njQNqt5lVzCZPFEV70MJmreYxiRHjUSU8yFvmJI6ZIhHHe1Kt5gKjwFk6ZbBvVM1-rC_pfTdREJUSih\" width=\"624\" height=\"416\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"A marketing team discusses audience segmentation strategy.\" /></span></p> \n<p>This doesn't really have anything to do with audience segments, right? But what you can do to remedy the situation is to make a scenario. For instance, \"A marketing team discusses audience segmentation strategy.\"</p> \n<p>This alt text uses keywords to describe a situation that fits into the theme of the post. That way, your image doesn't bring down the ranking of your post, but works towards improving where it ranks. If Google sees alt text, it's another box checked for a high position on SERPs.</p> \n<h3>6. Don't limit keywords to the body of your post.</h3> \n<p>Ultimately, keywords should be used in nearly every part of your blog. We've talked a little about where keywords can be included in your post: snippets, photos, and headers, for example.</p> \n<p>Keywords are so powerful because they're the jumping off point for SERPs. Google will always take what browsers type into the search bar and search for web pages with those exact words. So it's important to make sure every element, from the post title, to the calls-to-action, relate to your keywords.</p> \n<p>That said, it's also important not to keyword stuff your post. The goal is to make your page fully optimized, not overbearing. Find natural fits for keyword additions, but don't force them so your content is illegible.</p> \n<p>For example, if your keywords are \"account based marketing,\" \"startups,\" and \"sales,\" your meta description <em>shouldn't</em> be something like:</p> \n<p>\"Sales for account based marketing startups.\"</p> \n<p>Instead, try focusing on one or two phrases to make the description more natural:</p> \n<p>\"Are you looking for killer strategies to boost your account-based marketing game? Find out our surefire secrets in this post.\"</p> \n<p>That way, you're still using keywords, but you're not oversaturating the post to the point where it's illegible. Remember, even though Google is a search engine, it still has to comprehend your post in order to recommend it to website browsers. Additionally, a reader's experience will determine how well your posts rank. If readers bounce from your webpage because it's confusing to them, that will signal to Google that your post isn't good enough to rank.</p> \n<h3>7. Identify highly-effective keywords when looking for post ideas.</h3> \n<p>Google handles <a href=\"http://www.internetlivestats.com/google-search-statistics/\">over 40,000 search queries</a> a second. Staggering, right? If you want to cut through search result clutter and outrank your competitors, you need to target the specific keywords and phrases your potential customers are searching. How else will they find your content and website?</p> \n<p>To identify those hot keywords, head on over to the social platforms your target audience frequents and see what’s trending. Pay close attention to the exact phrases they use and monitor popular industry terms and topics.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.google.com/trends/\">Google Trends</a> can also give you a feel for what keywords are popular at any given time. If you see searches are steadily declining over time for a specific keyword, you know that’s probably not the right keyword to target for your marketing and vice versa for increasing trends.</p> \n<p>If you’re ever running low on keyword ideas, get inspiration from your competition. Use tools to see what keywords they’re currently ranking for — if these keywords are relevant to your business, consider using them too! <a href=\"https://www.semrush.com/\">SEMRush</a> lets you enter a competitor and see the keywords they’re ranking for, their position in search results, traffic received for that keyword and other key metrics.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that the most obvious keywords aren’t always the best keywords. Searchers tend to use very specific “long-tail” keywords, keyword phrases and questions when they’re looking for something.</p> \n<p>Long-tail keywords comprise up to <a href=\"https://www.hittail.com/blog/the-hidden-value-of-long-tail-seo\">70% of all search traffic</a> and can unlock the door to successful SEO. When <a href=\"http://www.wpbeginner.com/\">WPBeginner</a>, the largest WordPress resource site for WordPress beginners, adopted a long-tail SEO strategy, they increased their organic search traffic by <a href=\"http://www.wpbeginner.com/wp-tutorials/how-we-increased-our-organic-search-traffic-by-using-hittail/\">20% in just two months</a>!</p> \n<p>Because you face fierce competition for shorter, more general keywords, you often have a better chance of ranking in the top results for long-tail keywords. And, long-tail keywords allow you to zero in on higher quality website traffic that often knows what they’re looking for and may be farther along in the buyer’s journey.</p> \n<p>Once you’ve done your research and built a list of what you think are the most valuable, relevant keywords, plug them into a keyword research tool like Google’s <a href=\"https://adwords.google.com/KeywordPlanner\">Keyword Planner</a>, <a href=\"https://moz.com/products/pro/keyword-explorer\">Moz’s Keyword Explorer</a>, <a href=\"https://keywordseverywhere.com/ubersuggest.html\">Ubersuggest</a>, <a href=\"http://keywordtool.io/\">Keyword Tool</a> and so on. Many keyword research tools give you the monthly volume for any given keyword. Test out different keyword tools — marketers are drawn to different ones for different reasons.</p> \n<p>Depending on your business or industry (or budget or bandwidth for SEO efforts), it may be important to rank for high competition, short tail keywords. Still, try to also optimize for a healthy dose of long-tail keywords that are high in search volume but low in competition. You may find it’s much easier to rank for these words.</p> \n<p>Remember that your focus keywords will evolve over time as trends shift, terminology changes or your product/service line changes. Be sure to conduct keyword research periodically to ensure you’re still focusing on the right keywords for your target audience and not missing out on vital ranking opportunities.</p> \n<h3>8. Naturally integrate those keywords throughout your posts.</h3> \n<p>Once you’ve decided on a list of target keywords, it’s time to write a blog post focused on one of these keywords. Brainstorm blog topics with your team and decide on a topic that will entice and engage your target audience.</p> \n<p>Keep your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33491/Everything-Marketers-Need-to-Research-Create-Detailed-Buyer-Personas-Template.aspx\">buyer personas</a>, their motivations, challenges, interests, etc. in mind throughout the brainstorming process. Choose a topic that will <a href=\"http://experience.stratusinteractive.com/blog/how-to-create-an-emotional-connection-with-prospects-to-turn-them-into-customers\">emotionally resonate</a> with your potential customers and their needs, desires or pains.</p> \n<p>As you write your blog, your keyword and natural variations should be regularly interspersed throughout the post. Your primary keyword should appear in these key places:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-for-seo#BlogPostTitle\">Title</a></li> \n <li>Headings and subheadings</li> \n <li>URL if possible</li> \n <li>Image alt text (search engines can’t read images)</li> \n <li>Meta description</li> \n <li>Throughout the content</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Remember that you’re writing for humans, not search engines. Focus on engaging readers with a natural writing style that takes their needs and interests into account.</p> \n<h3>9. Link to influential websites.</h3> \n<p>As you build out your blog post, don’t be afraid to link to other articles or blogs.</p> \n<p>Linking to applicable and reputable websites not only offers blog readers additional reading material to expand their knowledge, but it also shows Google and other search engines that you’ve done your research. And the blogger or writer may even return the favor and link to your site.</p> \n<p>Nothing strengthens a blog post like hard-to-argue-with, research-backed statistics from influential websites. Compelling stats help you build a more convincing and concrete argument that will get your readers thinking (especially when they’re from trustworthy sites they know and love).</p> \n<h3>10. Aim for scannable, longer posts.</h3> \n<p>In an age of short attention spans (<a href=\"http://time.com/3858309/attention-spans-goldfish/\">average of 8 seconds for humans</a>), you would think shorter blog posts are the way to go. But search engines actually prefer longer, in-depth blog posts.</p> \n<p>The longer your blog post, the greater its chance of appearing in the top search engine results. <a href=\"http://blog.serpiq.com/how-important-is-content-length-why-data-driven-seo-trumps-guru-opinions/\">SerpIQ found</a> that the 10th position pages have 400 fewer words than 1st position pages. Longer posts will rank more easily for your target keyword.</p> \n<p>Think about it: the more content on the page, the more clues search engines have to figure out what your blog is about. We recommend writing a minimum of <a href=\"https://yoast.com/blog-post-length/\">300 words per blog post</a>. This length gives search engines plenty of keywords and text to crawl and helps them understand what your blog is about.</p> \n<p>The downside to longer blogs is that they may scare off your readers. We live in a world of skimmers and scanners. In a heat map analysis, CoSchedule learned that <a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/read-your-content/\">only 10-20% of their readers</a> were making it to the bottom of their posts. So, the million dollar question is, how can longer blog posts appeal to today’s online readers?</p> \n<p>You can write <a href=\"http://experience.stratusinteractive.com/blog/scannable-content-your-key-to-writing-successful-blogs\">scannable</a>, readable blog posts that hook online readers by tightening up your sentences and paragraphs. Turn a long-winded sentence into two. Keep your paragraphs to 2-3 sentences max.</p> \n<p>Also, take full advantage of bulleted lists and subheadings that grab reader’s attention. By following these tactics, you’ll create blogs that are easier to read (especially on a mobile device!) and less intimidating to the scanner’s eye.</p> \n<h3>11. Internally link words or phrases to other posts on your site.</h3> \n<p>Linking to other pages or blog posts on your website helps search engines crawl your website and create a more accurate sitemap. It also helps your audience discover more of your content and get to know you as a trustworthy, credible source of information.</p> \n<p>Internal links to other valuable content keep users on your site longer, reducing bounce rate and increasing your potential for a conversion (and isn’t that what it’s all about?).</p> \n<p>When linking to any pages on your website, or even outside sources, use natural language for your anchor text. Avoid using spammy or generic text such as “top-rated cheap laptops” or “click here.”</p> \n<p>Instead, use descriptive keywords that give readers a sense of what they will find when they click on the hyperlink, such as a <a href=\"http://hubs.ly/H05xGXn0\">search engine optimization guide</a>.</p> \n<p>Never force feed links to your top webpages, featured products or discounted items. These types of links will only turn off readers and could lead to search engines penalizing your website.</p> \n<p>A word of caution: don’t overdo your internal linking or any linking. We know it’s tempting to link to all of your blogs and webpages, but only choose the ones that best enhance the point or insight you’re writing about in any particular blog. Always think about whether or not these links naturally tie in with the subject matter and if they will offer significant value to your readers.</p> \n<h3>12. Optimize pictures for the fastest possible page speed.</h3> \n<p>Google <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">rewards pages with faster page speed </a>and places those that lag lower on its rankings. So, it's important to make sure your page-load times are as quick as possible.</p> \n<p>One of the leading culprits of page lag is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">large photos</a>. If the photo you uploaded is too big, it will make the page take a longer time to load -- even if the image <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">doesn't seem huge on screen</a>. Luckily, you can keep your posts visually interesting without sacrificing crucial speed.</p> \n<p>Once you pick a photo, use a free compression software, like Squoosh.app to make it as small as it can go before it loses any quality. Any removal of excess photo data will speed up loading times so readers won't have to wait.</p> \n<p>If you suspect that your SEO issues are related to low page speeds, Google offers a free tool that can score your page and give you suggestions for speed improvement. Here's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">a guide on how to use it and boost your score</a>.</p> \n<h3>7. Preform link building strategies.</h3> \n<p>Traffic from places other than Google is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/link-building-software\">crucial to your search rankings</a>. Why? Think of search results like a competition where the winners get the most votes. Each webpage that links back to you is considered a \"vote\" for your website, which makes your content more trustworthy in the eyes of Google. In turn, this will make you rise farther up on search results.</p> \n<p>So, it's good to write posts that other websites or publications will want to hyperlink within their own posts. You can also write posts on other business' websites that link back to your website in some way.</p> \n<p>To make your website's blogpost more linkable, include valuable assets or information, such as your own data, original thoughts, infographics, definitions, or other facts that people might not find anywhere else.</p> \n<p>Here's an example of how this mindset could help you. If you write a post titled \"How to Make a Video Tutorial,\" or \"13 Stats about Video Tutorials,\" bigger sites that are writing about something similar might hyperlink words like \"video tutorials\" or \"research from [Your Company Name]\" to your post so they can give their reader more context without repeating your work.</p> \n<p>Once you've written the post, you might want to start sending it to other publications or websites that might want to discuss it or link it to their other posts. This outreach lets other publications know of the post and might also help you grow link building alliances with them in the future.</p> \n<p>You can also consider doing promotion, such as interviews or guest posts that link to your website's blog post to further encourage link building.</p> \n<p>These strategies can be key to your SEO success, but they can be time consuming. To help you, consider trying out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/link-building-software?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Daily%20Emails&amp;utm_source=hs_email&amp;utm_medium=email\">one of these softwares</a>.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Title Blog Posts for SEO</h2> \n<p>Even with a great, SEO-friendly post body, a bad title could hurt you in search engines. To title your post with SEO in mind, draft a clear understandable title that both shows the reader what they're about to read and integrates the keywords you identified in the first step. As mentioned above, write something that pleases Google's ranking algorithms, but is also understandable and enticing to humans.</p> \n<p>Here are a few examples:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>If you're a beauty blogger and you see that people are searching \"how to wear matte lipstick,\" your post could be titled, \"How to Wear Matte Lipstick: A 5-Step Guide.\"</li> \n <li>On the other hand, if your blog covers artificial intelligence and you see that people are searching a new AI app, you could write a blog post called \"How to Use [Insert AI App Name],\" or \"We Tried the New [Insert App Name] App: Here's What Happened\"</li> \n <li>If you blog about farming or sustainability and find out that \"what to buy at farm stands\" is a regular search, you might write a listicle titled \"What to Buy at Farm Stands This Summer.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You know how to write content audiences will love. Now, it's time to write for what Google loves. SEO only heightens the chance of your post getting seen by the right audiences, expanding your reach.</p> \n<p>It can sound tricky at first, writing for two audiences, but just remember these takeaways: keywords, snippets, and descriptions. Learning a new language takes time, but luckily, your blogging software can likely remind you of these SEO tips. I can't wait to see your next blog post at the top of my search results.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fblogging-for-seo&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 19:34:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/jkrLX_FCneOwRvR527KfiHOfFW4ZYp15QeyUkS8X363Wr52Q5NKHlUw2JCvyFVAGwgi7k5CTIka7eKnNWO7XNaIHBbzMknV1lBsQCiE5ogQZdW0Yw0y1EGJbrB58OcHM8C1tY8IE","linkMd5":"09d376dc66fa9d912ba8e5b0b85f7658","sourceBytes":0,"destBytes":0,"author":"Courtney Feairheller","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/jkrLX_FCneOwRvR527KfiHOfFW4ZYp15QeyUkS8X363Wr52Q5NKHlUw2JCvyFVAGwgi7k5CTIka7eKnNWO7XNaIHBbzMknV1lBsQCiE5ogQZdW0Yw0y1EGJbrB58OcHM8C1tY8IE":null,"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/SthW36UwXSSgw6xA9MsSlcduXxbbMVKP3QpXTdUdc1KGMa4pqGAvSipqTkuL-TZICne4Dr-WXlVVEDagqYlDYavLLIPJEzesocOU6Gy9_qEHPbWEGmvwB6vIZJmd5zRmxy0YbxCg":null,"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/2jNZPSwpDQmCpp93qSsfmJzrztmQR8rQSjoBxLZDUz6vQLjPKBNCkbd2_njQNqt5lVzCZPFEV70MJmreYxiRHjUSU8yFvmJI6ZIhHHe1Kt5gKjwFk6ZbBvVM1-rC_pfTdREJUSih":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fblogging-for-seo&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn74@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-23-046_8f71651f20b60f93.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336432},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"The Social Media Content Calendar Template Every Marketer Needs [Free Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx","description":"<p>\"We have a 9 a.m. meeting? Hold on -- let me just click around the internet like a maniac to find something for the morning tweet.\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Sound familiar? Scrambling for social content is nothing new. We have meetings. We run late. Things come up. And it's really hard to get any meaningful amount of work done when you have the next social media update looming over your head every 30, 60, or 90 minutes.&nbsp;It all&nbsp;moves so fast that you might periodically feel a case of the vapors coming on, which is why pre-scheduled social media content should be your new best friend.<strong><br /></strong></p> \n<p>To make social media content easier for companies to plan and schedule across the accounts they manage, we created a <strong><a title=\"templated schedule\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\">social&nbsp;media&nbsp;content calendar template</a></strong><a title=\"templated schedule\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\"></a>. And recently,&nbsp;we updated&nbsp;to be better, faster, stronger, and just generally prettier.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>But first...</p> \n<h2>What is a content calendar?</h2> \n<p>A content calendar organizes your publishing schedule by date so that you can keep track of deadlines, better manage your content creation team, and create transparency with all parties.</p> \n<h3>What's in this content calendar template?</h3> \n<p>Every content calendar is different and should be adjusted for your unique process. However, in this one, you'll find a general schedule tab, your monthly planning calendar, a repository for website content, and updates for each of the top social media platforms:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#twitter\">Twitter</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#facebook\">Facebook</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#linkedin\">LinkedIn</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#instagram\">Instagram</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#pinterest\">Pinterest</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>This blog post will walk you through exactly how to use the template to stay on top of your social media content planning for each one.</p> \n<p><em><strong>Note:</strong> HubSpot customers can also schedule content through <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/social-inbox\">Social Inbox</a>, or use this spreadsheet to organize their content and subsequently upload it to Social Inbox. Detailed instructions for doing this exist in <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\">the cover sheet of the template</a>.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"></p> \n<h2>How to Use the Social Media&nbsp;Calendar Template to Plan Your&nbsp;Content Schedule</h2> \n<p>When&nbsp;you <a title=\"open up the social media publishing template\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\">open up the social media content calendar&nbsp;template</a>, you'll notice the bottom of the Excel spreadsheet has several different tabs, most of which are dedicated to a specific social network.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/content-calendar-excel-tabs.jpg?width=1362&amp;name=content-calendar-excel-tabs.jpg\" alt=\"content calendar excel tabs: schedule, monthly planning calendar, content repository, twitter updates, facebook updates, linkedin updates, instagram updates, pinterest updates\" width=\"1362\" style=\"width: 1362px;\" /></p> \n<p>The reason you'll want a different worksheet for every social network is simply that every social network is a little bit different.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-perfect-social-media-posts-slideshare\">You can't just craft one, single social media update</a> and use it across LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Pinterest.</p> \n<p>You can certainly promote the same piece of content across those networks, but that doesn't mean you'll craft your update in the same way for every single one of them. (In fact, you may even want to add additional tabs if you're active on other networks, like Quora or YouTube.)</p> \n<p>This following sub-sections will walk you through how to fill out each of the tabs you see in this template -- the updates for Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, Instagram, and Pinterest. But before we get to that, let's just walk through the \"Monthly Planning Calendar\" so you know what that's for.</p> \n<h3>Monthly Social Media&nbsp;Schedule&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>The tab \"Monthly Planning Calendar\" provides an overall snapshot of your monthly social media campaigns. It'll help you coordinate better with other stakeholders, not to mention keep all the moving parts straight in your own mind. Here's what it looks like:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-month-view.png?width=669&amp;height=388&amp;name=social-media-calendar-month-view.png\" title=\"social-media-calendar-month-view.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"388\" alt=\"social media content calendar month view with colored cells for each content type\" /></p> \n<p>There are three sections to take note of when you edit this template for your own purposes. First, the color-coding key: These are the types of content or campaigns around which you might coordinate, like ebooks, webinars, blog posts, product launches, and so on. Though only some of these might be relevant to you, they're there to indicate what you may want to put in there -- so be sure to edit these categories to align with your own campaigns.</p> \n<p>The other two sections you'll need to edit are the Month and Year at the top of the calendar (duh), as well as the cells below each day of the week. In those cells, you should&nbsp;enter&nbsp;the type of content you'll be promoting that day and color-code it to align with the campaign it's supporting.</p> \n<p>Instead of deleting all the content in this spreadsheet each month, I recommend copying this worksheet twelve times over, and creating a separate sheet for each month. (If that gets to be too overwhelming, you can always save those tabs as a separate file.)</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Twitter Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>Alright, now let's get to the social media content. This section will be the lengthiest, because all subsequent sections will draw on the instructions we go through here. So if you read one section in this whole post, make it&nbsp;this one.</p> \n<p>Let's say you want to add some tweets&nbsp;to your scheduling template.&nbsp;Skip over to the \"Twitter Updates\" tab, where you'll see this:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=296&amp;name=social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Twitter content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"296\" /></p> \n<p>The first four columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" \"Time,\" and \"Date &amp; Time\" are there for your convenience, and if you choose to use a third-party app for pre-scheduling your tweets (like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/social-inbox\">HubSpot's Social Inbox</a>), then these columns will be useful.&nbsp;For now, just fill in the date on which you'd like your updates to publish to Twitter, and the time at which you'd like them to go out. The \"Date &amp; Time\" column will automatically change based on what you input in the previous two columns.</p> \n<p>Now, let's move over to the \"Message\" column. Here,&nbsp;input the copy you'd like to appear in your tweet, bearing in mind you should<strong>&nbsp;cap it at 116 characters to allow enough room for a link, and at 115 characters to allow room for an image.</strong>&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/character-limit-social-media-blog-posts\">Read this blog post for a full character count guide</a>.) This spreadsheet will auto-calculate the number of characters you've entered to keep you on-point, turning yellow when you've reached 95 characters, and red when you've reached 116 characters.</p> \n<p>After you've composed your tweet, paste the URL you'd like to include in your tweet in the \"Link\" column. Be sure to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">include UTM parameters</a>&nbsp;so&nbsp;you'll know whether all of these tweets are actually driving traffic, leads, and customers. This is an important step to remember if you'd like to be able to demonstrate ROI from social. You can also use the \"Campaign\" column to add an associated campaign, which helps which more robust tracking and reporting.</p> \n<p>Finally, in the \"Image\" column, attach the tweet's image (if you have one). For Twitter, we recommend images that are 1024&nbsp;x 512 pixels. (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">Click here for a full cheat sheet of social media image sizes</a>.) If you're having trouble attaching your image to the spreadsheet, follow these steps:</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 1:</strong> Right-click the cell in which you'd like your image.</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 2:</strong> Click \"Hyperlink,\" then click the \"Document\" button, and finally, click \"Select\" to choose your image.</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 3:</strong> In the \"Choose a File\" window, select the image from your computer and click \"Open.\"</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 4:</strong> You'll now see the image attached to the \"Insert Hyperlink\" screen. Feel free to edit the \"Display\" text to change the file name, then click \"OK.\"</p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> This process is simply for organizational purposes. If you decide to upload the spreadsheet to your social media publishing&nbsp;software, it will not attach -- you'll have to do that with your marketing software. If you're a HubSpot customer, details for <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/social-media-user-guide-v2/how-to-upload-social-media-messages-in-bulk-for-schedule-publishing\">how to bulk upload your Twitter content to Social Inbox</a> can be found within the downloaded template.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Facebook Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>Now, let's talk about how to plan your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing\">Facebook marketing</a>&nbsp;in advance with the template. Navigate on over to the tab&nbsp;in your template labeled \"Facebook Updates.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=304&amp;name=social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Facebook content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"304\" /></p> \n<p>Facebook updates work similarly to Twitter updates, with the exception being bulk uploading your content is not possible in Social Inbox.</p> \n<p>The first three columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" and \"Time\" are there for your convenience. Head on over to the column labeled \"Message\" and input&nbsp;the copy you'd like to appear in your status update, corresponding to the days and times you'd like those updates to run.&nbsp;Then, move to the \"Link\" column and input the link you'll be, you know, linking to in the update. (Don't forget <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">that tracking token</a>.) If you'd like the update to be tagged to a certain campaign, include this in the \"Campaigns\" column. Finally, attach an image just like you did with your Twitter updates -- if you're using one, we suggest you edit it to be 1200 x 900 pixels.&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">Click here for a full cheat sheet of social media image sizes</a>.)</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your LinkedIn Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>LinkedIn updates are the most unique, because you have both Company Pages and Groups to consider. To demonstrate the difference between Company Page updates and Group updates, let's navigate over to the column labeled \"Title (For Group Discussions Only).\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=227&amp;name=social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for LinkedIn content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"227\" /></p> \n<p>LinkedIn Groups let you post a few kinds of updates, one of which is called a \"Discussion.\" You will only fill out the \"Title (For Group Discussions Only)\" column if you're looking to post a Discussion to your LinkedIn Group -- because Discussions are the only update you'll be posting that requires a title. If you're not posting a Discussion to a LinkedIn Group, you don't need to fill out this field, because your update will not have a title.</p> \n<p>You'll fill out the next column, \"Message,\" for every type of update you post, whether it's for a Company Page or a Group. Simply input your copy into this column, and then navigate to the next two columns, \"Link\" and \"Campaign\" to input the URL to which you're directing readers with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">the tracking token</a> you'll use to track&nbsp;activity, and the associated campaign if one exists. If you'd like to use an image for an update, attach it per the instructions laid out in the \"Twitter\" section. We recommend editing the image to 700 x 520 pixels.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Instagram Posting Calendar</h3> \n<p>Now, let's move on to&nbsp;how to set up your Instagram&nbsp;photos and videos&nbsp;in advance with the template. Navigate on over to the tab&nbsp;in your template labeled \"Instagram&nbsp;Updates.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=187&amp;name=social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Instagram content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"187\" /></p> \n<p>Instagram&nbsp;updates work similarly to Facebook&nbsp;updates, in that content can't be uploaded in bulk to&nbsp;Social Inbox&nbsp;like it can with Twitter.</p> \n<p>The first three columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" and \"Time\" are there for your convenience. Head on over to the column labeled \"Message,\" and input&nbsp;the copy you'd like to appear in your post's caption, corresponding to the days and times you'd like those updates to run. Keep in mind that although Instagram captions can be up to&nbsp;2,200 characters long, they&nbsp;cut off in users' feeds after three lines of text. The exact length of these three lines depends on the length of your Instagram handle.&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/character-limit-social-media-blog-posts\">Read this blog post for a full character count guide</a>.)</p> \n<p>Next, move to the \"Link for Bio\" column and input whichever link you plan to put in the bio when you publish the accompanying Instagram post. (The reason you'd put a link in your bio and not the photo caption itself is because clickable URLs aren't allowed anywhere except the single \"website\" box in your bio.) Oh, and&nbsp;don't forget <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">that tracking token</a>.</p> \n<p>If you'd like the update to be tagged to a certain campaign, include this in the \"Campaigns\" column. Finally, attach an image just like you did with your other social media&nbsp;updates -- we suggest you edit it to be 1080 pixels x 1080 pixels.&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">Click here for a full cheat sheet of social media image sizes</a>.)</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Pinterest Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>Alright, now let's go over&nbsp;how to set up your Pinterest pins&nbsp;in advance with the template. Navigate on over to the tab&nbsp;in your template labeled \"Pinterest Updates.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=246&amp;name=social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Pinterest content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"246\" /></p> \n<p>Pinterest&nbsp;updates work similarly to Facebook and Instagram updates, in that content can't be uploaded in bulk to&nbsp;Social Inbox&nbsp;like it can with Twitter.</p> \n<p>The first three columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" and \"Time\" are there for your convenience. Go to&nbsp;the column labeled \"Message,\" and input&nbsp;the copy you'd like to appear in your pin's description, corresponding to the days and times you'd like those updates to run. Then, move to the \"Link\" column and input the link you'll be, you know, linking to in the update. (Don't forget <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">that tracking token</a>.)</p> \n<p>If you'd like the update to be tagged to a certain campaign, include this in the \"Campaigns\" column. Finally, attach an image like you did with your other social media&nbsp;updates -- we suggest you edit it to be&nbsp;735 pixels x 1102 pixels.</p> \n<h3>Content Repository (Or, Where to Source Social Media Content)<strong><br /></strong></h3> \n<p>This template also provides you with a tab&nbsp;called \"Content Repository,\" which should help you keep track of all your content and maintain a healthy backlog of fodder&nbsp;to make sourcing social media content easier.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-content-repository.png?width=669&amp;height=146&amp;name=social-media-calendar-content-repository.png\" alt=\"social media content calendar's content repository\" title=\"social-media-calendar-content-repository.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"146\" /></p> \n<p>As you create more assets, you'll likely want to resurface and re-promote those pieces down the line, too.&nbsp;To ensure you don't lose track of all of that content, record it on this tab so you're never at a loss for what to publish on social. If the content you're promoting isn't evergreen, be sure to include an expiration date in the column marked \"Expiration\" so you don't promote it when it's&nbsp;jumped the shark.</p> \n<p>This tab will also help&nbsp;you maintain&nbsp;a healthy balance of content: A mix of your own content and others', a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-social-media-popularity\">mix of content formats and types</a>, and mix of lead generation content vs. MQL-generating content vs. traffic-friendly content.</p> \n<h2>Don't Forget to Interact With Your Followers</h2> \n<p>Whether you use this spreadsheet to plan your content out in advance or upload to a third-party app, you'll still need to supplement these updates with one the fly content. Breaking news hits? Whip up a quick update to share it with your network. Someone in your network tweets something interesting? Give it <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/27675/How-to-Retweet-the-Right-Way-in-4-Easy-Steps.aspx\">a retweet with some commentary</a>. Got a fascinating comment on one of your updates? Respond with a \"thank you\" for their interaction or an additional follow-up comment.</p> \n<p>Coming up with and scheduling your social media content in advance is a huge time-saver, but it should go without saying that you still need to monitor and add to your social presence throughout the day.</p> \n<p>Finally, we encourage you to experiment with your social media publishing. This template provides publishing dates and times for each social network, but you may find those are way too many updates for you to fill, or perhaps too infrequent for your booming social presence. You should adjust your social media publishing frequency as needed.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in January 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F33415%2Fthe-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
