computer viruses are the same, but the worst ones can enable cyber criminals to steal your most personal information, destroy your data, and even damage your computer’s hardware.</p>  \n<p>Macs and PCs both have built-in firewalls that help shield your computer from malicious cyber attacks, but if you want an extra layer of protection, you can purchase and download a personal firewall.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Check out the following personal firewalls to figure out which one is right for you.</p> \n<h2>5 of the Best Personal Firewalls for Mac and Windows</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.mcafee.com/consumer/en-us/store/m0/catalog/mls_430/mcafee-livesafe.html\">McAfee LiveSafe</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Price: $104.99 Per Year For an Unlimited Amount of Devices</strong></p> \n<p><strong>Available On: Mac and Windows</strong></p> \n<p>McAfee LiveSafe is an antivirus software that protects your computer from viruses and ransomware.</p> \n<p>It offers a safe web browsing tool that warns you about risky websites, links, and files, a multi-factor password manager app, a digital file shredder, and encrypted storage, which protects your most sensitive information on your computer with 128-bit encryption.</p> \n<p>McAfee LiveSafe <a href=\"https://www.toptenreviews.com/software/privacy/best-personal-firewall-software/mcafee-internet-security-review/\">performed well enough in recent third-party tests</a> to be considered one of the best antivirus software out there, and since you can use it on an unlimited amount of devices, it’s also one of the most affordable options on the market.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://us.norton.com/norton-security-antivirus\">Norton Security Premium</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Price: $54.99 Per Year For Up to Five Devices </strong></p> \n<p><strong>Available On: Mac and Windows</strong></p> \n<p>Norton Security Deluxe leverages one of the largest civilian cyber intelligence networks to protect your computer from viruses, spyware, malware, ransomware, and other advanced online threats.</p> \n<p>Norton Security Deluxe also offers a Smart Firewall, which can shield your personal and financial information from hackers that gain unauthorized access to computers from seemingly \"broken” sites that actually download viruses once people visit it.</p> \n<p>Norton Security Deluxe scored high on <a href=\"https://www.toptenreviews.com/software/privacy/best-personal-firewall-software/norton-internet-security-review/\">Top Ten Reviews</a>’ in-house testing, so if you’re looking for a powerful firewall solution, it’s the personal antivirus software for you.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://usa.kaspersky.com/internet-security\">Kaspersky Internet Security</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Price: $47.99 Per Year For Up to Three Devices </strong></p> \n<p><strong>Available On: Mac and Windows</strong></p> \n<p>In addition to shielding your computer from viruses, ransomware, and cyber attacks when you surf the web or download anything, Kaspersky Internet Security can also protect your bank and card details when you bank or shop online and safeguard your personal information from malicious links on social media.</p> \n<p>The software <a href=\"https://www.toptenreviews.com/software/privacy/best-personal-firewall-software/kaspersky-internet-security-review/\">constantly scores high on independent laboratory tests</a> that assess its capability of detecting and stopping malware, and the cheapest plan can protect up to three computers in your household, so if you need an affordable antivirus solution for your family, consider choosing Kaspersky Internet Security.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.intego.com/mac-protection-bundle\">Intego Mac Premium Bundle X9</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Price: 69.99 Per Year For Up to Three Devices </strong></p> \n<p><strong>Available On: Mac</strong></p> \n<p>After purchasing and downloading the latest version of Intego’s Mac Premium Bundle, you can leverage a real-time antivirus protection software that automatically scans your Mac, and an intelligent firewall and a hotspot network protection tool that blocks cyber criminals from accessing your computer through the internet.</p> \n<p>You also get access to a Cleaner Software that can remove unnecessary files from your computer, a parental control tool, and a data backup tool.</p> \n<p>Ranked as the <a href=\"https://www.toptenreviews.com/software/privacy/best-personal-firewall-software/intego-review/\">best personal firewall for Mac</a> by Top Ten Reviews and earning perfect scores on their in-house testing for blocking spyware, ransomware, and phishing attempts specifically designed to infect Macs, the Intego Mac Premium Bundle is one of the best antivirus softwares for Mac users.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.bitdefender.com/solutions/internet-security.html\">Bitdefender Internet Security</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Price: $79.99 Per Year For Up to Three Devices </strong></p> \n<p><strong>Available On: PC</strong></p> \n<p>By constantly testing different types of protection in malware detection tests run by independent labs, Bitdefender Internet Security has refined their solution enough to offer some of the best web attack prevention, ransomware protection, real-time data protection, anti-fraud, and anti-phishing tools out there. They also offer access to their own VPN, webcam protection, and vulnerability assessments.</p> \n<p>Ranked as the <a href=\"https://www.toptenreviews.com/software/privacy/best-personal-firewall-software/bit-defender-internet-security-review/\">best overall personal firewall in 2019</a> by Top Ten Reviews and the most expensive solution on this list, Bitdefender Internet Security is perfect for people who make shielding their computers from the most advanced cyber attacks a top priority in their lives.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in January, 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpersonal-firewall&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 21 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"133933d43d5bf6d63de83a90b5e0f947","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpersonal-firewall&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn54@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-22-149_d1539d973e8723c8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336423},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"Bringing Universities and HubSpot Clients Together: An Experiment in Applied Learning","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-experiment-applied-learning","description":"<p><em>This post is a part of Made @ HubSpot, an internal thought leadership series through which we extract lessons from experiments conducted by our very own HubSpotters.</em></p> \n<p>At the end of 2019, the Education Partner Program team at HubSpot had the challenging opportunity of deciding our priorities for the coming year.</p>  \n<p><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/education-partner-program\">The HubSpot Education Partner Program</a> — or EPP — is a community of educators who teach at colleges and universities worldwide that receive free software and support from HubSpot to train the next generation of marketing, sales, and service professionals.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image2-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=image2-1.png\" alt=\"hubspot experiment in applied learning hubspot academy tools knowledge\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">Supporting and empowering these students and professors is crucial in maintaining a healthy HubSpot ecosystem of future clients and users.</p> \n<p>Like most teams at HubSpot, we focus maniacally on how to create a positive experience for those who rely on our program - in this case, university professors. To ensure that we were creating such experiences, we first had to identify what novel problems and pain points this audience faces.</p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 24px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/education-partner-program\"><em>Click here to learn more about the Education Partner Program and how you can join.</em></a></p> \n<h2>Identifying Our Audience’s Pain Points</h2> \n<p>The EPP’s focus is on college students who need to enter the working world with the tools and methodologies they need to help a business grow. We care deeply, and invest heavily in, business education.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image1-Aug-17-2020-06-46-12-01-PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=image1-Aug-17-2020-06-46-12-01-PM.png\" alt=\"g2 grid online course providers hubspot\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Although HubSpot Academy serves thousands of learners across the world, the EPP focuses on education within college and universities. Our team would be remiss if we didn’t acknowledge and adapt to the educational inequity that pervades higher education in the US.</p> \n<p>Specifically, we wanted to address the problems below that these issues bring to light:</p> \n<h3>1. Students need to have experience applying the skills they learn in class to find employment after graduation.</h3> \n<p>Often, this means they pursue (sometimes unpaid) internships in expensive cities, which can add financial strain to an already expensive college experience.</p> \n<p>If HubSpot could find a way that would allow students to contribute virtually to helping solve a real business challenge in their course - all with the added safety net of their instructor being there to answer questions - we prime them for success. Subsequently, if they put this work on their resume, these students demonstrate a work experience that they might have otherwise been unable to find.</p> \n<h3>2. Educators have a mandate to prepare their students for real business challenges, but this can introduce so many unwelcome variables in the classroom.</h3> \n<p>Educations only have so many businesses in their rolodex that are open to working with students in their personal or professional network. On top of that, awkward conversations about expectations and due dates on deliverables can turn professors off from the experience completely.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, we have over 78,000 customers, all of whom are hoping to grow their business using our software and many of which could use some help and fresh eyes when approaching new projects. However, we recognized that it wasn’t enough to simply offer our customers; we needed a way for both our customers and our professors to hold themselves accountable to creating fruitful relationships and learning experiences for the students they work with.</p> \n<h3>3. HubSpot customers don't always have the bandwidth to complete their many projects.</h3> \n<p>Although the visible impact of the Education Partner Program is the support we lend professors, we also intend to embedding ourselves deeper into the company and work across the many teams at HubSpot that want their best for our users. As a small team of three, it’s important for us to make a large splash where we can. Working with other teams - and specifically, our Customer Success Team - to help HubSpot customers is mutually beneficial. We wanted to find a solution for our educators while also finding one for our customers. We needed to create safeguards that made sure that business didn’t exploit students’ free labor while making it easy (and pleasant) for a Customer to work with an Educator, and vice versa.</p> \n<p>And so, in 2020, we decided to focus on …. applied learning.</p> \n<h2>Providing a Solution Through Applied Learning</h2> \n<p><strong>Applied learning</strong> is the practice of alternating classroom learning with pre-approved practical, meaningful, and creative contributions of labor in a community or external organization, in a field related to a student’s academic and career goals. Has a HubSpot Customer not updated their lead-generation workflow since the early 2010s? Perhaps some students could come in and provide some suggestions. Does a HubSpot Customer not have the bandwidth to create engaging blog articles to promote their product or service? Have students in a Digital Marketing class provide some articles as their capstone assignment!</p> \n<p>As higher education shifted to virtual or hybrid models in 2020, we had a unique value proposition to provide our educators with the opportunity to enhance their students’ employable skills while also providing free work for our customers — many of whom were adapting to the challenges of conducting business almost entirely online and could use the help.</p> \n<p>Here’s how we did it.</p> \n<h3>1. We partnered with the best-in-class software for creating new applied opportunities in the classroom, Riipen.</h3> \n<p>We first explored what providers already had a foothold in this space. <a href=\"https://www.riipen.com/\">Riipen</a>, a technology platform that facilitates micro-experiential learning opportunities by connecting students with industry partners through in-course assignments or competitions designed by instructors, <a href=\"https://www.concordia.ca/content/dam/concordia/academics/experiential-learning/docs/Riipen-Instructions-for-Instructors.pdf\">came far ahead of any other options</a>.</p> \n<h3>2. We tested, and then tested some more.</h3> \n<p>Shortly after we decided to work with Riipen, we enlisted some of our most engaged Education Partners and customers to test out the marketplace to see if this was something we could expand to the hundreds more professors in our network.</p> \n<p>After a bit of research and conversation, we partnered with (and are eternally grateful for) Tim Marshall at Baldwin Wallace College and Elaine Young and Champlain College. These two educators’ students worked with six diverse HubSpot customers (three each), with much success.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.capa.org/\">CAPA The Global Education Network</a> (Boston, MA, USA): Students worked to develop lead-nurturing workflows to promote and encourage study abroad to freshmen college students.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.thewoodsmaine.com/\">The Woods </a>(Norway, ME, USA): Students worked to boost online ads and an ecommerce platform for a luxury treehouse in Maine.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.runawaytravelinc.com/\">Run Away Travel</a> (Miami, FL, USA): Students created marketing collateral and content for an all-inclusive travel agency.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.cosmicbooth.com/\">Cosmic Booth</a> (Orlando, FL, USA): Students created marketing collateral and content for a commercial photo booth rental business.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ettch.org/\">ETTCH </a>(Dublin, Ireland): Students created marketing collateral and content for an educational company that design tools for children coping with anxiety and low self-confidence.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://airworks.io/\">AirWorks</a> (Boston, MA, USA): Students doubled the amount of pillar pages for an AI start-up.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>My colleagues and I attended final presentations that students made to their employers and were impressed with the level of preparation and professionalism from everyone involved.</p> \n<p>The Woods saw tremendous growth (500%) in their apparel sales. Run Away Travel and ETTCH in particular had some great feedback on the maturity of the students and the innovative content they provided their businesses.</p> \n<p>Given the success of the pilot program, we decided to continue our partnership with Riipen and create even more connections between our customers and educators.</p> \n<h3>3. We promoted our program internally and collaborated with other teams.</h3> \n<p>There were several considerations we took into account as we planned to launch our partnership with Riipen at scale.</p> \n<p>We needed to make sure that our educators weren’t left without a HubSpot customer to pair with — and vice versa. This meant that our biggest obstacle was going both too fast or too slow in rolling this out. We needed to make sure we were recruiting at an even pace on both sides of the marketplace. For example, if we pressed the gas on recruiting educators to join, we could end up with more educators than we have customers. The opposite also applied. Since we could control the stream of educators who knew about and could sign up for this program, we also had to do the same for our customers.</p> \n<p>Enter the Customer Success team at HubSpot. We relied on the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-success-manager\">Customer Success Managers</a>, or CSMs, to hand-pick “good fit” businesses for this opportunity. We shared the “what” and “why” of our applied learning program through an internal “Applied Learning Resource Center” with small, actionable steps for CSMs that wanted their customers to participate in the program. CSMs then introduced me personally to businesses they considered a good match. We also built out public-facing pages for educators and customers that outlined the goals and responsibilities of each should they participate in the program.</p> \n<h2>Applied Learning in Times of Uncertainty</h2> \n<p>While we at HubSpot have always been excited about the prospect of matching customers with educators so that students can gain job-ready skills, these times of economic uncertainty have brought a new sense of urgency. When we experience fundamental changes to how we work and learn, we have to question how we can better prepare ourselves and others to respond to new challenges. The practice of remote-friendly learning has become the new normal for most colleges and universities worldwide, opening the horizons of what virtual leadership and project management looks like when it happens from your kitchen or bedroom desk.</p> \n<p>The project-based learnings students undertake with Riipen are always completely virtual experiences. Thus, they’re more flexible and obtainable to a new group of students who could never commit to the tradition 9-5, in-office internship experience.</p> \n<p>We have a long way to go to scale this from the highly-personalized, one-on-one outreach we have now to a more automated, self-identifying, opt-in process for customers and educators. Fall 2020 will present some interesting challenges as we prepare to launch this to our Education Partner Community during a time when many are questioning the ability to offer virtual learning — much less virtual applied learning opportunities.</p> \n<p>We seek to create 15 more matches between Educators and our Customers (and even more in the Spring) and are confident that we can hit this number. Ultimately, we want to create opportunities for students to graduate with the skills and experiences they need to feel confident in interviews and at their workplaces.</p> \n<p>Our partnership with Riipen is a major step in empowering these students and in building a customer base that appreciates the perspectives that these students bring.</p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 24px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/education-partner-program\"><em>Click here to learn more about the Education Partner Program and how you can join.</em></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhubspot-experiment-applied-learning&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 20 Aug 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"c87a19796c39256db352895b456a4a23","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Julia Gueron","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image2-1.png?width=1500&name=image2-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn44@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-21-187_f5b9d0020acde10b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image1-Aug-17-2020-06-46-12-01-PM.png?width=1500&name=image1-Aug-17-2020-06-46-12-01-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn69@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-28-274_f1c8f6f604e388ab.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhubspot-experiment-applied-learning&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn46@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-28-069_6f4fb33de4107334.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336424},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Find Your Business's White Space Opportunities","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/white-space-opportunity","description":"<p>When McDonald's first opened its doors, they had two items on the menu: burgers and fries. After surveying competitors, the founders saw that in order to stand out as a food company, they had to be different. Instead of offering a multitude of menu options, they decided to hyper-focus on the bestsellers, which catapulted their customer satisfaction.</p>  \n<p>What McDonalds' founders did was find white space opportunities in their industry. While other fast food restaurants at the time were offering a diverse menu but lacking in customer service — the McDonald's team decided to focus on two items so customer service would be at the forefront.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>By surveying what was missing from the market, McDonald's was able to grow into a billion-dollar empire. The founders saw what customers were lacking and turned that industry gap into a success.</p> \n<p>But what exactly are white space opportunities, and how can they be an asset to your company? Let's find out below.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, consumers don't know what they need until, well, they need it, so it's up to companies to be proactive. White space opportunities help marketers uncover customer needs that haven't yet been met.</p> \n<p>It's a useful tactic when identifying how to provide the most value to customers. But, because white space opportunities aren't as obvious as, say, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/keywords?_ga=2.258054088.373935806.1597717559-940436819.1565181751\">keyword opportunities</a>, it can be hard to know where to start.</p> \n<p>Sounds pretty taboo, right? How can businesses uncover value customers are looking for when the customer themselves aren't sure what they want? However, you may already have the right tools and knowledge at hand — they just need to be shaped for white space opportunities.</p> \n<p>Let's talk about what you can do to find white space for your company.</p> \n<h3>1. Innovate upon what you offer customers.</h3> \n<p>One of the best places to start with finding white space is within what you currently offer customers. Think of Apple's iPod. Apple's team probably came up with the idea to add a music player to their product stack by looking at what they already produce. Then, they figured out what other forms of entertainment they can make accessible with their resources.</p> \n<p>Consider identifying where, in your products, you can spot white space. Ask yourself where customer needs are and aren't being met. For example, if your blog team comes across a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht?_ga=2.258054088.373935806.1597717559-940436819.1565181751\">topic with high interest</a> from your followers, but haven't written about it yet, that's white space.</p> \n<p>Then, you can decide how to innovate: Are you going to write a series of posts about the topic, include subcategories for smaller posts, or turn the topic into an ebook?</p> \n<h3>2. Target a different audience segment.</h3> \n<p>If you're struggling to find where you can innovate for a certain audience, maybe it's time to shift your focus. Consider targeting a different part of your audience. For instance, if you're hyper-focused on providing value for your content marketing audience segment, consider the white space you might have for SEO audiences.</p> \n<p>Let's say you're in charge of a social media marketing agency focused on B2B clients in the technology sphere. Well, there are plenty of those — and yours is getting lost in the shuffle. Time to find white space.</p> \n<p>Instead of marketing your company as one focused on B2B clients in technology, you decide to shift your customer base to one that serves B2B developers. While this is still in the technology space, your focus on a different audience segment allows you to reach out to a market that's not as saturated in your industry.</p> \n<h3>3. Ask customers how they use your products.</h3> \n<p>Research how customers fit your offerings into their day-to-day. You might find white space you didn't know existed.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you're part of a company that focuses on chatbot software, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/surveys?_ga=2.258054088.373935806.1597717559-940436819.1565181751\">survey your customers</a> and ask them for their <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/case-studies?_ga=2.258054088.373935806.1597717559-940436819.1565181751\">stories</a>. Ask them how your services fit into their companies and webpages.</p> \n<p>Let's say you find that customers really enjoy using your chatbots for lead nurturing on ecommerce sites. That's an area you missed during the initial launch, but knowing this, your team can now work on making chatbots more online shopping-friendly. Maybe you add a way for your customers to demo their products and prices within the chat.</p> \n<p>That white space will help you serve your customers and improve their selling strategy.</p> \n<h3>4. Find where your company is different.</h3> \n<p>Imagine you're in charge of an analytics software company. Aware that there's a countless number of those companies in the market, you're struggling to find white space.</p> \n<p>In your business plan, you recognized that your company is going to be an easy-to-use, intuitive platform. That's the element that sets you apart from competitors. That's white space.</p> \n<p>A lot of <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/analytics?_ga=2.258054088.373935806.1597717559-940436819.1565181751\">analytics and reporting</a> software is hard to implement. Yours eliminates the struggle of turning numbers into results. Your company is going to be the one that's user-friendly — even a newbie can find success.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can use this discovery to find the most qualified leads. If your company is struggling to find white space, revisit your business plan. You may uncover the tactic you need to get back on track.</p> \n<p>White space can be used to solidify your company's branding strategy. Maybe you're struggling to identify where your product fits in the market. If you find a space for innovation, you can use that to strengthen how your company is seen by others.</p> \n<p>The McDonald's founders didn't have to look far for their opportunities, but things have changed since the 1950s. You might have to dig a little deeper and do some research, but ultimately, your business has something about it that's attractive to customers. Once you find it, you'll be able to keep delighting your clients, growing your company, and changing the industry.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhite-space-opportunity&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 18 Aug 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"f0a7647214e410ba1a26baac62d5132c","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhite-space-opportunity&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-27-349_35c715569f93b410.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336426},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"What is a Business Plan? Definition, Tips, and Templates","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-business-plan","description":"<p>The business plan is an undeniably critical component to getting any company off the ground. It's key to securing financing, documenting your business model, outlining your financial projections, and turning that nugget of a business idea into a reality.</p>  \n<p>In an era where more than <a href=\"https://www.oberlo.com/blog/small-business-statistics#:~:text=There%20are%2030.7%20million%20small%20businesses%20in%20the%20USA.,small%20and%20medium%2Dsized%20businesses.\">50% of small enterprises fail</a> in their first year, having a clear, defined, and well thought-out business plan is a crucial first step for setting up a business for long-term success.</p> \n<p>Business plans are a required tool for all entrepreneurs, business owners, business acquirers, and even business school students. But … what exactly <em>is</em> a business plan?</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll explain what a business plan is, list the reasons why you'd need one, and identify different types of business plans.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>What is a Business Plan?</strong></h2> \n<p>A business plan is a documented strategy for a business that highlights its goals and its plans for achieving them.</p> \n<p>Business plans outline a company's go-to-market strategy, financial projections, market research, business purpose, and mission. The business plan is also a prominent tool used to secure investors and financing for a business.</p> \n<h2><strong>Business Plan Template</strong></h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bpt-cover-gif-1.gif?width=443&amp;name=bpt-cover-gif-1.gif\" alt=\"bpt-cover-gif-1\" width=\"443\" style=\"width: 443px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">Working on your business plan? Try using <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template\">our Business Plan Template</a>. Pre-filled with the sections a great business plan needs, the template will give aspiring entrepreneurs a feel for what a business plan is, what should be in it, and how it can be used to establish and grow a business from the ground up.</p> \n<h2><strong>Purposes of a Business Plan</strong></h2> \n<p>Chances are, someone drafting a business plan will be doing so for one or more of the following reasons:</p> \n<h3>1. Securing financing from investors.</h3> \n<p>Since its contents revolve around how businesses succeed, break even, and turn a profit, a business plan is primarily used as a tool for sourcing capital. This document is an entrepreneur's way of showing potential investors and/or loaners how their capital will be put to work and how it will help a business thrive.</p> \n<p>All banks, investors, and venture capital firms will want to see a business plan before handing over their money, and investors typically want <a href=\"https://smallbusiness.chron.com/small-business-investors-percentage-forever-73824.html#:~:text=Angel%20investors%20typically%20want%20from,high%20risk%20it%20is%20taking.\">a 20-25% ROI</a> from the capital they invest in a business.</p> \n<p>Therefore, these investors need to know if – and when – they'll be making their money back (and then some). Additionally, they'll want to read about the process and strategy for <em>how</em> the business will reach those financial goals, which is where the context provided by sales, marketing, and operations plans come into play.</p> \n<h3>2. Documenting a company's strategy and goals.</h3> \n<p>A business plan should leave no stone unturned.</p> \n<p>Business plans can span dozens or even hundreds of pages, affording their drafters the opportunity to explain what a business's goals are and how the business will achieve them.</p> \n<blockquote>\n To show potential investors that they've addressed every question and thought through every possible scenario, entrepreneurs should thoroughly explain their marketing, sales, and operations strategies – from acquiring a physical location for the business to explaining a tactical approach for marketing penetration.\n</blockquote> \n<p>These explanations should ultimately lead to a business's break even point supported by a sales forecast and financial projections, with the business plan writer being able to speak to the why behind anything outlined in the plan.</p> \n<h3>3. Legitimizing a business idea.</h3> \n<p>Everyone's got a great idea for a company – until they put pen to paper and realize that it's not exactly feasible.</p> \n<p>The business plan is an aspiring entrepreneur's way to prove that a business idea is actually worth pursuing.</p> \n<p>As entrepreneurs document their go-to-market process, capital needs, and expected return on investment, entrepreneurs likely come across a few hiccups that will make them second guess their strategies and metrics – and that's exactly what the business plan is for.</p> \n<p>It ensures an entrepreneur's ducks are in a row before bring their business idea to the world and reassures the plan's readers that whoever wrote the plan is serious about the idea, having put hours into thinking of the business idea, fleshing out growth tactics, and calculating financial projections.</p> \n<h3>4. Getting an A in your Business class.</h3> \n<p>Speaking from personal experience, there's a chance you're here to get business plan ideas for your Business 101 class project.</p> \n<p>If that's the case, might we suggest checking out this post on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-plan-template\">How to Write a Business Plan</a> – providing a section-by-section guide on creating your plan?</p> \n<h2><strong>Types of Business Plans</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Startup Business Plan</h3> \n<p>Arguably the most common type of business plan, a startup business plan is used for brand new business ideas. This plan is used to take a business concept and lay the foundation for its eventual success.</p> \n<p>The biggest challenge with the startup business plan is that it requires its writer to completely start from scratch. Startup business plans start with a blank word document, and before they are finished, need to reference existing industry data and explain unique business strategies and go-to-market plans.</p> \n<h3>2. Business Acquisition Plan</h3> \n<p>Investors will still want to see a business plan to acquire funding to purchase an existing business in order to see how its new owner will run the business.</p> \n<p>What will change and what will stay the same under new ownership, and why? Additionally, the business plan should speak to what the current state of the to-be-acquired business is, and why it's up for sale.</p> \n<p>For example, if someone is purchasing a failing business, the business plan should explain why the business is being purchased and what the new owner will do to turn the business around, referencing previous business metrics, sales projections after the acquisition, and a justification for those projections.</p> \n<h3>3. Business Repositioning Plan</h3> \n<p>When a business wants to save itself, reposition its brand, or try something new, some CEOs or owners will want to develop a business repositioning plan.</p> \n<p>This plan should:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Acknowledge the current state of the company.</li> \n <li>State a vision for the future of the company.</li> \n <li>Explain why the business should (or must) be repositioned.</li> \n <li>Outline a process for how the company will adjust.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Companies planning for a business reposition do so – proactively or retroactively – due to a shift in market trends and customer needs. For example, <a href=\"https://www.restaurantbusinessonline.com/financing/pizza-hut-plans-close-hundreds-us-units\">Pizza Hut announced a plan</a> to drastically overhaul its brand last year, as it sees the need to shift from dine-in to delivery – a decision resulting from observing years of industry and company trends and acknowledging the need to reposition itself for the future of its sector.</p> \n<h3>4. Expansion Business Plan</h3> \n<p>Building onto a successful business venture with another location typically requires its own business plan, as the project may require a new location, focus on a new target market, and demand more capital.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, an expansion business plan allows its writers to reference sales, revenue, and successes from any previous location(s). However, as great as a reference as these points can be, it's important to not be <em>too</em> reliant on them, since it's still a new business that could succeed or fail for a myriad of reasons.</p> \n<h2><strong>Getting Started With Your Business Plan</strong></h2> \n<p>At the end of the day, a business plan is simply an explanation of a business idea and why it will be successful. The more detail and thought you put into it, the more successful your plan – and the business it outlines – will be.</p> \n<p>If you need help starting your business plan, download <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template\">Download HubSpot's Free Business Plan Template</a> and fill out the sections to meet your business idea's concept.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-business-plan&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 14 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"e7740a89a97811b84df5f3e27b6f4e3a","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"AJ Beltis","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bpt-cover-gif-1.gif?width=443&name=bpt-cover-gif-1.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-20-007_0f9f0df1ada75d87.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-business-plan&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn4@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-27-753_b4db0abc82431299.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336427},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Run a SWOT Analysis for Your Business [Template Included]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/swot-analysis","description":"<p>A SWOT analysis is a useful technique to evaluate a new project or objective your business faces, or your business as a whole.</p>  \n<p>Essentially, a SWOT analysis is a roadmap for how you should move forward with your business, which opportunities you’re missing out on, and which challenges you should tackle.</p> \n<p>It’s an effective method to maximize opportunities while minimizing negative factors associated with a given project or objective. Plus, it lets you unbiasedly evaluate your business’s strengths and weaknesses, which is key to avoiding unnecessary errors down the road from lack of insight.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Here, we’ll provide a SWOT analysis template, and conduct SWOT analyses on major brands Apple and Starbucks. When you’re done reading, you’ll have all the inspiration and tactical advice you need to tackle a SWOT analysis for yourself.</p> \n<p>You know a SWOT analysis is important, but, how do you conduct one?</p> \n<p>There are four steps you’ll want to take when evaluating your business as a whole, or your product in particular. Before you start, you’ll need to figure out what you’re evaluating with your SWOT analysis. Creating a social media program, launching a new product, or considering a brand re-design are all good reasons to conduct a SWOT analysis.</p> \n<h2><strong>Use this SWOT Analysis Template.</strong></h2> \n<p>To visualize your SWOT analysis, it's helpful to make a table. Here, I’ve created a sample using a simple Google Doc table -- feel free to use the model yourself, or create your own as it suits your needs.</p> \n<h3>Make a SWOT Analysis Table</h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable SWOT Analysis pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=imagesir\">Download a free, editable SWOT Analysis template.</a></p> \n<p>Use the four steps below as a references when filling in your table.</p> \n<p><strong>1. Identify your strengths.</strong></p> \n<p>Let’s say you want to use a SWOT analysis to evaluate your new social media strategy.</p> \n<p>If you’re looking at a new social media program, perhaps you want to evaluate how your brand is perceived by the public -- is it easily recognizable and well-known? Even if it’s not popular with a widespread group, is it well-received by a specific audience in particular?</p> \n<p>Next, think about your process: is it effective, or innovative? Is there good communication between your marketing and sales to ensure both departments use similar vocabulary when discussing your product?</p> \n<p>Finally, evaluate your social media message, and in particular, how it differs from the rest of the industry. I’m willing to bet you can make a lengthy list of some major strengths of your social media strategy over your competitors, so try to dive into your strengths from there.</p> \n<p><strong>2. Identify your weaknesses.</strong></p> \n<p>If you’re examining a new social media strategy, it’s critical to foresee any potential negative factors that could mitigate your success.</p> \n<p>Start by asking yourself these questions: First, if I were a consumer, what would prevent me from buying this product, or engaging with this business? What would make me click away from the screen?</p> \n<p>Second, what do I foresee as the biggest hinderance to my employees’ productivity, or their ability to get the job done efficiently? What derails their social media efforts?</p> \n<p>When identifying weaknesses, consider what areas of your business are the least profitable, where you lack certain resources, or what costs you the most time and money. Take input from employees in different departments, as they’ll likely see weaknesses you hadn’t considered.</p> \n<p><strong>3. Consider your opportunities.</strong></p> \n<p>This is your chance to dream big. What are some opportunities for your social media strategy you hope, but don’t necessarily expect, to reach?</p> \n<p>For instance, maybe you’re hoping your Facebook ads will attract a new, larger demographic. Maybe you’re hoping your YouTube video gets 10,000 views, and increases sales by 10%.</p> \n<p>Whatever the case, it’s important to include potential opportunities in your SWOT analysis. Ask yourself these questions: What technologies do I want my business to use to make it more effective? What new target audience do I want to reach? How can the business stand out more in the current industry? Is there something our customers complain about that we could fix with our social media strategy?</p> \n<p>The opportunities category goes hand-in-hand with the weaknesses category. Once you’ve made a list of weaknesses, it should be easy to create a list of potential opportunities that could arise if you eliminate your weaknesses.</p> \n<p><strong>4. Contemplate your threats. </strong></p> \n<p>It’s likely, especially if you’re prone to worrying, you already have a good list of threats in your head.</p> \n<p>If not, gather your employees and brainstorm: what obstacles might prevent us from reaching our social media goals? What’s going on in the industry, or with our competitors, that might mitigate our success? Is there new technology out there that could conflict with our product?</p> \n<p>Writing down your threats helps you evaluate them objectively. For instance, maybe you list your threats in terms of least and most likely to occur, and divide and conquer each. If one of your biggest threats is your competitor’s popular Instagram account, you could work with your marketing department to create content that showcases your product’s unique features.</p> \n<h2><strong>SWOT Analysis Examples</strong></h2> \n<p>The template above helps get you started on your own SWOT analysis.</p> \n<p>But, if you’re anything like me, it’s not enough to see a template. To fully understand a concept, you need to see how it plays out in the real world.</p> \n<p>Here are two examples of SWOT analyses on major corporations, Apple and Starbucks. The list of strengths and weaknesses is not exhaustive, and I’m sure you could add some yourself, but hopefully, it’s enough to inspire your own SWOT analysis.</p> \n<h3>Apple’s SWOT analysis</h3> \n<p>Here’s how we’d conduct a SWOT analysis on Apple.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png\" alt=\"SWOT analysis showing Apple's Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">First off, strengths. While Apple has many strengths, let’s identify the top three:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Brand recognition</li> \n <li>High prices</li> \n <li>Innovative products</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Apple’s brand is undeniably valuable, and was named the <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2017/05/23/apple-heads-the-worlds-most-valuable-brands-of-2017-at-170-billion/#192b9e3f384b\">world’s most valuable brand</a> by Forbes. Since it’s easily recognized, Apple can produce new products and almost ensure a certain degree of success by virtue of the brand name itself.</p> \n<p>This degree of recognition lends itself to Apple’s ability to sell products at extremely high prices. For instance, in 2016, Apple <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2017/05/23/apple-heads-the-worlds-most-valuable-brands-of-2017-at-170-billion/#192b9e3f384b\">sold 78 million iPhones, the average cost of which was $695</a>. In comparison, Samsung sold their smartphones for $500 less. And yet, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2017/05/23/apple-heads-the-worlds-most-valuable-brands-of-2017-at-170-billion/#7ca54732384b\">92% of the profits in the smartphone category</a> for 2016 went to Apple. Often, people don’t care about price as much as they care about brand recognition.</p> \n<p>Lastly, their innovative products: Apple didn’t earn its reputation for nothing. They create highly innovative products, which are often at the forefront of the industry.</p> \n<p>Next, let’s look at three of Apple’s weaknesses.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>High prices</li> \n <li>Closed ecosystem</li> \n <li>Lack of experimentation</li> \n</ol> \n<p>While the high prices don’t deter Apple’s middle and high class customer-base, they do hinder Apple’s ability to reach a lower-class demographic.</p> \n<p>Apple also suffers from its own exclusivity. Apple controls all its services and products in-house, and while many customers become loyal brand advocates for this reason, it means all burdens fall on Apple employees.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, Apple’s tight control over who distributes their products limit their market reach.</p> \n<p>Lastly, Apple is held to a high standard when it comes to creating and distributing products. Apple’s brand carries a high level of prestige, but that level of recognition inhibits Apple from taking risks and experimenting freely with new products that could fail.</p> \n<p>Now, let’s take a look at opportunities for Apple.</p> \n<p>It’s easy to recognize opportunities for improvement, once you consider Apple’s weaknesses. Here’s a list of three we came up with:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Expand distribution options</li> \n <li>Create new product lines</li> \n <li>Technological advancement</li> \n</ol> \n<p>One of Apple’s biggest weaknesses is its distribution network, which, in the name of exclusivity, remains relatively small. If Apple expanded its network and enabled third-party businesses to sell its products, it could reach more people globally, while alleviating some of the stress currently put on in-house employees.</p> \n<p>There are also plenty of opportunities for Apple to create new products. Apple could consider creating more affordable products to reach a larger demographic, or spreading out into new industries -- Apple self-driving cars, perhaps?</p> \n<p>Finally, Apple could continue advancing its products’ technology. Apple can take existing products and refine them, ensuring each product offers as many unique features as possible.</p> \n<p>Finally, let’s look at threats to Apple.</p> \n<p>Believe it or not, they do exist.</p> \n<p>Here are three of Apple’s biggest threats:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Tough competition</li> \n <li>Lawsuits</li> \n <li>International issues</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Apple isn’t the only innovative tech company out there, and it continues to face tough competition from Samsung, Google, and other major forces. Many of Apple’s weaknesses hinder Apple’s ability to compete with the tech corporations that have more freedom to experiment, or that don’t operate in a closed ecosystem.</p> \n<p>A second threat to Apple is lawsuits. Over the last few years, Apple has faced a bunch of lawsuits, particularly between <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/23/16519546/apple-samsung-patent-lawsuit-damages-retrial-october\">Apple and Samsung</a>, and so far it has only <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/6/16614038/apple-samsung-slide-to-unlock-supreme-court-120-million\">won one case</a>. These lawsuits interfere with Apple’s reputable image, and could steer some customers to purchasing elsewhere.</p> \n<p>Finally, Apple needs to improve its reach internationally. It isn’t <a href=\"https://www.androidauthority.com/in-china-the-iphone-is-only-second-best-830776/\">number one in China</a>, and doesn’t have a very positive relationship with the Chinese government. Then, in India, which has one of the largest consumer markets in the world, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/29/why-apple-sells-just-2-point-5-percent-of-indias-smartphones.html\">Apple’s market share is low</a>, and the company has trouble bringing stores to India’s market.</p> \n<p>If Apple can’t compete globally the way Samsung or Google can, it risks falling behind in the industry.</p> \n<h3>Starbucks SWOT Analysis</h3> \n<p>Now that we’ve explored the nuances involved with a SWOT analysis, let’s fill out a SWOT template using Starbucks as an example.</p> \n<p>Here’s how we’d fill out a SWOT template, if we were Starbucks:</p> \n<div>\n <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/starbucksswotanalysis.png\" alt=\"Starbucks SWOT Analysis example\"></a>\n</div> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Download this Template for Free</span></a>\n</div> \n<h3>Dine-In Thai Restaurant SWOT Analysis</h3> \n<p>Some small-business marketers may have difficulty relating to the SWOT's of big brands like Apple and Starbucks, so here's an example of how a restaurant might visualize each element:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Dine-in Thai Restaurant SWOT analysis example\">While a Thai or any other restaurant might not be as worried about high-level lawsuits like Apple, the small business might be more worried about competitors or disruptors that might enter the playing field.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Local Boutique SWOT Analysis</h3> \n<p>In another small-business example, a local boutique might be well known in its neighborhood, but it also might take time to build an online presence or get its products in an online store. Because of this, some of its strengths and opportunities might relate to physical factors while weaknesses and threats might relate to online situations.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png\" alt=\"Local boutique SWOT analysis example\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h2>When to Use a SWOT Analysis</h2> \n<p>Ultimately, a SWOT analysis can measure and tackle both big and small challenges, and opportunities, and both big and little strengths and weaknesses.</p> \n<p>While the examples above focus on businesses in general, you can also use a SWOT analysis to evaluate and predict how a singular product will play out in the market.</p> \n<p>Hopefully, our SWOT template will supplement your market research and business analysis, and provide fair insights into how to optimize your products for bigger payoffs, and less hurdles.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May, 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fswot-analysis&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 19:05:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"9f22ef1f9504cd42dddbf2da0dba5e4b","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn9@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-26-884_28f7ed392ffa061e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn78@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-28-382_d17ce5537f683cfa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/starbucksswotanalysis.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn74@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-27-634_a268c0f05cb65a0a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn49@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-22-195_e725d410d9523fc7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn56@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-21-243_8e5e600abafa5af5.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fswot-analysis&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn65@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-23-941_fb1068d473508007.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336434},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"15 Essential Social Media Marketing Tips From Beginner to Advanced","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/data-backed-social-media-marketing-tips","description":"<p>One of the most humbling experiences as a marketer is putting out that tweet you just <em>knew</em> would be a home run for your audience.</p>  \n<p>We’d like to think of ourselves as being able to come up with A+ <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/resources/courses/social-media\">social media</a> content every day, but the reality is that we're all human. Sometimes, we hit a wall with planning content that aligns with our company and goals.</p> \n<p>If you're just starting out in <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/social-media?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=social_media\">social media marketing</a> or are looking for a few tips to get inspiration, we've compiled some helpful knowledge to beef up your accounts — no matter your skill level.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Sync posts across all social media accounts.</h3> \n<p>If you're just starting out, it's a good idea to invest in a social media management service like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox\">HubSpot's Social Inbox</a>. This tool can help you schedule posts, monitor mentions, track your social analytics, and keep an eye on all your accounts. Similar tools include <a href=\"https://later.com/\">Later</a> and&nbsp;<a href=\"https://tweetdeck.twitter.com/\"> TweetDeck</a>.</p> \n<p>These apps will also let you sync posts across various accounts. Keeping content synced will ensure you post across all of your platforms and introduce followers with multiple accounts to your brand.</p> \n<h3>2. Republish and update older posts.</h3> \n<p>If you have a backlog of content that's outdated, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-updating-republishing-blogging-content-ht\">update and republish it</a> with fresh ideas for SEO. This tactic has the potential to draw in new readers and take less time than continuously pumping out new ideas.</p> \n<p>This can be blog posts, landing pages, and offers that you have on your website. Your social media strategy exists to put your best foot forward by building engagement, and you don't have to start from ground zero.</p> \n<p>In fact, this exact post is an update from 2017, originally posted in 2013. We regularly update posts to ensure our readers are getting fresh content on our blog, social channels, and emails.</p> \n<h3>3. Schedule posts for evenings.</h3> \n<p>Don’t be afraid of weekends either. Scheduling content launches for evenings opens up a door for engagement that isn't cut off by time zone. That way, even if it's 3 AM in your geographic location, your tweet about your new app update reaches audiences around the world.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/hubspotlife/?hl=en\">HubSpot Life</a> is a behind-the-scenes look at HubSpot's culture, posting content from global offices on social media. During what's considered \"off\" hours in the US, HubSpot Life features posts during work hours in other countries, like Paris, Bogota, or Dublin.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-08-11%20at%2010.25.49%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-08-11%20at%2010.25.49%20AM.png\" alt=\"hubspot life instagram\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/hubspotlife/?hl=en\"><em>Image Source</em></a></p> \n<p>This ensures that global audiences are able to get fresh content during their work days, as well.</p> \n<p>When scheduling posts for evenings, avoid content that requires engagement from your team. For instance, an Instagram photo that invites followers to <i> \"Comment below!\"</i> about something might not be the best idea to post at midnight, when you're not able to engage.</p> \n<h3>4. Include hashtags to increase engagement</h3> \n<p>Hashtags are like a golden ticket to increasing your online reach. Common tags like #SocialMedia and #MarketingGoals are great, but try searching for less-used ones like those of bigger brands (such as Adobe's #CreateYourStory), or community-based (#BrightonMA). Those are going to be the ones an active audience is checking out.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Buffer-on-Instagram-bio-example.png?width=1500&amp;name=Buffer-on-Instagram-bio-example.png\" alt=\"buffer on instagram hashtags\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.business2community.com/brandviews/buffer/the-science-behind-the-best-instagram-bios-02246266\"><em>Image Source</em></a></p> \n<p>As well as using existing hashtags, try your hand at creating your own branded hashtags, like <a href=\"https://buffer.com/\"> Buffer</a> did in the example above (#BufferLove). This allows you to track what your followers and customers are saying about your media presence and product.</p> \n<h3>5. Use visuals whenever possible.</h3> \n<p>If you're getting your feet wet with the social media game, it's okay not to invest a fortune into visual content. However, it's always a good idea to include pictures, videos, or graphics in posts whenever you can.</p> \n<p>There are a number of free services, like <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\"> Canva</a> , to help you edit and create content. <a href=\"https://giphy.com/\"> GIFs</a> are a great way to engage with a younger audience. And never forget the smartphone most likely in your pocket they produce beautiful pictures you can definitely use on socials.</p> \n<p>If you've tried your hand at social media before and feel comfortable branching out, these intermediate tips are for you. They're aimed at easing the process of creating uniform content across your channels while increasing clicks.</p> \n<h3>1. Post multiple times a day.</h3> \n<p>You don't need to post every hour, but one to three times a day keeps your brand fresh in your audience's mind. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-user-generated-content-campaigns\">Reposting user-generated content</a> also counts, so don’t stress about coming up with dozens of new content ideas.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/guide-user-generated-content-ecommerce\"><em>Download this free guide to learn how to leverage user-generated content to improve your conversion rates.</em></a></p> \n<p>If you’re looking for ways to brush up your content marketing, how about incorporating an infographic or eBook into that Facebook post? For more tips like those, check out our list <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-types?_ga=2.163078463.2000696366.1572268289-940436819.1565181751\"> here.</a></p> \n<h3>2. Incorporate your brand into your social strategy.</h3> \n<p>Your brand should speak for you. Once you've established your brand, think of ways to blend it into your social media marketing. This can mean adding your logo to posts, including a company hashtag, or highlighting your employees.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/metter%20media%20branding.png?width=1500&amp;name=metter%20media%20branding.png\" alt=\"Metter Media branding example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/mettermedia/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Check out this branding from social media management company, Metter Media. From a quick scroll through their Instagram homepage, you can quickly spot company colors, get a look into their team, and gain an idea of who they represent.</p> \n<h3>3. Engage audiences with interactive content.</h3> \n<p>From Twitter polls to Instagram Q&amp;As, there are many ways to engage your audience and make your company’s content diverse. You can use interactive content to educate your audience about your products or to connect with your audience.</p> \n<p>Think of ways your audience engages with competitors and how you can add your company into the mix. You can even ask your audience what type of content they prefer to see on an Instagram story, like this example below:</p> \n<div> \n <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/polling%20screenshot-1.png?width=359&amp;name=polling%20screenshot-1.png\" style=\"width: 359px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Instagram poll example\" width=\"359\"><a href=\"http://instagram.com/frommybowl\"></a></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://instagram.com/frommybowl\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n</div> \n<p>The story of this food blogger begins to recap previous recipes with links to corresponding blog posts. To put this in a B2B perspective, say you wanted to boost clicks on previous blog content. You could poll followers, <i> \"Which type of post goes best with your coffee?\" </i> and link to two options in the next parts of your story.</p> \n<h3>4. Invest in more visual content.</h3> \n<p>As you get into the swing of posting on social media, invest more time into visual content. On average, retweets with pictures gain more clicks and views than text-only posts.</p> \n<p>Visual content isn't just restricted to Instagram. Post infographics about your industry on LinkedIn, tweet a funny meme relating to your office culture, or post a video on Facebook taking viewers on a high-speed tour of your office.</p> \n<p>Next up are some advanced tips. These ideas are for social media pros in need of a new direction or options to brighten their feeds.</p> \n<h3>1. Use new app updates to your advantage.</h3> \n<p>Have you tried <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-tiktok\"> TikTok</a> or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/igtv\">IGTV</a> yet? If not, we suggest expanding your strategy to include these channels. After all, you don’t want to miss out on your content having the potential to meet <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-hit-1-billion-downloads-surpassing-instagram-in-2018-2019-2\">one billion</a> phones.</p> \n<p>New apps and app updates add to the ability to diversify your brand and keep things fresh. If you're looking to show your company's humorous side, try uploading a little <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brands-on-tiktok?_ga=2.157622713.2000696366.1572268289-940436819.1565181751\"> dance</a> video on TikTok. If you want to bring that podcast of yours to visual audiences, upload it to IGTV.</p> \n<div>\n <iframe style=\"margin: 0px auto display: block display: block; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.tiktok.com/embed/6720653674525363461\" width=\"340\" height=\"700\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div> \n<h3>2. Invest in influencers to promote your product or service.</h3> \n<p>It's official: young audiences listen to their idols. <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/consumer-insights/youtube-stars-influence/\"> Four in 10</a> millennials trust the products their favorite influencers promote on their social channels, so <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-work-with-influencers\">investing in influencers</a> might be an avenue to look into when trying to generate sales.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/influencer-marketing-guide\"><em>Download our free ultimate guide to getting started with influencer marketing.</em></a></p> \n<p>If you have an audience that's younger, research influencers in your industry and pitch potential partnerships. Or, for a more budget-friendly option, look at how influencers are branding their content — you may be able to incorporate some ideas into your strategy.</p> \n<h3>3. Diversify content on every social media platform.</h3> \n<p>You can update and sync content on your accounts like a pro. Now it's time to make that content unique. Save your high-definition videos for Facebook and meme posts for Twitter.</p> \n<p>When diversifying content, make sure they all relate back to your company's goals and mission. There's no need to post a recipe for falafel on your marketing company's Instagram, but an infographic displaying the 'recipe' for a perfect caption would be a compelling, spot on example.</p> \n<div> \n <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"> \n  <p>If you're a writer, a filmmaker, or really anyone who’s looking for good career advice, check out this thread from <a href=\"https://twitter.com/chrismcquarrie?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@chrismcquarrie</a>. 🙌 <a href=\"https://t.co/RRCbxoO8kg\">https://t.co/RRCbxoO8kg</a></p> — LinkedIn (@LinkedIn) \n  <a href=\"https://twitter.com/LinkedIn/status/1187391628916510720?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 24, 2019</a>\n </blockquote> \n</div>   \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/linkedin%20diversifying%20content%20example.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"LinkedIn Facebook post\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://facebook.com/linkedin\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>On October 24th, LinkedIn highlighted a blog post on Facebook. On the same day, LinkedIn promoted a Twitter thread aimed at aspiring filmmakers. Threads are a Twitter-specific tool aimed at sectioning off long thoughts, while the Facebook post gives LinkedIn more clicks from their Facebook followers.</p> \n<h3>4. Start promotions to build audience growth.</h3> \n<p>Have you run a contest on your Twitter account yet? Totino's does them well.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/totinos%20promotion.png?width=1500&amp;name=totinos%20promotion.png\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Totinos promotion tweet example\" width=\"1500\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://twitter.com/totinos\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Don't worry, promotions don't have to be this fancy. Running a promotion can be simple as giving 10% off of your product or service to a lucky winner who retweets. This expands your reach and sparks lead generation among your customers' followers.</p> \n<h3>5. Create timely content that resonates with audiences.</h3> \n<p>As a huge believer in taking advantage in the meme of the moment, creating timely content adds some fun to your channels and can explain the uses of your product in a new way. Memes aren't the only way to accomplish this, seasons are, as well.</p> \n<p>Is it wintertime in your part of the world? Celebrate by snapping a pic of your company's favorite snowy activity and share it to Facebook. Alternatively, #NationalSandwichDay is November 3rd. Popeye's used this holiday to announce the comeback of a recent fan favorite.</p> \n<div> \n <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"> \n  <p>Y’all…the sandwich is back Sunday, November 3rd. Then every day. 🤯🔥 <a href=\"https://t.co/JDxyCIv0zz\">pic.twitter.com/JDxyCIv0zz</a></p> — Popeyes Chicken (@PopeyesChicken) \n  <a href=\"https://twitter.com/PopeyesChicken/status/1188780503601680384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 28, 2019</a>\n </blockquote>  \n</div> \n<p>Is it too early to call this genius type of marketing “legendary?”</p> \n<p>Keeping content fresh can be difficult, even if you're a social media pro. The pressure is on nowadays when it seems like the trends are changing every second, and diving in can seem like jumping down a rabbit hole.</p> \n<p>These tips will keep you current on ways to organize your page, upgrade your content, and grow your target audience, but don't stop here. Check out our ultimate guide on social media marketing for more <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-marketing?_ga=2.192233897.2000696366.1572268289-940436819.1565181751\"> inspiration</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in 2013 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdata-backed-social-media-marketing-tips&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
