\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Move%20to%20Ecommerce%20How%20Retailers%20Can%20Adapt%20During%20a%20Crisis-1.png","linkMd5":"68d546ebacc964f8c37729dcc2478b44","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn69@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-16-733_2a818b6056bb5ca2.webp","destWidth":1600,"destHeight":978,"sourceBytes":442574,"destBytes":442574,"author":"Ronita Mohan","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Move%20to%20Ecommerce%20How%20Retailers%20Can%20Adapt%20During%20a%20Crisis-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn69@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-16-733_2a818b6056bb5ca2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Move%20to%20Ecommerce%20How%20Retailers%20Can%20Adapt%20During%20a%20Crisis.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn6@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-29-502_72d72b880265c7c8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Move%20to%20Ecommerce%20How%20Retailers%20Can%20Adapt%20During%20a%20Crisis-3.png?width=456&name=The%20Move%20to%20Ecommerce%20How%20Retailers%20Can%20Adapt%20During%20a%20Crisis-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn31@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-21-913_3f0f7847502bf1e9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Move%20to%20Ecommerce%20How%20Retailers%20Can%20Adapt%20During%20a%20Crisis-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn93@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-25-847_7f545fef13cfd545.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fretailers-adapt-crisis&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn29@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-27-968_fafbc9d66d124900.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336431},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Adapt Your Content Into an Instagram Story, According to HubSpot Marketers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/adapting-instagram-story-content","description":"<p>If you're a marketer, at some point, it's likely you're going to be asked the question, \"Is it on brand?\"</p>  \n<p>This is especially true for social media content. Companies with social media pages generally have a theme that relates to the organization. The use of colors, sensory details, and styling all contribute to the overall theme of a page. I, for one, <em>love </em>thematic Instagrams — they're so aesthetically pleasing.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>When the colors, text, and photos all fit, I find myself going through all the content because it's so easy to look at — the same is true for Stories.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, I come across posts that make me think, \"How did this marketer turn a simple content idea into this engaging Instagram Story?\" And, as always, curiosity got the best of me. I had a question, and I was ready to search for the answer.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, I knew exactly who to look to for help. I wanted to know just how social media marketers choose the right pieces to include in Stories, so I turned to the experts. I asked HubSpot's marketers this question and compiled their tips.</p> \n<p>Let's see what they had to say.</p> \n<h3>1. Look for buzzy, trendy content.</h3> \n<p>When choosing content to add to Instagram Stories, HubSpot Audience Growth Writer Pam Bump, asks herself a question: “<em>Is the content buzz-worthy?</em>”</p> \n<p>\"Trend or buzz-worthy content usually relates to a topic, trend, or piece of research that people in my industry are talking about or sharing on social media,\" she says. \"If a topic is already being widely discussed and shared, it might be more engaging as a story on a social platform.\"</p> \n<p>For instance, if you find that a hot topic in your industry is, say, personality tests, and you have a blog post all about them, think about how you can adapt that into a story.</p> \n<p>Check out this example from HubSpot:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-3.png?width=252&amp;name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-3.png\" alt=\"Example of content broken up in a story.\" width=\"252\" style=\"width: 252px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>This story corresponds with a post about <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/personality-tests\">free personality tests</a>. It takes the main ideas from the article and uses short, digestible sentences to recap the content. Additionally, the story's following tiles included a few of the options outlined in the blog:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-4.png?width=252&amp;name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-4.png\" alt=\"Example of reforming content into an Instagram story.\" width=\"252\" style=\"width: 252px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>This tile includes a \"<a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/instagram-swipe-up/\">Swipe Up</a>\" function, so audiences can see the post and get details about the test. Remember, the swipe-up tool is a great one to use for backlinking. You can bring new browsers to your website without making them exit the app.</p> \n<p>Sharing buzz-worthy content will throw your company into the conversation and keep the content fresh and topical on your page.</p> \n<h3>2. Choose media that's easy to comprehend.</h3> \n<p>When you want to adapt content, think about what can be split up into small, comprehensive pieces. If an audience member is scrolling through Instagram during their lunch break, it's likely that they're not interested in reading Stories that are full of text.</p> \n<p>\"Odds are, much of your audience is on Instagram looking for quick entertainment during a work break or daily commute,\" notes Kelsey Yamada, one of HubSpot's social media managers. \"This is why my most important tip is to start your story actively rather than passively.\"</p> \n<p>Yamada suggests that, to keep audiences engaged, \"Grab the reader’s attention with an interactive element, interesting fast-fact, a video, or eye-popping graphic. Then, use the following pages of the story to go into depth about the topic.\"</p> \n<p>Let's look at a visual:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-67-AM.png?width=252&amp;name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-67-AM.png\" width=\"252\" style=\"width: 252px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Example of starting a story interactively.\">\n</div> \n<p>This first tile asks the reader a question to get them thinking. The Story doesn't use much text, and instead, includes an interactive function — the<a href=\"https://about.instagram.com/blog/announcements/introducing-the-emoji-slider-sticker\"> emoji slider sticker</a>. The next tile gives survey data to add background.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-2.png?width=252&amp;name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-2.png\" alt=\"How to present data in an Instagram Story.\" width=\"252\" style=\"width: 252px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>This content is easy for audiences to engage with as a quick brain break from their busy day. It takes data that was previously collected by HubSpot and turns it into a visually appealing guess-and-check for marketers.</p> \n<p>You can use stats, like survey data, for Instagram Stories. Use short questions to engage users right off the bat, then use the following tiles to give them the full story.</p> \n<h3>3. Think about if you can make the story interactive.</h3> \n<p>One question Bump asks herself when choosing content for Stories is, <em>\"Can I make this content interactive?\" </em>For instance, you might have some less-than-glamorous topics covered on your blog or web pages, but take a look at them from a different perspective.</p> \n<p>Bump notes, \"Even a bland topic can be zested up with a quiz or poll. For example, sometimes, when adapting a post with heavy research into an Instagram Story, we’ll format the story like a quiz. Then the last page will offer readers the ability to swipe up to read more about the answers.\"</p> \n<p>For example, this story was adapted from a post about the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z?_ga=2.251058054.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">difference between millennials and Gen Z</a>:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers.png?width=252&amp;name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers.png\" alt=\"How to capture audiences with statistical content in an Instagram Story.\" width=\"252\" style=\"width: 252px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>It might not be the most exciting topic, but using Instagram Stories can make the content interactive, raising the interest level of audiences. If I were to see this story before the blog post, I would stop in my tracks and ask myself, <em>\"I think I know the difference, but what does HubSpot have to say?\"</em></p> \n<p>Alternatively, if I saw the blog post, I might not want to engage. But this story makes the content fun, gives the value of the post, and brings readers to the content in a new format. If the last tile included a link to the post, you could boost the number of reads.</p> \n<h3>4. Decide if you can make the text sparse and actionable.</h3> \n<p>\"One thing the social media teams I’ve worked with are mindful of are the amount of text and the amount of pages in each story. I’ve seen that more than a paragraph of text on one story page can result in reader fatigue, which, in turn, could cause people to drop out of your story,\" notes Yamada.</p> \n<p>Remember, it's likely that your Instagram audiences are checking their feeds as a quick brain break or a source of entertainment. Bombarding them with text-filled stories will take away from that experience.</p> \n<p>Instead of using a paragraph of text, include bullet points. This will break up text and allow for emojis, stickers, or other content that will make a story visually appealing.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-1.png?width=252&amp;name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-1.png\" alt=\"Example of a story with little text.\" width=\"252\" style=\"width: 252px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>\"If you can include a swipe-up with more content, consider a less-is-more approach where you include a quick tip, poll, or quiz related to a topic. Then, encourage the reader to swipe-up to learn more about the topic,\" recommends Yamada. \"If you can’t, but the story is more complex, consider breaking it up into a larger amount of pages.\"</p> \n<h3>5. Experiment, experiment, experiment.</h3> \n<p>What works for HubSpot's socials might not be the case for companies in different industries. So, remember to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-testing?_ga=2.19779768.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">experiment with your content</a> to find what works the best for your audience.</p> \n<p>Bump recalls, \"While you should do research and keep social media manager guidelines in mind as you craft a story strategy, don’t be afraid to try something different. For example, if you have a low drop off rate and most of your audience gets to the end of your Stories, you could experiment with a longer story to see how far they’ll get.\"</p> \n<p>Don't be afraid to think outside of the box. Sometimes, new ideas are the ones that will be the winning ticket to better engagement. That sales metric that you're unsure about sharing? Experiment with it, and see if you can change the wording to make it enjoyable.</p> \n<p>\"Regardless of which experiments you do,\" Bump continues, \"Be sure to start with a hypothesis, know which metrics you’ll be monitoring, and identify what you’ll do if the experiment works or doesn’t work. This will allow you to develop a strong set of learnings around your audience and their behaviors.\"</p> \n<p>As for metrics to look for, Bump recommends looking at story views, impressions, swipe ups, and exits. Outside of the app, analyze overall Instagram traffic, or use a tracking URL. \" If you include a swipe-up to your full web content, use a tracking URL, such as one made with HubSpot or <a href=\"http://bit.ly/\">Bit.ly</a>, as your swipe-up link,\" she says.</p> \n<p>\"A tracking URL will allow you to see how many page views you received from the story. If you have a CMS with an analytics dashboard that can distinguish social media sources, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/analytics?_ga=2.19779768.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\">HubSpot</a>, you can also see how much traffic your post has coming from Instagram.\"</p> \n<h3>6. Be mindful of story length.</h3> \n<p>We've talked a bit about keeping the audience's attention. The length of your story could impact their engagement. So when you're choosing content, think about how many tiles it would take to convey the message. Can you do this in less than five?</p> \n<p>Yamada says, \"If someone doesn’t get to the end of your story where a swipe-up link is located, they won’t swipe up. So, I try to keep Instagram Stories content within 4-5 pages if it will include a swipe-up.\"</p> \n<p>Remember, in our personality test example, the story had five tiles. At the end of the last tile, there was a link to the corresponding blog post. This captures the reader's attention quickly and backlinks the source before they exit:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-38-AM.png?width=252&amp;name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-38-AM.png\" alt=\"How to shorten content for an Instagram Story.\" width=\"252\" style=\"width: 252px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>\"Do your best to cut the content down to the biggest takeaways. If your audience wants all the details, provide a link to the source material in a swipe-up or in the DMs if anyone reaches out. If a piece of content can't be summarized and cut down, it's not the best fit for Stories,\" Yamada explains.</p> \n<p>In the example above, the content explains a test the audience can take, where they can find it, and how to get more information. Basically, the story is used as a \"preview\" for the rest of the content. Is there content in your arsenal that's similar — like a study you just performed?</p> \n<h3>7. Put yourself in the audience's shoes.</h3> \n<p>Keeping your audience in mind is at the forefront of content creation. Remember to think about their motivation as much as their interests.</p> \n<p>\"Whenever I’ve adapted long-form content into Instagram, Snapchat, or Facebook Stories, I’ve tried to imagine what my audience will be doing and thinking when they aimlessly tap through Stories and come across my brand’s,\" states Yamada.</p> \n<p>Think about how you interact with Stories on Instagram. A story that's short, simple, and includes visual elements probably keeps you more interested than a story that's too busy, with a lot of moving parts. It's jarring to tap to a story and see a huge video with no explanation, right?</p> \n<p>To choose content that your audience will be intrigued by, Bump encourages marketers to \"Think about what your audience likes to see from you on Instagram. If you get a ton of engagement on sales-related content, for example, try adapting a blog post about sales into a short-form story.\"</p> \n<p>As Yamada notes, \"Adapting your existing content into stories will give it the opportunity to provide value on a different platform to a different audience.\" If your audience misses content you want to boost, or you want to present it in a different way, take to your Stories to give it more exposure.</p> \n<p>Adapting your content into stories gives audiences a rounded view of what your brand is about from a different perspective.</p> \n<p>\"Why shouldn't more people see the awesome content you've already worked on creating?\" she asks. \"You'll also find yourself saving time when adapting content, as you won't have to create a whole new piece just for Stories. A win-win!\"</p> \n<p>These tips made me excited to jump into my content and see what I could turn into the next high-performing story. I can't wait to find new data or research that I can make more engaging with a few emojis. Plus, I feel more confident about what I can put out there. Knowing I have a solid direction now, I'm ready to be bold and experiment.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fadapting-instagram-story-content&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-3.png?width=252&name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-27-785_8a4e63b807fb70f1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-4.png?width=252&name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn27@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-23-465_306424884d76024e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-67-AM.png?width=252&name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-67-AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn41@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-27-543_3f5a157e622ceb1e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-2.png?width=252&name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-20-213_58c6ab9a852d7d10.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers.png?width=252&name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn58@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-25-002_68f4f2181a72d550.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-1.png?width=252&name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn54@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-24-961_8b25fdeed94f8e54.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-38-AM.png?width=252&name=How%20to%20Adapt%20Your%20Content%20Into%20an%20Instagram%20Story,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketers-Aug-10-2020-03-07-49-38-AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-29-159_2290e3e6f21ccf61.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fadapting-instagram-story-content&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn5@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-26-821_4945f28b0e43f6fc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336434},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How 3 HubSpot Managers Found Strong Co-Marketing Partnerships [+How You Can, Too]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips","description":"<p>A solid <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34188/what-in-the-heck-is-co-marketing.aspx\">co-marketing</a> partnership is one of the better ways to reach a previously untapped audience, generate positive publicity, and create a wealth of valuable marketing collateral. When done right, it's a mutually beneficial, thoroughly productive way to boost your marketing efforts as a whole.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Aligning yourself with an industry peer can pay off in spades, but these kinds of relationships aren't easy to start and sustain. Your partner's interests and qualities need to complement yours, and the companies you work with have to be reliable enough to consistently pull their weight.</p> \n<p>Finding a company that fits that bill is hard in its own right, but once you've identified one you want to work with, you're faced with the challenges of successfully contacting them, corresponding with them, and convincing them to work with you.</p> \n<p>Those processes can be hard to figure out on your own, so to offer you some help, we spoke with three HubSpot experts about how they found strong co-marketing partnerships and the steps you need to take to do the same.</p> \n<h2>What do you look for in a co-marketing partner?</h2> \n<p>When asked about what they look for in a co-marketing partner, our experts all seemed to agree that the number one priority is alignment in audience, messaging, and image. As HubSpot Senior Marketing Manager, Margot Mazur, put it, <em>\"We look for partners who speak to similar personas and address their needs. Specifically, we want to make sure our partners have a similar audience and voice — with similar values and goals to meet.\"</em></p> \n<p>Though finding a company that checks those boxes is central to a successful co-marketing partnership, there's still a lot more to the process. You might identify a potential partner that lines up well with your brand identity and appeals to a similar audience, but co-marketing partnerships need to be productive and mutually beneficial — you need to know you'll get something out of it.</p> \n<p>According to HubSpot Marketing Manager, Diego Santos, <em>\"Once we are happy with [a potential partner's] suitability, we classify them according to a co-marketing matrix — one that takes the partner's popularity, relevance, and objective into consideration. This process helps us to prioritize collaborations and look at the big picture.\"</em></p> \n<p>Ideological and objective-oriented alignment isn't enough. There needs to be hard, quantifiable potential behind a co-marketing partnership. As Mazur said,<em> \"We also look at a potential partner's audience across social and email channels, making sure that our businesses are of a similar size.\"</em></p> \n<p>Co-marketing partnerships are, at their core, strategic plays. They can be invaluable assets in targeted marketing efforts. For instance, HubSpot Marketing Manager, Clara Landecy, spoke on how they can be leveraged to target specific areas, <em>\"I always look for partners who have a strong presence in targeted regions. Partnering with local partners is essential if your company does business in multiple languages and across the globe.\"</em></p> \n<p>Santos succinctly captured all those points when he laid out the key questions to consider when finding co-marketing partners, <em>\"We usually ask ourselves the following questions to make sure they are a good fit: Who are they? What is their area of expertise? And who — and how big — is their audience?\"</em></p> \n<p>It's important to have a firm understanding of what you want out of a co-marketing partnership before approaching potential partners. Find a company with similar values that will enhance your ability to effectively reach your target audience — one that will pull its weight, complement your messaging, and ultimately suit your long term goals.</p> \n<h2>How do you approach and connect with potential co-marketing partners?</h2> \n<p>Our experts stressed the importance of a personal touch in connecting with potential co-marketing partners. As Santos put it, <em>\"A more personal, network-oriented approach is usually much more effective than a cold introductory email or message.\"</em></p> \n<p>Co-marketing partnerships are inherently personal, so it's only fitting that you start your relationship with your partner off on a <em>personal</em> note. But how do you get there?</p> \n<p>Well, according to our experts, your best bet is leveraging resources and co-workers from within your own company. Landecy said, <em>\"To increase your response rate, ask your colleagues if they have any contacts at the companies you’re looking to partner with, warm outreach always helps.\"</em></p> \n<p>Santos agreed, <em>\"We always try to leverage the connections we already have in HubSpot. When we are looking for partners in a particular area, we reach out to everyone in the relevant regional team and encourage them to send ideas of potential collaborations.\"</em></p> \n<p>Mazur reiterated their points but added some insight about what she does when she can't reach potential partners through her colleagues, <em>\"Generally, I'll see if anyone at HubSpot already has a connection to someone at the partner company. If not, I'll reach out to a partnership, BD, or marketing person at the company on LinkedIn, using their InMail tool.\"</em> As I mentioned earlier, no matter how you reach potential partners you need to do so with a personal touch.</p> \n<p>Do your homework. Make sure you have a firm grasp on the nature of the company you're contacting, what it might need out of a co-marketing partnership, and what you can do to suit its objectives and interests. Or as Landecy said, <em>\"Make sure your outreach is personalized! Showing you did the research before reaching out shows you are invested in the potential partnership and makes their work feel special!\"</em></p> \n<p>But let's say you don't have the know-how and personal connections to identify and reach potential co-marketing partners. You're at a loss when it comes to finding interested companies whose size, values, and interests line up with your own.</p> \n<p>What can you do? Well, there are certain tools designed to expedite the process. For instance, <a href=\"https://www.crossbeam.com/?utm_source=adwords&amp;utm_campaign=9977203105_100586914017_441699244276&amp;utm_term=&amp;utm_term=&amp;utm_campaign=Content+Lead+Generation+(Blog)&amp;utm_source=adwords&amp;utm_medium=ppc&amp;hsa_acc=7141001143&amp;hsa_cam=9977203105&amp;hsa_grp=100586914017&amp;hsa_ad=441699244276&amp;hsa_src=g&amp;hsa_tgt=dsa-915029285266&amp;hsa_kw=&amp;hsa_mt=b&amp;hsa_net=adwords&amp;hsa_ver=3&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIvOqtlKqW6wIVCTiGCh1VyQ9VEAAYASAAEgKksPD_BwE\"><span>Crossbeam</span></a> is a resource that leverages CRM data to help you find and connect with potential co-marketing partners with overlapping customer bases and other complementary attributes.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, a solid co-marketing partnership has tremendous potential that's only seen after tremendous effort. It often takes extensive research and critical thought just to identify the companies that suit your values, goals, and qualities. And actually conducting the necessary outreach and communication to establish one adds a whole new, often exhausting layer to the process.</p> \n<p>Still, there's a lot to be gained from these kinds of arrangements. If your business is looking for a shot of life to your marketing efforts, pursuing a co-marketing partnership is something to consider.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fco-marketing-partner-tips&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 19:45:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"b51605d148664a74132a069d63dd1ab4","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"jfuchs@hubspot.com (Jay Fuchs)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fco-marketing-partner-tips&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn18@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-26-117_ce74fcca29bc477f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336428},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Make All Your Accounts Safer With Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/two-factor-authentication","description":"<p>Nowadays, account security is a major concern for companies and their employees.</p>  \n<p>It can pose a major threat to your employer if you're hacked — if someone hacks your Gmail account, for instance, he will have access to company contacts, as well as your calendar, Google Docs, Google Sheets, and other private company information.</p> \n<p></p>  \n<p>For this reason, <a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.duosecurity.duomobile&amp;hl=en_US\">Duo Mobile</a> and other two-factor authentication apps have risen in popularity.</p> \n<p>Two-factor authentication (or 2FA) is a safety process you can enable on any of your devices, including your iPhone, Mac, Gmail account, or social media accounts like Facebook.</p> \n<p>Here, we're going to tell you what two-factor authentication is, and how you can enable (or disable) it on any of your accounts, to ensure your information is protected.</p> \n<h2><strong>What is two-factor authentication?</strong></h2> \n<p>To understand what two-factor authentication is, let's start with an analogy.</p> \n<p>Imagine you live in a dangerous neighborhood, and you only have one lock on your door. Alternatively, your neighbor down the street has a top <em>and </em>bottom lock, and each lock requires a separate key — which means, to break into his apartment, you need to break into two locks, not just one.</p> \n<p>Who's safer?</p> \n<p>Ultimately, two-factor authentication is your neighbor's top and bottom lock — but for your online accounts. It significantly decreases the risk of getting hacked by combining two methods of protection.</p> \n<p>Two-factor authentication uses two methods to ensure you're the correct user. It combines something you know (i.e. a password), with something you have (i.e. a mobile phone), or something you are (i.e. facial recognition).</p> \n<p>For instance, to access my online school account, I need to open the Duo Mobile app on my phone, <em>and</em> input my school account's password — while a hacker might be able to guess my password, he's going to have a tougher time hacking into my phone, as well.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>How to Turn Off Two-Factor Authentication</strong></h2> \n<p>It's relatively easy to turn off two-factor authentication on any of your accounts.</p> \n<p>On Facebook, for instance, simply go to \"Settings\" and then \"Security and Login\". Find \"Use two-factor authentication\", click \"Edit\", and then switch to \"Off\".</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).jpeg?width=1500&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).jpeg\" alt=\"how to turn off two factor authentification\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Alternatively, on Gmail, you'll want to go to <a href=\"http://myaccount.google.com\">http://myaccount.google.com</a>. Then, select \"Security\". Under the \"Signing in to Google\" section, you'll see \"2-Step Verification\". Click this section.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-03-20%20at%204.40.30%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-03-20%20at%204.40.30%20PM.png\" alt=\"two step verification to make your accounts safer \" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">Next, select \"Turn Off\" to disable 2-Step Verification for your Gmail account.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).png?width=1500&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).png\" alt=\"two step verification example\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>It's important to note, Apple removed the option to turn off two-factor authentication for Apple IDs created in iOS 10.3 or macOS 10.12.4 and later.</p> \n<p>However, you have a two-week period during which you can still disable the function. Simply open your iCloud email account and find the enrollment confirmation email, then click the link to return to your previous security settings.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in March, 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftwo-factor-authentication&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 21 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"9217b99d77f948e1bf837c7e1bd75c90","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).jpeg?width=1500&name=How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-21-725_4700113046091e69.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-03-20%20at%204.40.30%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-03-20%20at%204.40.30%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn8@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-19-980_f2f0b42df0bac6ba.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).png?width=1500&name=How%20to%20Make%20All%20Your%20Accounts%20Safer%20With%20Two-Factor%20Authentication%20(2FA).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn88@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-20-034_9cd0232b804b4c69.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftwo-factor-authentication&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn28@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-24-372_15d7bf6efbb0df7d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336423},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"What Is Product Classification, and Why It Matters for Your Marketing Efforts","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/product-classification","description":"<p>The other day, I roamed the aisles of CVS and picked up the same Crest toothpaste I've been buying for years.</p> \n<p>I didn't think twice about it. I made the purchase on auto-pilot. I didn't consider testing out a different brand, or purchasing one from another retailer.</p> \n<p>Toothpaste, as it turns out, is known as a \"convenience good\", which matches my buying behavior.</p> \n<p>Understanding product classification can help you understand your consumers' general buying behaviors, which will help you market your product more effectively.</p> \n<p>There are four types of product classification. Let's dive into each type, so you can determine where your product falls in the list.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>Consumer Product Classification</strong></h2> \n<p>There are four types of product classification — convenience goods, shopping goods, specialty products, and unsought goods.</p> \n<p>Let's dive into each one in more detail.</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Convenience Goods</strong></h3> \n<p>Like the Crest toothpaste example, convenience goods are products that consumers' purchase repeatedly and without much thought. Once consumers choose their convenience goods' brand-of-choice, they typically stick to it unless they see a reason to switch — such as an interesting advertisement that compels them to try it, or mere convenience at the checkout aisle.</p> \n<p>These products include toilet paper, soap, toothpaste, shampoo, milk, and other necessities that people buy over and over again.</p> \n<p>To market a convenience good, you want to consider that most people will impulse buy these products. Placing your products near the checkout line at a store could be a good idea for these products — which is why you'll often find candy and gum at the front of a store.</p> \n<p>Since most convenience goods are low-price, pricing and discounting isn't a major factor. I won't switch my toilet paper brand just to save a few cents. For convenience goods, brand recognition is key, so you'll want to implement wide-spread campaigns to spread awareness of your company if possible.</p> \n<p>For instance, Charmin toilet paper is a popular brand in the United States — likely in part due to the company's consistent and long-term advertising strategy, dating back to the <a href=\"https://www.charmin.com/en-us/about-us/charmin-history\"><span>1960's with the invention of \"Mr. Whipple\"</span></a>, a Charmin character who appeared on TV, print, and radio.</p> \n<h3><strong>2. Shopping Goods</strong></h3> \n<p>Shopping goods are commodities you likely think of when you hear the word \"shopping\". They might be higher-end items like cars or houses, or smaller items like clothing and electronics.</p> \n<p>Consumers typically spend more time conducting research, comparing prices, and chatting with salespeople when they're looking to purchase shopping goods. These are more one-off purchases, and are typically more important and higher economic-impact products compared to toilet paper or soap.</p> \n<p>For instance, while you will buy toilet paper over and over again for the rest of your life, you'll likely only purchase a house a few times at most. And, since it's an expensive and important purchase, you'll spend a good amount of time deliberating on it, attending different open houses, speaking with various retailers, and comparing pros and cons of your final selection.</p> \n<p>The same can be said for smaller products. A nice t-shirt from the Gap, for instance, isn't typically an \"impulse\" buy. Instead, you'll want to try it on, consider whether the price is worth it, and even text a picture of it to a friend.</p> \n<p>To market a shopping goods product, then, you'll want to invest in content that helps persuade your buyer that your product is worth it. It's important your marketing materials demonstrate how your product differs from the competition, and the unique value-add it provides consumers.</p> \n<p>This will vary depending on your industry and product, but ultimately, marketing shopping goods entails helping consumers understand why they should choose your product over others in the marketplace.</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Specialty Goods</strong></h3> \n<p>A specialty good is the <em>only</em> product of its kind on the market, which means consumers typically don't feel the need to compare-and-contrast or deliberate as much as they would with other products.</p> \n<p>A good example of this? iPhones.</p> \n<p>I've been purchasing new iPhones for years, and I haven't paused to consider other smartphone models — <em>not </em>because an iPhone is an \"impulse\" buy, but because of the brand recognition and unique quality I feel I'm getting from an iPhone. It's the same reason people buy Mercedes. There isn't anything else on the market like it.</p> \n<p>For this reason, if you're marketing a specialty good, you don't necessarily need to spend too much time convincing consumers that your product is different from competitors. They already know it's different. Instead, your company should focus on constantly <em>innovating</em> on its previous products and producing the \"next best thing\". This will ensure your customers will remain loyal to your brand.</p> \n<p>For instance, if Apple stopped making impressive improvements on their iPhones and promoting new features, I might consider switching brands. But since they've continued to impress me over the years, I've continued to purchase from them.</p> \n<h3><strong>4. Unsought Goods</strong></h3> \n<p>Finally, unsought goods — a product that people aren't typically <em>excited </em>to buy, and also don't buy on impulse. Good examples of unsought goods include fire extinguishers, batteries, or life insurance.</p> \n<p>People will typically buy an unsought good out of a sense of fear or danger. For instance, you wouldn't go on the market looking for the \"new and best\" fire extinguisher. You'd only purchase one due to the fear of a potential fire. Alternatively, some unsought goods, like batteries, are bought simply because the old ones ran out.</p> \n<p>When marketing an unsought good, you'll want to focus on reminding consumers of the existence of your product, and convincing consumers that purchasing your product will leave them with a better sense of security.</p> \n<p>For instance, Duracell's <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CZs7mwIOVe0\"><span>Beach x Bear commercial</span></a> encourages viewers to remember the importance of batteries in life-threatening situations, like impending bear attacks (as well as the everyday importance of batteries, like when using a metal detector ... ).</p> \n<p>Hopefully, you can find a clear fit with your product in one of these four classifications. Use consumers' buyer behavior to inspire your next marketing campaign. How can you meet — and exceed — customers' expectations of your product type?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fproduct-classification&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 21 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"be1ad833634ff7ed246ebf15e6fc27ed","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fproduct-classification&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn96@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-27-825_4b71fab47c8e7959.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336423},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"10 Great Examples of Welcome Emails to Inspire Your Own Strategy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/welcome-email-examples","description":"<p>We've all heard how important it is to make a good first impression. Show up late for a job interview?</p>  \n<p>That's a bad first impression. Eat a ton of garlic and forget to brush your teeth before a first date? Also a bad first impression.</p> \n<p>It turns out that the \"make a good first impression\" principle holds true not only in face-to-face encounters, but in email interactions as well.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>When you send a welcome email to a new blog or newsletter subscriber, or to a new customer, you're making a first impression on behalf of your brand. To help ensure you're making the best first impression possible, we've rounded up some examples of standout welcome emails from brands big and small.</p> \n<p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> Use HubSpot's <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">free email marketing software</a> to easily create a high-quality welcome email sequence like the ones featured below.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=400&amp;name=Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"free welcome Email Template to send to customers\"></p> \n<p>As you'll soon discover, each example below showcases different tactics and strategies for engaging new email subscribers. Let's dive in.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"></p> \n<h2>10 Examples of Standout Welcome Emails</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.virginamerica.com/\">Virgin America</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/virgin-america-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Virgin America welcome email with a red CTA to get started\" title=\"virgin-america-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>A welcome email is the perfect medium for introducing folks to the characteristics (and eccentricities) that make your brand unique.</p> \n<p>For Virgin America, that means putting the \"I love you\" hand symbol front and center. This small gesture signals to the recipient that the folks atVirgin America really care about their customers. The playful accompanying copy, \"Welcome aboard,\" and casual call-to-action, \"Grab a seat,\" also help to position Virgin America as a hip, fun-loving brand right off the bat.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://food52.com/\">Food52</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/food-52-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Food52 welcome email with a gray CTA to get started\" title=\"food-52-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>Sometimes the tiniest of elements in a welcome email can speak volumes about a brand. And when it comes to Food52's welcome email, their preview text at the top of the email, \"We brought snacks,\" definitely accomplishes this.</p> \n<p>Also known as a pre-header or snippet text, preview text is the copy that gets pulled in from the body of an email and displayed next to (or beneath) the subject line in someone's inbox. So when you see Food52's welcome email in your inbox, you get a taste of their brand's personality before you even open it.</p> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/preview_text-3.png\" alt=\"preview_text-3.png\" title=\"preview_text-3.png\"></p> \n<p>Food52's welcome email also does a good job of building trust by putting a face (make that two faces) to their name. As soon as you open the email, you see a photograph of -- and welcome message from -- the company's founders.</p> \n<h3>3. Monday.com</h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Video</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/monday.com-video-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Monday.com welcome email with a link to watch a video by CEO Roy Man\"></p> \n<p>From the subject line to the conversational tone in the email body, the welcome email above keeps it friendly and simple so the focus stays on the introductory video inside.</p> \n<p>Monday.com is a task management tool for teams and businesses, and the welcome email you get when you sign up makes you feel like the CEO, Roy Man, is talking directly to you. The email even personalizes the opening greeting by using the recipient's first name -- this is well known for <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">increasing email click-through rates</a> (especially if the name is in the subject line).</p> \n<p>The closer you can get to making your email sound like a one-on-one conversation between you and your subscriber, the better. If you have just so many details you need to inform your new customer of, follow Monday.com's lead and embed them in a video, rather than spelling them all out in the email itself.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.katespade.com/\">Kate Spade</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Thank You</h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/kate-spade-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Kate Spade welcome email with orange envelope graphic saying thank you\" title=\"kate-spade-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>Let's face it: We, the internet-using public, are constantly bombarded with prompts to sign up for and subscribe to all sorts of email communications. So as a brand, when someone takes the time to sift through all the chaos in order to intentionally sign up for <em>your</em> email communications, it's a big deal.</p> \n<p>In order to acknowledge how grateful they are to the folks who actually take the time to subscribe, Kate Spade uses a simple -- but effective -- tactic with their welcome emails: They say \"Thank You\" in big, bold lettering. And by placing that \"Thank You\" on an envelope, Kate Spade recreates the feeling of receiving an actual thank-you letter in the mail. (The 15% off discount code doesn't hurt either.)</p> \n<h3>5. Lyft</h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/lyft-welcome-email.png?width=690&amp;name=lyft-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Lyft welcome email with pink CTA to get started\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<p>If there's an ideal \"attitude\" that welcome emails should give off, Lyft has got it.</p> \n<p>The company's simple but vibrant welcome email, shown above, focuses entirely on the look and feel of the app, delivering a design that's as warm and smooth as the lifts that Lyft wants to give you. At the same time, the email's branded pink call-to-action draws your eyes toward the center of the page to \"Take a Ride\" -- inviting language that doesn't make you feel pressured as a new user.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"http://www.ikea.com/\" style=\"font-size: 1.5rem;\">IKEA</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Offer</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/ikea-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"IKEA welcome email with offer to join free membership\" title=\"ikea-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>It might not be the most beautifully designed email on this list, but that doesn't mean IKEA's welcome email isn't effective.</p> \n<p>Instead of going for the hard sell (e.g., \"By stuff now!\"), or explaining what it is they do (which is something IKEA probably assumes most people already know), IKEA uses its welcome email to turn folks onto its other, lesser-known programs and content channels. For example, there's a call-to-action right at the top that explains the value of its member benefits program. There are also prompts to visit their design blog and to contribute to their collaborative \"Share Space\" site.</p> \n<p>Of course, if you're not interested in any of that stuff, IKEA's welcome email also makes it easy for you to simply log in and start shopping (there's a login field right up top).</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"http://www.michaels.com/\">Michaels</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Offer</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/michaels-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Michaels welcome email with offer of 20% off an entire purchase\" title=\"michaels-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>The Michaels approach to the welcome email borrows elements from both Kate Spade and Virgin America. In addition to expressing gratitude to the folks who took the time to sign up, Michaels uses its welcome email to showcase the brand. And the company does a great job: The lengthy email feels like one big arts and crafts project, complete with paint, yarn, and chalkboards.</p> \n<p>Another standout feature of this welcome email is that Michaels makes it immediately clear what value its future email communications are going to provide. After thanking subscribers, there's this nice bit of copy that sums it up:</p> \n<p>\"We're going to send fun stuff like DIY tips and tricks, invites to in-store events, and exclusive deals and coupons.\"</p> \n<h3>8. Sphero</h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Hello</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sphero-welcome-email.png?width=690&amp;name=sphero-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Sphero welcome email with BB-8 Star Wars Droid saying hello\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<p>Sphero's welcome email might in fact be the cutest one we've seen recently -- and it was sent from a galaxy far, far away.</p> \n<p>If you purchase a bluetooth-controlled BB-8, the friendly Droid from <em>Star Wars</em>, it was probably made by Sphero. And if it was, you'll have an email similar to the one above waiting in your inbox when you activate your new rolling companion.</p> \n<p>This email's subject line is what qualifies it for this list -- \"A little Droid told us you wanted our emails.\" By cleverly personifying the product, and being somewhat candid about its <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">email marketing</a> newsletters, Sphero develops a relationship with their recipients through the product you just bought from them.</p> \n<p>Besides showing you how to use your new BB-8 Droid with your smartphone, all this welcome email wanted to do was say hi -- just like BB-8 himself.</p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/\">InVision</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Video</h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/invision-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"InVision welcome email with link to watch video\" title=\"invision-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>When you sign up for InVision's free prototyping app, the welcome email makes it very clear what your next step should be: using the app.</p> \n<p>To facilitate this action, InVision's welcome email doesn't simply list out what you need to do in order to get started. Instead, it <em>shows you</em> what you need to do with a series of quick videos. Given the visual, interactive nature of the product, this makes a lot of sense.</p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"http://www.drift.com/\">Drift</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/drift-welcome-email-1.png\" alt=\"Drift welcome email with link to get started\" title=\"drift-welcome-email-1.png\"></p> \n<p>No fancy design work. No videos. No photos. The welcome email Drift sends out after signing up for their newsletter is a lesson in minimalism.</p> \n<p>The email opens with a bit of candid commentary on the state of email. \"Most people have really long welcome email sequences after you get on their email list,\" Dave from Drift writes, before continuing: \"Good news: we aren't most people.\" What follows is simply a bulleted list of the company's most popular blog posts. And the only mention of the product comes in a brief post-script at the very end.</p> \n<p>If you're trying to craft a welcome email that's non-interruptive, and that's laser-focused on adding value vs. fluff, this is a great example to follow.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April, 2016 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwelcome-email-examples&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 15:08:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"dd3aad22891870a7e45a5d47ea543ca0","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"edevaney@hubspot.com (Erik Devaney)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=400&name=Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn58@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-22-187_03a99e311eca0ea0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/virgin-america-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn97@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-28-584_8fdeac7429e2fd25.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/food-52-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn74@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-28-424_ce0f7ae78d84f539.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/preview_text-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn98@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-20-944_8ead1ba4a4c18e18.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/monday.com-video-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn5@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-28-632_6da7f4217aa13774.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/kate-spade-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn1@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-26-635_d1744136ddd5194f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/lyft-welcome-email.png?width=690&name=lyft-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn77@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-24-071_35eb0c271499fe78.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/ikea-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn38@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-26-280_ea99e095eb844cf1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/michaels-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn93@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-23-101_d651c206de0777df.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sphero-welcome-email.png?width=690&name=sphero-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn7@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-20-110_c2c78bb8f30c40d7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/invision-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn59@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-21-315_e35af7101e39b26a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/drift-welcome-email-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-19-945_08c1ef8de2ef95cd.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwelcome-email-examples&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn17@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-26-981_9041613ae476bd94.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336435},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Write a Request for Proposal with Template and Sample","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template","description":"<p>Whether you’re working for a small agency or a major marketing firm, you’re probably eventually going to need to fill out a Request for Proposal, or RFP.</p> \n<p>Your company can’t do everything internally, and when your business needs to purchase a product or service from elsewhere, you might need to shop around. An RFP allows you to collect offers from various vendors and select the vendor that best meets your criteria, both in regards to skill and budget.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Any time you outsource work to a supplier, there's a potential for issues such as miscommunication around the scope of the work and the compensation. What a good RFP does is eliminate gray area so that both parties understand what needs to be delivered, when, and for how much.</p> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: 300; letter-spacing: 0.01em;\"></span></p> \n<h2><strong>RFP Template</strong></h2> \n<p>Here, we’ve provided an RFP template you can follow for initial structure, as well as a sample RFP for further inspiration. But it isn’t one-size-fits-all — you’ll need to tailor your RFP to best articulate your company’s needs.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"Free editable rfp request for proposal pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/rfp-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagesir\"><em>Download a free, editable RFP template.</em></a><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"></span></p> \n<p>RFPs come in all shapes, sizes, and visual formats depending on the needs of your company and the work that must be performed. At the top of a standard RFP, you'll find the following:</p> \n<p><em>Project Name or Description</em></p> \n<p><em>Company Name</em></p> \n<p><em>Address</em></p> \n<p><em>City, State, Zip Code</em></p> \n<p><em>Procurement Contact Person</em></p> \n<p><em>Telephone Number of PCP</em></p> \n<p><em>Email Address of PCP</em></p> \n<p><em>Fax Number<br /></em></p> \n<p>The body of the RFP will contain additional details about the project, including:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#background\">Background/Introduction</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#goals-scope\">Project Goals and Scope of Services</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#selection-schedule\">Anticipated Selection Schedule</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#proposal-submission\">Time and Place of Submission of Proposals</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#timeline\">Timeline</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#elements\">Elements of Proposal</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#evaluation-criteria\">Evaluation Criteria</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#roadblocks\">Possible Roadblocks</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#budget\">Budget</a></li> \n</ol> \n<p>Read on to learn more about what goes into each of these sections so that you can build an RFP of your own.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>1. Background/Introduction</h3> \n<p>In your introductory paragraph, you’ll want to include useful background information about your company — who founded it, what product or service your company offers, what sets you apart from competitors, and where you’re located. If any vendor is serious about working with you, they’ll want this information before moving forward.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>2. Project Goals and Scope of Services</h3> \n<p>Next, you’ll want to outline the project you need completed, and the goals you expect to accomplish from the project. It’s important you get as specific as possible — even outlining individual tasks and criteria involved. You’ll want to include phrases such as “The award will be given to X firm,” with the “X” establishing how you’ll determine the best candidate.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>3. Anticipated Selection Schedule</h3> \n<p>It’s crucial you include a detailed schedule so vendors know if they can meet your deadlines. You’ll also need to give vendors a window for when they can ask questions regarding your project. This’ll limit the hassle, for you and for them.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>4. Time and Place of Submission of Proposals</h3> \n<p>Similar to paragraph #3, this is important information you’ll want to clearly present, so vendors know how and where to submit themselves for consideration.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>5. Timeline</h3> \n<p>By including a time frame in your RFP, you’re able to eliminate any vendor who can’t work within your time constraints. If you’re flexible on your time, you can write something like, “Our company hopes to finish the project within six months, but we’re open to negotiation for the right candidate.”</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>6. Elements of Proposal</h3> \n<p>If you don’t outline clearly and specifically what you expect bidders to include in their proposal, you can’t necessarily fault them if they don’t include it. It’s critical you outline a checklist so vendors know which elements you’re expecting to receive. It’s also a good test for who’s capable of handling your demands — if a vendor can’t complete all elements of your proposal, you probably can’t trust them to finish your project, either.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>7. Evaluation Criteria</h3> \n<p>Outlining your expectations will help eliminate vendors who don’t meet them. For this section, you’ll want to do some brainstorming with your team to come up with a mandatory list of items you feel are the best indicators of impressive candidates. Your list could include samples of past work, a proven success record with companies in similar industries, the expertise and technical skills to meet your demands, and a cost of services within your price range.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>8. Possible Roadblocks</h3> \n<p>Here, you’ll want to outline any roadblocks, such as limited resources or a custom website, that might prevent certain vendors from successfully completing the project. This allows you to eliminate unsatisfactory bidders, and it will also help you determine which vendors have the skills and expertise to tackle those challenges.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>9. Budget</h3> \n<p>Any vendor needs to know how much you’re able to pay them for their services before they’ll move forward with their bid.</p> \n<h2><strong>RFP Sample</strong></h2> \n<p>The above elements might manifest on the page in a number of ways. For example, here is an RFP sample from TemplateLab.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg?width=485&amp;name=rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg\" alt=\"rfp sample templatelab with tables and red headings\" width=\"485\" style=\"width: 485px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><a href=\"https://templatelab.com/request-for-proposal/\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Image Source&nbsp;</span></em></a></img></p> \n<p>Now that you understand the elements of an RFP , you can build your own template and then fill it out so that you can start accepting bids. We'll use a fictitious company, Caroline's Websites, Inc., to illustrate exactly how each section should be executed, starting with the header:</p> \n<p><em>Project Name or Description: Marketing Services</em></p> \n<p><em>Company Name: Caroline’s Websites, Inc.</em></p> \n<p><em>Address: 302 Inbound Ave.</em></p> \n<p><em>City, State, Zip Code: Boston, MA 29814</em></p> \n<p><em>Procurement Contact Person: Caroline Forsey</em></p> \n<p><em>Telephone Number of PCP: 227-124-2481</em></p> \n<p><em>Email Address of PCP: cforsey@consulting.com</em></p> \n<p><em>Fax Number: N/A<br /></em></p> \n<p>Next, we'll go into each of the elements of the RFP with information using the same fictitious company.&nbsp;<br><br /></br></p> \n<h3>1. Background/Introduction</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc. is a web design firm created by Caroline Forsey in 2010. Caroline’s Websites, Inc. prides itself on a team-oriented, solutions-based approach to web design. We provide our clients with web design services including coding, development, and branding. Our staff is located in two offices in Massachusetts.</p> \n<h3>2. Project Goals and Scope of Services</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc. is seeking the services of a full-service communications and marketing firm to develop and execute a comprehensive integrated marketing plan that increases our SEO presence; attracts more social media followers; and effectively completes a lead generation campaign. The award will be made to a responsive and responsible firm based on the best value and professional capability.</p> \n<p>The selected firm will be responsible for the development and implementation of a comprehensive and cost-effective marketing plan.</p> \n<p>Tasks include but may not be limited to the following criteria:</p> \n<p>• Lead generation campaign</p> \n<p>• Paid media strategy</p> \n<p>• Production of creative material including collateral and direct mail</p> \n<p>• Online marketing campaign</p> \n<p>• Website enhancement</p> \n<p>• Search engine optimization</p> \n<p>• General account management</p> \n<p>• Other communications and/or marketing-related assistance as required</p> \n<h3>3. Anticipated Selection Schedule</h3> \n<p>The Request for Proposal timeline is as follows:</p> \n<p>Request for RFP: June 1, 2020</p> \n<p>Deadline for Bidders to Submit Questions: July 5, 2020</p> \n<p>[Company Name] Responds to Bidder Questions: July 20, 2020</p> \n<p>Selection of Top Bidders / Notification to Unsuccessful Bidders: July 31, 2020</p> \n<p>Start of Negotiation: August 5, 2020</p> \n<p>Contract Award / Notification to Unsuccessful Bidders: August 31, 2020</p> \n<h3>4. Time and Place of Submission of Proposals</h3> \n<p>The RFP will be posted on our website, Carolinewebsites.com, and can be downloaded from there directly as of 10 a.m. on June 1, 2020.</p> \n<p>Respondents to this RFP must submit one original and five copies of their proposal. Responses must be received no later than July 25, 2020. Responses should be clearly marked “RFP-MarketingServices” and mailed or delivered to the contact person listed above.</p> \n<h3>5. Timeline</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc. needs the project completed within 8 months.</p> \n<h3>6. Elements of Proposal</h3> \n<p>A submission must, at a minimum, include the following elements:</p> \n<p>• Description of the firm that includes a general overview, names and credentials of creative team, number of full-time employees.</p> \n<p>• A one-page narrative outlining the firm’s strengths and distinguishing skills or capabilities as they might relate to Caroline’s Websites, Inc.</p> \n<p>• A representative selection of social media ads, direct response material, collateral, and website development created for current and past clients.</p> \n<h3>7. Evaluation Criteria</h3> \n<p>The successful respondent will:</p> \n<p>• Have been operating continuously as a marketing agency for a minimum of 24 months and possess full-service, in-house capabilities for marketing, creative services, production, media planning and placement, direct response and research.</p> \n<p>• The education, experience, knowledge, skills, and qualifications of the firm and the individuals who will be available to provide these services.</p> \n<p>• The competitive cost of services.</p> \n<p>• The expertise of the firm in working with similar customers.</p> \n<h3>8. Possible Roadblocks</h3> \n<p>At this time, Caroline’s Websites, Inc. currently has custom coding on our website, of which bidders should be aware.</p> \n<h3>9. Budget</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc.’s budget for the project is $8,750.00.</p> \n<p>These elements were written in a way to clarify the scope of the project that Caroline's Websites, Inc. wants completed so that suppliers know whether or not to make a bid. Defining the project allows the bidder to determine if they're a good fit and how much they'd likely charge. Being as transparent as possible serves to benefit (and even protect) <em>both </em>parties in the long run.</p> \n<p>To use some of these elements in your own RFP, start with an RFP template and adjust it to your liking.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frfp-template&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 13:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"b16f44ad020dd479d55a150de2981c30","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn31@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-21-018_59851a7ee2fb2497.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg?width=485&name=rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn69@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-20-788_f309d07aeec0f7ac.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frfp-template&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-27-947_f7220c7d633eea49.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336436},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"29 Free Resume Templates for Microsoft Word (& How to Make Your Own)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resume-templates-word","description":"<p>No matter what industry you work in (or your experience level in that industry), a plain, black-and-white resume written in Times New Roman font can actually weaken a job application.</p>  \n<p>But just because resumes have gotten more creative doesn’t mean you need special design software to make your application stand out. On the contrary, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-resume\">writing your resume</a> in good old Microsoft Word is still the perfect way to develop your personal brand, while also communicating your experience and career goals.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Read on to find out how to make your resume in word, then download one of these amazing resume templates that open directly in Microsoft Word.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Resume%20Template%201.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Resume%20Template%201.jpg\" alt=\"free editable resume pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-resume-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagesir&amp;_ga=2.167404795.472723192.1596558721-1675356138.1572978608\"><em>Download a free, editable resume template. </em></a></p> \n<h3>1. Open Microsoft Word on your computer.</h3> \n<p>If you have Microsoft Word installed on your computer, open the program and let it load for a moment. There will be a couple of helpful options waiting for you on the first screen, specifically for resume creation.</p> \n<h3>2. Select either \"Basic Resume\" or \"Bold Resume\" from the template menu.</h3> \n<p>Once you've launched MS Word, a window of templates will appear. Scroll down until you see the template options designed for resumes -- there will be at least two of them. Double-click the one that suits your style and personal brand, but don't be too particular about design just yet ... you can customize these templates quite a bit.</p> \n<h3>3. Fill in your name and contact information at the top.</h3> \n<p>When your resume template opens, you'll see placeholder text for each line of your resume, starting with your first and last name at the top. Delete this header text and enter your name, as well as any contact information by which you want the recruiter to contact you.</p> \n<h3>4. Draft a brief summary of your experience and goals.</h3> \n<p>Use the first line below your name and contact info to describe who you are, what you do, and what you're looking for in your career.</p> \n<h3>5. Enter your school and latest education.</h3> \n<p>List any relevant degrees or certificates you received through schooling. You can safely exclude secondary education if you've graduated from an accredited college.</p> \n<h3>6. Describe each job you've held using the lines prompted on the template.</h3> \n<p>Your professional experience is frequently the most important section of your resume, so feel free to rank this section <em>above</em> your skills and education, depending on how many jobs you previously held.</p> \n<h3>7. List all relevant skills.</h3> \n<p>If you have experience in certain software, exercises, problem-solving, or management techniques, use them to populate your skills. Your resume's \"Skills\" section helps reveal what all of your previous jobs or related experiences have in common, based on what they taught you and what you provided them.</p> \n<h3>8. Describe any relevant accolades and accomplishments.</h3> \n<p>Finish out your resume with any personal accomplishments or accolades you think a hiring manager in your industry would appreciate.
