Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg?width=1500&name=One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-22-378_316daa92eb250477.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-08-07%20at%204.02.33%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-08-07%20at%204.02.33%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn36@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-20-010_f6d635f92e47261a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/thoughtco-sample-business-plan.jpg?width=393&name=thoughtco-sample-business-plan.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn97@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-25-133_51fd7ded8b60314a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bp-plans-business-template.jpg?width=364&name=bp-plans-business-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn45@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-22-162_9babe8b954f3fb19.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/panda-doc-sample-business-plan.jpg?width=449&name=panda-doc-sample-business-plan.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn97@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-25-975_0baf09bda7ca0d19.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/small-business-administration-sample-business-plan.jpg?width=600&name=small-business-administration-sample-business-plan.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn90@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-20-891_576c6683d95c8c26.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/culina-business-plan-template.jpg?width=381&name=culina-business-plan-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn30@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-27-088_e3c40c2fa898691e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/plum-sample-business-plan.jpg?width=369&name=plum-sample-business-plan.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn15@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-19-964_d9d704974bc8556b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/live-shop-buy-sample-business-plan.jpg?width=345&name=live-shop-buy-sample-business-plan.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn13@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-20-996_9bbdf24d36d593ed.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsample-business-plans&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn48@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-19-930_c6f59bdfcd9e8624.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336435},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"The 11 Facebook Ad Campaign Objectives and How to Choose What’s Right For Your Business","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-campaign-objectives","description":"<p>Facebook ads are a great tool to get your message in front of the platform’s <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/marketing/facebook\">2.5 billion monthly users</a>. With such a large audience, you can understand why the platform is attractive to advertisers. Over <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/marketing/facebook\">7 million</a> advertisers to be exact.</p> \n<p>To succeed and maximize your return on investment (ROI) among so many audience members and competitors, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/3-takeaways-from-start-with-why?_ga=2.35710624.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\" style=\"font-size: 1.125rem;\">start with why</a> you want to use Facebook ads and what you hope to achieve with them. After all, your campaign objective is the first thing Facebook will ask you about when you go to create an ad.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">Your <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/1438417719786914?id=802745156580214\">Facebook campaign objective</a> — meaning the action you want someone to take after they see your ad — is one way the platform determines who should be shown your ad.</span></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Within <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/tools/ads-manager\">Facebook Ads Manager</a>, there are 11 objectives spanning the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/1438417719786914?id=802745156580214\">three overarching categories</a> of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/what-is-the-buyers-journey?_ga=2.35710624.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\">buyer’s journey</a>: awareness, consideration, and conversions.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20TK%20Facebook%20Ad%20Campaign%20Objectives%20and%20How%20to%20Choose.png?width=1500&amp;name=The%20TK%20Facebook%20Ad%20Campaign%20Objectives%20and%20How%20to%20Choose.png\" alt=\"facebook ad objective\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/adsmanager\">Source</a></em></p> \n<p>With so many options, the thought of determining which objective is best for you may feel a bit overwhelming, but no sweat — we’ll break them down below.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/facebook-advertising-training\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><em>Check out HubSpot's free course on Facebook Ads Training: How to Build Great Ads &amp; Audiences</em></span></a></p> \n<h2>Awareness Facebook Campaign Objectives</h2> \n<p>Awareness objectives help generate interest in your product or service.</p> \n<h3>1. Brand Awareness</h3> \n<p>As you may have guessed, these ads help <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-awareness?_ga=2.203484816.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\">increase people’s awareness of your business</a>. If you’re looking to introduce your brand to new audiences, this can be a great option. That's because Facebook will show these ads to members of your target audience who are more likely to pay attention to and recall the ads.</p> \n<p>Facebook <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/1029827880390718?id=429023050853196\">predicts recall ability</a> by polling users on whether they remember seeing an ad and analyzing their past behavior and interactions with ads.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind the sole focus of these ads is to make people aware of your brand, so you shouldn’t expect significant engagement or click-throughs. However, they <em>will</em> help you establish brand familiarity and pique the interest of your target audience.</p> \n<p>Use these ads to keep consumers aware of, and able to recall, your brand as well as highlight what makes your business and product/service unique.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to increase the chances of your target audience recognizing and recalling your brand, and the features that make it stand out from competitors.</p> \n<h3>2. Reach</h3> \n<p>Facebook reach ads are shown to as many people in your target audience as possible while staying within your budget constraints. You can even specify the specific location you would like your audience to be in, so the ad only reaches people near your business. An added bonus is the ability to choose the frequency of these ads, meaning how many times someone will see the ad.</p> \n<p>On one hand, this strategy maximizes the number of people who see your ad. On the other, Facebook doesn’t take into consideration the likelihood of the user paying attention to the ad. Meaning, you may end up paying for your ad to be displayed to audience members who tend to scroll past any form of advertisement on the platform.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to send your business message to as many of your target audience members as possible, even if it means attempting to reach those who typically ignore ads. This objective can work well for local businesses.</p> \n<h2>Consideration Facebook Campaign Objectives</h2> \n<p>Consideration objectives encourage audiences to think and learn more about your business.</p> \n<h3>3. Traffic</h3> \n<p>The traffic objective aims to send people from Facebook to any URL of your choosing, such as your website’s homepage, online storefront, app, event page, etc.</p> \n<p>Facebook does this by showing your ads to users who are likely to click based on their past behavior on the platform (newsflash: <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/full_data_use_policy\">Facebook knows a lot about its users</a>). By bringing more visitors to your featured destination, you’ll increase the likelihood of a user taking favorable actions on your landing page.</p> \n<p>Note that, with the traffic objective, Facebook is only responsible for collecting clicks and does not measure any action(s) — or lack thereof — a user takes once they leave the platform.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to direct viewers to a new URL destination so they can learn more about what you’re offering or promoting.</p> \n<h3>4. Engagement</h3> \n<p>Also based on past behavior, the platform shows engagement ads to those who they predict will engage with your ads in the form of likes, reactions, comments, and shares. The are 3 types of engagement ads: <strong>post engagement, page likes, and event responses</strong>.</p> \n<p>Post engagement and page likes will boost engagement for your ad and Facebook business page respectively. Event response engagement ads are a unique way to promote your event to increase attendance and get people excited.</p> \n<p>Engagement ads use social proof to determine where users are more likely to pay attention to, and be interested in, an ad after seeing how others interact with it.</p> \n<p>Take yourself for example — would you spend more time considering an ad with 473 likes or an ad with 14 likes? I’ll take the former, please.</p> \n<p>When others engage with your ads, their activity will also be shared with their Facebook friends, reaching even more people. Their validation will help your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/how-online-word-of-mouth-marketing-is-changing?_ga=2.216279574.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\">online word-of-mouth marketing</a>.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to establish brand credibility through likes, comments, and shares and increase interaction with your business on Facebook.</p> \n<h3>5. App Installs</h3> \n<p>This objective helps drive mobile app installs by taking users directly to the App Store or Google Play store to download your app. Facebook shows these ads to members of your target audience who have previously downloaded apps from ads to increase chances of your app installations.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose app installs ads to increase app downloads for your business.</p> \n<h3>6. Video Views</h3> \n<p>Facebook will push video views ads to your target audience with the objective of getting as many views as possible. These ads can be a powerful way to tell your brand story or show your service in an engaging and consumable. After all, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-trends-global-preferences?_ga=2.216279574.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\">a HubSpot report</a> found that over 50% of consumers want to see video content from brands.</p> \n<p>What’s really valuable about video view ads is their ability to help you retarget those who watched your video. You can retarget people who watched your video content to remind them of your brand and product/service in hopes of boosting brand awareness and conversions.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to use video to share information about your business and reach your audience via an engaging medium. Then, retarget your viewers to boost chances of conversion.</p> \n<h3>7. Lead Generation</h3> \n<p>Lead generation ads are a great way to embed <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/creating-lead-generation-offers-from-blogs?_ga=2.13713847.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\">lead magnets</a> and collect leads while allowing the user to stay on Facebook. Users submit their personal information in exchange for an offer created by your business, such as an email newsletter or workbook.</p> \n<p>The ability for the user to remain on Facebook is a huge advantage for this type of ad. This makes it easy for the user to fill in the ad’s form, while never leaving the page or straying too far from what it is they originally went to the platform for — this results in a seamless UX and can increase chances of conversion.</p> \n<p>Facebook can even auto-fill these forms by pulling contact information from the user’s account details so all they have to do is click \"Submit”.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to collect leads for your business with an enticing offer. This works best when the user is already in the consideration stage of their buyer’s journey and is therefore willing to exchange their information for something of value in return.</p> \n<h3>8. Messages</h3> \n<p>With the messages objective, viewers can directly message your business through the ad using <a href=\"https://www.messenger.com/\">Facebook Messenger</a>.</p> \n<p>This is an effective way to personally connect with users to generate more interest in your business. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/tips-for-connecting-with-your-prospects-on-facebook?_ga=2.13713847.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\">Engaging with your audience through Messenger</a> allows you to connect with your audience versus talking <em>at </em>them.</p> \n<p>Leverage your conversations as an opportunity to answer any questions, offer customer support, build rapport with your audience, collect leads, and drive sales. Messenger is a great way to show your customers that there’s a human on the other end, ready to help them.</p> \n<p>With these ads, it’s crucial that you’re ready to respond quickly and effectively once the messages flow in. Otherwise, prospective customers may lose interest if you’re not responsive to their inquiries.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to encourage users to contact your business through Facebook Messenger, if you’re prepared to respond in a timely manner.</p> \n<h2>Conversion Facebook Campaign Objectives</h2> \n<p>Conversion objectives nudge audiences to buy or use your product or service.</p> \n<h3>9. Conversions</h3> \n<p>The goal of conversion ads is to encourage people to take valuable actions on your website or app, such as registering for an event, adding an item to cart, or making a purchase.</p> \n<p>These ads are most successful when delivered to people who are already familiar with your product — likely, those who have gone through the awareness and consideration stages and need an extra push toward conversion.</p> \n<p>Installing the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/learn/facebook-ads-pixel\">Facebook pixel</a> on your website will be required for these ads to help Facebook optimize your campaigns. The pixel is a piece of code for your site that tracks each time a user takes action and converts through a Facebook ad. With each conversion, Facebook learns who to target in the ads to maximize conversions.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad to increase conversion actions on your site or app. These ads should be served to those who are already knowledgeable about your business.</p> \n<h3>10. Catalog Sales</h3> \n<p>The catalog sales ad is made with a holistic view of ecommerce stores in mind. Instead of promoting a single product or service, ads with this objective will show relevant products from your store to people who have demonstrated interest in them before. Facebook is able to recognize this behavior based on its understanding of your offerings and the user through its pixel.</p> \n<p>These ads require you to integrate your product catalog with Facebook so the platform can pull a selection from your store and adjust it as needed for audience members based on various factors, such as your latest arrivals.</p> \n<p>Catalog sales ads are also more specific than conversion ads because the end goal is to generate sales, whereas the goal of conversions ads can vary from increasing registration or adding payment information.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad if you prefer Facebook select which products from your catalog are most relevant for your audience, based on their <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/top-tips-to-machine-learning\">machine learning</a> predictions, in order to increase sales.</p> \n<h3>11. Store Traffic</h3> \n<p>The store traffic objective is perfect for businesses with physical locations as the goal is to remove the digital barrier and bring in-person foot traffic to your store.</p> \n<p>The ads are delivered to people who are physically near your store, so they are more likely to visit. It’s important to mention these ads target based on location only, which means audience demographics will not be considered.</p> \n<p>There are two necessities for store traffic ads to work. As the advertiser, you must ensure that all your business locations are properly entered in <a href=\"https://business.facebook.com/\">Business Manager</a>. For the consumer, their location services must be enabled so Facebook knows when to show the ad.</p> \n<p>With those stars aligned, you’ll be able to track your store visits at each location from the ad.</p> \n<p>TLDR: Choose this ad if your business has brick and mortar locations and you’re looking to increase store visits.</p> \n<p>Now, when you log into <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/tools/ads-manager\">Facebook Ads Manager</a>, you should have a better idea what all the campaign objectives mean. If you’re ready to roll your sleeves up, we can help you <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-paid-ad-checklist?_ga=2.210823829.1083519983.1595599444-826779246.1592840265\">step-by-step through the Facebook ad creation process.</a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-campaign-objectives&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 14 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4685d3f14348e543283548fcd16dd92c","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"msheng@hubspot.com (Maddie Sheng)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20TK%20Facebook%20Ad%20Campaign%20Objectives%20and%20How%20to%20Choose.png?width=1500&name=The%20TK%20Facebook%20Ad%20Campaign%20Objectives%20and%20How%20to%20Choose.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn70@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-25-654_92dcc68d8aeeee99.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-campaign-objectives&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn90@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-29-359_7ae1f33603068e88.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336427},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"18 Beautiful New Ebook Templates [Free Download]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-ebook-templates","description":"<p>Did you know that landing pages have the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">highest conversion rate at 23%</a> than other types of signup forms? But landing pages don't convert visitors to leads all by themselves -- without attractive and compelling offers behind them, they won't generate the tons of leads for your sales team that you want them to.</p>  \n<p>That's why it's so important to create valuable content people want to download, and then package it in a way that's visually appealing to your readers.&nbsp;A big part of the ebook creation process is making it look both&nbsp;professional and attractive&nbsp;so people want to read it and share it.</p> \n<h3></h3> \n<p>We know not every team&nbsp;has someone in-house who can (or has time to) whip up a slick, highly shareable ebook design. But we have&nbsp;good news: You don't need to be a designer by trade to design beautiful ebooks yourself. With the right resources and approach,&nbsp;it doesn't have to be a&nbsp;daunting task.</p> \n<p>We created <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates?_ga=2.146592881.413518659.1563195890-1307414301.1541080541\">ebook templates</a> to help make this process easier for you -- and they were so popular that <strong>we decided to revamp the offer for 18 new-and-improved ebook templates for you.</strong>&nbsp;We hope these templates&nbsp;minimize the&nbsp;time you spend&nbsp;on the details of design, allowing you to concentrate on writing valuable, lead-generating content your readers will love.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates?_ga=2.229139292.1301801515.1563199473-1093622293.1516842654\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Untitled%20design%20(20)-1.png?width=1000&amp;name=Untitled%20design%20(20)-1.png\" width=\"1000\" style=\"width: 1000px;\" alt=\"Free ebook templates by HubSpot\"></a></p> \n<h5 style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates?_ga=2.183779171.413518659.1563195890-1307414301.1541080541\">Download the Templates Now</a></h5> \n<h2>Start With One of These Free Ebook Templates</h2> \n<p>Here is a preview of some of the ebooks you'll find in the template bundle:</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\">Artistic Theme</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/artistic-theme.jpg?width=400&amp;name=artistic-theme.jpg\" alt=\"example page from the artistic theme that reads &quot;creative ebook template with an artistic theme&quot; in purple along with a dynamic photo of a laptop with purple screen\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>This template uses white space so that you can have your colorful headers, eye-catching graphics, and stunning images do all the talking. It includes several layout options so that the design is kept fresh from one page to another.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\">Professional Theme</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/professional-theme.jpg?width=400&amp;name=professional-theme.jpg\" alt=\"example page from the professional theme that reads &quot;creative ebook template with a professional theme&quot; along with a photo in the center and banded blue background\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Create a professional but bold feel with image-based title pages and thick, bold fonts. This template also includes photo-heavy pages, making it perfect for a showcase or inspiration guide.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ebook-templates\">Honeycomb Theme</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/honeycomb-theme.jpg?width=400&amp;name=honeycomb-theme.jpg\" alt=\"example page from the honeycomb theme that reads &quot;An Intro To This Topic of Your Choosing&quot; in yellow against a blue background where the bottom half is repeated honeycomb shapes\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Speaking of geometrical shapes, this one uses hexagonal shapes in the background and for emphasis, providing a striking honeycomb theme. In addition, you'll also find page layouts for quotes and captioned photos, making it a good choice for ebooks with a variety of types of content.</p> \n<h3>With these slick new templates, you’ll be able to:</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Create beautifully&nbsp;designed ebooks</strong> without either the cost of a designer or experience with InDesign/Illustrator/Photoshop.</li> \n <li><strong>Choose from six different ebook designs across three different platforms (Adobe InDesign, PowerPoint, and Google Slides),</strong> and even add your own brand colors to any of&nbsp;them in a few quick steps.</li> \n <li><strong>Spend more&nbsp;time writing awesome content</strong> and&nbsp;less time getting the layout right.</li> \n <li><strong>Use all of the stock images provided</strong> in the&nbsp;templates, free of charge.</li> \n <li><strong>Save your ebooks as professional and attractive PDF files</strong> that are ready for download.</li> \n</ul> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-ebook-templates&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 20:30:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"8e72a2fdff2910ad0a9d1b78559b49ea","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"rohiggins@hubspot.com (Rachael O'Higgins)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Untitled%20design%20(20)-1.png?width=1000&name=Untitled%20design%20(20)-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn75@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-19-996_2b510bef68326e19.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/artistic-theme.jpg?width=400&name=artistic-theme.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn27@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-21-897_106ee0b5ca9ce267.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/professional-theme.jpg?width=400&name=professional-theme.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-23-018_50b38fed2dc50a8a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/honeycomb-theme.jpg?width=400&name=honeycomb-theme.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn10@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-29-503_3759583ac9f7ddb8.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-ebook-templates&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn82@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-25-696_6d0b03d698b19e03.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336434},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"Which Format Is Right for Your Next Blog Post?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-choose-blogging-post-format-ht","description":"<p>Choices are hard.</p> \n<p>And when it comes to choosing the right format for your next blog post, there's quite the smorgasbord to choose from. Perhaps how-to posts are your forte. Or maybe you just can't resist the list. But just because you have a signature format, doesn't mean it's necessarily<em> right</em> for the topic you're blogging about.</p> \n<p>Aah ... decisions, decisions.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>It's okay though! We're here to help you through it. So in this post, I'm going to break down some of the most popular blog post types and formats to help you determine which one is right for the blog idea you've got milling around in that head of yours.</p> \n<p>That said, keep in mind that some posts may even straddle two or more formats. I've written thought leadership posts that could also probably be classified as list posts. And if I'd added a SlideShare to them? They would've straddled three!&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The point is to recognize that there isn't just one type of blog post you can create -- and some formats are much more suitable for certain ideas than others. Another thing to consider is that a lot of times, it will all boil down to the angle you take on a topic. For example, if I wanted to write a post about social media, there is probably a different angle I could take that would work for each of the following formats. It will all depend on the angle I decide to take.</p> \n<p></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Blog Post Types and Formats</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>The How-To Post</li> \n  <li>The Listicle</li> \n  <li>The Curated Post</li> \n  <li>The Thought Leadership Post</li> \n  <li>The Fun Post</li> \n  <li>The 'What' Post</li> \n  <li>The 'Why' Post</li> \n  <li>The Feature Story</li> \n  <li>The FAQ Post</li> \n  <li>The Interview Post</li> \n  <li>The SlideShare Post</li> \n  <li>The Infographic Post</li> \n  <li>The Newsjack</li> \n  <li>The Comparison Post</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3><strong>1. The How-To Post</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Step-by-step guide that tells your readers how to do something.</em>&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how-to-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=how-to-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of a how-to blog post format that has the title &quot;how to write an email signature&quot; with the steps displayed underneath it\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>This is one of the most common blog post formats for business bloggers. It makes perfect sense, considering how-to posts are inherently educational and great for generating traffic from organic search. Use how-to posts when your topic has to do with educating your audience about how to do something they might not know how to do.</p> \n<p>Oftentimes, how-to posts can also be strengthened by supporting visual components for concepts that lend themselves to visual explanations, like an instructional video or a visual aid.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-post-templates?hubs_post-cta=inline&amp;_ga=2.205173456.1791040395.1555933654-1307414301.1541080541\">Download a Free&nbsp;How-To Blog Post Template Here</a></h3> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/professional-email-signatures\">How to Write a Great Email Signature [+ Professional Examples]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-social-media-report\">How to Create a Social Media Report [Free Template]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-start-a-blog\">How to Write a Blog Post: A Step-by-Step Guide [+ Free Blog Post Templates]</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>2. The Listicle</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>List of similar items or content.&nbsp;</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/listicle-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=listicle-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of a listicle blog post with the title of the list &quot;interactive blog post examples&quot; and list items beneath it\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Another very popular blog post format, the list post (commonly referred to as a \"listicle\"), is characterized by content organized in a list. List posts are easily recognizable by their titles, since they usually include a number in headline, and they're great formats for beginner bloggers since they're very formulaic. Unfortunately, it's for this reason that listicles have gotten a bad rap, and are often perceived as low quality pieces of content ... probably because there&nbsp;<em>are indeed&nbsp;</em>a lot of crappy list posts out there.</p> \n<p>But when done right, lists posts are great for posts that seek to aggregate tips, tactics, or ideas under a certain topic, and they <em>can</em>&nbsp;result in high-quality content. Plus, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/9-reasons-you-cant-resist-list\">people love 'em</a>!&nbsp;To learn about how to create a high-quality list post,&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32105/The-Top-10-Qualities-of-High-Quality-List-Posts.aspx\">check out this post</a>. <em>(Bonus: It also happens to be a great example of a list post in and of itself, in addition to the few below.)</em></p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-post-templates?hubs_post-cta=inline&amp;_ga=2.239777475.1791040395.1555933654-1307414301.1541080541\">Download a Free&nbsp;Listicle Blog Post Template Here</a></h3> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/interactive-blog-post\">10 Ways to Make Your Blog Post Interactive</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-calendar-tools\">10 Social Media Calendars, Tools, &amp; Templates to Plan Your Content</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-techniques\">12 of the Best Marketing Techniques for 2020</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>3. The Curated Post&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Highlights and curates (usually external) content around a certain theme.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/curated-blog-post.gif?width=1321&amp;name=curated-blog-post.gif\" alt=\"example of a curated blog post that has compiled a list of ted talks with embedded video\" width=\"1321\" style=\"width: 1321px;\">Another post that has historically (yet undeservingly) gotten a bad rap is the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6800/A-Marketer-s-Guide-to-Content-Curation.aspx\">curated post</a>. Although it's sometimes perceived as lazy and unoriginal, curated content can actually be extremely helpful to readers, since the research component of them can be very time consuming, and the end result is a compilation of helpful resources all in one place.</p> \n<p>The curated post is ideal for aggregating content such as industry examples, statistics, quotations, and videos -- <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/19044/10-Great-Ideas-for-Valuable-Curated-Content.aspx\">among other things</a>. It's also great for building relationships with the other bloggers and businesses you highlight within your curated content.</p> \n<h4><strong style=\"font-size: 1em;\">Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/15-phenomenal-ted-talks\">15 Phenomenal TED Talks You Need to Watch Today</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/messaging-app-stats\">43 Messaging App Stats That Marketers Should Know</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34006/15-Examples-of-Brilliant-Homepage-Design.aspx\">15 Examples of Brilliant Homepage Design</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>4. The Thought Leadership Post&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Original data or opinions intended to make the reader think.</em></p> \n<p><em><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/thought-leadership-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=thought-leadership-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of a thought leadership post that includes original data from an experiment along with a section titled &quot;what we learned&quot;\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></em></p> \n<p>One of the more difficult types of posts to write, thought leadership-style posts usually take the form of pontification about things like where the industry is headed or industry trends that seem to be emerging and what they mean.</p> \n<p>For this reason, they're not really the type of post you can just decide to write at the drop of a hat, like, \"I'm going to write a thought leadership post today!\" Rather, they're usually the result of thoughtful examination of things you've noticed or have been thinking about over time, and they tend to be speculative and sometimes controversial in nature. They also tend to spark some great discussions!</p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/predictive-seo-hubspot\">Predictive SEO: How HubSpot Saves Traffic We Haven't Lost Yet</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-b2c-marketing\">Can B2C Marketing Succeed on LinkedIn?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/sprint-planning-marketing-hubspot\">How Our Marketing Team Used Sprint Planning While Working Remotely</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>5. The Fun Post</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Entertainment.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/fun-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=fun-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of a fun blog post with an embedded video from a movie trailer with kurt russel in dancing garb\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Because who doesn't love to laugh, smile, or be amazed? Content whose main purpose is to entertain <em>does</em> have a place in your content mix, and it can be very refreshing to your audience -- as long as it's in moderation.</p> \n<p>These types of posts are great for publishing during holidays, the end of the day, the end of the week, and other times when your audience is burnt out, winding down, or could use a break from some of the more, um, <em>intellectual</em> content on the web. Just make sure you stay true to the focus of your blog overall by ensuring the concept of your fun post has a relevant tie-in. For more on the benefits of entertaining content, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/why-publish-content-entertainment-value\">here's why you should publish content for entertainment value alone</a> every once in a while.</p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/the-12-best-sales-movies-of-all-time-list\">The 20 Best Sales Movies of All Time [Updated for 2020]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/funny-weird-interview-questions\">15 Fun, Weird, &amp; Unexpected Interview Questions (With Sample Answers)</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/funniest-social-media-tweets\">26 of the Funniest Tweets About Social Media We've Ever Seen</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>6. The 'What' Post</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Explanation of a concept.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/what-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=what-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of a what blog post with the title of a concept &quot;purpose of marketing&quot; along with an explanation of that concept underneath\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>The 'what' post is perfect for introductory-style content geared toward a beginner audience. In general, the 'what' post serves to introduce and explain a concept, whether it be an industry trend, tactic, or tool; and it typically highlights what it is and why you should care. Linking to or including a call-to-action for more in-depth, intermediate content (like an ebook or another blog post) about the topic at the end of the post is a great best practice for 'what' posts.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-post-templates?hubs_post-cta=inline&amp;_ga=2.239777475.1791040395.1555933654-1307414301.1541080541\">Download a Free&nbsp;\"What Is\" Blog Post Template Here</a></h3> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33894/what-s-the-deal-with-this-whole-context-marketing-thing.aspx\">What Is Context Marketing, and Why It Matters [Quick Guide]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-blog\">What Is a Blog, &amp; Why Should You Create One</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-marketing\">What is the Purpose of Marketing? [FAQ]</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>7. The 'Why' Post&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Explanation of why a concept is important.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/why-blog-post.gif?width=600&amp;name=why-blog-post.gif\" alt=\"example of a why blog post that relies heavily on statistics to make a point\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>These posts are great when you're trying to call attention to and emphasize the importance or significance of a certain topic, whether it be a trend, a tool, or a concept in general. Given their nature, these types of posts tend to be pretty introductory as well. In these posts, it's smart to back up your <em>why</em>&nbsp;argument with supporting examples, facts, and statistics that will help convince the reader the topic is something they should care about. Think about it as something of a persuasive article.</p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/user-generated-content-stats\">Why Marketers Should Implement User-Generated Content: 23 Stats to Know</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/make-data-more-human\">Why HubSpot's Director of Analytics Wants You to Make Data More Human</a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/why-publish-content-entertainment-value\"><br></a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32892/why-purchasing-email-lists-is-always-a-bad-idea.aspx\">Why Buying Email Lists Is Always a Bad Idea (And How to Build Yours for Free)</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>8. The Feature Story</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format:</strong> Mimicks the style of a human interest story, detailing concepts and ideas of specific market interest.</em></p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/feature-story-blog-post.gif?width=1321&amp;name=feature-story-blog-post.gif\" alt=\"example of a feature story post that provides commentary on a trend\" width=\"1321\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; font-size: 18px; font-family: AvenirNext, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; width: 1321px;\"> \n<p>This type of post is great for topics, people, or trends that are worth more in-depth, detailed research and commentary. One of the more journalistic types of blog posts, these articles tend to be hard to define in a blanket statement and more of a \"you'll know it when you see it\" kind of post.</p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:&nbsp;</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-data-download\">I Downloaded My Facebook Data and It Got Weird Fast</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lessons-from-remote-week\">HubSpot’s Marketing Team Worked Remotely for One Week. Here’s What We Learned.</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/third-party-cookie-phase-out\">The Death of the Third-Party Cookie: What Marketers Need to Know</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>9. The FAQ Post&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format:</strong> Question and answer (Q&amp;A) format.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/faq-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=faq-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of an faq blog post that contains multiple questions about seo and their answers\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>The FAQ post is another format that's great for beginner bloggers, considering the Q&amp;A format is a built in template. These posts are great for addressing common questions your audience has, grouped under a specific topic.</p> \n<p>A great way to generate posts like these is to ask your sales and services departments -- the people who are talking to prospective and current customers all the time -- to write down any common questions they hear. You can also collect questions you get from blog and social media commentary, as well as attendee questions during webinars. These questions are great fodder for Q&amp;A type posts, and as a result, they can become great <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33797/13-Types-of-Product-Content-Sales-Needs-to-Close-More-Deals.aspx\">resources for your sales and services teams</a> as well.</p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:&nbsp;</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-seo\">The Definition of SEO in 100 Words or Less [FAQs]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-faqs-list-ht\">Answers to 18 SEO Questions You Were Too Afraid to Ask</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33466/answers-to-the-19-most-frequently-asked-questions-about-a-b-testing.aspx\">Answers to the 19 Most Frequently Asked Questions About A/B Testing</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>10. The Interview Post&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Quoted perspectives of a third party. May also manifest in Q&amp;A format.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/interview-blog-post.jpg?width=1027&amp;name=interview-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of an interview blog post with a stylized quote from the interviewee\" width=\"1027\" style=\"width: 1027px;\">Similar to Q&amp;A formatted posts -- since these posts may also be formatted as Q&amp;As -- is the interview post. Fantastic for introducing the perspective of a third party on a particular topic, interview posts are also great for developing relationships with the industry experts or influencers you interview. They also open up the opportunity for greater reach, especially if the interviewee shares the resulting post with their networks.<em><br></em></p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rise-above-marketing-mediocrity\">How to Rise Above Marketing Mediocrity, According to Ann Handley</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/affordable-ai\">How to Implement Affordable AI in 3 Steps, According to the Marketing AI Institute Director</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/trends-according-social-media-professor\">2020 Social Media Trends, According to HubSpot's Social Media Professor</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>11. The SlideShare Post</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Features an embedded SlideShare presentation.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slideshare-blog-post.gif?width=600&amp;name=slideshare-blog-post.gif\" alt=\"example of a slideshare blog post with the hubspot culture code slide deck\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">Posts that are built around a specific <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/11137/10-Ways-To-Become-a-SlideShare-Marketing-Master.aspx\">SlideShare presentation</a> do require a little bit more time investment and design savvy than the average text-based post, but the results are usually worth it. Content that lends itself well (but isn't limited) to SlideShare presentations include the curation of visual examples, quotes, charts, quick takeaways, and general storytelling. SlideShare-focused posts also make great social media fodder, since <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33800/Photos-on-Facebook-Generate-53-More-Likes-Than-the-Average-Post-NEW-DATA.aspx\">visual content is so shareable and social friendly</a>&nbsp;<em>(Hint: LinkedIn also owns SlideShare ;-) )</em></p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34234/the-hubspot-culture-code-creating-a-company-we-love.aspx\">The HubSpot Culture Code: Creating a Company We Love</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/hidden-linkedin-hacks-revealed-slideshare\">21 Hidden LinkedIn Hacks Revealed [SlideShare]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/10-best-storytellers\">10 of the World's Best Storytellers [SlideShare]</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>12. The Infographic Post&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format:</strong></em> <em>Features an embedded infographic.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/infographic-blog-post.gif?width=600&amp;name=infographic-blog-post.gif\" alt=\"example of an infographic blog post with an embedded infographic in the content\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Similar to the SlideShare post, the infographic post is also one that is high commitment and high reward. Infographics, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/28436/10-Traits-of-Amazingly-Awesome-Infographics.aspx\">when done well</a>, are very sharable and likely to generate inbound links, but you do need some design chops to pull them off -- or the money to outsource their creation to a designer. Infographics are great for compiling data and statistics in a visual way. They're also great for organizing information in a timeline format, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/social-media-cover-photo-sizing-cheat-sheet\">presenting visual&nbsp;tips</a>.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-post-templates?hubs_post-cta=inline&amp;_ga=2.239777475.1791040395.1555933654-1307414301.1541080541\">Download a Free Infographic Blog Post Template Here</a></h3> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/state-of-content-marketing-infographic\">The State of Content Marketing 2020 [Infographic]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/intelligent-marketer-infographic\">Are You an Intelligent Marketer? [Infographic]</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resume-advice-mistakes\">9 Ways to Make a Resume Employers Will Hate [Infographic]</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>13. The Newsjack</strong></h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format: </strong>Capitalizes on something in the news in a timely manner.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/newsjack-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=newsjack-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of a newsjack blog post that features a newsworthy study\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>If you're unfamiliar with the term, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32983/The-Inbound-Marketer-s-Complete-Guide-to-Newsjacking.aspx\">newsjacking</a> refers to the practice of leveraging the popularity of a news story to support your sales and marketing goals. It requires the careful monitoring of news, and when done correctly, a newsjack post will relevantly tie the news to your industry in a timely fashion.</p> \n<p>To identify and capitalize on newsjacking opportunities, load up your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/google-reader-rss-reader-alternatives\">RSS reader</a> with a combination of popular news publications and popular industry publications -- anywhere you could potentially discover news relevant to what your audience cares about. Never jacked the news before? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/4-simple-newsjacking-formulas-content-teams\">Check out these four simple newsjack formulas to follow</a>.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-post-templates?hubs_post-cta=inline&amp;_ga=2.239777475.1791040395.1555933654-1307414301.1541080541\">Download a Free Newsjacking Blog Post Template Here</a></h3> \n<h4><strong>Examples:&nbsp;</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/two-thirds-americans-still-get-news-on-social-media\">68% of Americans Still Get Their News on Social Media, Even If They Don't Trust It</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/australia-stimulus-package\">How Small Businesses Can Take Advantage of the Australian Stimulus Package</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/covid-19-benchmark-data-edition9\">Deals Closed Rise Significantly as May Comes to an End [COVID-19 Benchmark Data]</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>14. The Comparison Post</h3> \n<p><em><strong>Format:</strong> Compares two things to help the reader make a decision.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/comparison-blog-post.jpg?width=600&amp;name=comparison-blog-post.jpg\" alt=\"example of a comparison blog post that shows the difference between ebooks vs whitepapers and when each would be appropriate to use\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>In the Consideration Stage of the buyer's journey, your buyer persona might be comparing two different solutions to address their problem. In the Decision Stage of the buyer's journey, your buyer persona may have already decided on the&nbsp;<em>type&nbsp;</em>of solution they want to buy, but they're looking to compare competitors to decide which one is the right provider for them.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In either scenario, you can weigh in with your blog content and provide helpful information as they make a decision. Comparison posts that are not overly biased and contain situational breakdowns have the potential to provide a lot of value for your audience.</p> \n<p>This type of blog post is also high-intent at decision-making turning poitns, so you want to do a good job and provide opportunities for conversion.</p> \n<h4><strong>Examples:</strong></h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6145/why-ebooks-are-better-than-whitepapers.aspx\">Ebooks vs. Whitepapers: Which One Should You Choose?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/organic-vs-paid-social-media\">Optimize or Advertise? Comparing Organic vs. Paid Social Media</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-vs-inbound-marketing\">Account-Based Marketing vs. Inbound Marketing: What's the Difference?</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>As you may have noticed, there's even a ton of overlap among the most common blog types and formats.&nbsp;What matters is that you understand why your reader would land on the post, what they'd be looking for, and how you can best provide value once they arrive.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img 9-328_b1ebdb8bf5df74db.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slideshare-blog-post.gif?width=600&name=slideshare-blog-post.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-36-288_047bfc93ba7777b9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/infographic-blog-post.gif?width=600&name=infographic-blog-post.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn16@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-41-147_374a058cd460e480.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/newsjack-blog-post.jpg?width=600&name=newsjack-blog-post.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn77@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-24-932_8cb4815ba8c0ae37.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/comparison-blog-post.jpg?width=600&name=comparison-blog-post.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn5@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-25-960_7c30a11c435bb896.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-choose-blogging-post-format-ht&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn82@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-21-372_773926de688ce612.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336438},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"The Plain-English Guide to Data Deduplication","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/data-deduplication","description":"<p>Nowadays, with so much critical information saved on our computer systems, we've learned to backup data regularly -- including our email inboxes, our Word documents, our photos, and entire folders of old work.</p> \n<p>It's typically a <em>ton </em>of data. And, since we usually backup and save our data on auto-pilot, we might not realize just how much has been re-copied and re-saved, time and time again.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, over time, our data storage becomes unnecessarily burdened with redundant copies of data -- this could cost your company money, as data requirements become larger, or time, as processing time becomes slower.</p> \n<p>This is where data deduplication comes in.<br></p> \n<p>Andrew Le, an IT Helpdesk Technician at HubSpot, further explains the importance of data deduplication for a business looking to grow -- \"[Data deduplication] really improves scaling and efficiency when pulling data from one source. If you have lots of the same data in different spaces, your entire system can be slowed down.\"</p> \n<p>So, you might be wondering, <em>\"How does this work?\"</em> Let's dive into it below.</p> \n<h2>How does data deduplication work?</h2> \n<p>The data deduplication process might seem intimidating, but it's actually a simple process.</p> \n<p>You can use data deduplication software when you backup your computer. Additionally, some marketing automation software, like HubSpot, might have a deduplication feature to keep track of your marketing contacts.</p> \n<p>To ensure you're optimizing your data backup storage, we've cultivated a list of the best data deduplication software you can use to minimize unnecessary data copies, today.</p> \n<h2><strong>Examples of Data Deduplication Software</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/contacts/deduplication-of-contacts-companies-deals-tickets?_ga=2.176575980.81589904.1554671928-644648569.1551722047\">HubSpot's Deduplication Feature</a></h3> \n<p>If you use HubSpot's CRM to manage your contacts, you'll be impressed to find out you can also use HubSpot's machine learning-powered deduplication feature to keep your contact database clean. HubSpot contacts can be deduplicated by a user token set with a cookie in their web browser or email address -- additionally, contacts, companies, deals, and tickets can be deduplicated using a unique object ID.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.barracuda.com/resources/Barracuda_Backup_WP_Deduplication\">Barracuda Backup Deduplication</a></h3> \n<p>With a 9.1 user rating out of 10 on <a href=\"https://www.trustradius.com/products/barracuda-backup/reviews\">TrustRadius</a>, Barracuda Backup is a good option, offering a robust, secure, fully-integrated data deduplication solution. Their tool can help your business reduce bandwidth requirements and backup costs. Additionally, Barracuda is a good option if your business needs to protect multiple sites, since its cloud storage technology helps distributed networks stay protected.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.dellemc.com/en-us/data-protection/avamar.htm#accordion0\">Avamar</a></h3> \n<p>Avamar, a solution from Dell EMC, provides variable-length deduplication, which reduces backup time by only storing unique daily changes while simultaneously maintaining daily backups. Avamar is an efficient, secure option and is particularly useful for virtual environments, remote offices, and enterprise applications.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://buy.hpe.com/b2c/us/en/storage/disk-storage-systems/storeonce-systems/storeonce-systems/hpe-storeonce-systems/p/5196525\">HPE StoreOnce</a></h3> \n<p>HPE StoreOnce, a solution from Hewlett-Packard Enterprise, offers disk-based backup, deduplication, and secure long-term data storage. Their deduplication software is equipped for virtual backup machines in small remote offices, and equally capable of handling high-performance dedicated applications for larger businesses. Ultimately, this is an impressive tool to help you keep your data secure and efficient as you scale-up.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://exagrid.com/exagrid-products/product-architecture/\">Exagrid EX Series</a></h3> \n<p>Exagrid implements a highly efficient approach to data deduplicaton that allows six times the backup performance, and up to 20 times the restore and VM boot performance. With Exagrid, you can backup your data straight onto a disk without inline deduplication processing, enabling a shorter backup window.</p> \n<p>If your company stores a lot of data, it's important to begin the data deduplication process. By using software, you can simply automate this process.</p> \n<p style=\"background-color: #ffffff;\"><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdata-deduplication&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 18:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4f5256bb04b3a5f3f4d5776a29c900e7","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdata-deduplication&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn70@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-23-021_2adf3bddfac19183.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336428},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Managing Remote Marketing Teams","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/managing-remote-marketing-teams","description":"<p>Behind many great teams are great managers.</p>  \n<p>Take my manager for example. Each day, she oversees a team of blog writers and editors, reports on the HubSpot Blog's progress to stakeholders, and also manages many of the logistics and processes that keep our site running smoothly.</p> \n<p>But, the blog's editorial processes and traffic strategies aren't the only things she focuses on. Most importantly, she takes time to empower each individual on our team. She mentors us as we lead projects that benefit the blog, plans team bonding activities, ensures that we're getting the tools and training we need to do our jobs, and checks in with us regularly to make sure the work we're doing is fulfilling.</p> \n<p>It sounds like she does a lot, right? And the kicker? Half of the team she manages, mentors, and empowers isn't even based in HubSpot's Cambridge office.</p> \n<p>By this point, you might know that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/management\">managing a team</a>, even isolated to one office, isn't for everyone. On any given day, you need to balance your own workload, overall team success strategies, and working with individuals within your department. To do this, you must balance being a team player and a leader. You also must be highly organized, strategic, and have a high level of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/emotional-intelligence\">emotional intelligence</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>In a company that's primarily in-office, a manager can directly impact the success of their team. But, this role is even more important when it oversees a fully or partially remote team.</p> \n<p>Why? When your team is widely dispersed, a manager is tasked with bringing together their employees and giving them the tools to work well together. In times of confusion, questions, or ambiguity related to remote work styles, the manager is expected to make calls or answer critical questions.</p> \n<p>As the manager of a remote team, you need all the skills of an in-office manager -- and more. Not only do you need to be tactical and organized, but you also need to take extra time to make sure that colleagues feel in the loop, included, and like they can succeed at your company. This takes added time, much more communication, and a strong sense of inclusion and empathy.</p> \n<p>Whether you're a new or experienced manager, moving from leading an in-office to a dispersed team can be a major transition. To help you, I've compiled a guide of 10 tips for remote team management. These tips relate to logistically planning your remote team's processes, building an inclusive culture, and using emotional intelligence as a team leader.</p> \n<h2>How to Effectively Manage Remote Teams</h2> \n<h3>Creating Processes Around Remote Work</h3> \n<h4>1. Create an effective remote hiring and onboarding process.</h4> \n<p>Before you can manage a remote team, you'll need to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/recruitment\">hire</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/onboarding-remote-customer-support\">onboard</a> your talent.</p> \n<p>To get started, use digital platforms such as Indeed or LinkedIn to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/recruitment\">announce and promote your new job position</a>. Be sure to note that the position can be held remotely in any location. This descriptive language will make it easier for prospective candidates to find your listings via search engines, as well as your own promotions.</p> \n<p>Our managers have seen that one of the best ways to interview and evaluate a remote candidate is through a virtual hiring process. While this process could include video interviews with hiring managers and the candidate, it could also include other steps such as a writing test to evaluate a candidate's writing or other virtual tasks that allow a candidate to show off their level of skill in a given area.</p> \n<p>If you can accept candidates in different locations and timezones, you should also take steps to accommodate them in the hiring process. This could include hosting an interview during their work hours.</p> \n<p>When you interview remote talent, you'll also want to put any judgments related to a candidate's location aside and interview them in their natural work environment.</p> \n<p>Additionally, \"If you’re hiring for a position that is open to being remote or in office, conduct all interviews via video call to avoid any location biases in your hiring panel,\" says HubSpot Marketing, Sales, and Service Managing Editor Meg Prater.</p> \n<p>After you complete the hiring process, you'll want to welcome your new hire with a smooth virtual <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/onboarding-remote-customer-support\">onboarding process</a> that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/onboarding-process\">teaches how the company works</a> while allowing them to get to know their teammates remotely.</p> \n<p>As you prepare an onboarding process for a remote employee, identify ways that you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/onboarding-remote-customer-support\">digitize your current onboarding process</a>. For example, if there are documents or resources an employee should read up on, make sure they are in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/onboarding-remote-customer-support\">a PDF, Google Doc, or online format</a>. You might also want to create an internal training website, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/onboarding-remote-customer-support\">or knowledge base</a>, where employees can find these documents even after they've completed a new-hire orientation.</p> \n<p>If there's an aspect of your onboarding that is too complex for a PDF format, consider doing a virtual training session where you walk your employee through various tasks. This will allow them to see a demonstration of a process they'll do first-hand and ask you questions about it as they learn.</p> \n<p>On the HubSpot Blog team, each employee's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/onboarding-process\">onboarding process</a> lasts roughly 100 days and can be fully virtual. During this process, remote employees receive virtual training sessions, links to blog posts, and digital resources that relate to their role, self-paced mini-online courses that familiarize them with our software, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tips\">informal virtual coffee chats</a> which allow the new employee to get to know colleagues.</p> \n<p>On top of virtual onboarding, every employee has regular check-ins, career chats, and ongoing training with his or her supervisor to ensure that they're progressing in their role.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, the goal any manager should have when <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/onboarding-process\">onboarding</a> remote employees is to make them feel supported, informed about how their company works, and more confident in their new role.</p> \n<p>To start an employee off on the right foot, think about your current onboarding processes and where they can be improved to add more communication and decrease confusion. Then, determine how you can make these processes virtual.</p> \n<p>As you identify elements of the onboarding process that can be made virtual, create an outline for your process. Then, to help you refine or improve on this process, ask new remote employees who undergo it for feedback at the end of their first few months. This will give you an idea of what's working and what needs to be improved.</p> \n<p>To learn more about the logistics behind onboarding, the paperwork you'll need to have your employee filled out, and the things you can do to make their experience feel welcoming, check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/onboarding-process\">this detailed onboarding checklist</a>. If you're looking to onboard an employee in a customer-facing role, you can also check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/onboarding-remote-customer-support\">this remote onboarding guide</a>.</p> \n<h4>2. Schedule and run effective virtual team meetings.</h4> \n<p>When you or your team members are remote, team meetings will be a crucial means of communication. Not only do they allow you to all join on one video call to talk about projects or goals, but they also enable teammates to get to know each other and stay visible.</p> \n<p><strong>Determining Which Meetings You Need</strong></p> \n<p>When you have a remote or global team, you'll want to have at least one fairly regular meeting to regroup and get on the same page. For example, you might want a monthly meeting with your team and other stakeholders to discuss team performance and goals, and a weekly standup meeting to learn what your immediate team is doing.</p> \n<p>\"Conduct a weekly standup meeting for everyone on your team to be together in the same virtual room,\" advises Prater. \"It’s important to have that face-to-face time each week.\"</p> \n<p>\"Our team starts by giving a one-word overview of how they’re feeling, followed by an ice breaker, a roundup of what everyone’s working on, and then a discussion article provided by a different member of the team each week.\" Prater shares.</p> \n<p><strong>Preparing for a Virtual Meeting</strong></p> \n<p>If you haven't already, you'll want to designate a meeting software, such as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\">Zoom or GoToMeeting</a> based on your needs, budget, and how large your virtual meeting will be. Then, you'll want to make sure that all of your team members have the program on their computers.</p> \n<p>When you're ready to schedule the meeting, be sure to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips\">pick a time that works for team members in different timezones</a>. Stick to this meeting time and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips\">avoid canceling</a> to ensure that remote employees who didn't get a cancellation notice don't tune in.</p> \n<p>Send an email and calendar invitation to your team explaining why you've decided to hold the meeting and what they should do to prepare for it. You'll also want to include meeting login information or a number they can call into if they aren't near a computer.</p> \n<p>If you'd like employees other than yourself to present at the meeting, it can also be helpful to create a slide deck ahead of time so each teammate asked to speak can submit and get their slides approved by you beforehand.</p> \n<p>Allowing teammates to submit slides beforehand will help you ensure that each teammate will give the most valuable information to other remote employees in the time they have to present. Using one slide deck will also limit any issues related to switching screen-shares during the meeting.</p> \n<p><strong>Running the Meeting</strong></p> \n<p>Just before you launch the meeting, make sure that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips\">your computer's sound and video</a> are working and that you have a work-appropriate background. You should also ensure that the environment around you is quiet and not distracting to your teammates.</p> \n<p>Once you launch the meeting, wait a minute or two before starting the discussion, just in case other remote employees are running late from another virtual meeting. During this time, feel free to mingle with teammates and get to know them.</p> \n<p>If you have colleagues that can't attend the meeting, plan to record it. This way, someone who wasn't available or had technical difficulties can listen to the meeting discussion after to stay in the loop.</p> \n<p>If the meeting includes a small group of people or a new employee, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips\">leave time in the beginning for everyone to introduce themselves</a> and give a brief description of what they do at your company.</p> \n<p>You can also consider a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips\">quick virtual ice-breaker</a>. As Prater mentioned above, this is something that the blog team has embraced in our weekly meetings.</p> \n<p>\"Ice breakers might sound cringe-worthy, but they single-handedly transformed our meetings from transactional run-downs of everyone’s to-list to a fun, personal opportunity to get to know our teammates a little better,\" Prater says.</p> \n<p><strong>Wrapping Up the Meeting</strong></p> \n<p>At the end of the meeting, leave time for questions. If you have some in-office employees and some remote employees, it can be helpful to invite remote employees to ask questions first to avoid teams accidentally speaking over each other.</p> \n<p>Then, send the slide deck and meeting recording link to your team so they can reference these resources later on.</p> \n<p><strong>Refining Your Meeting Schedule</strong></p> \n<p>As you start to run multiple virtual meetings, Nataly Kelly, HubSpot's VP of Localization, says you should continue to evaluate their effectiveness.</p> \n<p>After each meeting, Kelly says you should try to answer questions like, \"Are the right people in the meeting?\", \"Is this the right frequency for meetings?\", \"Is the meeting too long or too short?\", and \"Is this the best use of everyone's time?\"</p> \n<p>\"Often, you only need to change one variable to make things work better for a remote team,\" Kelly says.</p> \n<p>While it might be tempting to book your team with tons of virtual meetings to stay on the same page, Kelly instead advises that you leave team members with some flexible calendar space each week.</p> \n<p>\"Make sure you're not filling your calendar with eight hours of video calls per day. Encourage your team to block time to work on other projects,\" Kelly adds. \"Or, if the team lends itself to it, consider doing most of your meetings in the mornings and leaving afternoons for other work. Just make sure you give people time in their day that is unscheduled.\"</p> \n<p>To learn more about scheduling an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips\">effective virtual team meeting</a>, check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-meetings-tips\">this list of tips</a> and strategies.</p> \n<h4>3. Check-in with individuals on your team regularly.</h4> \n<p>When you or your teammate is working remotely, you can't easily turn to them to ask them a question, get to know them, or have a casual work conversation. This is why, on top of your roster of remote meetings, you should also consider booking one-on-ones or informal virtual coffee chats with people you don't often see daily.</p> \n<p>This will allow you to keep up with your employees, discuss their work with them, help them with any blockers they might be facing, and offer visibility so they can feel like you're an accessible manager.</p> \n<p>Aside from discussing work with each employee, Prater says you should also schedule times to discuss your employee's career growth and progress.</p> \n<p>\"The biggest worry I hear from remote folks or those being managed by a remote manager is that they won’t have the same opportunities for advancement,\" says Prater. \"I over-communicate when it comes to career growth.\"</p> \n<p>\"I have weekly check-ins with each of my direct reports where we talk about what they’re working on. But I also schedule quarterly career chats where I draw up a personalized growth plan for each of them, and we run through prompts to check their satisfaction in their current role and their aspirations for what’s next,\" Prater explains.</p> \n<p>Aside from scheduled one-on-ones, you should also consider leaving some areas of flexible time on your calendar. This way, if a remote colleague has a question or concern that's easier to discuss in person than via text-based message, you're able to quickly jump on a call.</p> \n<p>\"Be ready to jump on a phone call or video conference without having to schedule a time for it,\" advises,\" Susanne Ronnqvist Ahmadi, HubSpot's VP of International Marketing advises. \"Let your team know you're available over your instant messaging software and build “air-time” into your calendar for check-ins and quick talks.\"</p> \n<h4>4. Embrace and implement digital productivity tools.</h4> \n<p>On top of video call software, there are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\">many helpful tools</a> that you can use to manage remote or dispersed teams. Here just a few types of tools you should consider implementing:</p> \n<p><strong>Scheduling Tools</strong></p> \n<p>When everyone is remote, having an email or Slack discussion just to determine a good time for a meeting can be redundant and non-productive. Luckily, there are plenty of tools that allow you to request, manage, and schedule meetings with your team.</p> \n<p>For example, if you have <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\">Microsoft Outlook or GSuite</a>, you can see your teammate's calendars, working hours, and availability. Then, you can send a meeting invite for a time that they're free. From there, your teammate can accept, reject, or suggest a new time for an event.</p> \n<p><strong>Task Management Systems</strong></p> \n<p>With a task management system <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\">like Trello or Asana</a>, you can create a joint team project and assign different team members to tasks virtually. You can also give tasks deadlines and check to see if they're been marked as completed.</p> \n<p><strong>Instant Messengers</strong></p> \n<p>Ever got caught up in a giant email thread where multiple people were replying to the same message?
