An <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\">instant messaging app</a>, such as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\">Slack</a>, will allow you to create group threads to discuss projects, upload assets within the conversation, and see when other team members have replied clearly. This is also a helpful way to communicate with your team about topics that don't require a full video call to discuss.</p> \n<p>Aside from quick conversations, you can also host mini-meetings on your instant messaging platform. For example, the HubSpot Blog has a weekly meeting where we submit blog titles to a group chat and request feedback on them virtually. This takes little time and provides us with an opportunity to work with in-office and remote employees.</p> \n<p>To learn more about 35 remote work tools, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\">check out this detailed guide</a>.</p> \n<h4>5. Be mindful of timezones and remote employee boundaries.</h4> \n<p>Remote work options allow you to hire talent from every area of the world. This is a great way to boost the level of diverse thinking on your team and learn about different marketers.</p> \n<p>However, one challenge global teams face is adapting to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/teams-in-different-timezones\">teammates in different timezones</a>.</p> \n<p>As a remote team manager, it's important to navigate around your teammates' differing work hours, while also encouraging teammates in your timezone to be mindful of other remote teammate schedules.</p> \n<p>As you onboard employees or implement a team calendar, ask remote teammates to mark their working and non-working hours on their schedule. You can also have an intro conversation with teams to discuss timezones and preferred work hours, just to ensure that all team members are up to date with who will be working when.</p> \n<p>If a large chunk of your team is in another timezone, you might also want to consider <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/teams-in-different-timezones\">working on that timezone's schedule</a> one day a week or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/teams-in-different-timezones\">doing a split shift</a>, where you complete half of your work hours when one chunk of your team is most active and another do another shift when a team in another timezone is online. This strategy could help you be more available to your global teammates and stay in the loop of what they're up to.</p> \n<h4>6. Align with outside teams virtually.</h4> \n<p>At a company with remote or dispersed employees, you shouldn't just focus on your own team. You should also be sure to communicate regularly with other departments to see where your team's work can align with there's and where you can benefit the bigger business.</p> \n<p>One example of this is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-smarketing\">sales and marketing alignment</a>. While marketers aim to reach goals related to traffic and brand awareness, salespeople are focused purely on the bottom line. While both teams are vital for their businesses, they can get disjointed due to their differing success metrics. However, when these two teams work well together, marketers can hit their KPIs while also benefiting the company's overall sales.</p> \n<p>As a marketing manager, you should try to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-smarketing\">plan virtual chats with sales managers</a> and other teams to discuss goals and where your team can align with theirs. You can also use digital tools, like marketing attribution software, to get an idea of how your work impacts the greater company.</p> \n<p>In the long run, these meetings will allow you to think of the company with a broader scope rather than just focusing on your team's efforts all the time.</p> \n<h3>Creating an Inclusive Culture</h3> \n<h4>7. Take steps to ensure all teammates feel included.</h4> \n<p>Commonly, remote employees struggle with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-visibility\">feelings of disconnection and a lack of visibility</a>.</p> \n<p>Without an office filled with people, remote employees don't have the opportunity to make small talk with colleagues, ask questions, or have a quick work-related chat. This can leave them feeling unincluded or out of the loop on team projects. They might also worry that it will be hard to excel at their company if <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-visibility\">they aren't as visible as other employees</a>.</p> \n<p>To help each employee feel a sense of belonging, identify where you can make processes and group events more inclusive.</p> \n<p>\"We often remind managers that it truly is the little things that can make a difference in allowing a remote employee to feel included,\" says Siobhán McGinty, a Principle Marketing Manager.</p> \n<p>\"That feeling of inclusion can make such a difference to employee retention, happiness, and performance — so the little things actually matter quite a lot,\" McGinty adds. \"During the remote week, we heard lots of examples of how managers and teams go above and beyond in ensuring that their remote counterparts are included in the day-to-day.\"</p> \n<p>In a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lessons-from-remote-week\">recent post</a> about the HubSpot marketing team's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lessons-from-remote-week\">experimental work-from-home week</a>, McGinty offered a list of actions that could make remote teammates feel more included. These could include sending e-birthday cards, inviting remote teammates to in-person get-togethers via video call, or organizing a virtual gift exchange around the holidays.</p> \n<p>Aside from making your remote employees feel included through simple actions, you can also schedule activities that allow them to offer ideas or work virtually with the rest of the broader team.</p> \n<p>For example, you could host a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brainstorm-productive\">campaign brainstorm</a> where all remote members are invited to share their ideas. Or, before you leave for the holidays, you could expense your team's dinners and host a virtual hack night where you work ahead to ensure the business still runs smoothly when everyone's on vacation.</p> \n<p>Not only do team bonding activities allow the team to work together, but they also allow remote members to feel included and get to know their colleagues.</p> \n<h4>8. Identify opportunities for virtual team bonding.</h4> \n<p>It can be easy to think that your team is bonding during business meetings and team celebrations. But, the truth is, your colleagues might only see each other during these times.</p> \n<p>To build an even better team, consider virtual opportunities that allow teammates to get to know each other on a more human level.</p> \n<p>Just the other day, my team took part in a virtual Pictionary-like game called <a href=\"https://www.drawasaurus.org/\">Drawasaurus</a>. While this meeting had nothing to do with work, it allowed us to chat, learn about each other, and have fun with teammates we don't get to see daily.</p> \n<p>If your schedule is incredibly limited, you can also make time for virtual bonding in regular team meetings. For example, as Prater, noted earlier each of our blog meetings begins with at least two icebreakers.</p> \n<p>Aside from enabling teammates to get to know each other during virtual events, you should also identify opportunities where you can get to know the individuals on your team more personally. For example, rather than scheduling a one-on-one to discuss only work with a remote employee, you could schedule a remote coffee chat that's just devoted to getting to know teammates.</p> \n<p>\"As with any relationship, time spent together is important. And if you're remote, that time naturally is more limited. As a result, building rapport is even more challenging,\" says Susanne Ronnqvist Ahmadi, HubSpot's VP of International Marketing.</p> \n<p>\"I try and make an effort in getting to know the people I'm working with to understand how we can best work together, communicate, and interact with each other,\" Ronnqvist Ahmadi explains.</p> \n<h3>Using Emotional Intelligence</h3> \n<h4>9. Encourage empathy among in-office and out-of-office teammates.</h4> \n<p>When it comes to remote work, some of the biggest challenges that employees face are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tips\">feelings of loneliness and disconnection</a>. They also find it <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-stats?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Daily%20Emails&amp;utm_source=hs_email&amp;utm_medium=email\">hard to unplug at the end of the day</a> because their work is not clearly separated from their home life.</p> \n<p>As a remote team manager, it's important to recognize the challenges your employees might face and give them any other guidance when necessary. If you have any teammates who are in-office, you should also encourage them to consider the challenges a remote employee might go through on a regular basis.</p> \n<p>Recently, to help in-office employees understand the benefits and challenges of working from home, HubSpot asked the entire marketing department <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-stats?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Daily%20Emails&amp;utm_source=hs_email&amp;utm_medium=email\">to remote for one week</a>. While some people really enjoyed the opportunity to work remotely, some struggled with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-stats?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Daily%20Emails&amp;utm_source=hs_email&amp;utm_medium=email\">staying focused, communicating with teammates, and finding an effective workspace</a>. Although the experiment only lasted for a week, it gave in-office employees a taste of the workstyles benefits and challenges.</p> \n<h4>10. Use emotional intelligence at all times.</h4> \n<p>While you might be calm and collected when managing a team in the office, overseeing remote teams might feel different to you emotionally. Even though you can't see a team and they can't see you, you should still use<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/emotional-intelligence\"> emotional intelligence</a> at all times.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/emotional-intelligence\">Emotional intelligence</a>, also called EQ, is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-future-marketing-workplace\">a sought after skill</a> that enables you to understand your emotions and train yourself to react in an appropriate way to certain scenarios.</p> \n<p>For example, when managing a remote team, you might need to resist the urge to mistrust or micromanage colleagues that you can't see every day.</p> \n<p>In this scenario, leaders that lack emotional intelligence might panic about their team going off-course and begin to control every aspect of everyone's work. Meanwhile, an emotionally intelligent leader might address this concern by scheduling check-ins with teammates to make sure a project is on the right track.</p> \n<p>\"Resist the temptation to micro-manage, even if you feel uncomfortable about having less visibility into the day-to-day,\" says Kelly. \"Autonomy and flexibility are hugely important for managing remotely.\"</p> \n<p>\"Keep your team focused on the critical goals, and don't worry about how they get there,\" Kelly adds/ \"Trust them to solve problems and make good decisions, but set a high bar to show you trust them to accomplish great things with the privilege of autonomy and flexibility.\"</p> \n<p>In another common team management scenario, you might find that your employee made a big mistake when you were offline.</p> \n<p>While a less emotionally intelligent leader might send a long ranting email, someone who understands their emotions will take a minute to note what frustrated them about a situation and then plan a chat to discuss constructive feedback with the employee.</p> \n<p>\"No angry emails,\" Kelly advises. \"Trust and respect matter hugely for remote teams to operate well, and because email is more important for remote teams, it's important to keep emotions out of it where possible.\"</p> \n<p>Kelly explains that email and other digital communication should be respectful and \"not a place for venting.\"</p> \n<p>Emotional intelligence can also help you in scenarios when there's a disagreement amongst your teammates, according to Kelly.</p> \n<p>\"When you sense someone is angry or disagrees with a decision on a remote team, jump on a call quickly to resolve it,\" Kelly says. \"Don't let things fester.</p> \n<p>\"Sometimes, the lack of face to face interaction makes it easier for people to jump to conclusions or feel misunderstood. It's important that you signal to your team that if they are upset or concerned, that you're there for them,\" Kelly advises.</p> \n<p>While you should use emotional intelligence to manage your own responses, you should also encourage your team to use the skill in their work life, too.</p> \n<p>For example, if you find that someone is inappropriately venting over a communication platform. \"make it clear what people should do instead.\" Alternatively, ask your teammates to schedule one-on-ones or send polite messages requesting a quick chat to discuss a situation.</p> \n<p>\"Give your team an option to vent about things that won't be disruptive to others, and importantly, won't lead to side chatter either,\" Kelly says.</p> \n<p>When you use emotional intelligence properly, your teammates will feel comfortable coming to you with questions and concerns more often. They'll also develop a stronger sense of trust in you as their manager. Ultimately, a manager who understands their emotions and the emotions of others can manage teams in a number of different scenarios.</p> \n<h2>Navigating Remote Work</h2> \n<p>If you've never worked remotely or managed remote teammates, it might take time to develop the perfect dispersed team management strategy.</p> \n<p>As you build up your management tactics, your most important goals should be to help the team to function smoothly, build an inclusive work culture that enables employees to succeed, and use emotional intelligence at all times. While building solid processes is key to ensuring work gets done, taking time to build a positive company culture will allow team members from every region to feel like they can contribute their diverse <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/psychological-safety-according-to-edmondson\">thoughts, ideas, and strategies</a>.</p> \n<p>Want to learn more about the remote work style? Check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-stats?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Daily%20Emails&amp;utm_source=hs_email&amp;utm_medium=email\">this blog post</a> on remote work stats or<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tools\"> this post on work-from-home productivity tools</a>. If you're curious about how work styles like remote work could expand and evolve, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-future-marketing-workplace\">this post will walk you through</a> how the marketing workplace could change in the near future. You can also check out our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/management\">Ultimate Guide to Management</a> for more tips for running in-office and remote teams.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmanaging-remote-marketing-teams&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 17 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"64b4da052cbf2d14f2a5031252bbefeb","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"pbump@hubspot.com (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmanaging-remote-marketing-teams&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn34@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-27-036_cfaa5073f7d32126.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336427},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Conduct Research for an Infographic: A Simple Step-by-Step Guide","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-research-infographics","description":"<p>They say a picture is worth 1,000 words. In reality, a picture is worth closer to <a href=\"https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~afb21/publications/Student-ESP.html\">84.1 words</a>&nbsp;depending on a variety of other factors, but let’s face it, that’s not as catchy.</p> \n<p>The original point of the saying still stands, though: Images communicate information more effectively than text alone, and they’re best when working together.</p> \n<p>And, brands agree with the statement above. In fact, in 2020, infographics were considered the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?_ga=2.257152651.1039809124.1597073295-631527517.1595282187&amp;hubs_signup-url=www.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing-statistics&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\">third-most effective type of marketing content</a>, just behind blogging and video.<br></p> \n<p>But before you design&nbsp;an eye-catching infographic, you must first do the research to determine what story you’re going to tell, and how you’re going to tell it visually. And that research stage can be pretty tricky -- especially if you don’t have a plan.</p> \n<p>That why we put together a helpful guide that’ll walk you through how to conduct research for an infographic, without driving yourself crazy.</p> \n<h2>Why Marketers Should Use Infographics</h2> \n<p>There’s a reason infographics are such a popular form of content: Viewers love, engage with, and remember them.</p> \n<p>When people hear information, they're likely to remember only <a href=\"http://www.brainrules.net/vision\">10% of that information</a> three days later. Meanwhile, if a relevant image is paired with that same information, people retain <a href=\"http://www.brainrules.net/vision\">65% of it after the same timespan</a>.</p> \n<p>This is clearly a type of content your readers search&nbsp;for, so how do you make an infographic that’s informative, beautiful, and <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/anatomy-of-winning-infographic\">shareable</a>?</p> \n<p>Siege Media conducted a study on what makes infographics inherently shareable (the results of which they turned into a <a href=\"http://www.siegemedia.com/creation/infographics\">great infographic</a>&nbsp;of their own), and as it turns out, the most oft-shared infographics had an average of just 396 words.&nbsp;(For a point of reference, you’re almost 300 words into this article.)</p> \n<p>That’s some seriously effective storytelling, and if you want to craft a killer story, no matter what the content format, you have to do great research.</p> \n<p>You might think that all research is created equal, but there are specific tasks to ensure that you tell the right story for a graphical interpretation.</p> \n<p>Check out our list below for tips on how to begin your infographic design journey with a strong foundation of research.</p> \n<h2><span>How to Conduct Research for an Infographic</span></h2> \n<h3>1. Identify your audience.</h3> \n<p>Before you start conducting research on your topic, it’s essential to think about the audience who will view it. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Market research</a>&nbsp;is important because it makes you think beyond just one piece of content and instead about the impact it will have.</p> \n<p>Questions content creators should ask&nbsp;themselves before starting infographic research include:</p> \n<ol> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Who searches&nbsp;for information on this topic? What are their ages, job roles, and demographic traits?</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">What emotions do you want to evoke with your infographic?</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">What do you want viewers to do with your infographic once they view it?</li> \n</ol> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://images.google.com/\">Google Images: </a></strong>Hop into this search tool&nbsp;and check out infographics on similar topics. Then, drop them into the search bar and conduct a <a href=\"https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/1325808?hl=en\" style=\"font-weight: 400; background-color: transparent; font-family: proxima-nova, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 1em;\">reverse Google&nbsp;image search</a>&nbsp;to see what sites link&nbsp;to these graphics. What do they have in common, and what trends can you apply to your research?</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-template-creating-buyer-personas?_ga=2.92329885.1039809124.1597073295-631527517.1595282187\">HubSpot’s Buyer Persona Templates</a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-template-creating-buyer-personas?_ga=1.124373450.170111609.1470925141\">:</a>&nbsp;</strong>These templates&nbsp;make it easy to keep track of what your audience is motivated by and searching for. Even though you’re not selling the infographic, if you’re using this content to attract potential customers, you’ll want to keep their objectives and motivators in mind.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Leverage keyword research to find image SEO opportunities.</h3> \n<p>Once you’ve determined <i>who</i> will be searching for your infographic, you’ll want to figure out exactly <i>what</i> they’re searching for.</p> \n<p>In her article, HubSpot Customer Demand Manager <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/rachelsprung\">Rachel Liest</a> explains <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">how to conduct keyword research</a>&nbsp;for SEO.</p> \n<p>Key to this process is starting with broad topics and potential search terms, then&nbsp;working your way to more specific terms using quantitative data.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://google.com\"><strong>Google Search: </strong></a>At the bottom of a Google search engine results page, a list of related popular search terms appears. Below is an example of my search for “blogging.” (Remember -- start with broad search terms.)</li> \n <li>Use the related search results to dig&nbsp;into the information your audience searches&nbsp;for so you can better tailor your infographic research.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png?width=254&amp;height=145&amp;name=blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png\" alt=\"blogging   Google Search.png\" width=\"254\" height=\"145\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/trends/\">Google Trends:</a></strong> This tool shows you how searches for a specific word or term have evolved over time. If searches for a certain term are increasing, that may be an angle to pursue in a piece of content. <br><br>Below is the search history of “blogging” over the past five years. From this result, it’s reasonable to assume that search volume for this term is on a slight decline, and that my research process could benefit from more specific search terms to really pinpoint my audience.</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png?width=669&amp;name=blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png\" alt=\"blogging   Explore   Google Trends.png\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"blogging   Explore   Google Trends.png\"> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://adwords.google.com/KeywordPlanner\">Google Ads Keyword Planner:</a></strong>&nbsp;This tool&nbsp;shows you the search volume of terms compared to similar terms. This is&nbsp;helpful to determine which words or set of several keywords, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/definition-long-tail-keyword-100-words-sr\">long-tail keywords</a>, are the most popular in search. These long-tail keywords will help determine the angle your content should address.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-trial-keywords-tool\">HubSpot SEO Marketing Software:</a></strong> If you're a HubSpot customer, this handy app has several of the above capabilities already built-in. You can use the tool to conduct general keyword research and narrow your focus when selecting a topic. For example, I once searched for “blogging” and found that “how to make money from blogging” has a high number of search terms, so I might consider that angle as the topic of my infographic.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Keep search terms broad to find lots of data.</h3> \n<p>Once you start to conduct&nbsp;research on the topic of your infographic, don’t limit your content by what angle you <em>think</em> the infographic should pursue. It’s smart to do general research on a topic so you gain a basic understanding, but be mindful that it can influence the information you’re searching for.</p> \n<p>For example, if you decided to focus your infographic on how to make money from blogging and only researched advertising as a means to achieve that goal, the data you pull won’t provide all of the information necessary to create a comprehensive infographic.</p> \n<p>Research a topic, not a particular story or angle, until you have more concrete data.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/\">Google Scholar:</a></strong>&nbsp;This resource serves as a great place to start your research. It’s a free search engine of scholarly literature on a variety of different topics and disciplines that will give you an idea of the type of data aggregated on the topics you research.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"http://www.jstor.org/\">JSTOR:</a></strong>&nbsp;This tool provides a&nbsp;database of primary resources, such as journals, original research, and books. You may need to purchase login access ($19.50/month) or log in through the credentials of an academic institution you’re associated with.</li> \n <li><i><strong><a href=\"https://hbr.org/\">Harvard Business Review:</a></strong>&nbsp;HBR</i>&nbsp;is a scholarly magazine that publishes research, case studies, and statistics on a variety of different topics, including business, leadership, strategy, and economics.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Pull data from reputable, original, and validated sources.</h3> \n<p>When you find data during your research process, we recommend the following standards to decide&nbsp;whether or not to use it in your content:</p> \n<p><strong>Is it original?</strong></p> \n<p>Find the original data source for any statistics you encounter during your research process. Due to the plethora of different blogs and news outlets, many different websites can cite the same statistic without citing its original source. If you find a compelling data point that you want to use in your infographic, trace it to the original research source.</p> \n<p>If you can’t find the original source, the statistic is unsubstantiated and shouldn’t be used.</p> \n<p><strong>Is it reputable?</strong></p> \n<p>Another question to ask yourself <i>when</i> conducting research is <i>where</i> you’re conducting research. Any individual or organization can start a website and publish content, but that doesn’t mean all content on the internet can be taken as fact.</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.verticalmeasures.com/content-marketing-2/how-to-do-research-for-an-infographic-video/\">Vertical Measures</a>&nbsp;recommends starting internet research on .gov, .edu, and .org sites, which are associated with governing bodies, educational institutions, and organizations with greater legitimacy than blogs or individuals.</p> \n<p><strong>Can it be validated?</strong></p> \n<p>Even if you find a statistic on a reputable source, you’re not done yet. <a href=\"https://raventools.com/blog/infographic-research/\">Raven Tools</a>&nbsp;recommends that researchers make sure to properly fact-check information they find by a) determining if it’s cited by any other organizations or b) checking the methodology of its original research. If the data point seems unreasonable, trust your instincts and dig deeper.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"http://www.pewresearch.org/\">Pew Research Center:</a></strong>&nbsp;\"From economic conditions, to political attitudes, to social media usage, the Pew Research Center website has a ton of free research that you can use to better understand your target market,\" noted HubSpot Content Strategy Manager <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/jamioetting\">Jami Oetting</a>&nbsp;in her roundup of the&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-tools-resources#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">best market research tools</a>.&nbsp;Check out the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-tools-resources?&amp;_ga=1.230592218.7546083.1477915232#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">full article</a> for even more related tools.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/\">HubSpot Research:</a></strong>&nbsp;Our very own research hub offers free market research data and <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/charts?_ga=1.150021622.170111609.1470925141\">presentation tools</a> to visualize your data.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Use recent data.</h3> \n<p>You've put time and resources into researching and designing a great infographic.</p> \n<p>Make sure you cite recent data so other sources will be interested in referencing&nbsp;your graphic once it's published.</p> \n<p>We recommend sticking with data that’s one to two years old so your graphic will be relevant for months to come.</p> \n<p>As a caveat, some original research data that would make a compelling case for your infographic may have set the standard for its industry more than two years ago.</p> \n<p>For example, I’ve referenced research on the <a href=\"https://www.cmu.edu/dietrich/sds/docs/loewenstein/PsychofCuriosity.pdf\">curiosity gap</a>&nbsp;that’s from 1994 in previous posts, as this original study coined the term that’s still used today.</p> \n<p>The trick is to find <a href=\"https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1308286\">more recent research</a>&nbsp;that re-tests and substantiates the original theory so it’s a legitimate data point, instead of simply dropping an older statistic into your infographic.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.google.com/advanced_search\"><strong>Google Advanced Search:</strong></a>&nbsp;This feature allows you to limit search results to a certain timeframe to search&nbsp;for only the most recent info available. If you have trouble, widen the time range slightly. To set this up, enter a search term, select ‘Search Tools’ in the menu bar at the top of the page, and narrow your results by choosing how recently you want the data to have been published.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google%20advanced%20search.png?width=640&amp;name=google%20advanced%20search.png\" alt=\"google advanced search results for blogging.png\" width=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p>With the feature above, you can filter your search engine results according to when articles were published and according to their domains (.gov, .edu, .org, .com), among other features.</p> \n<h3>6. Imagine how your data could be visualized.</h3> \n<p>Remember what Siege Media found?</p> \n<p>The most-shared infographics had an average of just under 400 words. This means that the graphics relied on data visualizations, charts, and illustrations to tell the data’s story.</p> \n<p>Research for a blog post is different than research for an infographic because visitors expect to read a blog, but they don’t necessarily anticipate close-reading a graphic.</p> \n<p>Think about data that can be turned into visuals while you research. Numbers, such as percentages, survey results, and change over time can be easily <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/data-visualization-choosing-chart-0?hs_preview=SwwNpWDi-4361706628#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">visualized</a>&nbsp;using graphs and charts.</p> \n<p>Are there categories within your data that you can visualize using icons or illustrations? Can you turn a multi-step process into a mini-graphic instead of writing it out?</p> \n<p>Analyze all of your research findings wearing the hat of an illustrator and ask yourself if there’s a balance between data that can be visualized and data that must be written out.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva:</a></strong> HubSpot Senior Content Strategist <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/amandazantalwiener\">Amanda Zantal-Wiener</a>&nbsp;wrote an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resources-for-creating-infographics#sm.000825bf4hgvedv10qu25jm8py60v\">article</a>&nbsp;about tools to make your own infographics, and Canva made the top of the list. Even if you won't design your infographic yourself, experiment with this design tool (and others on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resources-for-creating-infographics?&amp;_ga=1.235833927.7546083.1477915232#sm.00001jv8k2j9vzembr7434ir2v3u3\">the list</a>) to see how easily your data can, or cannot, be visualized.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>7. Use the data you've compiled to craft a story.</h3> \n<p>When you think you’re done with your research, try to lay out the story that your graphic will tell. You may even want to storyboard your infographic: Write out your data points, and lay them out according to the order they’ll be visualized in the infographic. Does the story make sense? If the story isn’t clear or obvious, then you’re not done researching.</p> \n<p>It’s easy to get stuck in the story you think your graphic should tell, but does your research data actually tell the story? <a href=\"http://www.verticalmeasures.com/content-marketing-2/how-to-do-research-for-an-infographic-video/\">Vertical Measures</a>&nbsp;suggests that you let&nbsp;the research drive the topic and narrative of the infographic. If you’re stuck in what you think the data should be saying, you run the risk of citing your research in a way that manipulates the data.</p> \n<p>If a data point isn’t self-evident as a visualization, it’s probably not the right data point, or it doesn’t have the right context. Go back and gather more research if you can’t craft a story that makes sense with just the data -- If you have to fill in too much with text, it will make for a visually unappealing and potentially incorrect infographic.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/trello-board-tips-for-teams#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Trello</a>.</strong>&nbsp;This interactive planning and organizing tool lets you create cards that you can move around your board to organize in any way you want. You can storyboard using Trello by creating cards with different statistics on them and rearranging them to create a skeleton for your infographic.</li> \n <li><strong>Index Cards:</strong>&nbsp;Okay, so this one requires you to get a little crafty, but it's actually my personal favorite method. Write out the key facts of your story and start laying them out on your desk to get an idea of your infographic’s flow.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>8. Choose a provocative fact to anchor your infographic.</h3> \n<p>Strong infographics are loaded with interesting data that’s beautifully illustrated. These infographics are shared when they prompt an emotional response.</p> \n<p>Content that shocks, disgusts, saddens, delights, or scares people performs well: Researchers Jacopo Staiano and Marco Guerini found that content that prompts feelings of <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1503.04723.pdf\">valence, arousal, and dominance</a>&nbsp;tends to go viral.</p> \n<p>Additionally, in an analysis of photos shared on Reddit,&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.frac.tl/research/viral-emotions-study-2\">Fractl</a>&nbsp;found that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/shareable-content-emotions#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">positive emotions</a>&nbsp;were most likely to generate virality, but that content that provoked negative emotions with the right combination of arousal and dominance could be hits as well.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://raventools.com/blog/infographic-research/\">Raven Tools</a>&nbsp;and <a href=\"http://killerinfographics.com/conducting-research-that-matters.html\">Killer Infographics</a>&nbsp;suggest finding a data point that gets to the heart of the topic you’re tackling to hook your reader and incite an emotion that will make them share your graphic. Then, use that hook as the infographic’s visual focal point, and build the rest of your story around it.</p> \n<p>Check out Siege Media’s meta <a href=\"http://www.siegemedia.com/most-popular-infographics\">infographic</a>&nbsp;about what makes infographics popular. They visualize and highlight the most surprising findings first to keep viewers scrolling, and then break down each finding with more research results.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/siegemedia.png?width=669&amp;name=siegemedia.png\" alt=\"siegemedia infographic example\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"siegemedia.png\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://www.siegemedia.com/creation/infographics\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px;\">Image Source</span></a></p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/\">Google Search:</a>&nbsp;</strong>To avoid being&nbsp;repetitive, &nbsp;“[topic] + infographic” to see what else is out there. Ask yourself:&nbsp;<span>Has this angle already been covered, or would you provide a unique view on the topic?</span></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>9. Get feedback from your peers.</h3> \n<p>This may seem obvious, but feedback is a critical step in determining when the research phase is over and when writing and designing your infographic can begin. Before presenting a design proposal to your manager or client, tap your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/peer-feedback-tips#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">peers</a>&nbsp;for their input. Ask questions like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Do you understand the story’s flow?</li> \n <li>Is the hook of the infographic interesting?</li> \n <li>Does this data need further explanation to make sense?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>It’s often challenging to remove yourself from a project you’re immersed in to honestly edit it, so feedback during the research phase will identify any weaknesses that may need to be addressed with the help of further fact-finding.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/drive/\">Google Drive:</a></strong>&nbsp;Teams can provide feedback on documents and images by sharing them on Google Drive&nbsp;and leaving feedback comments.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201740\">PDF Preview:</a></strong>&nbsp;This tool lets you edit image files and share them with your team for feedback. They can add comments or delete items from the infographic and share their feedback with you by sending PDF or JPEG files back and forth.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Ready to Research?</h2> \n<p>In most cases, great&nbsp;data is the foundation of a successful infographic, so it’s worth investing time and efforts in finding the most relevant, current, and credible information out there.</p> \n<p>Key to the process is remaining open to letting the research inform the editorial strategy, instead of the other way around. And once you’re ready to start designing, check out these <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-infographics-2015\">infographic examples</a>, as well as these free <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-create-infographics-in-powerpoint\">infographic templates</a>, for inspiration.</p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-research-infographics&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"643f098f02205a5c8e23435e2787f2fd","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"sbernazzani@hubspot.com (Sophia Bernazzani)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png?width=254&height=145&name=blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-29-217_7f8742ea24234da2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png?width=669&name=blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn2@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-22-25-169_3377173d282654c4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google%20advanced%20search.png?width=640&name=google%20advanced%20search.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn38@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-25-479_b73c127c3e0bb3a4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/siegemedia.png?width=669&name=siegemedia.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn52@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-22-23-689_6381f7ebe3d7232b.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-research-infographics&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn50@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-26-346_a0b6e07efdc17a1c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336434},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"How to Use Instagram Insights (in 9 Easy Steps)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-use-instagram-insights","description":"<p>It's no&nbsp;secret that we love data.</p>  \n<p>Data helps you understand your audience. It tells you how they do things, what they prefer, and who they are.</p> \n<p>And when it comes to social media, our love for data doesn't fade.</p> \n<p>That's why we love analytics and insights. They help you measure the impact of your marketing efforts across different channels to see if there's something you need to do differently -- like target a different audience, post at a certain time of day, or experiment with a new content format.</p> \n<p>Instagram Insights are no exception. Here are the analytics on this channel that marketers need to know and understand -- and how to use them.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>To use Instagram Insights, you must first have a business profile.</p> \n<p>If you're already using a personal account, you can switch to a business profile. In order to have a Business Account, you must also have a Facebook Page for your brand. Instagram will give you the option to create a new one during this process if you don't already have one. Here's how to convert your account in a few simple steps.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Once your set up as a Business Account, you can begin to use Instagram Insights. Here's how to get started.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Click the insights icon.</h3> \n<p>To view insights into your overall Instagram account, start by visiting your profile. Then, at the top, click the icon of a bar chart, which will take you to your overall insights.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2136%20copy.png?width=300&amp;name=IMG_2136%20copy.png\" alt=\"Instagram Profile with circled Instagram Insights Icon\" width=\"300\" title=\"IMG_2136 copy.png\" style=\"width: 300px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>From there, you'll see some general information about people are engaging with your profile, like how many followers you gained or lost in the past week.</p> \n<p>Next, we'll get into the more specific profile insights you can explore.</p> \n<h3>2. View your impressions and reach.</h3> \n<p>This insight represents how many times your ads appeared on users' screens. Reach reflects the number of unique users that have seen any of your Instagram posts.</p> \n<h3>3. Determine website clicks.</h3> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times any links you've included in your business profile have been clicked.</p> \n<h3>4. Track profile visits and followers.</h3> \n<p>Profile visits reflects the number of times your profile has been viewed. Followers reflect how many followers you've gained or lost over the past week, as well as the average times of day when your followers are using Instagram — data that can be highly beneficial when planning posts. To view insights for a specific Instagram post, start by visiting your profile. Tap on the post you'd like to look into, then click \"View Insights\" below the image.</p> \n<h3>5. Click view insights below a post for specifics.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>You may have also promoted a certain post -- if that's the case, an arrow icon that looks like this will appear:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg?width=59&amp;name=13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg\" alt=\"View Post insights button on Instagram\" title=\"13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg\" width=\"59\" style=\"width: 59px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>For these posts, you can either view insights on the original version of the post, or specific ones from its promotion. For the latter, tap \"Promotion.\"</p> \n<p>Next, we'll get into the more specific post insights you can explore.</p> \n<h3>6. View your posts likes, comments, and saves.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Likes speaks for itself, and reflects the number of users who liked your post. As with likes, comments reflects the number of comments left on your post. Saves highlights the number of unique users or accounts who saved your post, or clicked the bookmark-like icon that appeared below it in their feeds.</p> \n<h3>7. Learn which actions were taken on your post.</h3> \n<p>These insights indicate the number of actions that users took on your profile as a result of seeing your post -- things like visiting your profile, then taking an action like clicking on your website link or following you.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png?width=308&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png\" alt=\"Instagram Insights Actions Feature\" title=\"Screen Shot 2018-01-18 at 2.01.33 PM.png\" width=\"308\" style=\"width: 308px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/788388387972460?helpref=related&amp;ref=related#\">Instagram</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>8. Use Discover to see where your post showed up in feeds.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>As the name might suggest, these insights indicate <em>where</em> your post was seen -- or discovered -- the most, including how many accounts weren't already following you when they first saw the post.</p> \n<p>This section includes metrics on Impressions, which reflect the number of times your post was discovered from a particular place within Instagram, like the user's home feed, a search, your profile, a location tag, or a hashtag.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png?width=433&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png\" alt=\"Instagram Insights Discovery Feature\" title=\"Screen Shot 2018-01-18 at 2.06.26 PM\" width=\"433\" style=\"width: 433px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/788388387972460?helpref=related&amp;ref=related#\">Instagram</a></em></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Discovery insights also include data on a post's reach -- which reflects the number of unique accounts that saw your post.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">9. View Instagram Story Insights</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span style=\"font-size: 1em;\">Finally, Instagram users with a business profile are able to view insights into their ephemeral Stories. Instagram does not, however, offer such analytics for live videos.</span></p> \n<p>To view your Story insights, start by visiting your profile. Then, at the top, tap the icon of the bar chart, which will take you to your overall profile insights.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2136%20copy.png?width=300&amp;name=IMG_2136%20copy.png\" alt=\"Instagram profile insights feature\" width=\"300\" title=\"IMG_2136 copy.png\" style=\"width: 300px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Scroll down to the Stories section, and you'll be able to see insights for older stories, as well as any that have not yet expired.</p> \n<p>Next, we'll get into the more specific Story insights you can explore.</p> \n<h4>Impressions</h4> \n<p>This insight represents how many times your Story was seen.</p> \n<p>When viewing these insights, keep in mind that you're able to add multiple images or videos to your Story. When you do this, every piece of visual content in your Story is counted as a single photo or video in your post.</p> \n<p>Let's say you add six photos to your Story. Whether someone only views one or views all six, Instagram only counts your entire Story having received <em>one</em> impression.</p> \n<p>The same goes for Story content that has been viewed by a single user more than once. Instagram still only counts that interaction as the entire Story having received one impression.</p> \n<h4>Reach</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of unique users that have seen your Story.</p> \n<h4>Taps Forward</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times a user taps your Story photo or video to skip to the next piece of media.</p> \n<h4>Taps Back</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of time a user taps your Story photo or video to go back to the previous piece of media.</p> \n<h4>Replies</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times users send messages through the \"Send Message\" text box on your Story.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2138%20copy.png?width=300&amp;name=IMG_2138%20copy.png\" alt=\"Replies on Instagram Stories\" title=\"IMG_2138 copy\" width=\"300\" style=\"width: 300px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h4>Swipe Aways</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times users swipe to skip to the <em>next account’s</em> Story -- not to be mistaken for \"tap forward,\" which reflects users skipping ahead to <em>your</em> next piece of Story media.</p> \n<h4>Exits</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times a user leaves the Stories section entirely to return to the home feed.</p> \n<p>Now that you know how to measure the effectiveness of your Instagram strategy using Insights, you can analyze that data and determine what's working for your audience. From there, creating content that gets a ton of engagement will be a lot easier as you consider those benchmarks.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in January 2018 but has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-use-instagram-insights&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 13 Aug 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"eecd826bb39f09b5e07cac1f62ae055f","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Amanda Zantal-Wiener","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2136%20copy.png?width=300&name=IMG_2136%20copy.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn83@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-28-550_00850413dbb8e0b7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg?width=59&name=13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn5@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-21-096_5e5ecfb6bdc5c630.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png?width=308&name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn52@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-21-102_c3a6f7de0bb3d9f2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png?width=433&name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn36@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-22-24-359_4803b943f96aea89.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2138%20copy.png?width=300&name=IMG_2138%20copy.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn46@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-22-27-224_5b3c709865855896.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-use-instagram-insights&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-22-24-444_eea03947b9e34ff2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336428},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"Is Page One Overrated? The Truth About Organic Search Results","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/page-one-google-overrated","description":"<p>For many marketers, ranking on page one of Google is the ultimate sign that your piece of content has <em>made it</em>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Every SEO strategy ever devised aims to get you there. If you're lucky enough to land a high ranking, you'll enjoy a pretty big advantage over competitors when it comes to finding new customers. At least that's the prevailing belief among modern marketers and SEO specialists.</p> \n<p>But — just how valuable <em>is</em> a page-one ranking?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.teknicks.com/marketing-research-survey-google-search-behaviors\"><span>Teknicks surveyed</span></a>&nbsp;more than 1,000 internet users using a representative sampling method to uncover their Google search behavior and find out how far they'd go to find what they're looking for online.</p> \n<p>Answers were predictably varied, but they allowed us to draw some pretty clear SERP statistics and conclusions.</p> \n<p>For starters, marketers who say the first page is the only page that matters aren't exactly wrong.</p> \n<p>However, simply making page one might not be good enough — more than <a href=\"https://blog.teknicks.com/marketing-research-survey-google-search-behaviors#.XyrB-RNKiRY\"><span>43% of survey respondents</span></a> said they wouldn't be very likely to scroll down the page to see additional results. If you're going to aim high, you might as well aim for the very top.</p> \n<p>And if you think page two is good enough, you might want to reconsider this search engine traffic statistic: <a href=\"https://blog.teknicks.com/marketing-research-survey-google-search-behaviors#.XyrB-RNKiRY\"><span>roughly 56% said they would rather</span></a> try a different search query or engine than click on the second page of search results. That's a lot of traffic to miss out on.</p> \n<p>And as for clicks? Pages two and three get&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.advancedwebranking.com/blog/google-organic-ctr/\"><span>just 5.59% combined</span></a>. The percentage of Google traffic by results page decreases drastically with every new page you click on.</p> \n<p>So what do these SERP statistics mean for you?</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3><strong>What Marketers Can Learn About Keywords, Rankings, and Users</strong></h3> \n<p>When you know how far people are willing to search, you have a better idea of what your goals should be. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo\"><span>Getting to page one on Google</span></a> is far from easy. In fact, it requires a huge investment of time, and potentially money (depending on the keyword you want to rank for).&nbsp;</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say a marketer knows that only the top three results for a particular term attract users. If they're nowhere near that ranking, then they should put some budget toward paid search or social (if applicable).</p> \n<p>Of course, such a big investment of time and money doesn't make sense for certain keywords, since the value of Google result positioning&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2017/10/30/the-value-of-search-results-rankings/#2c8cb72444d3\"><span>varies</span></a>. An easy way to calculate a keyword's traffic value is to multiply its earnings per click by the number of searches that incorporate it and then multiply that by the click-through rate. Just don't expect that value to remain constant.</p> \n<p>It's also worth noting that keywords shouldn't be the main focus of your content strategy. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/timeline/google-algorithm-updates\"><span>Google's algorithm</span></a> is constantly evolving thanks to machine learning. As it does, keywords are becoming less integral to a high ranking.</p> \n<p>This makes sense — keywords were useful during the early days of search, but computers have evolved to more effectively interpret human speech. So go ahead and write naturally, incorporating keywords only where it makes sense.</p> \n<p>The&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.blog.google/products/search/search-language-understanding-bert/\"><span>BERT update</span></a>, for instance, helps Google process words in relation to the rest of the sentence, rather than one at a time in order. For example, the search query <em>\"Can you get driver's license renewed for someone else?\"</em> forces BERT to acknowledge \"for someone\" changes the meaning of the query.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>This is especially important considering how often people use voice-controlled devices like Amazon's Alexa or Apple's Siri. In fact, <a href=\"https://blog.teknicks.com/marketing-research-survey-google-search-behaviors#.XyrInxNKiRZ\"><span>over 25% of our respondents</span></a> have conducted a voice search, and we expect that percentage to increase in the coming years. To make page one, you should focus on answering these questions and securing featured or Google rich snippets.</p> \n<p>And if you're wondering why we're only talking about Google search results statistics, it's because the search engine has cornered&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.oberlo.com/statistics/search-engine-market-share\"><span>roughly 92%</span></a>&nbsp;of the total search market.</p> \n<p>Does that mean Google search stats are the only ones that matter? No, but we think it's safe to assume that Google search behavior is representative of broader user behavior.</p> \n<p>So let's talk about how you can capitalize on said behavior by getting to page one.</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Start With a Question</strong></h3> \n<p>On the basis of the Google search statistics our data provided (and corroborating stats from around the web), we'd recommend starting your SEO journey with a question:&nbsp;<em>Should I even aim for page one?</em></p> \n<p>To answer this, you'll need to have a general idea of where you're starting. If you already have a fairly robust content marketing program, you may not be that far away. But maybe you haven't heavily invested in content yet. That doesn't mean you can't start — just don't plan on reaching search results stardom overnight.</p> \n<p>You should also evaluate the competitiveness of the keyword you want to rank for and be realistic about your chances for success. Depending on how competitive the term is, you might want to focus on other discovery avenues such as <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/podcasts/skill-up/s01/e07-voice-search-future-seo\"><span>voice discovery</span></a> (and no, we can't emphasize this enough).&nbsp;</p> \n<p>You might also conduct an eye-tracking study for your term to find out where a user's gaze typically goes when results appear. It might land on one of the top three results, but it might also drift down the page.</p> \n<p>That said, if you're going to attempt a page-one ranking, you should still aim for the top even if users scroll down (more on that in a moment).</p> \n<h3><strong>2. Try Pivoting to a PPC Strategy&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p>If you don't see yourself on the first page anytime soon — or ever, you can pursue plenty of other avenues. Put some budget toward paid search, which can be even more effective than organic search results.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Roughly 35% of our respondents weren't sure whether they could distinguish between an ad and an organic search result, and people who click on ads deliberately intend to make a purchase. And the top three advertising spots get <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tabid/6307/bid/1514/paid-search-vs-organic-search.aspx\"><span>46% of the clicks on the page</span></a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>However, you may have a shot at achieving success on the first page organically. How? Let's dive into that, next.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Play the Long Game</strong></h3> \n<p>To land a high ranking for a fairly competitive term across all channels that your customers are using, you're going to need to put in the time. Here's what to focus on:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Get your FAQ page optimized.</strong>&nbsp;An SEO friendly FAQ page can be a great way to increase your rankings and CTR. Just don't overdo it: The primary purpose of this page is customer support, so be sure it adds value. You can then mark up that content using&nbsp;<a href=\"https://developers.google.com/search/docs/data-types/faqpage\"><span>FAQ schema</span></a>&nbsp;and be eligible to have a rich result.</li> \n <li><strong>Focus on link building.</strong>&nbsp;Search engine algorithms are driven by links, which is why&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/link-building-software\"><span>link building is critical to SEO</span></a>. Build highly resourceful content, develop relationships with other site owners, and work on getting links on their pages to your best content. Pro tip: Focus on quality over quantity.</li> \n <li><strong>Be relevant.</strong>&nbsp;You should be creating content consistently, and that content should be fresh. Regularly update old blog posts and pay attention to current events. The news can be a great source of inspiration, and building content around trending topics enhances its visibility.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Search engines want to give their users the best experience possible because they want those users to keep searching. Google search query statistics<strong>&nbsp;</strong>show that the tech giant's algorithm is constantly improving, leading users to more relevant results and more useful content.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>People want to find what they're looking for fast. If you want them to find you, make sure your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/seo-trends\"><span>strategy is constantly evolving</span></a>, as well. The moment you stop trying is the moment you slide onto page two.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpage-one-google-overrated&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 19 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7159,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"c7744ba3c7f10efec0ae07b935662e62","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Nick Chasinov","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpage-one-google-overrated&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn70@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-22-22-073_e704e2eac39e7cbc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311336425},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:22:16","title":"8 Really Cool Ways to Use Video in Email Marketing","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/video-email-marketing","description":"<p>This morning, as usual, I started my day by checking my emails.</p>  \n<p>While this process doesn't usually excite me and is just my method for waking up, I came across a subject line that made my heart race with excitement:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/6%20Effective%20Ways%20to%20Use%20Video%20in%20Your%20Email%20Marketing.png\" alt=\"An example of a video in a subject line. \" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Knowing that I would be starting my day with a new music video from one of my favorite bands made me smile. It also made me feel valued as a subscriber to their record label's emails — with just one video, <a href=\"https://shop.specialistsubjectrecords.co.uk/\">Specialist Subject Records</a> strengthened the consumer relationship I have with them.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>This is why video email marketing is such an effective strategy. With a simple embed and subject line, you can build stronger relationships with customers, generate leads, and strengthen the content behind your brand.</p> \n<p>Let's talk a little more about it.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">What is video email marketing?</h2> \n<p>Video email marketing is simply including videos in email marketing. If you're unsure about how to do that, we have a quick how-to post <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/embed-video-in-email?_ga=2.210323100.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\">here</a>.</p> \n<p>Because video is an extremely popular medium in marketing, (in fact, <a href=\"https://www.smartinsights.com/digital-marketing-platforms/video-marketing/video-marketing-statistics-to-know/\">83% of marketers</a> feel its importance is only growing) including it in your email marketing can engage your subscribers and increase your conversions.</p> \n<p>Additionally, did you know that over <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/state-of-video-marketing-new-data?_ga=2.193425637.939240069.1576511670-940436819.1565181751\">80% of businesses use video</a> in their marketing efforts? This is likely because of the results video implementation gives them. While using video in email can seem like a taboo topic, it can be very effective.</p> \n<p>By using video, you can tap into the imagination of an audience that absorbs information visually — sometimes text just doesn't do it. With video, you have a chance to make dense topics more compelling for your audience.</p> \n<p>Next, let's talk about ways you can use it in your next email campaign.</p> \n<h2>How to Use Video in Email Marketing</h2> \n<p>Videos can dramatically increase click-through rate (CTR).</p> \n<p>For example, B2B software company Igloo Software decided to show off their workplace culture by creating 200 videos in three months for future email content. This approach <a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/customers/how-igloo-boosted-email-ctr/\">doubled their CTR</a>.</p> \n<p>This is one way to use video in email marketing — showcase your brand in email and use it to increase CTR. We have six more, which we'll explore now.</p> \n<h3>1. Use video for bonus content to delight your subscribers.</h3> \n<p>Consider using emails to give subscribers bonus content. Email subscribers are likely<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-stats?_ga=2.244845068.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span> to enjoy a variety of your content</span></a>, so going the extra mile with a surprise bonus could delight your audience.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>For instance, if you share weekly newsletters about Instagram content, you can add a link for early access to a live webinar you're hosting about Instagram Stories at the end of the month. That way, you can build interest for the event, keep subscribers in the loop about things going on within your company, and give them an incentive to keep checking your emails.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can use emails to alert subscribers about bonus material you offer through other channels. For instance, this is an email I received from creators I subscribe to on <a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/\"><span>Patreon</span></a>, a subscription-based content service:</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/C1bMv68XXlDrJ9NxRkHWFxq5E0FIuLZE1UyLEsIbmVMdxxNI83CcMM1qSBIEg9FShJFOCLUd8FW_Lc3I1LfBkPvzNRvpD2_opNLzqw6D0orEHbNwGQZoq_BN8FqFAdcw4tw2Bnty\" width=\"624\" height=\"361\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"LGTC video email marketing example\"></span></p> \n<p>The email served as a reminder to check my Patreon dashboard to see other offers. I could also play the video directly in the email, which is a great method for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-delivery-deliverability?_ga=2.244845068.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span>email deliverability</span></a> <em>and</em> <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/personalize-emails-with-smart-content?_ga=2.244845068.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span>personalization</span></a>. It was a wonderful surprise, and kept the email format readable.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. Make emails a more personalized experience.</h3> \n<p>Do you have a backlog of video content on your website? Consider using that to your advantage and sending personalized emails.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say someone watches a portion of a video on your website that they don't finish, and you're noticing this is a pattern when you analyze your website data.<a href=\"https://www.marketo.com/\"> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Marketo</span></a>'s formula is to automatically send that video in an email to remind that user to finish.</p> \n<p>By doing this,<a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/customers/marketo-video-enabled-business-case-study/\"> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Vidyard reported</span></a> that Marketo raised their CTR by over 144% due to the personalization of that email. If I were sent a video I meant to finish in an email, I'd surely open it to complete that video. I'd also feel pretty important to the company as a customer.</p> \n<p>From a business perspective, this means more clicks for you, a better relationship with the customer, and more views on videos.</p> \n<h3>3. Display company culture with a video.</h3> \n<p>If you're struggling with thinking of out-of-the-box ideas for email content that shows off company personality, consider heading to YouTube.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Yes, you read that right: YouTube.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>What better way to show subscribers the culture in your company than going straight to the source? Let's look at this email from beauty company, <a href=\"https://www.glossier.com/\"><span>Glossier</span></a>, to illustrate:&nbsp;</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/SwF82M2gjY7Eb8Dn0XHCS6a_xdbWMpBQ3lruimwvEzu4xddI2lXyKamx-ow0iuAQ44p9Ji-mv5uTfdtmcXm932ubLSh_W-jeHccghGcQBbgedmB-qd4P1B_mPhop7oc_yMvxhvQk\" width=\"624\" height=\"487\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Example of Glossier inserting a YouTube video into email marketing.\"></span></p> \n<p>This email embeds a simple video from a Glossier influencer, showing viewers her morning routine using the company's products. If you click on the video's image, you're taken to a <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vD2wWteW5vA&amp;list=PLWpusBRtNAW9CQwXDRCUo-N9D238vFEiP&amp;mi_u=115134%3Fmi_u%3D115134&amp;utm_source=glossier&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=9c0d6a58-a0ad-490c-bfef-76f212a62b26&amp;utm_content=1910c6fd-1137-4a48-8d3f-8e1301175604&amp;utm_term=\"><span>YouTube playlist</span></a> that highlights the makeup routines of Glossier affiliates, celebrities, and employees.</p> \n<p>Getting a peek into how Glossier employees use the skincare and makeup in their daily routines adds a sense of normalcy and relatability to the company. I got to see the people behind the marketing emails, and what I saw were employees who were just like me.</p> \n<p>Framed as a fun, <em>\"TGIF!\"</em> email, this messaging also had a promotion. If you click on the CTA, you're brought to Glossier's main product page with a reminder to spend Friday's payday at the company's ecommerce store.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Email marketing doesn't have to be a blatant show of products. Sometimes, you can subtly promote your products within a display of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/company-culture?_ga=2.42354476.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span>company culture</span></a>. Try experimenting with a blend of public-facing content to promote your brand, like Glossier.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>For example, let's say you want to bring attention to that new advertising metrics tool you've just launched. You might consider asking your marketing team to film a short video of the product's daily value. Then, you can embed the product page in the video's thumbnail. (Consider giving employees a heads-up that their response might be part of a marketing email).&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>4. Announce an event with a video.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>If your company hosts events, whether internal or external, take videos of the events for a recap to send subscribers. This way, you can give subscribers a taste of how your brand works in-action and build interest in your company's events overall.</p> \n<p>For instance, do you host or participate in quarterly industry mixers? Try including a video in an email about the most recent one, along with a CTA for subscribers to learn more about the next one. The video can also serve as social proof that these events are well-attended and informative for other people in your industry.</p> \n<h3>5. Announce a product line or launch with a video.</h3> \n<p>Confession: I'm a <em>little</em> obsessed with makeup company, <a href=\"https://www.fentybeauty.com/\"><span>Fenty Beauty</span></a>. When it was first announced, I immediately signed up for emails. It seems fitting, then, that the team at Fenty Beauty teamed up with <a href=\"https://www.fentybeauty.com/fentyskin\"><span>Fenty Skin</span></a> for its initial launch.</p> \n<p>Fenty Beauty subscribers were sent an exclusive video from CEO, Rihanna, about the new company and what it would entail. It's a great strategy to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/product-marketing?_ga=2.42354476.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span>market complementary products</span></a> through email, since&nbsp; subscribers are already interested in what your company offers.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/ZDtG-fLxEmoylT-RaArPi27qMzZWrWOLPItNhVbw-ueKmyfT9XEY2X2z19yZUn6AgPF6i9nx75nWtp0bYMhneP75LAD3LDQ--ue_oGoulQg0pY4YOFjMYCh1WMA-VW9U_B2BWhc3\" width=\"624\" height=\"471\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Using video email marketing for a product launch.\"></span></p> \n<p>If you're launching a new product in the upcoming quarter, maybe it's a good idea to include email subscribers in the pre-launch phase. For instance, if you're launching a chatflow bot as part of a CRM update, let email subscribers know first. That way, dedicated customers can express their interest in the product and bring in that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30490/the-qualities-of-a-powerful-word-of-mouth-marketing-strategy.aspx?_ga=2.42354476.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span>word-of-mouth marketing</span></a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>6. Send out newsletters with videos.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>If you're giving subscribers scheduled newsletters with no video, you're missing out! There's a lot of ways to include video in newsletters so they can be effective. Video-heavy businesses can benefit from newsletter video embeds so subscribers can catch up on content they may have missed — especially if your subscribers prefer watching over reading.</p> \n<p>Another way to use video in newsletters is to round-up popular videos in your industry. If your company doesn't do many videos, this is an excellent avenue for you. Alternatively, if a member of your team is interested in a routine video schedule, try filming a round-up of weekly content in video-form.</p> \n<p>For instance, if there was a commercial that rocked your industry recently, include that video in your newsletter with a corresponding blog post about your thoughts to increase traffic on your blog.</p> \n<h3>7. Move leads along their customer journey.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Email marketing isn't just limited to loyal customers — you can also use it to nurture leads. Just use workflows in your CRM to automate videos that will move them along the customer journey. This works with forms you can add right into that video.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>These forms might give your sales team enough information to follow up with interested customers. Or, give leads an opportunity to watch your latest crash course in SEO link building — in exchange for the completed form fields, of course.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>If you're currently thinking, <em>\"I'm no tech wiz, how do I do that?\"</em>, don't worry. <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/video/wistia?_ga=2.243830668.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span>HubSpot's integration with Wistia</span></a> makes it easy to add this widget into your marketing emails. Check with your CRM software to see if it offers something similar.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/QL8inYniLHNtmnD8mlUaXQU32PrPdNzWKAYTVD5_aQN_diuBltjwh8W-PjUOCu_nRmp8I4oI02EA-iI0aI4Mo4gf1bFfB6zybZ-GqgE4pbWw8Ge2AHuSFIGlWSg0MwbD6UGevToA\" width=\"624\" height=\"351\" alt=\"Using Wistia to include video email marketing in a campaign.\"></span></strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/video/wistia?_ga=2.243830668.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>With this integration, you can add HubSpot forms into a Wistia video for higher engagement. If a lead converts within the video, their viewing data will sync with their contact record. This can be useful for future customer research with video marketing campaigns.</p> \n<p>Think about piloting a video email marketing campaign for conversion. If you download viewing data, you can see how to tweak video content to further delight your customers.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>8. Include video in email subject lines.</h3> \n<p>Formatting is super important in emails and it starts with the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/improve-your-email-subject-line?_ga=2.243830668.820272776.1598034036-940436819.1565181751\"><span>subject line</span></a>. As a consumer, if I see an email with emojis in the subject line, I'm immediately more interested in the email because emojis stick out to me and feel more inviting.</p> \n<p>Try including \"Video\" or a corresponding emoji in your subject line to entice subscribers to open it. You'll likely want to A/B test a variety of subject lines in the beginning to figure out what your readers prefer.</p> \n<p>Another important formatting tip is to embed the video in the email in a place that keeps readers interested. Putting videos at the beginning of an email is a good idea, but placing it near the end invites readers to keep reading to better understand the video.</p> \n<p>Video is an incredible way to engage subscribers, old and new. I just received a new one in my inbox, and I'll prioritize that over other emails. If it sounds pretty hectic to produce new videos for email campaigns, think about using the ones you already have. You may be able to repurpose them into great content for your audience.</p> \n<h3></h3> \n<p></p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p>  \n<img
